reviews.review: A great overview of Sydney and its icons. If on holiday or wanting some relaxed time, a visit to the Opera house and the vicinity is a must. Make sure you pick a day with nice weather and you can catch public transport getting off at Circular Quay. You could walk around the harbour bridge, operahouse, botanical gardens. Thia would take about 45minutes Make aure you are in comfy walking shoes and hat!The Opera bar is great for brunch, or a drink over looking the harbour at night.

Romantic stroll from the gardens to the Opera House. A lazy morning walk through the Botanical Gardens with the vast variety of plants along the harbor and back to the Opera House, one of the more interesting walks in Sydney.You get amazing vista of the Bridge and Opera House from the path and across the harbor to north Sydney, all the way the back drop of birds singing and Cockatoo's squawking from the tree tops. Just a wonderful way to spend a morning. Not may walks end at the iconic shape of the Sydney Opera House.

Must see if you visit Sydney. No brainer and a great spot to chill on a warm summers day. Take a ferry ride to Manly or Luna Park or to Taronga Zoo. Walk around the water front towards East or West and you cannot go wrong.

Romantic Skywriting Over the Royal Botanical Garden. Started on the steps of the magnificent Opera House, then strolled through the lovely gardens with amazing plant specimens (like the century old Woolemi pine). Saw at least one bride being photographed. Coincidentally or not, a plane overhead spelled out "Forever" with a tiny heart. Final touch: a wild white yellow crested Cockatoo greeting us loudly from his perch right above us.

a lovely path. Husband and I are both runners, so we are constantly looking for new places to go. The path from the opera house to the botanical gardens was beautiful scenic and comfortable. It was a nice way to stay fit and experience the views.
A nice walk. Beautiful views and a great way to get some exercise in. The gardens are a lovely park with lots to see. We got lost but had a lot of fun!
great spot to visit. plenty to see in a spectacular setting - the opera House is magnificent at a distance and also up close and provides some unique photo opportunities
Great place. Went to Opera house with colleagues from work to watch the show My Fair Lady. The place speaks for itself. Beautiful and has great architecture. One of a kind!
Picnic. Totally perfect - so near to the CBD - Easy parking during the week - not crowed - but avoid the food area - very unpleasant - the food offered is overprice

Dr . It is the most enchanting walk. The sea harbour bridge and Sydney Opera house views are super. One is really overcome with the majesty of the variety and exoticness trees and flowers. It is a must once in a life time walk experience.
A real nice walk. The Opera House is always worth a look but I have done this walk down to the Botanical gardens many times. Plus won't cost a cent.
State library of nsw. Great free exibitions. Really enjoyed the shaping of Australian gardens. The landscape design was very inspiring. On till 15 January

A lovely walk past two icons. The walk from Circular Quay (main ferry terminal in Sydney) around the foreshore to the Opera House is very interesting . Across the Quay you have great views of the Rocks and the Harbour Bridge not to to mention the buzz of the ferries and and other recreational watercraft coming and going. Once you proceed around Bennelong Point ( the site of the Opera House) you move seamlessly into the Royal Botanic Gardens. I think these gardens go back to 1816 and are free, in the heart of the City and have magnificent harbour views. Not to be missed!

Beautiful Walk in CIty centre. The walk from the Sydney Opear House to the Botanic Garden and Mrs Macquarie's Chair is one of the modt spectacular walk in any city in the world. With the Opera House and The Sydney Bridge in the background walking along the waterfront is very relaxing with beautiful lawn, you are actually encourage to lie and walk on the lawn unlike some other countries' gardens. See the jurassic fern at Botanic Garden which is rich in a huge variety of plants. Do the walk and you will go home delighted.
Lovely walk with family. This is a beautiful area of Sydney. Botanical gardens are just lovely to pick a picnic spot and have a bit by the harbour.

Stunning Flowering Lotus & Water Lilies. Started off at the Opera House and walked to the left path to catch the little train for a relaxed tour of the gardens...breath taking where the Lotus and flowering water lilies were... I had not seen how big the Lotus flowers are until then. Took our grandchildren into the little cafe located near the Palm Grove for a treat. Lovely service and great coffee and food.The only drawback we found was limited parking, you had to be there early to get a decent parking spot. The trees in the park are just so beautiful and shady...I love trees.Fantastic views also.

Wonderful walk to watch the water.. Start at Circular Quay then walk towards the Opera House where you can look at the special markers that show the original shoreline. Sample from restaurants or have a coffee or wine. Continued on and walk around the Opera House. Do a tour inside the Opera House see the view of the Harbour from inside. There are frequent shows, concerts, ballets, or Operas to buy tickets for. Carry on with your walk just beyond the O.H. along the waterline into the Gardens. There are paths and in the middle a cafe and restaurant along a short creek, with lily ponds. A few green houses are higher up the hill and if you continue across and up you can go to the art gallery or back into the city.

Sydney Opera House Botanic Garden and NSW Art Gallery. The Sydney Opera House to Royal Botanic Gardens is a short and easy walk with magnificent views. We also visited the NSW Art Gallery, located in the Domain (next to the Botanic Garden in the south), interesting collections of Australian, European, Asian and contemporary arts (free entry).
Beautiful walk. This is a lovely walk to take by oneself or as a couple. The botanic gardens are beautiful and it's a level walk suitable for all ages.
Great walk in the garden and close to the Sydney Harbour. Great walk in the garden and close to the Sydney Harbour. This gives a good view at the Sydney Harbour. Must not do on a cold windy day

Stunning views and at peace with nature. This is a must do walk for both Sydney locals and tourists. Take in the view of the iconic Sydney Opera House and be one with nature in the glorious botanical gardens. Take a picnic or just enjoy the view.

Calming Blue. Sydney Harbour is a beautiful harbour wether on a sunny or dull day. Always activity going on. Botanic Gardens maybe not up to Singapores Gardens by The Bay but beautiful in another way with ponds and man made lakes and nice cafe's . The large greenhouse is spectacular and the view cannot be beaten. Sydney harbour always spectacular no-matter what with the iconic Sydney Bridge and the iconic Opera House. Always someone happy to help visitors from overseas very friendly. Great boat tours and the local ferries take you to most stops. Manly ferry a good place to start or a trip across to Luna Park. The harbour always buzzing and a great place to start.

Fantastic photo ops. Not many people know about this, but if you walk to the around the Opera house and keep going around the ocean path you will end up at the botanical gardens. If you keep walking along the path keeping the ocean to your immediate left you will end up at Mrs. Macquarie's chair. This is a great place to get some photos of BOTH the opera house and the bridge in one shot. You may also be lucky and get an ocean liner departing as you take your photos.

Iddylic Walk. Enjoying the beautiful flora and fauna. We can spend hours just sitting in the shade looking at the skyline and bridge, seeing runners jogging by, people picnicing and just generally enjoying the fresh air.

From the City Centre Via the Domain and the Botanic Gardens to the Opera House. A good place to start is at the Anzac Memorial in Hyde Park. You can detour to the Australian Museum on the corner of Park and College streets. Continuing along College street you can visit St Mary's Cathedral.Crossing Prince Albert road will bring you to MacQuarie street and the Hyde Park Barracks Museum, the Mint, Sydney Hospital, the NSW Parliament and the State Library. Behind these buildings is the Domain - now used as a multipurpose open space, it was originally used in 1788 by the first governor Arthur Phillip.Just beyond the Domain are the Botanic Gardens, which are vast and contain so much to see.Head towards the east and Mrs MacQuaries road will take you to Mrs MacQuaries chair - a sandstone bench cut into the rock in 1810 by convicts.At Mrs MacQuaries Point you can see the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge side by side.Continuing around Farm Cove brings you back to te Botanic Gardens and finally the Opera House.

Birthday weekend . Probably one of the most iconic places to visit in Sydney A beautiful building that caters for concerts dining experiences and special occasions There are great little gift shops too for souvenirs and a great beer garden by the waters edge with great meals and drinks The Botanic gardens are next to this wonderful building great for a casual walk or a lovely picnic

Beautiful flowers!. My wife is a flower lover and she was in 7th heaven. We took the choo choo tour and that was also very nice. A flat white in the serene green surroundings at he cafe was also very memorable.
Big 2016. The Botanic Gardens has a big 1816 to 2016 sign just near the Opera House. Great walk to see some iconic views of Sydney Harbour
Sydney sunrise. Lovely daily start to the day , remember the botanic gardens don't open super early . Great opportunities abound for photos.

Beautiful sunset views, easy walk and great time.. Walking from the Opera House to Mrs. Macquarie Chain is everything but dead easy. The Opera House is located at the northwest part of the gardens, which gives you enough time to grab something to eat or a quick drink before you head to the gardens to enjoy the relaxation time, chat with friends or have a quick run.I tend to take friends and family along to this walk as they get the feel of how most Sydneysiders are around this area. Most of the time we take a blanket with us to have a little picnic around and enjoy the sunset. Is a beautiful sight although you get less than optimal photos of the Opera House and the Bridge.If you are visiting (tourist) my city, I will suggest to you buying a bag of walnuts (or dried fruit like apricots) as the Cockatoo's love them and you will be attracting them to you. Cockatoos eat around 4:50pm to 6pm (Spring or Fall) or a little bit later in Summer and they are located east of the gardens. Be gentle with the birds and avoid over feeding them.If you come here early in the morning is beautiful too, but the number of other activities to do is reduced. In this scenario, I would walk first the botanic gardens towards the opera house to finish it with a brunch at the cafes and restaurants of Circular Quay... or walk a bit further (especially on weekends) towards the rocks and enjoy the Rocks Market.

Fabulous. This is a beautiful walk through the stunning botanical gardens culminating at the Opera House. There are some really unusual plants in the garden all with the backdrop of Sydney Harbour. Wonderful!

Great city views for all visitors to Sydney. Imagine strolling through acres of greenery and exotic plants of the Royal Botanic Gardens and still being able to see the city skyline with the skyscrapers and the busy Sydney Harbour in front of you. Look for trees that are nearly 200 years old and vegetables planted by the early settlers to the Colony. Visit Macquarie Chair and get a clear view of the iconic Opera House with its famous roof gleaming in the sun against a clear blue sky. You may be fortunate enough to witness a wedding on the grounds.Watch the busy ferry and tourist boats as they sail in the Harbour and see the many kayaks that cut through the water. There is so much activity in the Harbour!There are lots of signposts so you will not get lost!

Easy and peaceful walk through botanic gardens. With opera house as the start point and the harbour to your left this is a really beautiful walk. There are very many specimen plants to see, great birds wandering around and making lots of noise in the treetops. There is a cafe in the middle and you can walk through to the art gallery which is well worth a visit. Peace and tranquility in the very centre of the city and its free of charge

Free and rewarding. The walk from the Opera House to the Royal Botanical Garden gives you some most spectacular scenery of Sydney Harbour and its park. It is free and you can arrange the time at your own pace. It is suitable for everyone including children and families. The entrance to the park is opposite to the right side of the Opera House. You do not need to return to the same entrance. There are a number of exits. One of them is opposite to the State Library which give you another chance to view the beautiful architecture of the building.
Breathtaking walk. Whenever I visit Sydney I walk through the Botanic Gardens and come down the hill to the Harbour and Opera House and, each time, the sheer splendour takes my breath away.

Fabulous Gardens. A fantastic way to spend 3 - 4 hours relaxing and wondering around the gardens If you like Cactus and succulents , you will very impressed with the range they have here , also a very impressive range of Cycads

Don't be in a hurry to get somewhere. I didn't have anywhere I needed to be, and enjoyed strolling the meandering path at my leisure. Walk on the left, stay out of the way of the runners and relish in the beauty of the views.

Relaxing afternoon. We spent a whole afternoon here and still never saw the entire grounds. We did stop for a coffee at the centrally-located cafe. And we visited the small rainforest sections and the cactus/succulent garden. We just strolled through trees - sooo many beautiful trees around!

Great views of Opera House and Bridge from Gardens. Walked round on a nice day, excellent photo opportunities great view of the Opera House, Bridge and Harbour. Nice to then grab an ice cream and take a dander round the gardens with the cities buildings in the background.
Sydney Gem. Beautiful and lovely location to visit. Sydney Gem. Romantic for walking around and scenic walk. Weekdays are great.

Lovely place . Take a walk around the Opera House, and you get stunning views of the bay, and if you're luck, see a cruise ship in Harbour. The botanical garden has a lot of places to sit and relax or have a picnic. One can spend half a day there. You can also walk up a small hill and see Sydney buildings around.

Peaceful walk in the city centre. We walked from the opera house around past the botanical gardens & mrs Macquarie's chair round to woolloomooloo wharf. What a beautiful, peaceful walk! You're so close to the cbd but it's just so quiet and peaceful. There's a path all the way round which is on the flat for the most part and the views are just spectacular. The gardens are lovely, watch out for the cockatoos though we were bombarded by them on our way past.....don't see those in the wild in the U.K. We stopped at mrs Macquarie's chair to take photos with both the opera house & harbour bridge in....beautiful! Then carried on around past the pool. If you have a couple of spare hours on your visit to Sydney and want to escape the hustle & bustle of the city, this is the place to be!

Beautiful inside and out. What a great place to visit. We didn't do the tour but we were able to go inside and get all kinds of info on the Opera House. Plus they have some great restaurants on the lower level. We also took in a symphony in one of the theaters. Great to visit such an iconic structure.

Pick a pair of confortable shoes and Enjoy!. Yes, you are going to walk, a couple of miles but it totally worth it! Try to start from the botanical garden, there you are going to get a couple of amazing photo locations of the Opera House. Bring water, and take a look to the trees, the bats are hanging on the top of them.Once you complete a track of the Botanical Garden you can walk straight to the Opera House area.

Locals enjoying the scenery . Took my mum here after visiting the Art Gallery of NSW. Always great to explore your own city. Lots of variety in the garden, animals/birds, and enjoying the beautiful harbour. We are so fortunate to call this out home!

Tranquility. I've visited for the first time in 13 years. Great water views, opera house and harbour bridge views. Plenty of age old trees, herbs, flowers etc. Good thing was the display "barrangal dyara (skin and bones)" by Jonathan Jones. Pram, Wheel chair accessible. One can find peace in the middle of the city.
Iconic Harbour Views. Nothing like the opera house out there. Beautiful on a sunny day when the harbour is gleaming and the sailboats are drifting about.
stunning vews gardens worth a visit. botanical gardens are lovely even on the rainy day like we had wheni we were there . well work a look .

A great walk for the soul. On a sunny day is there anything better than walking where you can see some sensational architecture (Sydney Opera House) and engineering (Sydney Harbour Bridge) set on the most beautiful harbour - and then wander into the stunning gardens. At the start of the day it is inspiring and a wonderful kick-start for the soul. At the end of the day a wonderful way to wind down and gain some peace. On any day its gorgeous, but on a sunny day it's Sydney at it's absolute best.
Easy flat walking path, beautiful views. Cant get enough of the amazing iconic views around Sydney Harbour. The Botanical Gardens are green and provide an oasis of serenity so close to the CBD.

Sydney Lover. Check out Circular Quay,walk around the Opera House,possibly watching a live band on the waterfront.Then proceed into the Botanical Gardens.Take a hat,sunscreen and a camera.You can then walk to the Art Gallery or further to the Finger Wharf.It is possible if you have the time to walk all the way to Watson's Bay and get the ferry back

A Relaxing Walk. On a recent trip to Sydney I had a few hours to spare and, rather than hit the shops, I decided to stroll in an area that not too many people realised has great historical significance.Starting from the Opera House (Bennalong Point) and armed with a little bit of local knowledge I walked around the foreshores of Farm Cove, skirting the northern edge of the Royal Botanical Gardens. Bennalong Point was named after an Aboriginal gentleman called Bennalong, a favourite of Governor Phillip, who used to spend long periods of time in the area contemplating who knows what. Prior to the Opera House being built the site was used as a tram depot. Man-of-War steps was used by naval ship captains as they visited Government House to pay their respects to the NSW Governor. Farm Cove was named because of the vegetables that were originally grown in the area to augment food supplies in the early days of the colony. The botanical gardens came about following the plantings of Mrs Macquarie and later residents of Government House.The walk was extremely relaxing, away from the noise of city traffic, with the harbour foreshores on one side and the greenery of the gardens on the other. There were lots of options on the route I took. On this occasion I strolled around to Mrs Macquarie's Chair then back through the gardens and the domain, Hyde Park and back to the hotel. Very pleasant.
Trip to Sydney. This walk provides amazings views on Opera house, Harbour bridge and skyline of Sydney. TiP: don't forget to visit "Mrs Macquarie’s Chair" after passing by the "Royal Botanic Garden".
day walking. walking around the opera house which is a good spot to start the botanic gardens are one of the attractions to spend an afternoon or morning there

Great walk...... Along the waterfront, through the gardens, reading about the trees and shrubs. Fabulous colours and aromas. Sea on your left, flora on your right. Opposite when you come back! Perfect hours walking.

Great walk Botanic Gardens and Opera House. We had plenty of time and actually did this walk twice because the Gardens were wonderful and the final destination (Opera House) was certainly worth it. Even though it was a bit windy and cold the Botanic Gardens were so good that you could just leisurely take your time and look at everything they had to offer and you always had the vision of The Bridge and Opera House looming in the background as you walked through the Gardens. Some of the fountains, people , buildings and other sites on the way made this a well worthy decision to do this walk.

Buy tickets in advance. We werein Sydney for ver a week and misssed out on going to a performance due to pooor planning. There multiple options of prices for seats, so it's not so expensive to actually see a performance/concert.

Botanical Gardens on one side, beautiful harbour on the other.. Great way to enjoy the best of Sydney. Very relaxing as the walk is away from traffic and city noises. Perfect way to fill in an hour or 2.

Good walk to the Botanic gardens. The walk from the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens is pleasant and should you so wish, you can immediately walk into the gardens, however we decided to walk on along the sea front and then into the gardens. The walk along the sea front is nothing spectacular as the sea is on your left and the gardens on your right.
It was nice. If you have time to just take a light walk with someone or by yourself. You can see some ice looking plants and flowers. Great first date spot

Splendour Plus!. Don't miss a visit and a show to Sydney's Opera House! My group recently attended a performance of My Fair Lady in the Joan Sutherland Theatre at the SOH. such a beautiful setting right on the harbour in the Botanic Gardens Right beside the Harbour Bridge as well. Beautiful to see at night.Our coach briefly managed to drop us off almost at the door! However a little more difficult with our after performance pickup as coaches not now allowed near Opera House for security reasons, and a little walk required.Steps, lifts, escalators got us efficiently to the JS Thestre and great A reserve seating . Very comfortable , excellent viewing, and amazing acoustics. Prices in our area seem to be around $ 110 .00 pp for our group. Interval for about 20 mins after a couple of hours - bar and usual facilities for patrons.Sydney Opera House is an architectural panorama - with a very interesting history . Must be the most photographed building in Australia, Tourists everywhere!
Floral spectacular . After visiting the Opera house, take the stroll through the gardens the aroma of flowers is intoxicating!!

Highly recommended . This walk gives you great views of the habour bridge and the Opera House and the Gardens are beautiful as well. This walk is suitable for everyone it is relatively flat and you can go at your own pace
Just do it. If you don't visit the pointy house on the Harbour you've not visited Sydneu. It is one of the world tourist sights so just do it.

A pleasant walk. We did the walk from the Opera House through the Gardens towards Darlinghurst. The views from the garden are the better view of the Opera House. The walk is nice and isn't too long with lots to see and do. I would recommend this to everybody.

Precinct excellent - Garden's Train should be more customer ume friendly. Family enjoyed the gardens and Opera House precinct. Train could have circulated more frequently and should been more customer-driven. Staff were probably tired heading towards 3pm. They could take some lessons from SeaWorld staff in helpfulness. It is a long way to walk with kids. A couple of train rides would have made more pleasant instead of walking for hours.

A beautiful walk. This is a beautiful walk and there is nothing like rounding the last corner and seeing the Opera House appear. It is easy to take a detour off the path and head into the Botanic Gardens proper where you can spend many hours exploring. A word of warning. The gates to the path the passes through the gardens to the Opera House are open at different times in the morning and evening depending on the time of year.

A MUST!!!. I'm not a fan of museums, because I prefer the outdoor tourism, but I loved the Opera House!We took a spanish tour and it was great! The tour is very complete, and I enjoyed the history and the architecture os the Opera... Definitely a must in Sydney!

An Enjoyable Walk. My daughter and I walked from Four Seasons Hotel to the Botanical Gardens all the way to Margaret's bench by the water. Very pleasant walk, lovely scenery. Beautiful trees. Lots of places to rest or lie down. You can see the cityscape/skyline from different points of the gardens. We saw some men fishing, and many families biking along or just walking about.
Beautiful building. A must do don't miss the opera house. Worth the walk or jump on public transport. Have a coffee and enjoy the view
Such a pretty area. Such a pretty area to see. When in Sydney it is definitely worth having a walk through and seeing the area.
Lovely Walk. Great walk along the waterfront and nice open areas to enjoy. A good place to exercise and would recommend visiting this area.

Nice walk. Beautiful botanical gardens. One criticism is that the information of some of the fascinating trees was not clearly readable or on the tree, which was in the middle of thick bushes so you couldn't get close enough to read about it.
I love the walk and coming around to the opera house was great.

Pleasant. After a 19 hour flight 3 hrs catnap took the ferry over and well worth a walk through the Royal botanic gardens which looked fantastic. A great place to walk through listen and smell the sights and sounds. Got one or two great pics which I will share later another must see even if your not that into plants and flowers.

If you were to visit one place in Sydney, this is probably it. it's a really short walk, but you'll see the Opera House, the Harbor, the Harbor bridge and the downtown skyline - these are all the most iconic landmarks in Sydney, and they are unforgettable. And it's all free and accessible 24x7 (well, they do close the park at night and if you want to get inside the Opera house - it has it's own schedule and ways to get in, but walking between them - you can always do it, regardless of the season or time of the day).

Beautiful Gardens. This is free and a great way to save money and have a great day out for free, you get great views of the city and the gardens have many species of plants and a wildlife just go to the opera house and you cant miss it, I would recommend to all ages

Impressive gardens. This was one of the best walks I have ever done. The sun was out and it was just so peaceful. The gardens tucked behind the Opera house are marvellous. I must do walk while in Sydney.

The Opera Bar is amazing.. Loved it. The Opera Bar on the waters edge, next to Opera House is amazing. A long spacious outdoor bar/cafe/eatery that overlooks Sydney Harbour and the Harbour Bridge. It's a beautiful relaxing place for drinks, dining, pizza or a coffee. The perfect place to take in the harbour sights and watch the sunset.
Great experience. Go for a jog in the morning or evening to enjoy some stunning views of the Harbour Bridge and Sydney Opera House.

Beautiful and really special. Okay, so you know you are going to see the opera house. Do yourself a favor and go on to the botanical garden next door. It is a short walk next to the water and bay. Really beautiful and fun to see the cool tree specimen and scores of friendly parrots and cockateels.

Walk thru Botanical Gardens. Such a lovely and peaceful walk.started from the Sydney Opera House and walked through the Gardens by the water and then through the garden itself....lovely restaurant and a less formal coffee shop...sat in the shade near the big pond and peacefully watched the world go by....amazing place in the heart of a busy city....

A walk in the park. This has got to be one of the best walks in Sydney that is wheelchair accessible and kid friendly. I usually start up at the Art gallery of New South Wales after a visit to see some great free artworks and use the free toilets and fill your water bottle at the free fountain. Then it's an easy walk down through the Botanic Gardens. There are so many different walkways that it can feel like a different trip each time. But no need to worry about getting lost, it is really well signposted. There is a lovely cafe in the middle of the Botanic gardens if you felt like a light lunch or coffee. Continue on toward the Opera House with a walk around the harbour foreshore when you round the bend you will see the majestic and iconic Opera House looming larger than life. A great way to end and reward yourself from the meandering walk is to order a drink at the Opera Bar and find a table with a spectacular view across Circular Quay to the Harbour Bridge.

Touch of paradise. I love walking through the gardens anytime of year but especially in spring. Thoroughly recommend the spring walk. On a nice day sit on the grass near the ponds with stunning views of the harbour.

"Simply the Best". Take a relaxing train ride from the south west of Sydney (Campbelltown) to Circular Quay....I always.enjoy coming out of the city circle tunnel to the light of Circular Quay and am either greeted by wonderful sunshine, a great cruise ship berthed at the dock, festivals and entertainment on the Opera House foreshore, Smiling face of Luna Park across the harbour or just the beautiful view!!!!!

Lovely place to have brekkie on a great day. We walked to the Bot Gardens on a glorious day and had a spot of breakfast before continuing our walk through the gardens on the way to the opera house. Just stunning.

A must do. You can't come to sydney with out seeing the opera house get to the domain start at Saint Ann's and walk if you brisk walk can do in 30 min but take your time and take all day in the botanical gardens stop at nsw art gallery. Pde local

Perfect place for a summer time run. Looking for somewhere to run in Sydney over summer? So was I. I found this perfect place to run around the edge of the harbour with great views and plenty of other runners to give you some motivation. If you feel like stopping and walking for a while, there is the gardens behind the walkway for a good cool down walk before you head back to your life feeling much happier and healthier.
Beautiful walk. Definitely worth walking along the waterfront through the botanic gardens, you get a different vantage point than from circular quay and it is breathtakingly beautiful!

Beautiful Walk. This is the best views you will get of the Opera House, the Harbour Bridge and the Sydney skyline while walking. It's a great tranquil setting that has many places to stop and sit and enjoy the sound of crashing waves and passing boats. A must do for anyone traveling to Sydney.

Just playing tourist in our own city. Beautiful spring afternoon to walk around the area. As you enter the gardens you can feel tranquillity settle around you. Stunning views over the harbour and garden of course to explore. Amble along at your own pace. At lunchtime watch out for the office joggers!!
The best view of Sydney. This is a beautiful walk. If you are new to the city this is a must do. The botanical gardens are a lovely spot.

Best Harbour Walk in the World. What a great way to explore the Opera House to the Botanic Gardena to Mrs Macquarie's Chair. Can't beat this for a thing to do on a beautiful spring day. The views are fantastic. Tip: order a picnic lunch from the Botanic Gardens Cafe. They supply the picnic rugs and all the food and drinks but you will need to pre-order this.

Sydney is very walkable. We spent about 5 to 6 hours a day walking this city. There is so much to see along the way. The Royal Botanic Gardens are awesome and the views are lovely. The gardens are very well maintained and there are plenty of benches for rest stops. ENJOY!

Opera House to Wooloomooloo walk. On a fine day one of the amazing walks in Sydney. Just over an hours slow (very) stroll with views of Garden Island, through the Botanic Gardens and around the Opera House. Cityscape and Harbour views the whole way. A great way to walk off that brunch.
Lovely walk. Wander round and savour the atmosphere around one of the worlds most famous buildings. Take a nice walk into and round the botanical gardens.

Beautiful, best to escape crowds.. The serenity of the gardens is a peaceful escape from the crowds at SOH and Circular Quay. If you are walking from the BG to SOH it is possible to walk from the top of the hill and down the stairs to the forecourt. Here you will be able to take a good picture if the rear of SOH at an elevation. Possibly the best time in terms of lighting is mid morning to midday.Walking from SOH to BG you will have pleasant bay views and towards the naval base and Fort Denison. Note that the Queen Elizabeth gates have been removed for restoration but the pillars remain. It is a splendid walk to be enjoyed by all. Do stop at the BG, currently in centennial celebrations.
A nice walk. The best way to see a city is walking-do the walk from the Opera House to the Botanical gardens-you will enjoy it very much

Culture to horticulture.. Go to a play in the Drama Theatre or the Playhouse, then a walk along the stone foreshore promenade, grab a drink at the Gardens cafe, check out the new Calyx glasshouse, and any exhibitions in the Palmhouse. Plenty of flowers in season or buy a favourite plant from the Friends nursery. Check out the thorns in the Cacti Garden, and the farm garden edibles. Head up to Art Gallery Road- more culture1 and catch a bus back to the city/ train/ bus.

Best Done From Gardens to Opera House. This walk is best done in the other direction. And preferably during the late afternoon to enjoy the sunset over the Opera House. Although if you are a morning person, this could end with a lunch picnic at the Gardens. Depending on the time you prefer to spend. The walk is very relaxing and there's not much of a hike. Remember, stay hydrated.

Wonderful walk. We'd had lunch at the Botanic Gardens and decided to walk over to the Opera House. It was absolutely lovely with meandering pathways and beautiful gardens all along the way. It was helped of course because the day was weather perfect. Even so, the views were interesting all along the way. Kudos, Sydney.
Nice walk. Really nice walk between the sea and the gardens, with different routes. Be aware of the opening times.
Lovely walk. Was a beautiful scenic walk for all ages. Was blown away by its beauty. Takes approx 20 minutes. Great for the elderly and little ones.
Lovely place to visit on a sunny day !. I always take my family and friends to visit this area and it does not disappoint , specially on a sunny day ! Beautiful views of the Sydney Harbour ! 👍

Walk this way to Mrs Macquaries Chair. Such a beautiful walk, lots to see in the gardens and views for miles across the harbour. We decided to do this walk as someone told us it is the best place to get the classic tourist photograph with the Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge in the same photograph - they weren't wrong! We walked to Mrs Macquaries Chair, took plenty of photographs and then walked back a different way through the gardens to Grosvenor House. I would highly recommend this on a sunny day to see the sights of Sydney!

Great place for a run. I took a morning run around the Botanic Gardens to the Opera House. Very nice paths. The weather was excellent. Great views of the Opera House, downtown and the Bridge from the path. Lots of other people out as well.

Tour of the opera house and walk in the botanic gardens. Well worth the expense, touring the opera house with a guide. Beautiful shell of a structure with a very interesting version of history behind its build, so be open minded. Shame of it all is that nothing within it is named after the man behind it all. Such are Australian politics

Perfect for tourists perfect for locals. Sydney is an outdoor city and with that reputation the Botanic Gardens and Opera House walk is the perfect way to showcase this great city. if you dare you can walk all the way around to WOOLOOMOOLOO where you can grab a casual bite at Harrys Café De Wheels or dine at one of the many restaurants on the Wharf But enjoy the walk and enjoy the weather

They are stunning!. Walking through the botanical gardens in Sidney is a real treat the gardens are stunning so beautifuly manicured with a vast array of different species of plants foliage etc.A delightful experience by any standards!
Winter walk. Beautiful and easy walk for all ages. Watch out for the Pokemon hunters who are everywhere at the moment !!!

something you have to do. That's an activity in Sydney that one simply has to do and take time for it. So, it's not something spectacular or extraordinary, but it's a quiet and beautiful scenery to enjoy. The Garden is well maintained and a good spot to spend some hours to simply relax and enjoy yourself.

Obligatory tourist photo, watch the seagulls . Great views but watch out for the seagulls that stole a woman's entire hamburger.
Food and drinks are pricey but if you want to soak in the view then be ready to shuttle for a seat with the people and birds .

Exhilarating walk. The combination of a beautiful Botanic Garden ,Sydney Harbour and the Opera House is exquisite. Whichever way you do the walking here you are sure to feel wonderful and exhilarated by all that surrounds you. Unmissable

One of the best places i ever travelled. I was there for one night and we had to explore all that area in one day, people were freadly alot and offered to take us pictures and the bridge, harbour, Madam tussaunds wax area and darling harbour were perfecto.

Stunning. I live close by and have done this walk often. There's always something different to see, whether in the garden or the harbour. Seasons and weather play their part, but it's always beautiful. Worth foing.
Just so pretty. as the title says its just so pretty the views the sea breeze and nature itself. Try and get a sunny day to really enjoy it :)
Beautiful. If you love walking this is a great place to do it take so many photos of the harbour,opera house,bridge,ferries,boats and the parklands
Pleasant Walk. After visiting the Opera House we strolled along the front towards the botanic gardens, some brilliant scenery on a warm autumn day
Lovely area to walk around. I walked all around this area on a beautiful sunny day and sat in the botanical gardens. Most relaxing place in Sydney and lovely views.

v erey beautyful, relaxing and interesting. The coast is arranged very beautiful and tasty. It was a pleasure foir me and my wife to walk here a couple of hours and to enjoy beautiful outlucks, plants, lakes, birds and view to ocean, Opera and Bridge.

One of our favourite walks. We walk 5 days a week. Rest on weekends. With Spring just around the corner the Botanic Gardens will burst into the most colourful scene.Full blooms everywhere. Many great statues. Unbelievable views of Sydney Harbour.Great lakes. Bird life all over. Magnificent city views.A flat walk except for the Queen Elizabeth Steps but you can bypass them if you wish!If tired catch the Garden train which you can catch at through the gate at the Opera House end or the Art Galley end inside the Gardens.

Different View Of The Opera House & Gardens. We found this to be a pleasant walk along the harbor. With a different view of the Opera House, And Bridge. You have the Royal Botanic Gardens on one side of the walkway and the Sydney Harbor on the other.Great to take a nice walk and take some pictures.

Beautiful Walk To Enjoy!. My boyfriend & I were vacationing, in Sydney, Australia, in May 2016. We decided to get up very early one Saturday morning and walk, from our hotel, to the Sydney Opera House then onto The Botanical Gardens before all the other tourists were out and about. I am so glad we did because it was beautiful and so tranquil! It was a nice & sunny day outside. The scenery is spectacular and the Botanical Gardens is so beautiful. In between walking, we sat down on benches, in the gardens, just to take in nature at it's best! The design, of the Sydney Opera House, is amazing to view in person and up close. Admission, into The Botanical Gardens, is FREE.

Nature & Gardens HARBOURSIDE. Walk up through the Botanical Gardens from the Opera House alongside the harbour and pass the rose gardens , the Conservatorium of music, the kiosk, then up to the Mitchell & State libraries or, past Boy Charlton pool towards the Art Gallery of NSW. On a sunny day, take time to stretch out on the grass in the sun or under a tree or walk right around Harbourside edge of the gardens to Lady Macquarie's chair. Even throw in a line if you're so inclined.Never know what you might catch!

Just as spectacular in real life!!. You see things In pictures and on the TV and they never do them justice. The detail up close and personal to the Sydney Opera house is just amazing. We only walked around it, didn't go inside but that was enough. We got plenty of iconic pics of our own, hubby had a jog one morning around it and thro the botanical gardens and he said they were amazing, never disappointed, we went over on a ferry and walked back into town. Was fab...
Nice walk on a sunny day. Takes quite a while but the views of the harbor are worth it. You approach the Opera House from a different angle to all the promotional photos.

Immense.. Wow! This backdrop is incredible, and with far fewer tourists than coming from circular quay!The Sydney Opera house is elluminated by the sun and the reflections off the water, with the Harbour Bridge nestled in the background. This view of the opera house is a must see. I could sit and admire this view for hours.
Very pretty walk. A must do while in Sydney! Very pretty garden, lots of exotic birds can be spotted and of course the view of Opera House and Harbour Bridge behind it can't be beat.

An Iconic Walk. A wonderful day out. Wether you arrive by train, bus or ferry a walk from the Quay to the Opera house then along the walkway to the Botanical gardens is memorable. Lunch in the gardens is peaceful and the gardens provide paths to stroll through enjoying the plants and birds. You can then walk up to the art gallery and St Mary Catheral.
Botanical Gardens. Beautiful and lovely place, strongly recommended. Very relaxing and stress-free walk around. Very pleasant. Awesome

A world class walk in the heart of Sydney. One can start at either end, that is near the Art Gallery and walk along past Lady Macquarie's Chair and then around Farm Cove to the Opera House or start at the Opera House if one is already in the city and go the other way. There are many detours to take through the beautiful gardens, especially in spring and summer. There are also several places to eat, each with a lovely outlook. This is a very special place and on a good day its unbeatable. Easy handicapped access. If parking near the Art Gallery meters are expensive-$7.00/hour.

One of the great history walks of Sydney!. The walk from the Opera House and ending up in the Botanic Gardens is a must for any visitor to Sydney! It not only offers views and close inspection of some of Sydneys iconic landmarks but it also takes the visitor on a trip back in time, visiting the landing spot of the First Fleet, some early buildings and sites of importance. The bonus is the beautiful Sydney Harbour, the perfect backdrop to the stunning Opera House and the beautifully maintained Botanic Gardens.
Such pretty gardens. Lots of different plants to enjoy. There's even a section with different lawn grasses so you can compare!

Good for a leisurely walk to explore the view. It ia a nice way to explore and photoshoot the beauty of this man made architecture, Opera House on one hand and the nature and the greens in the form of Royal Botanical Gardens on the other.A leisurely walk along the coast gives you various views of the city as well. A treat for people found of walking.
Day in the sun. Great for a lazy day stroll, beautiful harbour and lovely park.cafe for refreshments, feed the ducks, sit in the sun and enjoy the day.

Walk by the harbour. You must bring along a camera. Whether you are local to Sydney or not. The views are spectacular every time. Allow an extra hour plus to visit the Art Gallery and have a cup of tea and a cake at the cafe there. The trees in the Botanical Gardens are very exotic by today's standards and were brought in from far flung locations all over the world. Most have name plates. A must do.

Lazy sunny Sunday in a beautiful city. This is a beautiful part of Sydney.So much history with an open phography exhibition under the Opera House detailing the build, the design and the marvellous human engineering and excecution on sich a big scale! Just amazing and free. Kids were also facinated.☺Then we set off on the walk to the Botanical gardens, such an unriching experience in a carefree fantastic setting! Kids can run, read about the plants, watch the ducks and the pond and finish off at the beautiful cafe within the gardens for an easy lunch!! Highly recommend it.
Beautiful walk. This was such a nice and beautiful walk. The view is gorgeous, and the garden is very beautiful. Even on a cloudy rainy day, it was nice to walk around here.

How Lucky are we?. I walked from the Art Gallery of NSW all the way around to Mrs Macquaries chair, through the Botanical gardens, into St Mary's Cathedral and up through Hyde Park back to my hotel. How lucky I consider myself to have all this to experience for free. No wonder Sydney is voted the best City on earth to live in. Stunning!

Great walk. This is an easy walk to do. Can walk right around to Mrs mcquaries chair and further if you wish. Lovely places to sit and take in the views of the water, bridge and opera house. Definitely worth doing. Just be careful as there are a lot of runners in large groups running past. Will do this again next time in Sydney.

Trip of a lifetime. I visited Sydney in Nov 2007 and took the walk from the opera house to the botanic gardens. It was a lovely sunny day and we managed to get some great pics from a vantage point. A really lovely walk and there is a lot of informatiin regarding the plants etc.
The Opera House to the Botanic Gardens. The Opera House to the Botanic Gardens, you can go to Botanic Gardens from Opera House Sydney. Nice place to visit
a great walk. i love the walk around the bay from the Opera House to Mrs Macquaries chair it is a must do Sydney thing without fail

Walk to the gardens. This walk is not that long and us very enjoyable. You can continue out to the point and Mrs Macquarie's chair. Good views of the harbour and not strenuous. Bus and train points clean se if you need to get off your feet but there are plenty of seats along your walk.

Sydney Opera House and Sydney Botanical Gardens. The Sydney Opera House and Botanical Gardens are some to the many thousands of outstanding attractions which Sydney has to offer visiting tourists (and residents).Continuous views over Sydney´s magnificent Harbour and the Opera house in all it´s glory. Restaurants and snacking spots galore. The rich timber panelled Opera House and Concert Hall interiors and magnificent sound reproduction mage the Opera House a superb place to visit. Please do attend at least one (or better still more than one) Concert there. A Concert at night is best, as the harbour-side shows off its lights. The Botanical Gardens are best seen when it is not too hot. It is a very big space and the trees and shrubs are amazing. Well identified also. The large expanses of mown grass are a pleasure for the eyes as well your feet. There are places to eat and wine and dine well in the middle of the gardens.
Fantastic walk on a lovely sunny day. This was a very interesting and pleasurable walk. The reward is the stunning Botanic Gardens and the view from the highest point there.

The Best Spot. If you want to see the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge together, then heading to the Botanic Garden is a good idea. From the Botanic Garden, you can get a glimpse of both iconic tourist spots together. The view is even better during sunset. It's truly captivating.
Great stroll. Great views, birdie and photo opportunities. Escape the crowd and find somewhere quiet to sit and enjoy the plants and birdlife. The Cockatoo are great entertainment

Grab some lunch and take a stroll... Such a lovely location to go and grab some take away lunch form the city/harbor and then take a leisurely stroll around the outside of the Opera House and through the Botanic Gardens.
Lovely walk. Lovely to stroll past the opera house and then into the beautiful botanic gardens. Definitely worth a stroll

Easy walk that delivers a good view of the city. This is a lovely walk if you are time poor or unable to access some of Sydneys other less accessible walks. Always lots of people around and mostly flat so accessible to disabled folk or older persons.
A must. Nice place to walk from the Opera along the bay. Here can do much better photos of the Opera House and the bridge.
The best thing to do. Love the way from the Opera House to the Royal Botanic Gardens. Enjoy the view and relax some time seated in the grass.

Pleasant Walk. The Sydney Botanic Gardens and the Sydney Opera House are very close together and close to the City. From the Opera House it's a walk down the steps and a turn left and you're in the Botanic Gardens, which also overlooks Sydney's beautiful Harbour. Obviously best on a sunny day. The Botanic Gardens have several sections of different flora. There are Cafe's and in the Summer, many events, such as outdoor plays and Open-air Cinema. If you walk "too far", you will end up at the NSW Art Gallery or another wonderful "play" area of Woolloomooloo.

enjoyable walk with plenty to see along the way. This is a busy route at times, particularly lunchtime when there are a lot of runners passing by. I liked watching the boats as I walked and then turning back to see the Opera House and the Bridge. There are bats hanging from trees in the gardens and lots of pigeons looking for scraps around the cafe. I went up to Mrs. Maquarie's Seat and back.

Must Do! Really gorgeous!. With out a doubt Sydney Opera House is a must visit! Even if you don't do a show, a walk around Circular Quay, along the boardwalk to the Opera House and around it is great! Standing on the point looking out over the Harbour, Sydney Harbour Bridge and Luna Park (esp at night all lit up) is totally memorable. Wouldn't miss it. New Year's Eve is a press of humanity and very crowded, but great to do even just once.
Cruise destination. Ship anchored right between the opera house and the bridge couldn't ask for a better spot.We walked from the ship to the opera house and the garden walk and it was beautiful.

Good for distant walking...... We parked underneath the Opera house and started walking towards the Botanic Garden. Its quite tiring because of the elevation, but, the unobstructed spectacular awesome views are something to behold...From here, you can see from a far distance the Garden Island, the Fort Denison, but still can capture a good view,and its just amazing..
Iconic. The kids were excited to see a building they have only seen on TV and in pictures. I wish you could see inside when nothing is going on.

Iconic spot to visit. Anywhere along the harbour foreshore is great for a visitThe gardens are lovely and the kids can run off some energyThe opera house is worth a tour but not with little kids or prams etcFood is expensive all along the waterfront of course , you could spend the day in the gardens and then walking along the waterfront through circular quay and the rocks to the new park at Barangaroo

Sensational architecture. This is one of the most sensational wonders in the world and must be seen. The architecture is very unusual, and it looks great sitting out on the water of the harbour. There are many restaurants nearby.

Must see architecture. If you're visiting Sydney, even briefly, you must see the Opera House. The walk provides an excellent view of both the Opera House and the harbor, good even in poor weather. You can see into the office space, which is kind of fun, as well as stop at a cafe. We didn't go inside the Opera House, but the outside shouldn't be missed.

Lunch and a walk on a rainy day. After the Art Gallery of NSW, I love to walk through the gardens to view the art of nature. The gardeners work hard to have the beds and vegetation in perfect order. There are historical plaques through the gardens to remind the visitor of the 200 year history. Stop at the bookshop and the cafe. We packed our own lunch to eat outside. My friends visited some of the special attractions but I like to just sit and take in the views to Farm Cove. Walk around to Mrs Macquarie's Chair or go straight to the Sydney Opera House. I love the curve of the giant sails as the SOH comes into view. Government House is adjacent. I always feel restored after a visit to the gardens.

Amezing Construction. This an amezing architectural work, it's a building the leaves you wonder man's capability in building these types land marks buildings, if you are in Sydney this is a must see site

Good walk with Breathtaking views. This is a great walk either from the Opera House to the Botanical Gardens or vice versa. You get to explore the other side of the gardens; get to see some amazing sculptures and pass by the Governor's House (and note Australia's unique history of still being governed)...if you have kids, there are playgrounds worth stopping at....and if you fancy a picnic, the gardens beckon...

Great spot. I used to walk here during the week if I needed a break. This time it was with friends from out of town.Whether you're from in or out of town, if you have the time then take the time: a walk from the rocks, through the quay up to the opera house and then through the gardens is terrific on a nice day.You have the harbour lapping to your left, the grass, gardens and trees on your right and above them, in the background, the city skyline. There are a number of paths through the gardens, you can take 10 minutes or an hour, whatever suits. To me this is Sydney !

On time and frequent. The ferries do what they are there for, plenty of room, fast enough and on time. We used them often during our 8 day stay in Sydney. The Opal Card is an easy way to travel on theses ferrys.
Pretty urban garden. This was a pretty walk with several entrance points. Amazing for a leisurely stroll, and saw a lot of runners and families alike

A lovely day for a stroll. After a refreshing drink at the Opera House bar, take an easy stroll to the Botanical Gardens. Along the way, one might catch wedding parties - a great venue for photos. Rolling gardens and lawns.

Royal botanical garden next to Sydney Opera House. Many people dont know that these two attractions are linked through a nice riverside walkway. Royal botanical garden can be accessed by several entrances and anyone can eventually end up in front of the opera house ... they are nicely linked....it was great to enjoy the sunshine laying on the green grass of RBG where you would find many doing the same....great way to spend an afternoon amid the plethora of trees and flowers....

Nice & beautiful view. We just had a marvellous time walking from the Botanical garden to the Opera House. We even managed to stop by the Art Gallery which was on our way. It was summer but the temperature was cool enough for us to enjoy the whole walk.

Great walk. I walk quite long from Botany garden to Opera house started from Sydney City. It was a great walk along way. Love all the gardens, so nice, beautiful and neat. One point is they need to repaint the statue in the middle of the garden. Others are fine.

What do I take a picture of first?. Did this walk with my daughter and grandson recently. Very easy and without doubt the best for gorgeous pictures. We climbed the fleet steps and walked on to wooloomoloo wharf where we crossed the road for a delicious lunch at sienna marina. Essential walk for visitors to Sydney. Its hard to know which way to point the camera. Stunning.
Striking building in the Harbour. The opera house is a famous landmark in the Sydney Harbour. It is a beautiful building and and is worth your time to explore it, both inside and out.

Green Grass, Blue Water and Whiie Sails. On a nice day, its very relaxing to take a break from the city and walk in the Botanic Gardens. Take your camera and you will find some wortwhile opportunities especially along thr gardens foreshore to the Opera House.
Nice walk hrouh harbour and parks. A nice walk from the botanical gardens to the Opera, along the sea, with lots of birds and nice plants.
Beautiful. You feel really beautiful and fresh while passing from botanic gardens towards the opera house walk.

Pleasant, FREE, and safe. PleasantWalked there at night during Vivid Sydney 2016. It was crowded. On normal days (day time), there were some people strolling the park esp lunch time. For a short cut, go up the old stairs between modern buildings (housing cafes and restaurants) before Opera House. On weekdays you would probably bump into a bunch of school kids with their teachers like i did. There are few huts along the way. Best to equip yourself with an umbrella.

Explore the gardens.. Visit the various theme gardens and landscapes in the Royal Botanic Garden; a significant heritage site in Sydney. Good place to have a picnic. Check website for Whats On re. exhibitions. Great views of harbour and city from Mrs Macquaries Point/Chair.

A great walk and an even better run.. If you are staying in Sydney, then the walk through the Botanic Gardens is a must. If you are a runner, it is a great early morning run.The water views near the Opera House are ever changing - the ferries coming and going, the high speed boats - but as you move away you can enjoy the park settings and there are even some interesting rock formations, if you search them out.The Gardens are beautiful especially during the Vivid Festival when they were illuminated with thousands of tiny lights at night.If you do decide to do this walk as a run, then I suggest doing it early in the morning because it is very popular - especially on weekends - and it can be difficult to navigate safely with lots of people about.
Beautiful Walk. The walk from the opera house to the Botanic gardens is a beautiful walk. At the northern end of the opera house you can see seals on the stairs.

Great Run. Went for a run through the Gardens and by the Opera House - a most spectacular run! Quick tip, don't run into the Government House grounds (where the Governor lives); you can walk in those grounds, but no running allowed.

Easy walk, great views. Really easy walk with really great views back out over the city.
We walked in along the harbour and back through the gardens. It's a lovely escape from the city.
Definitely worth a visit, especially if you're only in Sydney for a short time.
Always worth a visit. A trip to Sydney would not be complete without a visit to the Opera House. I always find it a little less impressive right close up, but still, a must-do.
Take a walk. Gorgeous area for a walk or a jog. Lots of places to stop and sit and enjoy the scenery. Bring your camera to take some fabulous pictures.
exciting, interesting. Facinating experience, take the opera house tour, eat in the bistros below the opera house, great value prompt service, family friendly
Springtime is the time to visit the Botanical Gardens. Even if you are not a garden lover this walk is still worth the visit. Wonderful views of the Harbour.

Beautiful Walk. Have walked from the Opera House through the Botanical Gardens many times and love it each time. The views from the Opera House of the harbor are spectacular and then you turn around and stroll through the trees and gardens within the Botanical Gardens. The city seems to disappear and you can sit and read or chat in peace. I am not sure who designed this, but they certainly did Sydney a favor.

Beautiful walk after Lunch. After a fabulous birthday buffet lunch at Cafe Opera in the InterContinenial Hotel Sydney, we walked through the beautiful Botanical gardens down to Lady Macquarie's Chair Mrs Macquarie's Chair which is an exposed sandstone rock cut into the shape of a bench, on a peninsula in Sydney Harbour, hand carved by convicts from sandstone in 1810 for Governor Macquarie's wife Elizabeth.... then onto thee Opera House....a great way to walk off those extra birthday calories..

A gorgeous walk along the edge of the harbour.. You can see the Opera House, the Harbour Bridge,mthe harbour itself, and get some lovely photos along the waters edge and in the botanic gardens itself. I really don't understand some of the negative reviews of the gardens - people writing things like 'it's just gardens' - well, yes, it is just gardens - what exactly were you expecting? I'd say do your homework & if you don't want to see botanic gardens, don't go there!The walk there from the opera house, however, allows you to see the iconic Sydney landmarks for free, in a lovely garden setting. If gardens aren't for you, just stay along the path that runs around the waters edge, or even catch a ferry from circular quay and see it all from the water. Personally, I enjoy the walk between the iconic sights, with a breeze off the water and plenty of people to watch along the way - the fact that it has the Botanic Gardens as a backdrop is simply an added bonus.

Beautiful space in the City. Lovely harbour views. The gardens are a peaceful oasis in the busy City, all year around. Spring is always special and the flowers are on show. There is a cafe in the gardens, or you can take your own picnic. My grand kids loved rolling down the grassy slopes and climbing some trees.

Beautiful walk with beautiful views!. Beautiful walk between two major attractions in Sydney: Opera House and Royal Botanic Garden. It is open every day of the year and access is free. It is positioned on Sydney Harbor and immediately adjacent to the Sydney Central Business District, the Sydney Opera House and the large public parklands of The Domain. You can spend hours near Opera House and in the garden. There are many walks with beautiful views. Cacadu parrots are everywhere and very noisy bunch. Beautiful!
A distant view of the Opera House Is stunning.. The tiles that make up the roof looks absolutely beautiful , a slow walk around the building taking in the breath taking structure is amazing.

Not to be missed.. A beautiful way to spend some free time is to take a walk around the Opera House, also to head to the Botanic Gardens. It is a truly beautiful setting where you can admire some of the rarest species of plants and trees, besides other surprises. You can see the harbour and all its beauty. Something not to be missed.

Revered walk. Coming from the Art gallery we walked through the Botanic Gardens before heading out as recommended by Gardens volunteers via the furthest gateway exiting onto the sweeping concourse that leads to the Opera House. The stone walls and stone stairs are dramatic as is the splendour of the Opera House. So popular for photos. Rightly so!
Beautiful Gardens. This is a must, such beautiful gardens you can wonder around for hours looking at all the wonderful pants and flowers

Walk of views. To walk round the botanic gardens is an absolute must,if you are visiting Sydney. Apart from the sheer beauty of the harbour. There us much to discover,from the many beautiful plant beds with majestic trees and pretty ponds,to the spread of wonderfully kept grass,for people to picnic,play,or just sit and enjoy the passing parade. There is always something going on, in and around the Opera house. Indeed if you feel up to it,do the whole walk till you reach the NSW Art gallery,on the other side . There's always a friendly game of Soccer going on ,on the green space next to the gallery ,and the gallery itself is a wonderful place to wile away a couple of hours. There are cafes in and around the gardens as well as in the gallery. You will get a real feel for Sydney.

Leisure walk with beautiful view. The walkway connects The Opera House and the Botanic Gardens is popular, suitable to all ages, well maintained. The stretch of 1.3 km from the Opera House to Mrs Macquarie's Chair offers magnificent view of the Opera House and the Harbour bridge, particularly beautiful at sunset on one side, and the beautiful Botanic Gardens on the other.Best access is by public transport. There're car parking areas on Mrs Macquaries Road at $7/hr.
Went here during the VIVID display - FANTASTIC!. The VIVID display is at its best in the gardens and the eastern side of the opera house. Make sure you go there.

Beautiful Botanic Gardens in Sydney. Walk from the iconic Opera House to the Royal Botanic Gardens for a wonderful Sydney experience. I live in Sydney and try to do this each season as the gardens have something to offer all year around. It is also a beautiful haven from the city and in a wonderful position on the harbour. Take some time to soak it all in. Take a picnic or stop by the cafe for something delicious to eat. Seeing the Opera House, the Harbour Bridge, the Harbour and the Botanic Gardens in one sweep reminds me how lucky I am to live here.

Must see and free. The Botanical Gardens is 200 years old this year, there is huge, and there is lots to see. Great for photographers, great place for a picnic, beautiful views.If you are a Pokemon GO hunter the Opera House and Botanical Gardens is the place to go
Perfect for run, walks, or picnic. You will find enough photography opportunities. This place is equally beautiful on a cloudy and sunny day.

Scenic Culutral Walk. taking the walk from Opera House through Botaniacal Gardens on a nic day is wonderful, you have the Gardens, You have the COnservatorium of Music, The Mitchell Library and the Art Museum, all is an easy pleasant walk with the Harbour in view at all times

Family weekend for vivid. Great walk . Family friendly and easy on the legs for Adults and children .So many things to look at for all the family . Makes you appreciate how lucky we are to have the most scenic harbour in the world .The walk is so pleasant that you sometimes have to remember that the kids are with you , because they at a young age are entranced by the surroundings and are discovering new and wonderful sights and therefore making your walk all the more enjoyable .
World class. Look up and you'll see birds and critters. This is a must see when you are in Sydney. Look up and you'll see kookaburras, bats, ibises nesting.

Spectacular Walk - not to be missed. So many things to look at - not enough superlatives to describe it.. Wonderful Harbour Views as you walk along - Opera House, Bridge, Fabulous gardens and Great Central City Skyscraper Views… this walk around to Mrs. Macquaries Chair.. is not to be missed… Even if it is rainy, put your coat on - get your umbrella out and enjoy this walk - FABULOUS !
Easy walj. Botanical Gardens are an easy walk to/from the Sydney Opera House. The gardens are in their winter months, but there were flowers still visible.

Lovely walk. Really nice walk alongside the Sydney harbour from the Botanic Garden to the Opera House. There are plenty of rest points, lots of lovely photo opportunities. The walkway can get quite crowded on sunny days but that just adds to the atmosphere. If you do the complete walk, make sure you have a drink or snack with you - it's quite a fair distance and the cafes were really only clustered at either end.
A beautiful walk. Stunning views abound from this path an ding in the beautiful Botanical gardens - take time to meander .

Amazing stroll from landmark to park. Explore the Opera House and then take a walk through the beautiful Botanical Gardens. There is a wonderful cafe in the park with an adjoining fantastic gift store.

Checking out the Opera House. A must for all to visit it was amazing to get up so close to the Opera House to see what it was made of and how big it is. Then to have the Botanical Garden so close was great too as you could experience that too. Amazing!
Best workout ever. My husband and I ran around the Sydney Opera House and to the Botanical Gardens. It was quite possibly the best workout ever. It certainly had the best view ever!
Don't miss it.. This is surely a place to put on your bucket list and NOT to miss. Brilliant acoustics, fabulous look and great seats...everyone can see, especially after the first eight rows.

Where icon meets panorama. We have done this section of the harbour many many times. And because it is simply amazing, we will continue to introduce our guests to it. Walk the stairs of the iconic Opera House enter the Botanical Gardens, sit down to admire the activities or picnic.

We walked through the Botanic Gardens daily. Our hotel was in Potts Point, a small way from the Bontanic Gardens then onto Circular Quay. It was a little farther than we thought, but ended up loving the location.

See the harbour from a new angle. Its great to get away from a busy city and walk along the front. The botanical gardens are an escape from the city, and with plenty of seating, just sit and take it all in.
Nice. Going to Sydney without visiting the Opera house is something is a huge no no. The opera house and botanical gardens are a nice combination if you want to go for a stroll.
An amazing walk. I love jumping on a ferry from Manly to the city and doing the walk it is so relaxing and a lovely day out. Take a picnic or buy some lunch there.

Great view of Opera house. Another good point to take photo in Sydney. Anyway, do not stay too late as the gate of Botanic Garden closes around 6pm; otherwise you have to make a long walk back to the city.
Pleasant. The walk is pleasant & the gardens are vast, quiet, and beautiful. The cafe in the gardens offers delicious pain-au- chocolat.

Take a comfortable stroll - you will enjoy the gardens and the views. I walked this in good weather, but I am sure that as long as you wrap up well, the walk would be equally good in less favourable temperatures. The gardens are lovely with some beautiful trees at which to marvel. Then as you continue your walk towards the sea, your eyes capture the Opera House, which we all know is stunning. Remember to pick up a map of the pathways.

Wonderful views. Great spot to relax in nature in the middle of the city. One also had wonderful views of the city, opera house and other sites. Beautiful large trees spread through out the botanical gardens.

easy walk and so pretty. grab a gelato at the Quay and off you go. this is a pretty walk, easy to do and so peaceful. Great harbour views, and the gardens there as well. Lovely spot to take you lunch to

A wonderful little wander . Just perfect for an easy stroll , with some loverly views along the way not to mention at both ends .
A very easy walk so ideal for the older amongst us .
Wonderful place to visit. Must see peaceful relaxing walk from the Opera House. Grand mature trees, colorful flowers, cheerful birds and interesting people and sights.

Sydney's Iconic. It's beautiful, never tire of seeing or visiting, even though I live 2km away! Plenty of shows/performances at different times of the year. Bennelong Restaurant is excellent too. Don't forget to say hi to the seal who has taken up residence on the steps. Can't fault his taste in real estate!
Awesome Walk. What a great way to enjoy the view of Sydney Opera House, the harbour, and the garden from a different angle.
Fantastic.. You can see Sydney and the harbour from this walk. Along the water fronet it is a good pathway with amazing vistas.

look, it is opera house, you have to be here once in a life time. dont just go to the opera house, take a walk from the botanical garden to the opera house, continue to the circular quay and the rock area, then you will appreciate all the sorrounding

Take the right route if need wheelchair access. Our route was a little longer as we had a pram and couldn't make our way up the large stairway from the base of opera house up to the gardens, but there is access if you follow the sea then head uphill on the pathways further along (or instead follow the street opposite opera house then head into alternate garden entrance). Our route was still a beautiful walk- just be aware of stairs if you're heading from gardens down to the Opera House, as changing route will add an extra 5-10 mins to your walk.
Australia with kids. Very nice walk, try to go behind the Opera House, as there can be seals on the piers. Wheelchair access.

A great walk to explore. The gardens walk up to Mrs Macquarie's Chair is delightful and not too difficult. The gardens themselves are an oasis and the cafe is affordable and serves delicious food. Beware of the birds though! (It is quite entertaining to see them pounce on a table as soon as it is vacated).

Lovely walk with so much to see. I actually did the walk from the Botanic gardens to the Opera House, rather than the other way round, but there is so much to see that it is easy to detour elsewhere within the Botanic gardens. Take time to stop and look at everything going on around you. I had weddings, nesting birds fighting over the smallest twigs, fishermen... and of course, great views
A nice relaxing walk. I'd imagine this is the perfect park for a good run or a good walk. In general it's quite a beautiful and plain park. Great for a post-meal stroll!
headphones..music…garden…walk. with sneakers, take your headphones, listen to Sia, and walk the park…forget the time and some cheese and wine

Great Walk. This is a great walk! What a treasure to have such a beautiful green space filled with many different types of birds. The walk travels along the water with many benches for you to sit and just enjoy the view. It's used by many for fitness reasons and if I lived there I would use it too. It's very well maintained and has great views. Take a path into the gardens to enjoy the serene beauty of the gardens.

Onward along Sydney's tourist trail.. A short flat, stroll from Sydney's iconic Opera House to the Royal Botanic Gardens, along a path adjacent to a stone wall, edging Sydney Harbour. You can see most of the highlights of Sydney in a few short steps. Really nice on a sunny day, not so nice on a wet one as there is no cover available. On weekend mornings and weekday lunchtimes, there are crowds of joggers intermingling with tourists on pathways, all around the park. That isn't so nice, but typical of a modern society in a cosmopolitan city. The pathway around the water takes you to Mrs Macquarie's Chair and onwards to the Andrew Boy Charlton Public Swimming Pool, facing the naval base at Garden Island. The path continues through the Domain, past the Art Gallery of NSW and on to St Mary's Cathedral. The Botanic Gardens offer a feeling of being close to nature, with examples of fauna and flora throughout the park. I like to read the signs on the tags on the plants, which fun for adults and children, alike. The rose garden up on top of the adjacent hill is really beautiful in season. There is a restaurant and a café in the park and plenty of public toilet facilities. A worthy sojourn, if you are staying in the City or just visiting for a few hours.

A Lovely way to see the harbour for free.. This is a lovely walk on a sunny day, and even nice on a not so sunny day. It is easy for people with a lesser fitness level and I think kids would enjoy it as well. There's always something to look at.
great walk/run path. great path for a run or walk to get view of opera house and bridge/harbor. go in the morning for best views with sunlight

Sydney sights for free!. A walk round circular quay to the opera house and on through the wonderful botanical gardens is a must - this allows you many options with a number of stops either in the gardens or the art gallery at the other end. Try two or three different routes over a couple of days - well worth it and only cost is your legs! Enjoy!

Relaxing stride along the waterside.. Was quite surprised at how much I enjoyed this walk. Parked my car at the domain and walk to the Opera House from there, past the Botanical Gardens. I have been to the gardens a few times but never walked to the Opera House from there. Beautiful scenery. It was great watching the reaction of my nephews when walking down from the domain to the waterfront, as the trees hide the Harbour Bridge and Opera house from where our car was parked. Have to pay to park at the Domain. $7 an hour I think.Great picture opportunities.

One of the great walks . The setting against the Harbour, Opera House and Bridge is unbeatable. It is a fairly easy walk. As it is near the water there is usually a breeze. Sydney weather near the harbour is usually pleasant and rarely too hot. A place to relax in great surrounds.

An Easy Walk. From the Opera House, the walk to the Botanical Gardens is an easy one. Best time to walk is early in the morning or in the evening as the sun can be rather hot. However, the botanical garden itself is rather large and you need to spend at least 2-3 hours if you plan to walk around. There are water refill stations and toilets inside the gardens.
Beautiful walk. Very relaxing and scenic walk. Take your time and enjoy the flora and fauna. And its free. Would highly recommend it.
Did the train trip around gardens. Enjoyable and definitely worth a look! Historic gardens, buildings and statues. Kids enjoyed it too.

A beautiful walk. You start from the Botanic Garden where you enjoy the various gardens, head towards Macquarie's Chair along the water, and head back towards the Sydney Opera. Good exercise n pleasant setting. We were lucky Sydney was not experiencing a heat wave when we did this!

Evening stroll with 4yo grand daughter & her parents to view the Vivid lights. Even though it was a wet showery night the lights made the walk look like a fairy land for the 4yo! A relaxing evening followed by a water taxi tour of the harbour around the Opera House to the Botanical Gardens & return via the Harbour Bridge.
Ok. Not bad, its a nice walk with nice views and location is nice.Sit and have a picnic if you have the time.

Tranquility in the middle of a busy city. Whether it's to spend a couple of hours wandering around the beautiful gardens, lying in the dappled shade of a generously sprawling tree or taking a quick lunch time rest, visiting the Botanical Gardens is a must for everyone. Children can run around freely or take them on a 'train' ride that meanders through the gardens. IT'S FREE!!!

Witless on the roof!. What an amazing building, very interesting guided tours and almost surreal as you visit this amazing opera house! Beautiful sound reflection inside. And more then a million tiles not the roof.

Stunning easy walk. We have walked from Circular Quay station past the ferry terminal to the Opera House, very easy walk for families or wheelchairs as well. Plenty to see, you can stop and watch the boats or ferries passing as well as a beautiful view of the Harbour Bridge and also Luna Park.
