Walking up to the Opera House is always a magnificent feeling, its a spectacular sight, from here it is an easy walk into The Botanic Gardens. Plenty of space for picnics on the grass, there is a lovely cafe in the middle of the gardens plus many different plant and tree species to admire. A beautiful pond and just magnificent views of the harbour.

A walk in the garden. A trip to the Botanic Gardens is many fold. The walk, the view of the harbour, Sydney Bridge, the Opera House and finally the gardens. Keep in mind that you would be looking at a 200 year old monument, very old trees, diverse and beautiful. I personally love the bamboo collection over there. Pick a nice sunny day and just go there for a lite picnic. Enjoy the scene and the sea view. Kids will love hopping on the train that takes the, around the garden. If you love your herbs have a look at the upper section where the herb collection is. Sit and enjoy, walk and wonder. Keep your mobile in your carry bag :)

Nice Walk. We walked from Macleay Street, past lovely historic houses, down some very steep steps & through the Botanic Gardens where we stopped for coffee & cake. At some stage we walked along a very old wharf (Finger Wharf??) lined with interesting looking, very expensive restaurants. Of course the harbour view with its many boats & activities is nearly always present as you walk on to the Opera House. You can always stop for a meal around the Opera House & surrounds or a drink/meal/nibbles at the Opera House Bar in the lower forecourt overlooking the harbour. This whole area is only a very short walk from the gardens by the way.

Stunning walk. I always love the Opera House to Botanical Gardens Walk . The views over the harbour are spectacular, the Opera House so magnificent and accessible. My favourite thing to do in the Botanic Gardens is to take a picnic, a good book and just soak it all in.

Hidden gem behind the opera house. If you are in town and going to go to the opera house, set aside a little more time to walk around the Botanic Gardens just behind opera house.... Lovely views, beautiful gardens. It was an amazing sight during the Vivid festival. First time I had walked through there, and have been back since! I had no idea we had such a lovely place to go and see the harbour or just sit and enjoy the quiet.

Taking a stand on history.. Recognised as one of the most unique man made structures world wide, this is also the site of the first farm of the First Fleet in 1788. Today, the wide, flat paved concourse enables easy movement of many people at once( Australia Day Vivid Celebrations). This is my favourite way to enter The Royal Botanic Gardens- celebrating its centenary 2016. To walk through the Gardens harbourside to Lady Macquarie's Chair is an activity many people are unaware of. A hidden gem of Sydney so easily accessed from the steps of The Opera House. Walk it- a photographer's delight.

A beautiful and interesting walk. This is an easy and interesting walk. There are almost always freee exhibitions on at the Gardens and you can combine the walk with a trip to the Art Gallery, lunch, State Library etc. You can make a full day tour out of this small corner of Sydney
Gentle walk with views. The House lends a magical charm to the gentle walk to the Botanic Gardens, which are really special, and yet again enhanced by the Harbour views.
Lovely veiws. this is a great place to take a snack sit and watch the passing crowed and stroll through the gardens .
Botanic Gardens. interesting plants from all over the world. The location is quiet and serene good for a picnic. Beautiful water sites.The glass houses are worth entering.

Stunning. This is such a beautiful area with magnificent views, we have been here many times and will keep returning...even just to grab a coffee and sit on the lawns to take it all in, is a great way to pass the time! Do yourself a favour and wander around this lovely area!

Tranquility. The walk around Farm Cove from the Opera House to Mrs Macquarie's chair, follows the bay and the Northern edge of the Botanical gardens. With the harbour on your left and gardens on your right, one can be overwhelmed by the beauty of the place....and wonder what the 1st settlers thought of it. The gardens are expansive, lovely and worth several hours. Go right to the point for great views back of the Opera House, the Bridge and the city skyline. Visits in the evening are also spectacular with the city and Bridge lights coming on....

Lovely walk even in winter. Having lived in Sydney most of my life I had forgotten what a fabulous place the Botanic gardens are. Once you get pass the tourists around the Opera House keep on the path and continue your walk through the gardens, I did this on Sunday which was a cold day but the park was absolutely glorious. Had recently come back from NYC and the Sydney Royal Botanic Gardens is equal to anything I've seen overseas. What other large city park also have fabulous views of a magnificent harbour. If you visit Sydney make sure you amble around the park, take a picnic and blanket to sit on and have lunch.
Vivid was great. What a time to walk around, it was vivid and the gardens 200th birthday, it was spectacular. The gardens came alive again at night
GREAT WALK. Easy level walk with spectacular views. The Botanical gardens are lovely and you can continue your walk to the art gallery. Of course The Opera House is Spectacular.

Beautiful gardens on an amazing harbour. They really are quite stunning gardens, very well kept and with an amazing array of plant life. Reasonably large in size with large grassed areas to picnic and for the kids to run around. There is an abundance of shade to get away from the harsh summer sun and there are enough little nooks and crannies that it's not too difficult to find yourself a little space away from the other visitors.Let's not forget that the gardens are also situated smack bang on Sydney Harbour which is a site in itself. Well worth a stroll if you are visiting Sydney and well worth making sure that you remind yourself every now and then how great they are if you are a regular visitor to the CBD.
Opera House to Botanic Gardens, Sydney. A great walk! If you have time, continue on through the Gardens and the elevated walking path to Woolloomooloo

Opera House - Botanic Gardens Gentle Walk. As an an over 70 with knee problems I find walking to see the sights somewhat difficult. Not so with this one. Starting from the Opera House and waking around through the flat water edge paths, one not only may enjoy the flora but get great views of possibly the greatest harbour in the world. You will need at least 2 hours or even half a day. There is a fine restaurant and also snack bar within the park, or take your own food and have a picnic. Great for locals and visitors alike. Take a hat. 2016 is the parks 200th birthday and there are special events through the year.
Awesome!. Amazing place to visit by day and by night! Enjoy the view of the harbour and the bridge. Lots of places to grab something to eat.
Lovely walk beside the harbour. Escape the city bustle and enjoy the Harbourside walk surrounded by bueatiful expansive gardens.lovely!

Easy walk. It's a flat walk on a path with spectacular views of the harbour around into the gardens. The gardens are one of the jewels to Sydney. Free entery and you could spend your whole day relaxing here or just an hour if that's all the time you have.

Great Walk.. This is a great walk on a lovely day. The Botanical gardens are right next to the opera house and it's free to walk around. On a nice day, it's a great walk. you will find people hanging out under the trees and just enjoying the weather. If you have time and are looking for relaxing things to kill time and enjoy the city, I highly recommend the gardens and walk around it.

Take this walk for the best photo opportunities. A relaxing walk, allowing for possibly the best Harbour photo opportunities in Sydney. Pack a picnic lunch and enjoy the view from any of the grassy areas, overlooking the Opera House.
Beautiful scenery. This is one of my favourite pastimes whilst in Sydney. The Botanic Gardens are lovely and to stroll past the Opera house en route is an added bonus.

Good walk with great views. It is an easy and lovely, short walk. It is good to see the Opera House from this different perspective and then to go on to the Botanical Gardens. Once there, you can sit and enjoy the views of Sydney Harbour - or walk around and see the various types of gardens there - or picnic closer to the city itself (or eat at the restaurant in the grounds).
Nice walk anytime of day. Strolls, prams, zimmer frames all possible. Easy flat walking with a nice view over the harbour and surrounds.
Easy walk . Comfortable walk. Mainly in the sun, I would suggest a hat if not sun tolerant. Great place to n people watch and the wild "cockatoos" were a great sight.

Lovely stroll. We did a lot of walking on this day. We were in the middle of the city and had just walked through St Mary's. We went out the back way and ended up walking through the Botanical Gardens. Beautiful grounds with signs pointing out interesting facts about specific breeds of plants and/or where they came from and their age. We kept walking and found ourselves coming up on the Opera House with the Harbor Bridge in the back ground. We did go into the Opera House as the grounds are open to all. Lots of people walking around or just sitting on the steps. A beautiful place/area to just sit and take in for a little while.
A beautiful path!. My husband and I walked and ran this path several times while in Sydney. The views were spectacular, and we got lots of great pictures along the way. A must do for sure!

Wow, wow, wow!. The Sydney opera house is a stunning piece of architecture and it is great to stroll around. You can also do guided tours or even take in a performance if there is anything on. There are tonnes of cafes and eateries around the opera house and it can be bit of a chaotic tourist zoo but is definitely worth checking out. Just a little further on is the botanic gardens, which is a stunning spot and is great for a picnic in the sun.
Iconic walk. Amazing to actually be in Sydney & walk to Opera house, lovely walk by sea. It was very special to walk here.
Best views of Sydney. Love both these places so a walk between the two is always going to be a winner. Terrific views in every direction

Take the Opera House Tour!. This is the world famous opera house and the jewel of Syndey. Make sure to take the tour. You may have the opportunity to watch rehearsals while you are inside, but you will definitely learn and see what makes tis venue so special!

Great walk in a natural relaxed setting. Good walk on a fine day to see the 'other side' of the famous harbour area. Take a hat, sunglasses and sunscreen if in spring, autumn or summer. Really beautiful on a sunny day!

Beautiful!. I walked from my hotel in the city, through to the art gallery (which was a little bit of a let down) and then through the botanical gardens to the opera house. It was a stunning walk, that was the perfect length and was very safe! Very good to do by yourself, if you're elderly of for families!
Vivid light festival . Along the walkway from the opera house yo the botanic gardens, while the vivid festival is on, there are sound bars and various lights displayed.

Beautiful walk. It's just fantastic not too long and not to short ,plenary benches to seat and enjoy the best view . After walk I end up in botanical garden which no one would like not to visit. All year around garden is popular spot either just for a walk or to enjoy such a variety of the plants.I will highly record this walk to everyone .Enjoy your day out!!!

Beautiful Area. The Botanic Gardens are a short and worthwhile walk from the Sydney Opera House. We visited during Vivid Sydney, but it was during the day, so things were not lit up. Beautiful walk. Definitely worth it.

Stunning views from the city. Not everyone knows but you can easily get to the beautiful botanical gardens from the back of Opera House; this park is lovely all year round with ponds, trees and great views of the Harbour and the city. You can spot wildlife and there are public toilets. well worth a detour. If you're in Sydney now Vivid Festival also offers some lighting display in that area.

See the Highlights of Sydney. Walking around Circular Quay is a definite MUST for all visitors. It showcases what Sydney has to offer. After inspecting the Opera House, there is only a short walk to The Botanical Gardens which also houses the NSW Art Gallery.

200 years old spectacular. During the Vivid festival the Botanic Gardens turned 200 years old and was aglow with spectacular lights. This truly was a wonderful sight that I will carry always, the best lights overall!
Sculpture walk. Botanic gardens to Hyde park using the City of Sydney Culture walks App-fabulous & saw things we did know existed despite having walked through the areas before-highly recommended

Lovely walk around the Harbour.. If you are in Sydney, you must walk from Circular Quay to the Opera House and beyond to the Botanical Gardens and Lady Macquarie's chair. The scenery is simply stunning.

Lovely Walk around Harbour to Gardens. The entrance to the Botanical Gardens is on the other side of the Opera House. We paid $10 (Adult) for the train ride which is a good, quick way to see the highlights of the gardens if you have only limited time in Sydney.

WALK. Very easy walk with stunning views of the harbour,opera house and the gardens worth the walk.
Recommend it for all

One of the World's Great Walks!. I do this walk along Circular Quay, up past the Opera House and on to and through the Botanic Gardens, often en route to the equally wonderful Art Gallery of NSW, just across the road on the opposite side of the gardens every time I visit Sydney.Each place is worth time for detailed exploration. As a walk, it captures the essence of Sydney, including great views across the Harbour of The Harbour Bridge and equally across, approaching and behind the Opera House.This is also a walk where you can "see and be seen" in equal measure.Wear comfortable shoes and protect yourself from the sun. Even on cool days there is little protection from the sun and refection from the water adds to its intensity.Simply enjoy this glorious walk and allow at least an hour or two to take it easy, drink in the sights and to also enjoy the Botanic Gardens.A "must do" whenever you visit Sydney!

Leisurely walk. It started as a visit to the botanical gardens but we ended up walking to the opera house for a sight of the building and also the Sydney Harbour bridge. The walk was great as the weather was awesome that morning. The walk is leisurely with clear signs and plants all around. Very good for young children to run around without worries.
nice to see. just enjoy the walk and the surrounds. very easy. no steep grades nor difficult terrain. easy path but with great views all around.

Walk from The Opera House to Wooloomooloo Bay. A lovely walk that I have done both with others and alone many times over the years. I would highly recommend it for anyone coming to Sydney whether you visit frequently or you are a first time visitor. It doesn't take long to do and is one of those special Sydney things to do. If you have time try to do some of the other harbour and coastal walks - they are magnificent at anytime of year.
Must see. Begin in Sydney means to visit the opera House and the Botanic Garden. The environment around is awesome. Walking around, drinking, and enjoying the nice restaurants is unforgettable.

Superb walk. Considering that this is the most accessible place where you can get the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge in one shot it is not packed with people. It provides a great opportunity to take a couple of nice shots
Vivid Lights. I was here with My Fiance,sister and her Husband for the Vivid Lights show it was fantastic we will be back next year.
Fabulous walk. Don't forget to go for a walk around the gardes and not just by the water but also follow the paths and venture into the park too.

Walk around during Vivid 2016 - great views. During the Vivid 2016 light show around Sydney Harbour you can take the The Opera House to the Botanic Gardens Walk around to view the new areas added to Vivid this year. The walk allows great views of the harbour, the bridge and the Opera House. A great to the Botanical Gardens with some excellent photo opportunities.

The place to walk for ambience and photo opportunities.. This park and walk round the bay is one of the must see walks in Sydney, the park is just stunning and extremely large so give yourself plenty of time to explore, enjoy and photograph. The views of the Opera House in front of the bridge, especially at Sunset, are very popular.
THAT view!!. Nice nature and sea...! And that view to the Opera house! Just nice slow walk and look around! You will enjoy it!
Great vivid lights. Been here many times but looked great with the vivid lights worth seeing with the lights, don't forget to look back towards the city as well

Tour of Australia . Wow ... Beautiful gardens .. Soo much to see.. Very clean .. Lots of signs explaining all routes.. Exhibition concerning the history of the invasion of the British and the tragic impact for the aboriginal population ... Free entry.. Not to be missed ...

Australian Icon. This is an amazing piece of architecture and the gardens are stunning we were lucky enough to time our visit with the vivid lightshow. It was an amazing experience and at night just beautiful with the light show.

Panaromic view of the opera house from the botanic gardens. It's a beautiful & lovely stroll from the Sydney opera house to the botanic gardens on a cloudy/ sunny day. But don't come on a rainy day because floor can be slippery. Right at the end of the gardens pass the gates you will find the famous Macquarie chair. Definitely must spend half day here for photo taking & soak in the fresh air. Beautiful views of the Sydney opera house from the gardens as well. You can have a picnic whilst in the gardens & just enjoy the moment. In the night you can see the vivid lights on the Sydney opera house as well as the vivid displays in the gardens itself from 6pm to 11 pm. Entry is free.

Such a great way to take in the city!. it's a great walk and to really see the city on foot. Also would recommend just posting up at the macquire's chair and taking in the view of the opera house. The botanical garden is a cool place to visit too.

Walk Along Bay. Entrance fee is FREE. Good way to enter the Botanical Garden. Walk along the seawall, then pick a walkway to wander up the easy slope. You end up at the top of the hill after many miles of walkways. I enjoyed the Fern Garden. There are also historic trees. You look down towards Circular Quays and The Rock historical region. For me, very relaxing stroll. Most shrubs and trees labeled.

Great place to run. When visiting Sydney, we stayed at the Marriott Circular Quay, right near the gardens. It was a great jog from the hotel thru the gardens. Great for a morning or evening walk. Take the time for a morning stroll before you start your day, its worth it!
Must go place in Sydney. Beautiful place to visit both during day time and at nights under lighting, specially when events and fireworkds are happening

A Short Stroll or a Long March, Your Choice !. A walk for all levels & abilities and on a nice day, pretty hard to beat , just keep an eye open for the joggers ! If you continue on the waters edge path to Mrs Macquarie's Chair , you can view Garden Island & return through the Garden proper to view the amazing variety of plants, shrubs & trees. If you pack a picnic lunch you could spend a whole day easily, I know, I have in the past.

Lovely walk great views. Beautiful Gardens amazing variety of plants and trees. The pathways are smooth to walk and not steep so its a great walk for every one. Could spend hours wandering around. Our hotel had maps of the garden paths which are useful as its extensive snd you dont wsnt to get lost in the gardens. We walked around the gardens to Mrs. Macquaries Chair then to the Opera house. You get a great view of the bridge and opera house from across the harbour. Lots of joggers, walkers and bicycle riders take advantage of these pathways. Makes for a good bit of exercise.

Easy Walk. Extremely easy walk from the Opera House to the Gardens. We went in the early morning before the crowds and the tour buses arrived and it was an extremely enjoyable walk with the occasional runners. We went during Vivid Sydney, and in the evening, the place is packed with people, not sure how busy it gets any other time of the year.

Beautiful Botanical gardens. We could and have spent hours and hours walking around these beautiful gardens and there is still more to see than we have managed.There is so much space and things to see here, you need more than a day to get around fully.Every day there is something going on and in the holiday seasons, even more with open air shows, events and just groups of friends meeting up to have fun.Walking around the waters edge is lovely, but you don't get to see all the gardens have to offer. so head inland a bit and be surprised that you are in the middle of Sydney, but surrounded by amazing plants and flowers. Not forgetting the bats at dusk!

Really long walk!. This walk is amazing and you'll see most of the great sights of Sydney. All the things you seein a guidebook as the starting place of Sydney are along this walk. Architecture, history, flowers, Harbour -this has it all. I was huffing and puffing by the end of the walk (where, oh where, was my water bottle?), but I'm glad I walked it. I really saw how Sydney got started and enjoyed nature whilst in a huge city.

stunning!. This is a walk you must take in order to feel this vibrant city and this magnificent landmark. You would be surprised to see the variety of plants and trees they have at this Botanical Gardens. And you will stop and take pictures with the Sydney Opera House at the background.We took this walk on 2 days during our 3 day stay in Sydney.

Night walk to view Vivid.. Not to be missed the night walk from the Opera House through the Botanical Gardens due to the introduction of Vivid which goes to the middle of June. This is the 200th Anniversary of the commencement of the Gardens on this wonderful site. The beautiful harbour is highlighted by this walk. Stop and sit on one of the seats to enjoy the surroundings. This is a great walk but even better during Vivid which transforms the trees and surrounds into a magical wonderland. Not to be missed by locals and visitors to Sydney at this time of the year.
not sure where the garden bit was. walking around we saw lots of grass but not a lot of gardens?? maybe we missed them? there is the governors house which is open at certain hours for a fee

Breathtaking views of Opera House and Botanical Gardens.. I took my two grandchildren for a day trip to Circular Quay on a gorgeous sunny day in April 2016. As usual the view as you walk towards the Opera House takes your breath away, with the stunning Harbour Bridge and sparkling harbour to the left and then you cast your eyes on the sails of the Opera House. My grandchildren loved to run up and down the steps of the opera house, counting the number of steps and checking out all the little nooks and crannies and exciting places to crawl and climb. We then explored the inside of the opera house which is very interesting.Then on to the Botanic Gardens where the fig trees were the favourite for them. They loved climbing around and into the big fig trees. Sliding and rolling down the slopes. Having a picnic on the grass and looking at the big boats going by. This was the best day out.

Leisurely scenic walk. From the Opera House you can walk into the Botanic Gardens which this year celebrate their 200 years. There are some stunning views from the gardens including looking back over the harbour bridge and Opera House

One of the best public parks I have ever seen.. Absolutely beautiful and well looked after, with plenty of space to find your own area for a picnic. Plenty of amenities too, and a very diverse style of park throughout each section.
Good Views!!. This is one of my favourite walks within Sydney. You get wonderful views of the harbour and the harbour bridge as well as the wonderful gardens at the Botanic Gardens

the BEST view of the Opera house and bridge. This is how I show my over seas friends my town. After a fabulous walk through the Botanic gardens we will walk down to the Opera House take some great selfies with BOTH great icons in the back ground then its off to the shops or a ferry ride to Manly for Fish and chips by the sea

Magical place. This is one of favourite places in Sydney.Love to go for a walk there at any time of the year.Botanic garden have plenty of fantastic plants, just stop and read the information usually provided in front of the specimen.And don't omit the huge fig tree.The weekend I was there were not too many people which was quite surprising.The view of the Opera House from the botanic gardens side is breathtaking as well as the whole bay...This is a must see place for all visitors.Take time to walk up to the Opera House and around it.
The Walk. The Gardens were spectacular, very quiet in the morning, enjoyable, very easy walk down to Circular Quay
A Relaxing Walk Made Better by a Sunny Day. After a cup of coffee at the Opera House we took a walk back to the CBD through the Botanical Gardens. A short walk well worth taking.

Nice walk.. Great to walk all around the headland of the Opera House past bars and restaurants. Hopefully you can catch a sight of the resident seal. Follow this with a stroll through the gardens makes for a great day with a cup of coffee by the lake.

Nice walk with views, birds & the garden. Nice walk with views, birds & the garden. We saw a ton of cockatoo that let us get very close for some great pics along with some other beautiful native birds. See a different view of the opera house & bridge. Worth the walk and very easy/leisurely.

Either way this walk is worth it. From Circular Quay to the Opera House a look round and enjoy the classic iconic views then stroll on into the Botanic Gardens and relax in the green surroundings take tea in the cafe and breathe. Or start the outer way round and take a road train ride around the gardens then walk to the Opera House and feel the excitement and buzz. The choice is yours.
Traumhafter walk. Enjoy your trip by the walk beside the ocean and in the middle of amazing nature feelings! Really, there aren't words to describe the view and features you'll have!
Gorgeous Park. Well laid out garden. Well maintained and very clean. Great place to relax. Fantastic for walking exercise.
Stunning views. Surprised by how big the botanic garden is! It's an easy and relaxing walk to the Opera House and is definitely worth a visit.

A walk through the Botanical garden. we walked through the Royal Botanical Garden, and to the end, its the other side of the Opera house across the water, very nice view to take some pictures. then walking all the way to the front of the opera house, it was a very nice walk in the morning.

Can't be missed. A great walk that will amaze you. Seeing the Opera house from up close and from the distance as you walk the garden will wow you for sure. As you look the other way the city skyline is almost as impressive.

A very relaxing walk. A much better way to get back from the Harbour/Opera House than walking along the busy streets. Beautifully laid out gardens with lots of birdlife flitting amongst the trees. I seem to remember the gates do close at some point during the evening so just keep an eye on the time. There is a land train that goes through part of the gardens if your feet are getting tired!

Visiting Sydney you must visit these. If you are visiting Sydney for the 1st time or not you have got to visit these landmarks. The walk around the Opera house and through to the Botanic Gardens is easy for any age it is flat and sealed. The Botanic Gardens are 200 years old this year so go and visit and enjoy your stroll around them.

nice and easy walk . We walked from St James train station, along the way you will pass through the Hyde Park, St Mary Cathedral, Art Gallery of NSW, Royal Botanic Gardens and Opera House.There are many gardens and peoples picnicking on the grass ground. was a good view of the harbour bridge and opera house from there.

Scenic walk. On hot summers day this is a beautiful walk, around the harbour foreshore. The Opera House looks great & the Botanic Gardens are peaceful. You can sit on the grass and just soak up the experience.
Best Views of Sydney. Make your way to Mrs Macquaries chair and take in the beautiful scenery that Sydney has to offer. Watch out for all the runners though!

Most relaxing & beautiful spots to visit when in Sydney.. I am very blessed to be living in this beautiful harbour city. The Sydney Opera house, the harbour bridge & the Botanical gardens are all in my backyard. I catch public transport at least once a month & it's about an hour's bus trip to Circular Quay. From here I would walk to the Opera House (about 5 mins easy walk) & then continue on to the Botanical garden finishing off at Lady Macquarie's chair. On the walk you will have lots of places to take spectacular shots of the harbour, Opera house & of course the harbour bridge. Do not miss this walk.

Whoever designed this walk was brilliant!. To walk from the Opera House to the gardens was a wonderful experience. So many sights to see and sounds to hear, all while strolling along a beautiful setting!
Great gardens. Spent the morning wandering around these beautiful gardens. Started at the top of the hill and ended on the foreshore. Easy access for disabled husband.

Fun, Active and Pretty Setting. Lovely to walk along the waterside. The gardens are pretty and relaxing and, if you're lucky, some colorful parrots might fly by. On the other side of the Opera House, it's much busier with lots of shops and restaurants. From quiet and scenic to the city hustle-bustle, the entire walk along the water is delightful!

Even in the rain this is very lovely. It rained and we found shelter inside on a bench for awhile. When it let up we wandered around taking more pictures than we ever needed. We wanted to go to the garden but the rain was still off and on so we just walked a while at the waters edge. We found a nice bench under a big tree looking out to the water and watched walkers, joggers, and families walking past. I was lucky enough to get some shots of wild Lorikeets in the trees right above us! It was a really lovely day.
What's not to like? . A pleasant walk with no complaints from the young ones. Love Sydney and you can't go wrong doing this leisurely stroll

a very nice walk. It is a 20 minute walk from the Sydney Opera House to the Botanic gardens that lets you see the opera house from a different perspective. Also, the botanic gardens have some plants and threes that i recommend to see while in Australia.Highly recommended.

Beautiful setting. Loved that the Harbour Bridge, Circular Quay, the Opera House, and the Botanic Gardens were located in such a compact area, in an incomparable setting.We were just off the plane and jet-lagged - walking through the gardens and this central area was an ideal way to be reinvigorated, to get a general orientation to Sydney - and to take in the beautiful setting for the first time.

botanic gardens and syd harbour. backs on to the intercontinental hotel great place to chill out and walk or exercise its a great spectacle plenty to see and do and lots of eating places for all budgets
Very nice walk . I was blessed to be there on a 70 degree kind of day. There are a lot of walkers and joggers. The view is just great.
Great Australian land mark. beautiful place to visit, the garden is huge and full of little places to hide away and relax. try the opera bar for a beer with a view

Really enjoyable nature walk with cosmopolitan ending. We walked through botanical gardens with beautiful scenery and delightful flowers smells. After a beautiful lunch at the garden restaurant and another 30 min walk we arrived at Sydney opera house with wonderful views over the harbor and bridge. The promenade has multiple shops, bars and restaurants right on the harbor and it is such a great way to finish 2 h plus walk
Must Explore!. In general, Botanic Gardens do not often call to me. This Botanic Garden is the exception. The birds alone are worth a visit. Wild cockatoo everywhere and breathtaking trees.
Botanical Gardens. The views are beautiful.......could sit and watch the harbor for hours!! The blooms are amazing and the whole park is just tranquil...
Lovely gardens. The gardens are beside the opera house and also have some glass houses you can go into. A small restaurant in the middle was a pleasant place for a sit and rest.
What a view. Saw a opera and a drink at the opera bar before the opera. Next day did a behind the scenes tour of the opera house which was great and kept us dry as it was raining.

A quiet area behind Circular Quay often used by joggers.. Great quieter place to walk connect to B Gardens or Opera house. On a hill so be prepared when you walk up from Opera House. Careful at night as the park is closed and it can be isolating at times.

Lovely walk. The walk from the Opera house through the Botanic Gardens is a very lovely, relaxing walk. There are a lot of unusual plants along the way to view, and there are some interesting views of the Sydney sites from the gardens. And it's free!

Stunning views from Mrs Macquarie's Chair to The Opera House. While walking from Mrs Macquarie's Chair back to The Opera House, walked through the Botanical Gardens, stunning views, the Bridge and Opera House were "framed" by the trees and surrounds

A great walk!. The walking paths in Sydney are great, as long as you can avoid the many, many runners! (They'll avoid you, but they are absolutely everywhere.) The walk is along the botanical garden and is quite beautiful.

Lovely morning stroll through Botanical Gardens. Following our backstage Opera House Tour, my husband and I walked through the Botanical Gardens. We enjoyed the breeze from the harbour as we strolled though the gardens. Pretty flowers, birds, relaxing. Lovely morning.
botanic Gardens and Opera House. so many different plants/trees at the Botanic Gardens that you don't see in the states. very clean. Great walk to the Opera House so beautiful.
One of the best detours in Sydney. This is always a busy area as tourists flock and take this route everyday. Just make sure to wear your comfy shoes to totally enjoy what this place has to offer.

Great walk in and among the beauty of nature. Colorful loud squeaking birds, plants and fauna of any/all types that you can see and photograph, gift shops, guidebooks you can buy, ponds that you can see the fish in, places to rest and relax and sit on a bench and read or look at your photos, have a nap amongst the trees.Awesome for a few hours.
Stunning walk. Beautiful vistas. The walk along the Sydney waterfront near the Opera House is great. How can one complain it's free.

Easy walk along the bay. This is a great walk for anyone and easy on those with strollers, etc.Train stop is Circular Quay and the walk from the station to the Opera House is about 5 minutes. The walk to the Gardens is right on the Harbor so the views are always changing. Easy access to the Botanical Gardens.

Convenient to each other. I suggest you include the Botanic Gardens on the same day or time as your visit to the Opera House, because as you exit the main entrance of the Opera House, you can descend the stairs and head to the left and the gates of the Botanic Gardens. You can do the gardens from another street, but this is so easy and convenient. No fee to enter and also a small train to take you around if needed, but it is tiny, more for kids.

Opera House and Botanical Gardens, Sydney. The tour of the Sydney Opera House was very interesting. Learning about the history including the Architects and construction details etc were most interesting. This was mostly an inside tour but we did get outside to see how the outside of the O H functions as well, i.e. drainage off the roofs, what the covering materials are etc. We were into some of the theaters and were overwhelmed with the size and beauty.It's interesting to hear how the facility is used for very diverse concerts and events, including some on the outside areas. There were problems with the audio system being used, however, it was noted that it is being upgraded. That was a distraction.if you take a tour, there may be discounts for current shows and events.During the tour we learned about The Opera On the Harbour and took advantage of rush seats. This out door opera was a highlight of our trip. The back drop was the setting sun behind the Sydney Bridge and Opera House. Beautiful!

Leisurely walking sight seeing. We stopped at one of the cafes along the Opera Quay for coffee and cake overlooking the most beautiful harbour to start the morning. Then took a leisurely stroll along the shopping strip towards the Opera House - an amazing building. We walked past and into the Royal Botanic Gardens. Right next to this entry gate is a Choochoo train ride available at reasonable rates. A good way to see a fair bit of the gardens with a guide and in a short time. It is hop on hop off when you want so we hopped off to do a bit more walking on this beautiful day. Then hopped back on when we were ready. Such a beautiful place to spend some time.

A great short walk to spend time with that special person.. We had spent a special time the night before at the Opera House but the daylight exposes a different magnitude of this spectacular creation. You really don't realize the immensity of this structure until you area close up.Leaving this complex we headed along the harbor continuing to the left. This walk took us along the bordered coast at the foot of the Gardens. The area is so beautiful seeing nature and the gentle breaks of the waves on the shore.We had to stop and take a break laying on the well manicured lawns below the gardens. Laying down with my wife next to me brought a feeling of contentment and togetherness to both of us.A special time to remember of our time in Sydney.!
Amazing. We start our walk from the Botanic Gardens and then arriving to the Opera House. This is a must-do: you will see so much nature in a city!! The view is also amazing.

My favourite - The Botanic Gardens. Spent many hours strolling around the gardens. Breathtaking at every turn. When people ask what was the favourite part of my visit I have to say, above all else, the amazing tree trunks! Sounds crazy, but they fascinated me. Cafe busy and not appealing, but the restaurant upstairs was peaceful, excellent service and good food.

Flat, easy walk but little shade. Easy walk of around a mile or so. Flat paving. The path runs along the edge of the bay and there is little or no shade until you can hide under some trees in the RBG. Take water, wear a hat and cover your arms if sun is hot. It was when we were there. Path continues on to Lady Macquarie's Chair, a viewpoint for great photos.

Even walking is surprising how far you can cover. A very nice, free activity and very relaxing. But, don't rush. This is a very large area. Whether you have all day or just a short time, you can cover a small area or a large area. It certainly does Sydney proud to visitors and locals alike.
Beautiful walk for anyone. Stunning scenery of Sydney Harbour, plus the beauty of the Royal Botanic Gardens, what more could you ask for. Wheelchair friendly, strollers, let the kids run free!

A truly perfect walk. Nothing more beautiful than the walk from the Opera House to the gardens. Easy and well tended, the views are magnificent. This December, we stumbled upon a catamaran race that was amazing. This is a Sydney MUST do, including carrying on to the art gallery of New South Wales.

Pleasant walk, then outstanding sites. Except for the honey-Toni like atmosphere of the east wharf at Circular Quay, the walk for the Gardens to the Opera House is quite pleasant. Then your reward is the incredible structure up close and personal.

Great...Watch for the Mice. We took this walk today...excellent. We chose to take the cutoff to the Botanical Garden Shop (nice shop, cafe and restrooms!) then swing back to the Memorial Gate and across midtown on Brent to George north to The Rocks, an easy walk. This is about half way to "The Mrs. Chair" point. Along the harbor I saw and photographed some very unusual fish (stop, look over the wall into the water...remember the old Athabaskan Grandmother's advice in Michener's Alaska: "when hunting the giant woolly mammoth, remember the mice"). Likewise near the Garden Shop Pond there were dozens of Magpie, Ibis and Sulphur Crested Cockatoos!! Great pics!!! Enjoy.

Great pix!. There is no cost to go explore the opera house from the outside to the botanic gardens. You can touch the tiles of the opera house and get fantastic pix of it as well as the bridge. Just a short walk to the gardens and the train. Better to go when it isn't as crowded, but plenty of places to get great pix.

Great walks.. Walking through the Botanic Gardens to the Opera House gives you some great views of the bay. Its also not too crowded so you can get some great pictures without a lot of people milling about.
Must do Bucket List!. If you're visiting Sydney , you'd better go here. The souvenirs were nice, the view from atop was good, and the pictures were priceless!
Beautiful Walk. We walked all around the opera house and from there to the Botanic Gardens. Beautiful sights in almost every direction. Wonderful way to spend a gorgeous sunny day.

Strolling along this walk is refreshing, jogging at lunch time is great for the soul. Going along this walk past the water is peaceful and soothing. When you get to Lady Macquarie's chair, most days you get to see someone having their wedding photos taken against this wonderful backdrop. some of the trees are so old and the branches so large they have them propped up so not to break off. The trees and plants have a name plate if you are interested and the grass is so soft to walk on. When I worked I (and lots of others) jogged this route everyday. In the middle of the walk are stairs we ran up and down to strengthen our legs. You will find bubblers and benches for when you are tired or thirsty. Just the best place to relax or get fit.

Get your walking shoes on!. My 15 year old daughter and I spent a few days in Sydney. We regularly got off the train at Martin Place and walked to the Domain through the beautiful old hospital. We then walked down to the Opera House via the fantastic Botanical Gardens. Really easy walk and great to exercise so you can eat more! I think the best way to the Opera House, Rocks, Circular Quay is via the Gardens, just gorgeous!

Nature at it's best. Walked 10 minutes from Circular Quay up to Elizabeth Street, then along to the entrance. Cockatoos very friendly, interesting architecture and sculptures. Lovely walk round to Sydney Opera House

Loved every minute of this walk. A stunning place...we walked through the botanical gardens first, then headed along the water to the Opera House..there was so much natural beauty around us---we were in awe. Everyone on the walk looked fit and healthy---it seems to attract running clubs and fast walkers, but is suitable for anyone.

Great walk on s sunny day. Like many other TA Reviewers we walked from Circular Quay, along the quayside, past the Opera House and continued on along the shorline into the Botanical Gardens.Stop when you like, plenty of seats and shaded grass and brilliany sceneary. A must do for anybody. Just take your time and enjoy.

Great way to experience Sydney. The Botanic Gardens are almost as old as Sydney itself. Great place for a picnic. Never seems too crowded and lovely views of Sydney Harbour as you walk from the Opera House. Highly recommended for visitors.

A short walk nothing spectacular but gets you to the park. Not sure why this needs a review, it is a short walk to the park and the park from this end is more like a broad grassed garden rather than a focused intense garden. However that quickly changes and it is worth walking from this entrance into the park

The Best. On a sunny day it seems like a dream. Water dappling, fishing, excursions in motor and sail boats, eating your fish and chips on the steps of the Opera House, catching the ferry to Manly, stopping off at Taronga Park Zoo, gawping a the Rich Peoples' houses from the ferry but feeling very happy to be picnicing in the Botanical Gardens - free as air.
Walked . Walked from circular quay round to the opera house down the stairs and through the Royal botanical gardens. What a beautiful place and blessed with such a beautiful day too

For lovers of old Sydney this walk is superb.. Take your friends along and also your visitors to Sydney. Enjoy the essential Sydney and its historical past. Let the kids wander and be amazed, tell them how it was during the colonial days and why Mrs Macquarie's chair is called so! Discover the wonderful walks through the gardens and give yourself some time at the NSW Arg gallery.
Tour the Opera House. Do not miss the tour of the opera house. He history is very interesting and the inside of the opera house is surprising.

Easy stroll with the best view in the world. Free and easy, the stroll around Farm Cove is a delight. As you pass in front of Gothic Revival Government House, you can see why it was put there in the mid 19th century, as the Governor could see right up the harbour and be quickly alerted to the arrival of any ships - friendly or otherwise. The Botanic Gardens are interesting and relaxing - even more so on an overcast day where the greenery soothes the eyes.
SYDNEY HARBOUR WALK. A leisurely walk from the Opera House to Lady Macquarie's Chair in the Botanical Gardens is well worth it, a beautiful stroll, magnificent views, especially on a sunny day.
plants - interesting and beautiful. most of the flowers were gone - April is their Fall, but what was there was outstanding. Very friendly and a must see especially if you like plants.

Lovely place. Beautiful place to go for a walk and to conect with the nature.Also awesome landscape and great for taking poctures of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge For the little ones tehre is also a little train so you can ride around the garden (its a hop on hop off)

Beautiful walk in the park. From our hotel we walked through the gardens to the opera house. Some very interesting trees that you wouldn't usually see.. It's well signed for cafe or opera house etc so you shouldn't get lost. We photographed the park map at the entrance which helped.

Unique in opera design, The Sydney Opera House.. The Sydney Opera House is a unique structure that will surprise you. Managed by the Sydney Opera House Trust, it was built by the gambling habits of NSW consumers.Today you can sit and watch the water craft move past whilst enjoying a snack or a meal at one of the venues.The back stage tour are a must and having worked at the Opera House its internal workings will quench your needs.And then there are the shows through the day and evening. This icon a must visit in Sydney.

Garden lovers will enjoy the variety of Australian species for free.. A very pleasent walk, or stroll on a good Summer day, if not too hot or Spring. Winter if not raining or Autumn is also a good day to go for a visit you will not forget.

Great views. Lovely walk that takes you to the botanic garden. It is nicer if you start at Macquarie chair and walk to the opera house. The morning light is the best to enjoy the spectacular skyline of the city.

A beautiful part of the city. Starting from circular quay we worked past the opera house and through the botanical gardens. A beautiful park with great views of the harbour. You can walk all the way to Mrs Maquaries Chair.

most beautiful and romantic place to visit in sydney. The botanic garden is a world on its own, walking through the garden make you feel happy, romantic, layback, you can enjoy peace and the beauty of all varieties of plants and trees. you can enjoy picnic sitting on the lawn for free enjoying the seaview just few meters from the garden and feel safe. I would advice any visitor coming to sydney to visit this amazing place and don't forget to have a ride on the red train in the garden.
Nice walk. Had an enjoyable walk from the opera house through the botanical gardens. Pathways are wide. Very relaxing

Perfect even for Family with Young kids!. We visited the place with 3 young kids. The paths were kids friendly and the kids enjoyed running around towards the State House. Was definitely a great time spend there :)

great activity. we did the 9am opera house tour very informative and enjoyable you can see the history and drama involved in the construction of it .we then wandered through the botanical gardens great free activity
Walk. A nice walk at your own pace form The Opera House to The Botanic Gardens I left the crowds at the Opera House and spent time relaxing in the Gardens.

Lovely Running Route. Great route for running. Suggest to start from the south entrance (Domain) near Hyde Park and run along the bay overlooking Woolloomooloo towards the best vantage point of the Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge at Mrs Macquarie's Chair. Stop there for a breather and some great photographic opportunities then continue on the path along side Sydney Harbour whilst enjoying the beautiful landscaping of the Botanic Gardens. End your run/ walk at the Opera House with couple schooners of well deserved beers, or coffee at The Rocks.
always a treat to see. enjoy the stroll have a picnic or just enjoy the scenery well worth it a day our for the family just go and enjoy

Awesome up close and personal. Spent a lovely afternoon in the shadow of the Opera House. The venues are numerous, food great and atmosphere great. Was great to be so up close and personal with such an iconic part of the Australian landscape.

A day in Sydney for free. Friends from the USA were in Sydney for one day at the end of February between cruises. I met them at the Dawes Point Wharf beside Sydney Harbour Bridge. We walked around Circular Quay to the Opera House and then wandered through the beautiful Botanic Gardens. After a bite to eat in the shade, we headed for the Art Gallery and wandered through the galleries. Next, we made a short walk to St Mary's Cathedral, which has excellent proportions and a beautiful stained glass rose window, and then crossed the road to Hyde Park to admire the Archibald Fountain. Its strong Art Deco sculptures are a delight. Moving along to the other section of Hyde Park is the minimalist Art Deco War Memorial with a poignant sculpture of a fallen soldier inside and brilliant high relief sculptures outside.We then headed to the central shopping and business district for lunch. Later, we popped into St Andrews Cathedral, Sydney Town Hall and then took time to explore the architectural delights of the well maintained Queen Victoria Building with its beautiful staircases, patterned marble floors and leadlight glass. After a downhill walk, we arrived at Darling Harbour. We observed the activities of visitors along the waterfront and on the water, where ferries and boats of all description criss-cross at regular intervals. It was happy hour, so we managed to find shady seats to enjoy a few drinks while watching the action.We continued on to Barangaroo, Sydney's newest waterfront park and then returned to Dawes Point Wharf.The only cost was for food and drink. It was an extremely hot day, so a hat, sun block and comfortable clothing were essential. Much of our touring avoided the worst of the sun. This exploration of Sydney took 7 hours and proves that you can 'do' Sydney cheaply. I thoroughly enjoyed being a guide and a visitor in my home town.

Beautiful. Start off at the with coffee & nibbles at the Poolside Café, 1 Mrs Macquaries Chair, then wander through the gardens, past the Opera House ending up at The Rocks Markets...what better way to spend a Sunday morning!

Le Grand oll Opera!. I was AMAZED at this iconic building! Did not visit the inside but just looking at it from the outside was simply stunning! It's location does take ones breath away. All the pictures I've seen of the Opera before I actually visited never did Le Opera any justice! Take a stroll along the water, especially during sunset for amazing picture taking!

Beyond photogenic (which the Opera House is in spades), the whole setting excels.. An amazing facility within, without and set in an outstanding environment. We did the tour and attended a performance same evening. Had to delete many pictures later since I couldn't help but take it from all angles.

The eternal water, the historic past and a modern marvel are all blended together. Be prepared to slow down and relax. Turn your toys off and take your eyes up, around and onto the spectacular natural and human made vistas. Don't talk, or if you do, make sure it's brief and meaningful. This is one of the wonders of the world.
Go green, walk to botanical garden!. Take the time, walk along the waterside. Take a rest at mrs. Macquaries "chair" and watch the harbour life.

Fantastic area to stroll and enjoy. Sydney has many marvellous places to go to and enjoy the harbour but this is certainly one of the best, maybe equal (but different) to the Bondi beach to Tamarama walk. The environment with the beautiful atmosphere and views is a really world benchmark place to go.

A free walk past a icon. You can spend all day walking around the opera house which is alongside the harbour , so plenty to look at , View the ocean liners coming into Sydney as the botanic gardens are only ten minutes walk away . Worth a look even for non gardeners , full of tropical type plants and trees . All free , so you can treat yourself to a good meal at the many restaurants near the opera house

Easy and very pleasant walk. We did this walk on scooters on a busy Sunday Afternoon. It was so much fun. Such an easy walk, fir all ages, so much history. So many trees to see and look at. The view from the Opera house is spectacular also!! Highly recommend this walk!!

A lovely garden walk. In warm weather, after you have crawled over and around The Opera House, continue on to The Botanic Gardens. Not only is this a scenic walk, but also an educational one if you are interested in trees and plants, as most of them are labelled. The Gardens were established soon after the first white settlement in 1788. Unlike many parks in Europe, you ARE encouraged to walk on the grass!!

Walked this waterfront path, after a gardens wedding.. Gardens a great place for a wedding with the Opera House and Bridge in the background. Leisurely stroll along the foreshore to the Opera House and a lunchtime cruise for the reception. Magic:)

Excellent Venue. Saw 1st concert there 2 days ago (Josh Groban). Brilliant venue, with the acoustics as good as I have ever heard anywhere. (I have seen shows throughout Aust, and England. I would rate this equal to the Vic Arts Centre in quality...
Great walk. Beautiful gardens - definitely worth a visit! I would recommend bringing a picnic and making an afternoon of it.

A lovely gentle walk. The walk can be as long or as shot as you want, as the Botanical Gardens are right next to the Opera House, but for a stroll from Circular Quay via The Opera House and then into the Botancal Gardens its hard to beat. The views are stunning, the Botanical Gardens are lovely and with the bay all along the walk within easy reach, its the perfect Sunday afternoon walk.
Scenery. The botanical gardens were amazing, and the walk through to the opera House is relaxing. You can wear a camera out here.
Gorgeous walk with spectacular scenery and views. Love this walk. The Gardens are stunning and the views from Lady Macquaries Chair are magnificent. Take a picnic and sit and look at the view
Great! . It is really nice walking around here. I like it at lunch time on a sunny day. That way you don't get wet! Not too far either if you are not a super athlete

Gorgeous walk. Really enjoyed our walk it was great to see the iconic opera house. The botanical gardens are really big. Hidden away is a cafe take your own drinks though and sit by the pond filled with very tame fish.

A great afternoon walk!. Although I've seen prettier gardens in the world, the walk along the harbour from the Opera House through the Botanic Gardens is wonderful. You will be amazed how many times you will stop for photographs. Also, the wild cockatoos in the park are fun and very picturesque.

Picturesque Sydney Opera House and scenic walkway. After a ferry ride on the Sydney Harbour it was time to take a stroll and what better way to do it than to take a walk along the foreshores starting from Circular quay towards the Opera house leading to the Royal Botanical gardens and beyond. The Opera House a beautiful architectural masterpiece and the Sydney Harbour Bridge in the background in close proximity was breathtaking indeed. The Princess Cruise Liner berthed alongside the Rocks provided an added attraction to the many visitors who had flocked on a beautiful Sunday afternoon. There were many foreign tourists as well as locals mingling with each other lapping up the beautiful sights. There are several entry points to the Opera House but everyone's favourite seems to be the long flights up to the top where many gather around to take photos from different angles with the city skyline on one side and the Sydney Harbour on the other. It is also a favourite spot for many wedding photos. The well paved walkway is normally very busy and you have to make way for other road users as well. In summer it can get very hot but there's always a cool breeze blowing across the harbour to make you feel quite comfortable and refreshed. Also there are trees planted right along providing plenty of shade and there are benches to sit and relax. You can also take a walk along the Royal botanical gardens if you turn right or you can continue your walk alongside the harbour. If you are a keen gardner a visit to the Royal Botanical gardens is a must where you will not only see Australian natives but also other rare species of plants. Stay tuned to the sounds of the Kookaburra a rare bird found only in this part of the world. It will stay proudly perched on the branch calling it's mates to join while you take photos before it will suddenly fly away reminding you it is no ordinary bird. The walk will take you past Lady Macquarie's Chair where you get a panoramic view of the Sydney Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge overlooking the Harbour to remind you how much Sydney has changed from it's humble beginnings in such a short period of time into one of the most beautiful cities in the world.

Take your time and enjoy. Enjoyable leisurely walk, we didn't have a lot of time, so walked round to Mrs MacQuiries Chair and then down to the cafe and shop. Huge area with lots of sculptures and plants (obviously). Not a lot of flowers, it is autumn but lovely all the same. Also went past an area full of wild cuckatoos which was an awesome sight. Lots of other birds around as well.

Geat walk with fantastic views. This can be a very leisurely walk even for Seniors. The views are extremely interesting with the boats and trees etc. The Botanic garden is very well laid out and to any 'gardener' full of interest.
The botanical gardens were beautiful. and a reasonable walk up a hill from the Opera House. And there is a cute coffee shop with outdoor tables at the Garden to watch all the tourists go by.
It's just the best part in town. I doubt that someone won't like this perfect place. 10 out of 10 people will love this place. Make sure you have at least a whole afternoon there.

Great walk and view of the city. Sydney is a great city to walk around and enjoy. The walk from the Botanic Gardens along the Quay to the Opera House will make your trip to Sydney most memorable. The views of the harbour, opera house, and quay are worth seeing. With the gardens and water beside you, it is so peaceful even when the walk is very crowded with others enjoying the views.
Simply Stunning. Both locations are stunning and well worth a visit. You won't be disappointed.Take plenty of photos.
Excellent paths for runners. Hyde park, botanical gardens and the Opera House makes a great loop that was about 4 miles long from my hotel and included minimal city sidewalks.

Walk to Mrs Macquarie's chair. A truly memorable and leisurely walk through the botanical gardens to Mrs Macquarie's chair takes you through the wonderful diversity of plants and trees in the gardens while providing vistas over the beautiful harbour, the Opera House and the Harbour bridge and there's a neat cafe in the centre of the gardens to sit and enjoy a drink and a snack.

Waterfront Walk. After taking in the beauty of the Opera House you can walk down the stairs and begin your journey to the Botanic Gardens. The entrance to the park is almost at the foot of the stars. Admittance is free. There is a walkway all the way around the fringe of the park great for sightseeing, strolling or jogging.

A beautiful walk. The walk from the Opera House to the Botanical Gardens is well worth it.
Take the train, it takes you round the gardens and you can hop on hop off at a couple of stops.
Take your time and enjoy

Pure and genuine pleasure. It was the last part of our Sydney Cove walk and it was great final to it! The place is not only great for its flora but is a bit historical, as Royal Botanic Gardens were opened in 1816 (probably one of the oldest 'museum piece' in Australia). You can also see "Sydney City" as the background and the tops of Harbour Bridge and Opera House also jut out over the green horizon made of trees and flowers. If the place is visited on the hot day when the sky is blue (just as it happened to us) it is just perfect quintessence of Sydney.

Stunning Stroll For All. Amazing stroll along a wonderful paved walkway makes this activity suitable for all! The views are stunning and there are many beautiful benches to rest on along the way. Only caution is to take your time and "share the road please" with others. This is a popular and busy route - Could be seen as a baby carriage / stroller freeway on weekends!

The Birds Make It Special. The gardens themselves are reasonably nice but nothing special but the beautiful birds really add value to the whole experience so make sure you go on a sunny day and take a camera and some bird food or something.

The Walk from Barangaroo to the NSW Library. The walk for Barangaroo to the NSW LIbrary took about 1 hour at a slow pace. We were surprised by how beautiful Barangaroo is and loved the walk up to Upper Fort Street, under the Bridge, along the Cahill Express to the rear of the Con where there are old building remnants which have been placed in a semi circle and look like Sydney's homage to Stone Henge. This was a great walk on a beautiful Sydney day.
Nice place to walk and enjoy the weather. I do enjoy this place; if you are around the sydney opera house, this is a must place to visit. hangout, enjoy the weather and watch people.

Fabulous. These grounds are a wonderful oasis in a busy city. Spectacular trees abound, as do views out into and across the harbor to the west, north, and east. You can get away from the water if you choose, or you can walk the shoreline until you are across from naval ships and out of sight of the Opera House. Sit on the grass or on benches, walk near the water or elevated in some areas, but you will feel completely separate from the streets and traffic. More cities should use their waterfronts like this.

Breathtaking!. The opera house is an architectural marvel fashioned after sections of an orange. It's views from afar are quite different from the view up close so do both! The performance hall is exquisite. There is a fascinating gift shop too for interesting souvenirs. The walk along Macquarie Street to the Botanic Gardens is quite pretty with many history buildings.
Fine spaseretur. Nice green area!just go before 5:45pm in April, because they close. You really get a very nice shoot of the opera from here.
A scenic and fun walk. This is an easy walk that really lets you enjoy the views of Sydney. One of the best free things you can do .

Not a big deal. *Hard to get to, no public transport
*Nothing to do, not much to see, very boring and badly managed too, rubbish all over

Postcard perfect. This place is buzzing with activity. So many people, tourists and locals. We saw so many brides having their wedding pics taken in this vicinity. We took many pictures here and stopped so often to marvel at the views. We sought refuge in the gardens from the hundreds of people milling about to take in the whole scenery. It's a must do.
NIce to start our first day in Sydney. We started our way from the cathedral and passing along this direction. The place not crowded during our visit.

Iconic and lush. Combined with a guided tour of the Sydney Opera House, this walk is a pleasant way to spend a couple of hours, surrounded by eye-catching garden beds, sparkling harbour views and pleasantly positioned greenery walks. Take a picnic lunch in a basket and you have an excellent way to spend half a day in this iconic Harbour City!

Sooo stunning!!!!. After visiting the Harbour and the Opera House, one organically walks into the Royal Botanic Gardens. What a lovely walk! I would suggest spending time walking the gardens, the further you walk, the more it surprises you with its sights and when you're almost at the end of the Gardens, the views back to the Opera House are equally stunning. A perfect spot to take a nice picture without other people standing between you and the Opera House. There are water fountains, public and clean restrooms and a lot of natural shade. If you're lucky, like me, you'll see more than one wedding. Purely magical!
Make sure you have fresh batteries and memory cards on your camera!. And allocate more time than you think you need for a short walk like this as you will make a lot of photo stops!

A great easy walk. I good easy walk from Circular Quay along ashphalted foreshore paths past exotic tropical vegetation, looking out at the fort and the harbour as you go. Meander in the Botanical Gardens which is 200 years old this year. Finish at Lady MacQauarie's Seat or wander up to the NSW Art Gallery.
Beautiful place. An amazing walk, the gardens are so beautiful and an pleasant experience to walk through. Just make sure you go in pleasant weather as there is no under cover spots as to be expected
A short but pleasant walk. This is a great way to see Circular Quay and the surrounding area. Easy access to Opera House, Botanical Gardens and Mrs MacQuaries Chair

Turandot - Opera on the Harbour...A dream!. We were lucky to have a beautiful warm night and I am trying to find the right words for this experience. It was truly amazing and superb.The setting, the quality of the performane...just brilliant.
Autumn strolling. This is a flat stroll along the waterfront with plenty of seating when you're weary or just want to absorb the activity on the harbour.

A beautiful walk . I would recommend this nice walk to everybody as is reasonably easy and not very long. The gardens are spectacular, so well conserved and kept. And you can't beat the views of the opera house, the bridge and some part of the city from there. Really lovely.
Great Walk. Walked from Circular Quay to the steps of the Opera House and on into the Botanic Gardens. Simply stunning.

lovely walk in the afternoon sun. worth the effort to meander round the opera house, beside the botanics and along to MacQuarries point. It took about 45 minutes but then we were not jogging....what do these joggers do all day when they are not jogging? Nice ice-cream place at MacQuarries point

Beautiful walk with fantastic views. We stayed in Potts point and walked to the ferries via woolloomollo. It's a fair walk but it's actually peaceful. The views are amazing as you come over the hill in the the gardens from the Potts point end. On the way back its water views the whole way round, you can see fort Denison and all the boats going by.Lots of people running and walking, taking in a picnic. Kinda hard to believe your in the middle of Sydney.
Nice easy walk. Beautiful walk from the opera house through the botanical gardens. Easy to enjoy the opera house then on to the gardens easily accessible.

Nice walk. The opera house of course is the main attraction but the adjoining botanical gardens are free and well worth the walk. They offer free tours but the timing didn't work out for us. Still plenty of beauty to explore on your own

A short walk from the Opera House to the Botancial Gardens. The two attractions are just a few paces from each other. The gardens are a very large and peaceful location with differnet garden styles. In the park you have a flock of white sulphur crested cockatoos - very cool!
I was there. I have a photo of this exact place but where do I put it up on here, ooh well it is a must visit when you come here
Excellent. Good views, tidy and green. A great walk with marvellous views which are to die for. Nothing more to add.

Varied plantings, meandering walkways, delights, repose. This is a large park and botanical garden, make no mistake about that. The northern end, which bends around the Government House complex, is more parklike and sees good use by runners, strollers, lovers, kids playing games, etc. As it opens into the botanical gardens, the plantings change to more exotic groupings, e.g., a bamboo grove. Signage is good, and there are signs for the restaurant and welcome center, different areas of the garden, and routes to the exits near the Art Museum. This is, in fact, a lovely way to walk from the Opera House to the Art Museum. Currently, there is some major construction occurring in the midst of the garden, necessitating some detours, but nothing major. The paths are well trafficked in daylight hours and appear to be safe.

walking trips. making a sandwich the night before and freeze it ,take a popper and peace of fruit, catch a train to Circular Quay and you can walk from thereto the opera house then on to Lady Macquarie's chair through and around the Domain to Woolloomooloo ,Garden Island then up passed the ship yard to kings Cross passing the famous round fountain along and down oxford street to Hyde park walk through park then cross Elizabeth street and head for Darling Harbour and have dinner there in one of the many restaurants and a rest and then off up the road to central for a train back to Penrith ,I catch the Katoomba or Mt Victoria train on platform 6-8 as they are a fast train and you can rest comfortably and your in Penrith in 55minutes,in your car and home a great day and only a small expense for dinner and the train and a good night sleep . drink water so you don't get headache and there are toilets all around and no charge for them just carry a bit if tissue with you as they may be out. have a great walk regards Margaret S
"All the Bats in the trees at Botanic Gardens". So awesome to see all the Bat's in the day time at Botanic Gardens and close walk to the Sydney Opera House
Great walk, great views.. This is a lovely walk along the harbour wall, great views with the harbour to the left and the gardens to the right.

Great place to chill. Great place to escape the crowds and relax. There is a cafe and water fountains. Make sure you go as far as the Chair for the views. Take time to explore and see the different plants and trees etc.

Fantastic views and ideal for picnics. Great walk for kids who enjoyed seeing the bird life in the gardens as well as the ocean views, trees, flowers and sculptures. Cheap day out as carried our sandwiches and drinks in our backpacks and had a picnic in the gardens. Fantastic views of the harbour very enjoyable fay out for the family.

GREAT DAY TO RELAX. Great way to check out quite side of Sydney. Botanic Gardens are a real treat to walk thru with water edge right there. Find a place to kick back and enjoy the view. End your trip at Opera house with good photo shots.

A must for overseas visitors. You can take an hour or all day to do this walk. I prefer to start at the Botanic Gardens and walk downhill to the Opera House as it is downhill but it is only a slight upwards grade if you start from the Opera House end. When you reach one of the Botanic Gardens gates stop and have a good look at the map. You can decide if there is anything in particular you want to see or one path that looks more interesting. Perhaps you want to go via the cafe and grab a bite to eat. For tired tourists this is a lovely place to go and chill out, On a sunny day you will see people lying on the grass having a nap! It is a great space for children to run off a bit of energy too. There is an interesting sandstone installation that children love to climb. My grandchildren like to sit in it to eat their lunch! We usually have lunch in the Botanic Gardens after taking the children to a play in the Opera House. How lucky we are to have such a great green space in the middle of our city.
Tour of Opera is a must. We enjoyed the one hour plus tour of the Opera.It was a most informative and interesting visit animated by an excellent guide?It is a must visit for a trip to Sydney.

Magnificent Building Architecture & Relaxing Walk! . This is a must to do if you are in Sydney! Stop by at Sydney Opera House, take a panoramic photo and of course the glorious Opera House itself. After that, dont go back to Circular Quay station yet! Go for a relaxing walk into the Royal Botanical Gardens and laydown on the grass there after a tiring walk. Finish? Not Yet, go into the Art Museum first for an Air Conditioned room and see a lot of astounishing artistic paintings and scluptures while cooling down your body if you ever in Sydney during summer. Perfect venue to spend a day if you ever visit Sydney!

Harbour views and green oasis. This is one of my favourite walks. The stark modern architecture of the Opera House and the forecourt give way to a green oasis walk and harbour. If inclined you can wander into the Botanic Gardens or just follow the path around Mrs Macquarie's Chair. Great for a run or power walk if that takes your fancy or just stop off on the grounds and have a picnic or imbibe the view. This is one of Sydney's premier attractions ... and it's free !!!

Stroll in the City. Recently did this exact walk to the Opera House. Absolutely wonderful grounds/botanical displays...and yet just a few minutes from the Central Business District. Spent a week in Sydney, and this 45 minute 'free' stroll turned out to be a highlight for us! Just Do It!

Photographers' Paradise. Make sure you walk all the way around to Mrs Macquarie's Chair, where you will get fine views towards the Sydney Zoo and Wooloomooloo and the eastern areas of Sydney Harbour.Keen photographers will be rewarded with stunning images of Harbour traffic, our iconic Bridge and Opera House, the city skyline and, if you wander into the gardens, some gorgeous plants. Best of all this feast for the eyes is FREE.

Beautiful and calming. A beautiful park and gardens so close to the CBD - an easy walk that will not push anyone but so much to see whether it be the gardens themselves or the view to the city, bridge, Opera House or looking east to Kings cross. Now celebrating its 200th anniversary, it is a great time to see the gardens.

Enjoyable urban escape. The Opera House Gate to the Gardens is adjacent to the Opera House, and the most popular walk simply follows the sea wall around Farm Cove, ending up at Mrs Macquarie's Chair, where there are wonderful views - indeed the "iconic" views - of the House with the Harbour Bridge behind. You can continue beyond this point along the shore of Wooloomooloo Bay, emerging close to the Art Gallery of NSW, then walk back to Circular Quay through the main body of the Gardens. This loop walk, as long as you don't stop too long to take in the wonderful panorama of the Harbour, or pop into the Gallery (free), can be completed in less than 2 hours, so it is ideal for visitors on a tight schedule. But equally, you could fruitfully spend half a day in the Gardens, which are possibly Australia's finest, and certainly its oldest.
Wonderful clean park with harbour views. Wonderful clean park with harbour views - we walked all the way to Potts Point and back from the Opera House.

Absolutely gorgeous walk. For tourists, this is a great way to see the Opera house, get some great pics and enjoy the Royal Botannical Garden. For locals, when the sun is shining but you're all beached out this is a great walk. Plenty of places to picnic!

Away from the busy Quay. It's incredible that this area, which is so close the the hustle & bustle of Circular Quay, can be so quiet and calm.We walked from the Botanic Gardens down toward the Opera House and the views of the Harbour and the Bridge are quite unique. And it is an easier walk this was as it's down hill!

Almost took a taxi and missed this beautiful walk!. The walk from Hyde Park through the Botanical Gardens to the Opera House is gorgeous. We were there during the summer In late January and all the flowers and plants were bursting with color! At the end of the walk you look up and there is the Opera House...magnificent!
Must take this walk. So relaxing and inspiring. The views are so special. The glistening blue water, the ferries with the Botanical Gardens behind just wonderful
Great first stop in Sydney. I started my time in Sydney with a walk to the Opera House and then over to the Botanical Gardens. Very nice walk and a great area for just relaxing.

Wonderful use of our 10 hour layover in Sydney. We had a 10 hour layover in Sydney on our way to new Zealand and decided to spend the day wondering around the city. We took the Sky-train from the airport directly to Circular Quay. From there you can walk along the water to the opera house and then on to the botanical gardens, the museum, do some shopping at the mall, have a bite to eat and return back to the airport having gotten to do some sight seeing, gotten some much needed exercise after a 15 hour flight from LAX and enjoyed a sample of what is SYDNEY. This introduction to Sydney was enough to plan a separate trip to Australia some time in the future.

One of my favorites.. On any day and almost any weather , this is one of the most awe inspiring places to visit and wander around. If you want views,,, fantastic. If you want food, wine..... plenty of choices.
Relaxing and beautiful walk, away from the Quay chaos!. Great walk which offers wonderful views of the Harbor, plus you avoid the mess around Circular Quay, where the cruise ships dock

Beautiful setting. We walked along from the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens and the scenery was beautiful. You have the harbour on one side of the pathway and the gardens on the other. A lovely walk.
