For first time visitors to Australia, seeing ibises, lorikeets and kookaburras so easily was wonderful although it's easy to get blasé after a while.

Lush And Green. l walk around the gardens on Monday afternoon the sun was shinning, the view of the Harbour was breath taking and it was the most restful part of my afternoon, the gardens are a must when your in Sydney. Great if you have kids, they will love it very safe.

Nice walk. walking around the gardens is amazing. We choosed a day when it is not too hot. A Fantastic walk to get magnificent views of the opera house Aand bridge.Recommend to carry a bottle of water
Sunday out. Relaxing trip acrosss the harbour from manly and enjoyable lunch looking over Sydney harbour.Pensioner return $2.50 was graeat value

Beautiful Evening Walk!. My friend and I visited the Opera House and decided to walk through the Botanical Gardens to the viewpoint near the open view cinema, where you can see both the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. It was a lovely atmosphere and we really enjoyed our surroundings during the walk.
A beautiful walk. Right in the heart of Sydney, is this amazing Botanic Gardens. Don't miss it! It's an easy walk with lots of lovely things to see!

The Best Casual Walk in Sydney. This walk starts (or ends) at the Opera House and winds its way through the Royal Botanic Gardens eventually getting to "Mrs Macquarie's Chair". This is a lovely, flat, and peaceful walk. The actual path is very well maintained, wide enough for wheelchairs, and has a wonderful view of the harbor for the entire stretch.

Magnificent scenery and superb gardens. A walk from the Opera House to Botanic Gardens is limiting ones appreciation of the harbor foreshore. What one should do is walk through the Rocks passing under the Harbor Bridge to view rows of delightful terrace houses being certain to view the Old Garrison Church. Then make your way back to the Opera House along the foreshore. Once at the Opera House continue on through the Botanic Gardens onto Macquarie Street. Or, follow the foreshore through the Botanic Gardens and past lady Macquarie's chair and on to the Sydney Art Gallery.

Best when reversed and walking towards the Opera House. I love the walk starting from the Hyde Park side of the Botanic Gardens towards the Opera House. There's something wonderful about the view of walking towards the Opera House along the water. Wind through the gardens and enjoy the fabulous roses and then make your way down to the water.
Lovely walk. Very enjoyable, and if you feet are tired and sore, you can take the Scenic Train, which will take you right around the gardens, allowing you to get off or on, on any of the 4 stops.

Beautiful and Very Peaceful. The walk around the opera house and the botanic gardens is a great walk. The path that goes around the opera house is well maintained, wide and affords a wonderful view of the harbor and the activities on the water. Inside the botanic gardens birds are active and make a delightful sound. There are many interesting trees, many that were gifts from other nations. The garden is large and beautiful. This made for a very delightful afternoon walk as the trees provide shade and protection from the sun

A wonderful walk around the gardens. Wonder around and enjoy the beautiful gardens and special plants. Stop anytime and have a break in the cafes within Botanic gardens. Take a tour ($15 I think each) in a tractor ride look like a train going up and down the gardens if you don't fancy walking.

Lovely place for a walk!. This is a wonderful place to stretch your legs after a long flight. The gardens are gorgeous and so well-maintained. The pathways give you an expansive view of Sydney Harbour and the Opera House. Also, a great, safe place to have an evening run. Wish we had parks like this at home!
Breathtaking Scenery. The view of the harbour on a beautiful day was magic.The Botanic walk if taken with eze is very enjoyable.

Beautifully kept... Nice to discover Government House nestling there between the Opera and the gardens. The walk all the way to Mrs Macquarie's seat along the prom is nice. You may have to compete with the busloads of tourists at the seat, but if you've been around Oz much, it's the way things are..

Very colourful.. A lovely little walk to do from the Opera House to the Botanical Gardens, which offers a lot of colour and webbed arachnids. We actually stopped at the cafe in the Botanical Gardens and the wildlife, along with the flora and fauna in the vicinity were stunning.A must if you have a bit of spare time and find yourself that way.
Great walk. Very pleasant and easy walk, the gardens are a delight with lots of variations of plants. Well set out with ponds and lakes. I would recommend this as a must walk.

Chill Out. After viewing the wonderful Opera House we found it very relaxing to take a peaceful stroll in the adjacent Botanical Gardens. It's a very flat and even walk around to Mrs Macquaries Point from which there are stunning river views and with a bit of history attached to the seat there. You can retrace your steps and visit the Oriental Gardens close by or meander off on the various paths through tropical plants and vegetation. A very pleasant cafe is situated in the centre of the Gardens and there is ample seating throughout the park if you want to rest awhile and soak up the peaceful atmosphere. If you wish you can exit the Gardens via various gates other than the one by the Opera House and the whole Gardens make a splendid picnic site.
A must do. A pleasant walk around on the Harbour. Easy and flat all the way around. Would highly recommend. Walked around from Woolloomooloo to Opera House.

Nice but Confusing. My gf and I strolled thru the gardens after getting off the ferry at circular quay. Finding an entrance was easy and the gardens were lovely for fall. Wish we could see them in the spring. Our only problem was the confusing array of pathways and signs.

Wonderful Opera House. The scale of the Sydney Opera house has to be seen to understand the brilliance of the design. No amount of photographs can do it justice. As you come through the botanical gardens and come down to the harbour it comes into view and is an awesome sight. Huge achievement for architecture.
Lovely for a morning run. It's free, it's beautiful, it's easily accessible and it's safe. What more do you need for a morning run

Lovely walk. Walked from the Opera House through the Botanic Gardens to see a delightful production of Aida at the Handa Opera on Sydney Harbor. It is a delightful walk. Everything is so green and beautiful.

Botanical gardens. Very beautiful gardens but allow plenty of time as they are larger than expected. They run onto the Domain and Hyde Park which I didn't have time to get to. You could dedicate a whole day to these three gardens.

One of my favorite areas of the city. My Bonza Bike Tour took me to this part of the city (where I hadn't made it yet). I think these are some of the best views you can get. Loved strolling along here.
Fantastic. Just do it! Its relaxing and the views are fantastic. At times there are box jellyfish in the sea and big fruit bats in the trees in the Botanic gardens Great vibe!
Stunnung. We shared a beautiful Day pon Sydney Harbour. The walk from the opera House is not long, but much to see.
A beautiful walk. It is not far from the Opera House to the Botanical Garden and there is so much to admire as you walk.
Relax. Wonderful way to relax and enjoy the surroundings. View the gardens, or take a peek at the Governor's home, maybe spot a fish near the wall, or a catfish in the pond!

Beautiful Gardens. What could be better than walking through these amazing gardens and via Opera House to get to Circular Quay. So much to see by taking side tracks or take direct path to harbour. All plants labelled with interesting facts. Visited in autumn but intend going back for a spring visit when I should imagine it to be awesome.

Spectacular harbour. Absolutely fabulous vista from all points of this walk. Easy walking right on the harbours edge. Walk through to the Charlton pool and stop for a coffee or continue to Wooloomoolo to one of the hotels for a well earned beer.

A must for every visitor to Sydney. This is definitely worth an hour or three, although I'd do it in reverse - visit the gardens first and then finish with lunch or afternoon tea in the Opera House/Quay precinct. The Gardens themselves are beautiful and interesting, particularly in spring when the bulbs are out or summer when the sea breezes and shade make for a wonderful place to sit and watch the world go by. There's a kiosk as well as an upmarket restaurant. The walk to the Opera House/Quay precinct has the best views of the Harbour and surrounds. Once there, the choices of places to eat is quite good - from oyster bars, to full on restaurants, cafes and ice creameries.

Walk to Botanic Gardens. Excellent walk to gardens,however there is a small train for those who cannot go that far........free guided tours in the Botanic Gardens organised by volunteers at the cafe within

Easy level walk suitable for all. Great view of the Opera House and at the far end you can get amazing photo's of the OP with the sun setting behind it and the Harbour Bridge in the shot as well.Don't forget to detour off the main path to the Botanic Gardens, they are a truly special place in the heart of the city. The Bay is known as Farm Cove as this is where the first settlers started the farm that saw the tiny colony of Sydney grow to the country we now know as Australia
Easy walk thru lovely scenery. Take your camera and relax , not a strenuous walk with extra wide pathways with easy access for prams and wheelchairs

A well maintained Garden. If one is fond of lush greenery and the the walk in the park.thereis no better place than the botanic gardens.They have grown 15 different types of grass.we spent an entire afternoon just wandering around and enjoying the lush greenery.The weather was very pleasant just the beginning of winters so it was a real heavenly experience.
Beautiful walking / jogging route in the hub of Sydney. Lovely walk or running route if you're staying in central Sydney - highly recommended for a morning jog, evening walk or weekend stroll.

Beautiful. This place is a must see. Wonderful place with art in the air. The view of Sydney bridge from here is amazing. Also the gardens are well maintained. Do not miss going to the Opera House cafe.
Easy, lovely walk. It was a rainy day. Cool. And a walk from the Opera to the lush botanical gardens was a day brightener.
Beautiful. Worth your time while in Sydney.. We walked this route, and much of the rest of the gardens, in the rain. It was still great. Be sure to allow time for this.
Easy, spectacular. I never get sick of this area. So easy to walk from The Rocks/Circular Quay area to the Opera House and then to the Botanic Gardens.

The Opera House/Botanic Garden Walk. Pure Gold - The O.H. is an amazing piece of architecture.The exterior structure is incrediable & wow we were in awe at its interior too. We didn't do our research on this dream architecture so didn't know what to expect. Once we got our tickets we were put into small groups for a guided tour & were given audio/headphones to communicate with the guide who was very informative. On the off set we were told there were plenty of stairs to climb, not wrong there. So if your motorbility is restricted please ask about access. (We did notice there were lifts). There are many theatres within, we were taken into four & were lucky even if only for ten minutes to see a ballet in rehearsal. The foyer of the O.H. has lush purple carpets, our guide told us a story about Pavarotti who was due in concert but alas 'couldn't' perform & the concert was relocated later that evening within another theatre in the building, this was because of his superstition - purple bringing bad luck! The views of the harbour are beautiful and the whole trip unforgettable. Moving on now taking in gentle stroll along the waters edge you come to The Botanic Gardens ( (free of charge) home of a 'flora showcase'. The many pathways, twists & turns make the walks so interesting, a place of sheer delight & beauty. We spent most of our day here totally unhurried meandering through the vegetation admiring nature at its best. The sculptures also add interest. There is a cafe, we had sandwiches but also needed a knife & fork to tackle them, mmmm delicious! Both attractions well worth a visit, Highly recommend.

Beautiful walk. After the stop at opera house I saw one of the gates to the botanic gardens. I didn't realize the gardens were this close to the harbor. Wonderfully manicured gardens and nice walking paths. If you enjoy nature (plants and animals) this is a must.

Botanical Garden Walk and Opera tour. We walked the Botanical garden twice a day from our hotel in the Woolloomoo wharf area to the Circle Wharf. What a fabulous, peaceful way to begin and end each day. The Opera house, which is just off the Botanical Garden is, of course, a masterpiece of architectural beauty. The sound quality of it's theaters is outstanding (we attended Madam Butterfly). Be sure to get the tour. It's well worth the price!
Obviously better with a nice weather. we experienced the walk under the rain and the next day with sun and blue sky.... definitely a must do when you are in Sydney

A must do when in Sydney........ What a truely beautiful walk - along the waters edge from the Botanic Gardens through to the Woolloomooloo finger walks
Such stunning views - a beautiful walk - and all for free
Don't miss out.....

Showcasing the best of Sydney's outdoors. As a short term visitor to Sydney, I stumbled upon the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens walk by chance. Tidy pathways sweep through themed garden areas of the Botanic Gardens and showcase the best of Sydney's outdoor environments. That the pathways lead to the entry to Sydney's inner Eastern locations of Woolloomooloo makes the walk a great thing to do for tourists and locals wishing to get to know Sydney a bit better.

Lovely gardens. The botanic gardens are lovely, near to the opera house, great views over the harbour too. There is so much to see and do in the harbour. Take a trip on the ferries to different places the cost is very reasonable.

A lovely experience close to the Sydney shoreline. This is a walk that has beautiful vistas of the sea, a host of different and exotic flowers and bird life as well as many different paths. You can easily spend a full day in this magnificent area and still want to go back for more. Highly recommended.

Beautiful gardens great view . My daughter and I spent 2 hours walking through the Botanic Gardens to the Opera House on a beautiful Sunday morning. It was a very enjoyable and easy walk. We then had a good brunch at a cafe near the Harbor before visiting the Sunday market nearby.

A walk with a view. A bright sunny day for a visually stunning walk from the highly visible opera house to mrs mccarthurs chair. A leisurely stroll with a photo opportunity every few steps. This walk took an hour and i highly recommend it as there is very little for free in Sydney. ☝☝

Beautiful way to view the harbour. My family and I walked from the Opera House through to the Botanic Gardens. We spent a few hours exploring and soaking in the atmosphere of the gardens and the many spectacular views of Sydney Harbour. We saw 6 weddings taking place - what a gorgeous spot to tie the knot!

Beautiful Views of the Harbor. We started at the opera house and walked along the path taking many photos along the way. Looking at the opera house just took my breath away. It is such an iconic building, I couldn’t believe I traveled all the way from NY and was looking at this building in person.Make sure you make your way to Mrs. Macquarie’s chair for some beautiful photos of both the opera house and bridge together. The botanical gardens are spectacular and I took one of my best photos with the opera house and bridge in the background of the gardens.  A nice way to spend a few leisurely hours walking at your own pace and admiring the many gorgeous, colorful flowers along the way.

Beautiful and Peaceful. After you've visited the Opera House try the walk to the Botanical Gardens which is right next door. It is a delightful stroll through the majestic gardens and lawns with the occasional park bench so you can rest your weary legs.Great way to spend your afternoon in Sydney.

Walk to Mrs. Macquarie's Chair. It took me about an hour to do this walk, but i was stopping every 5 mins to take pictures and soak in the different angle views of the Sydney Opera house. It was quite hot, but was worth it.
A nice but very crowded. You can have a really good time around but its very noisy as it is main attraction. lot of tourists do come here. its flooded with people.

An iconic Sydney Exprience. If you are a first time visitor to Sydney: After looking at the opera house, go down the front stairs, turn left into the gardens and begin walking.Not only will you have one of the best free experiences the city has to offer, you will be rewarded with the very best photo opportunity of your holiday once you reach Mrs Maquaries chair.(The Opera House with the bridge behind in a perfect vista)Totally worth your time.
Wander away from the main path. It's only about a 10-15min walk along the harbour, so nothing special. The gardens are amazing though & it's a good place to escape the many tourists.

Excellent walk. This is a fantastic walk to get magnificent views of the ocean/bridge/opera house. Just choose a day when it is not too hot and also make sure to carry a bottle of water (we did not see too many vendors selling water)

Hot, Hot. We had just arrived in Sydney from Canada, the temperature swing was about 45C (-15 to +30) so the walk was very hot for us, but quite beautiful and we enjoyed it. We did find the signage to be a bit confusing and as a result we ended up at the wrong areas a couple of times.

Enjoying Opera House and Botanical Garden. Enjoyed Opera House as well as walking on Botanical Garden were you can see nature in the city.Disliked high prices of foods in Botanical Gardens Cafe and Restaurant.

A beautiful walk. This must be one of the few beautiful gardens in the world where they ask you to "Please walk on the grass".Take hours and meander around the various gardens, take a book and sit and read under the magnificent fig trees. meet friends and take a picnic or have lunch in the café. Walk along the foreshore to the opera House and enjoy the busy waterway of Sydney Harbour.Sadly I think people do the more "touristy" things and miss out on this - we have lived in Sydney but always enjoy this - I highly recommend it - but wear comfortable shoes.

Great sight seeing. This is a great walk which is not only free but gives you a great view and feel of the harbour. Make sure you pack your camera as there are many great photo opportunities along this route
Heavenly Harbour..... The walk is gorgeous and not to be missed. The Botanic Gardens are simply stunning. Would be incredible if I could walk the dog through the gardens, but sadly not allowed.
Beautiful walk. The walk is so picturesque. The Opera House is great to visit and the tour is interesting. You get to see a good deal of the inside. The walk through the gardens tops off day.
Lovely scenery and views. I was a lovely walk around the botanic gardens - such a lovely day with great views and lots to learn

Best view in the world. I've seen quite a few harbour cities around the world and I have to say Sydney Harbour is one of the best. One of my favourite walks is to start at the Opera House and end up in the Botanic Gardens. By continuing along the foreshore all the way around to Mrs Macquarie's Chair you have the most relaxing walk with magnificent city and water views the whole way. There is something about being near water that soothes the soul. I enjoy this walk alone, with my partner and/or with my kids. There is something for everyone. You don't have to spend much money if you choose to take a picnic lunch with you. Alternatively, there are many restaurants/cafes on the walk to the Opera House or you can eat at a lovely cafe in the middle of the Gardens, sitting amongst the fabulous plantlife. There is also a more upmarket restaurant upstairs where most tables have extraordinary views looking down into the gardens with glimpses of the harbour. Walking all around these gardens,not just near the water, is a must, as I always seem to find something new everytime I visit. All in all a day well spent.

Very nice walk. It was a beautiful day and therefore we had an amazing time walking around the opera and the botanic gardens. The boats passing, the great nature, sitting down on a bench to relax, all of that was just great!
lovely walk. this is a great walk - though we were interrupted by a triathlon! This must do walk is popular with visitors and locals alike, and the lush gardens beckon detours!

Must do!!. In one word, 'beautiful'!Wonderfully manicured lawns, with the Sydney Harbor running next to it. One could hardly ask for more. it is a very peaceful, calming experience and a must have experience when in Sydney.Missed mentioning that it gives you some great angles for photography (selfies or otherwise).

A lovely walk. This is a great walk around the Cove walking towards the Royal Botanic Gardens and Mrs Macquaries point. It is a gentle level walk easily accessible by wheelchair or prams. If you go into the gardens there is a cafe and rest room.Excellent photo opportunities.There is no charge.

Beautiful Walk. This is a lovely way to see Sydney and enjoy the gardens as well. We were very lucky to have the Aieda Stage set up to add to the effect. The gardens are very beautiful and to finish at the Opera House is fantastic.
Sydneys Best. One of the best things to do in Sydney. Catching a show at the Opera House is a must. A world class experience.

Beautiful Gardens. we walked through the gardens to the Aida performance. Beautiful flowers, trees and lots of birds. We saw a bunch of cockatoos, they were beautiful, I have never seen cockatoos in the wild before. Be aware the garden gates are locked at 6.pm. You will have a view of the opera house and harbour bridge together for a great photo from the botanic gardens.
Go to Both. The short walk between these two attractions is nothing special, however the two attractions are worth seeing.

A Lovely Day Out. I loved the walk, the gardens and the views. Down-side is that we went on a very hot day and that made it a bit unpleasant to see it all. We had taken water bottles but it was too far to the shop to buy more when we ran out. However, we got the little train back to the Opera House where we had refreshments and sat and admired the view for a while.

Very nice seaside and garden walk. Very good pathways and maps of the gardens so that you can enjoy the sea vistas and the Botanical Gardens. Does not seem crowed in spite of very high visitor numbers. Even got to walk through the are of the AIDA opera as they were working on the stage.
Hot walk. The one hot day and we walked to the opera house. Ate a lot of ice cream! Nice walk. More more more more.
Nice walk. Go on a nice sunny day, which is most of the time, and enjoy the scenery. Beautifully-manicured lawns, trees and gardens with some art mixed in. Really great.
romantic stroll. Very relaxing and quite scenic. Gardens are well kept and could trap you for hours! Easy walk around from Garden's to The Oprah House

Memorable. We walked from St Mary's cathedral right over to the Opera House via the Botanic a Gardens which were stunning. Although busy in places it's big enough to feel free to sit on the grass and just take in the views, sounds and wildlife. We found a wee cafe and shared a sandwich (but not our beer) with the ibis that were milling about and a fabulous gift shop - ideal for some Ozzie souvenirs. There was a smashing little road train going around but we didn't get on that.
Nice Thing to Do. Walked from Opera House all the way around the botanical gardens. Easy stroll. Stop at Mrs McArthurs Chair.
Amazing. Not really a fan of thnigs like this but walking around the gardens is amazing to be so close to the busy areas that surround it and also offers amazing views of the harbour
RELAX IN THE CITY. Amazing walk on the harbour, right in the city centre but nature is amazing! Lots of trees, flowers, birds, and the view is awesome... wish to be back there!

Great walk in a beautiful city. We loved this walk so much we did it twice - came back the next day because we wanted the light to hit the bridge/opera house view just right! Really very gorgeous waterfront and gardens. What a great city- you should all be proud!
Amazing. Had guided tour around opera house, was very interesting and very detailed, it was absolutely amazing in there.

Splendid!. Rain or shine, a walk through the Botanic Gardens is a joy with the avenues of trees, lovely flowerbeds, winding paths and hothouses. One can enter through the Macquarie Street gate or by the opera house, but it is important to be aware that opening and closing times vary with the time of year. There is a venue for exhibitions which change regularly and are a well worth a look. The view on the waterfront is second to none and one can while away the time nicely in one of the several cafes and restaurants. It is possible to do an opera house tour but one needs to book in advance. Water taxis at $10 per person one way are available at the Man 'O War steps by the opera house. These go to various points around the waterfront. It is an easy walk into the city from both the Botanical Gardens and the opera house.
great walk thuogh the gardens approaching the Opera house. gardens are peaceful, although on the edge of the city,Do it from the gardens to the Opera house, the approach is better
Botanicals gardens visit. Had a lovely walk thru the gardens, not as good as Melbournes but still nice. Hyde Park is lovely too with the avenue of Plane Trees to walk under.

Our favourite walk. When in Sydney we very much enjoy the walk from Opera house to the Domain via Botanic gardens or Mrs Mcquaries chair and Boy Charlton pool and try to do it more than once. I don't think you get better city scenery anywhere in the would. It is very quiet and you would not know your in a big city with beautiful gardens on one side of you and Scenic Sydney harbour with all its activity on the other. Just love it.

What a great city. The harbour, the opera house and the botanic gardens a wonderful trifecta.I have travelled the world and still am in awe of the opera house sited on Sydney harbourAdd in the wondrous botanic gardens and you have a magical combo!
Beautiful!. Take the opera house tour.... it's well worth the time and money! Walk all the paths through the lovely gardens.

More than a must. One of the best areas of Sydney. It is definitely a must! The beautiful walk by the sea with the Opera behind... The huge gardens full of amazing trees. I enjoyed a lot there! Don't miss it!
Must do.. This is a classic walk – beautiful views, non strenuous and very accessible. The Opera House is an important modern architectural piece and a must see.

A Breath of air in the city. I imagine that many travellers arrive in Sydney on flights that arrive in the morning before their hotel rooms are available to them. If this is the case, i can think of no better way to start you tourism in Sydney. It is the perfect antidote to a flight that may have left you cooped up for anything from 14 to twent+ hours.That first view of this incomparable harbour as you walk through the gardens is sublime. The gardens are home to birds that you may be seeing for the first time and vegetation which is unfamiliar. It is the perfect introduction to what is to come in your visit to this wonderful city.

A lovely way to idle through a sunny day . I start at circular quay after catching the ferry in, then I meander around past the opera house and into Domain and the botanical gardens, lovely way to spend a morning.

What a walk. This is one of the nicest parks I have ever seen and the walk was just wonderful on a crisp afternoon. I was so surprised to see the mackaws flying all over the park. It is also nice how people go there just to hang out, have a picnic and spend time enjoying the great views,
Lovely Views. This is a lovely area to walk along with stunning views and to take lots of photos, well worth a visit

MY REVERSE WALK - ROYAL BOTANIC GARDEN TO THE OPERA HOUSE. I walked to the Opera House TWICE during my visit of Sydney. First Walk - I walked from my hotel to the Opera House, using primarily the MacQuarie Street. Attractions noted along the way include St. Mary's Cathedral, Hyde Park, Sydney Hospital, Military Barracks Museum, Mint, Parliament, National Library of New South Wales, the Royal Botanic Garden, and then, the Opera House.Second Walk - On Day 2, I entered the Royal Botanic Garden at the Macquarie Street. I visited its various areas that have beautiful flowers, huge trees, shrubs, ferns, fountains, statutes, etc. After visiting these areas, I simply followed the posted signs showing the arrows/directions towards the Opera House.The views are spectacular! I saw both the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House at this particular section of the Garden. Landmarks of the Garden include another statute, lawn areas, circular flower beds and a small pond. Staying on the left side of the path, I continued my walk until I reached the Opera House again. Which option is better for you? Start at the Opera House or at the Royal Botanic Garden? It's your call!

A must do. Who can blend all so well together?Amazing architecture, stunning harbour view, lovely and peaceful garden. One can lie on the grass, rest under canopy of huge trees, and taken very nice photos of the Opera House also. Can easily spend half a day here.

Wow!. Exceptional tour given by their tour guide. The guide imparted lots of knowledge related to the architecture, the architect and the events that are held there. The architecture is so interesting, that you can spend an entire day trying to figure out how the building was built. It will wow even the novice, who is only mildly interested in how things are made. Loved it!

beautiful gardens and a easy walk. Just a beautiful walk through a beautiful city...the gardens are keep beautifully...you can spend hours...do what I did and take a packed lunch and a thermos...you can stop anywhere then..i spent 3 hours just enjoying the views and gardens.

A refreshing alternative and break away from the city. If like me ,you hanker for green space and trees after spending a couple of hours in the city then let this be your escape.The gardens are immaculately maintained . Think if trees could talk,some of the trees here would be able to tell us a lot of wonderful stories as they were very mature and healthy.You could access the Sydney Opera house via the gardens which for some may find that it offers an alternative vantage point. Most paths are wheelchair friendly too.

Amazing views from a lovely garden. Nice way to spend an afternoon surrounded by lovely well kept gardens ending at the most iconic Australian landmark. Great way to admire the gardens, seascape and building of Sydney all at no charge. Plenty of spots to sit in the garden along the way. Take your time walking through, its not a strenuous walk but go slow and admire all the views

Lovely Walk at any time. Even in the Rain!!!. Botanic Gardens, green, colourful, birds nesting whilst we were there. Sydney Harbour Bridge and then the skyline on the other side of the garden, brilliant. Allow at least two hours to fully walk around and not forgetting the big plant houses. Take the camera, water and a sandwich!!

This is Sydney. the opera house is doubtlessly the symbol of sydney, and it is amazingly beautiful when you really look at it rather than a photo. I believe the Mrs. Macquarie's Point in the Botanic Gardens is definitely the right spot to enjoy the view of the Opera House and Sydeny Harbour Bridge.

Must see to Appreciate. W e took an inside Opera House tour.It's massive.The inside has to be seen to appreciae the building,At the end of the tour we booked a jazz concert.So enjoyable.Some days several different operas/concerts are on! After the tour take the easy option on the little train around the botanical gardens close by,

Relaxing, scenic and exciting. I have done this walk many times usually starting at Hyde Park or Circular Quay but this time we walked via the domain & were delighted to find the stage set for Aida across form the Opera House in the gardens. This made our walk very exciting as we were able to check out the props and witness some of the preparations. Other than that the view is always great and so is all the flora . The Sydney Botanic gardens have a great collection of exotics as well as native trees and I highly recommend visitors to Sydney, who need to chill out a bit, to take this walk..
opera house to botanic gardens. Beautiful, relaxing walk. Pleanty of areas to take a relaxing rest, read a book, or simply enjoy the view.
DON'T MISS this!!!. Need to see this, the garden is probably with its location the most wonderful one in the world.Walk through the gardens and also enjoy the harbour views
Lovely sightseeing. Visitors must walk around the Opera House, which is a great start of your tour around the harbour. This area is surrounded by nature and history. Enjoyed the sunset!

Great walk through gardens, opera house looking bit tired. The gardens have a great WOW factor, heaps of really interesting trees and beautiful surrounds, big area to cover and taking a picnic lunch is suggested.The opera house although grand and appreciated in design is looking a bit tired, we enjoyed the waterfront and gardens so much more than the visual of the opera house
Even on a grey morning. Worthwhile walk around great gardens with water views and manageable for everyone with wheelchair access facilities.

Delightful on your way there or back from Circular Quay. I believe these are the same Royal Botonical Gardens which also contain the Government House (free tours till 3:30pm), The Gardens are free but access to active Govt House is fenced so makes manuevering thru gardens tricky, We could not find the Begonia House but everything else was quite easy to locate

Sightseeing with a touch of nature. The Opera House is always buzzing with people around it. But one of the world's most iconic landmark is nested in a magnificent garden. As the Aussies use to say "please step on the grass and enjoy!"

Great way to while away some time. Do yourself a favour and do this walk. Great Harbour views from beautiful gardens that are well maintained. Try to avoid the crowds at Mrs Macquaries Chair (good luck as this is a stop for the miriads of tour coaches) and expect to be leg weary but satisfied.

A must when youre in Sydney!. I have visited Sydney many times and never found time to walk through the gardens, now I wont visit without doing it again! BEautiful relaxing spaces, really intersting gardens, even if you are not facinated with plants the views are spectacular.

One of my favourite things to do in Sydney. I just love the Botanic Gardens, they're beautiful all year around. I like to start at the Opera House, walk around the gardens to the exit up near the Art Gallery and then walk back to Martin Place along the Domain road. My suggestion is to take off your shoes and walk along the grass rather than the path to really feel connected to the gardens. Skip the train ride, it's expensive and you will appreciate the gardens so much more by walking through them.
Amazing Views. We were here early in the morning and the views of the opera house and harbor are absolutely breathtaking.

A Favourite!. This is my favourite walk in all of Sydney. It is possible (and highly advisable) to walk from Circular Quay to the Opera House and then continue on to the Botanic Gardens. If you walk all the way around to Mrs Macquarie's chair you will be rewarded with a stunning view of the harbour with the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge in the one photo. It is quite a long walk and it is the same path back but it is possible to simply turn around at any time as it is scenic all the way around.

visit to Opera house. 20 asd for the opera house tour great value for money and even managed to see some rehearsals for that evenings show and learned a bit about the architecture and history great value and fun for all the family ,
Beautiful walk. Loved the walk. You can see the Opera House from every angle. Would love to do it again. Highly recommend.

Wonderful way to spend a few hours. We walked to the Botanic Gardens from the Cathedral, leisurely paced, and the views across to the Opera House and Harbour bridge were stunning. Then a short stroll through the gardens to the Opera House - a must do for all visitors.

Very pleasant interlude in a Sydney sights stroll. Took an OS visitor mid-week on a ferry on the river to Darling Harbour for lunch & then took a lovely long walk through the city, which included walking from the Opera House to & through the Botanic Gardens. Relaxing to amble along up gentle shady paths on a warm day. Quenched thirst with water from a bubbler (Aussie word for 'water fountain'). Not too crowded after main lunch hour, the quiet green space was soothing to the senses. Great views especially from Mrs Macquarie's point with plenty of photo opps for the tourist.Refreshed, we impulsively decided to walk further and ascended the Sydney Tower Eye for an aerial view of the city - amazing to see how far we had walked that afternoon!
Serene. Serene walk during afternoon...! After visiting great architecture of Opera House this walk takes one to nature and gives great feeling in afternoon with cool and greenery.

Autumn Winter Summer or Spring. This walk is one of my favourites. The restaurant /cafe in the Botanical Gardens is a must. Delicious food art reasonable prices... and the outlook - Priceless.
If you haven't been - Go!!

Simply Beautiful. I think many miss this wonderful place as they are captivated by the awe of the opera house and it is not at all obvious where the path past the buildings lead. One is in for a glorious treat with wide pathways, beautiful trees and gardens and a fantastic view of the harbour. While many say that sunset ids the time to see it, we went at mid-day and it was simply glorious
A Walk on the Two Nice Sides!. Altogether a very pleasant walk alongside the sea on one side and the Botanical Gardens on the other although the day was very warm!! Well worth doing!

This has to be done at Sunset!. Sydney may be the one place on earth that is exactly as good as everyone says it is. The pier and Botanic Gardens were pretty special late in the afternoon - we had the birds literally eating seeds from our hands.

Any time of the day. If one is visiting Sydney on holiday then the Opera house and the botanic gardens nearby are places that can be done anytime of the day. Personally I have been to the Opera house in the evenings around sunset time, when it is bustling with people. Also the stroll to the Botanic gardens at a leisurely pace of your own is a very soothing experience.
Wow. Botanic gardens were so great. Perfect for a walk, picnic or a nap in the grass. Great free experience to do while near Opera house.

Absolute favourite in Sydney!. The best way to relax after a long day in a city- stroll into Botanical Gardens and lay down on a soft grass. The view is stunning throughout. Do check the weather though, heat can become a little tiring- make sure there is plenty of water at hand.Next time I will make sure I have something I can lay down on-a scarf, or a shawl. Next time I am having a picnic there!
Long walk in a beautiful and exotic botanical world.. We walked mostly downhill from the City Cathedral through several parks and into the Gardens. It is a long walk to the Opera House but worth it.

Great walk - nice views and very tranquil. This is one place were tourists must take a stroll - but unfortunately, many miss it all together. Just away from the city centre, it is a beautiful walk with breathtaking views and such wonderful parklands and garden rest areas - perfect just to sit and chat or have a picnic. And unlike Central Park, you won't ever need to worry that you are entering a "no-go" zone that locals know about but tourists don't.

It Never gets Tiring. I LOVE Sydney! The only other places that rival Sydney's beauty would be Hong Kong and Victoria, BC. Walking from the Gardens to the House is just a beautiful walk. We have done the daytime and at night (without any problems) it just didnt get old.

Thoughts from Mrs Macquarie's Chair. If I wanted to choose one spot on this walk to pause and reflect it would be this point, before I backtracked and wandered up through the spacious greenery of Sydney's Botanic Gardens. It is a marvellous walk, especially if you approach it, first time, at sea level. This is one of the beautiful harbours of the world. Going as far as Mrs Macquarie's Chair, takes you round the bottom of the garden to a point where you can look back to the Opera House and Bridge and then up the harbour. It's one of those very special places. Then, you can walk up the ridge or back to the bay around which you have walked and begin your exploration of the gardens. I never go with a plan, just wander to see what takes my fancy on any particular day. there's still a lot to see and enjoy. The bonus is you literally step out of the city and into a peaceful park.

First viewing. was treated to an afternoon in the Opera House even got to join in and sing. great fun and would definitely go again. Lots of steps though so bear this in mind. Some escalator access etc.

Restful and scenic walk in the heart of Sydney. The opera house itself is a magnificent sight and from a vantage point, you can see both the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge in one view, which is breath taking. The walk was on a sunny day (very common here unlike in Manchester UK!) and very soon you enter the beautiful Botanic gardens. Ideal to forget your worries and just take in the beautiful scenery and wonderful flora.

Informative and gorgeous. The plants at the Royal Botanical Garden have an identification card and they are beautifully positioned to construct a gorgeous landscape. Along with the Opera House, it's a must when visiting Sydney.

Love the opera house and Botanical gardents. An early morning walk is so wonderful. Clean pathways and safe precincts to walk around by oneself. I walked from the Opera house all the way through the Botanical gardens. The rose garden was worth seeing up there. Just amazing to see such beautiful roses smiling at me in the morning sunlight

Lovely easy walk.. The Botanic Gardens is beautiful and just strolling through is so peaceful. The walk to or from the Opera House is nice and easy and views everywhere. If you have some spare time, its worth doing. :-)
Lovely walk. The Botanical Gardens is a must see in Sydney, very well kept, with some really beautiful plants and trees and cockatoos flying around!

Relaxing. After having a litle drink at the Opera House and took some amazing pictures, I decided to walk through the Botanic Garden. Very beautiful and green, enormous trees and people having picnics, and laying on the grass. Was very relaxing, it is very big but I managed to enjoyed the rose garden. If you like to take photos or macro photos, you will enjoy the botanic garden. So many flowers and birds you can be hours taking photos.

Tour on the train. After walking to the Opera House and taking that tour, it was a welcome sight to see the amusement park-like train and narrator to tour us around the park. Unique plant life and millions of birds. Beautiful.
peaceful. Loved the walk beside the water in to the tranquility of the Gardens, lots of shady walks with different types of plants.
Amazing. all is free to go, just make your time to do it, walk around. I had the hop-on-off bus. It's wirth of taking it. You caan hop off and the next one will take you forward

Lovely walk. This is a lovely walk from either way. We preferred walking from Botanical Gardens to the opera house. View from Macquaries chair looks towards Harbour Bridge, great photos. Can also see Garden Island where navy ships are docked.

Bird life. An astonishingly beautiful place and the variety of bird life was truly incredible, even the cockatils were behaving themselves with people photographing them from as little as 6 feet away. I spent two afternoons sat in the gardens listening to music and people watching , along with several more hours just exploring the diversity of plant and tree life in the gardens.
Nice walk. We did it in reverse -- Botanic Gardens to Opera House. Lovely walk. The Botanic Gardens and the Opera House are both terrific destinations for a day's outing.

Beautiful walk with some harbor view!. We actually walked around in the Botanical Garden first, it was nice and quiet, with many different vegetation, gigantic trees, and open grass field where people can sunbath. We ran into a little iguana standing right on the walking path, so cute! Then we walked towards the Opera House along the water, the view was splendid, we took many pictures! At the Opera House, there are people selling last minute tickets to that night's show, with very reasonable price, too bad we had a dinner date with friends, otherwise it would be so cool to watch a show at the Sydney Opera House!
Must Do. The most amazing spot. Perfect place for the picture of the Harbour Bridge and Opera House. The park is amazing and you can do a picnic there.
Refreshing. With a lovely breeze blowing off the water as we walked along the path from the Opera House to Macquarie point, we were away with the fairies. Superb views, smells, warmth.....brilliant.

A little walk. Well my husband. Had never been here. So we walk around the beautiful we'll keep gardens for. A few hours stop and enjoyed a sit at mrs Macquarie 's. Chair took in the wonderful view of our beautiful harbour. We then enjoyed in the garden cafe a wine and beer which was not to pricey . You can take a picnic which would be lovely in such a beautiful place.

Just Beautiful. This walk from the Opera House through the Botanic Gardens is just beautiful. If you come to Sydney you must do this. Make sure you also do the free tour of Government House within the Botanic Gardens. It gives a great insight into the history of Sydney and the best part - it's FREE !!
Surprised. Not at all like it looks in pictures, well worth a look and if you can, take in an opera, it's amazing

Beautiful!. Botanic gardens are awesome! You need to visit them at once and please reserve at least 2h to observe every corner and see all the beautiful views that are present. Also the Opera house with its iconic view and spectacular position in the Harbour

Must do. This is the kind of thing you can't leave Sydney without doing. Go there on a sunny day and you'll have a great time walking through the botanical garden. Walk all the way to it's end and you'll have a great view of the Opera House and Harbour Birdge.

Enjoyable walk In a gem of a city. I have lived in Sydney all my life and everytime i go Back to the Botanical Gardens for a walk, in and around Mrs maquaries chair and the Opera house, i love it. My wife and I love taking photos around the area, and stopping for a coffee in the Botanical Gardens cafe. It's a must do, not just for visitors but for locals as well :)

Dont forget the pond!. Lovely walk and keep on the waterside path until you see a man made pond on your right. In this pond you are very likely to be able to watch large eels compete with equally large fish for scraps of food thrown into the water.Beautiful views over the harbour beyond the bay to your left.

Take a Walk. We decided to walk to the Sydney Opera House one early morning. After leaving there, we discovered the Botanic Gardens Walk. It was a beautiful walk. It was quiet and relaxing. No bikes are allowed in the parks, so you did not have to worry about being run over by a bike. If you like to walk, just to enjoy scenery, make sure you walk through the Botanic Gardens.
So nice. This is a very nice place to take time, to have a picnic.Take time to listen birds, to discover the flowers, trees and other surprises in this wonderfull garden !

Best place ever. I could walk about here again and again and the whole place is simply beautiful.Well maintained gardens with a splendid variety of trees and views to die for.My favourite holiday destination on the planet, by along way.
Walk with a beauty around you in Sydney. Walk is always good for the body but when walk is along with the best sceneries around you, add a different flavour to the time spent.

beautiful walk spanning along the city. loved the way how view changes from a navy harbour to the city. It starts from Domain, and ends at opera house. There is a nice view of Kiribilli and the housing community there.
Botanic walk. The walk round the Botanic gardens is a lovely thing to do.you can also take the little train if it's too much for you to walk.Well worth the visit

Beautiful views. This is a beautiful walk. If you want a quiet place to sit on the grass, pick up a take away and bring it to the botanical garden. It has beautiful views of the harbour and is very quiet and peaceful place. The Opera House is stunning and the gardens are well tended. We went in March (Fall) so not too much was in bloom. But the trees and shrubs were very nice. A small train will drive you around for a few bucks. The park is very expansive.

My Favorite. This may have been my favorite part of Sydney. The Botanic Gardens near the opera house are not to be missed. There are acres and acres of beautiful scenery along the waterfront and beyond. Flowers, trees, birds, paths, classic old buildings, and late in the evening, some of the largest bats I've ever seen, flying over hear. You can spend hours and hours walking, sitting, looking or whatever - so relaxing! A nice break from the bustle of the city.

Free, invigorating and beautiful walk!!. This one of my walking (and running path), I usually start from circular quay (you can get train to Circular quay station or ferry to her) towards the Opera house, and then stand a while watching the bridge (it's really amazing and beautiful bridge). Continue the walk to the botanical garden, which the Elizabeth gate will be the closest one (the gate open and closed at various time during the year, please notice the opening hour), follow the water and you'll arrive at Ms Macquarie chair (1st governor's wife, where she used to sat there awaiting her husband). Here, you can see the Opera house with harbour bridge at the background (FYI - opera (april) and movie (Feb) held annually every year, YES every year :)) DO not stop here, continue further to ABC (Andrew Boy Charlton) pool, one of the salty water pool, and domain (another park in the middle of the city), further away you'll end up at hyde park, St Mary's Cathedral and Sydney tower. The whole trip usually took around 1 - 1.5 hour (slow walk + stop), if you run, just took you around 30-40 minutes :) Enjoy Sydney mate!!
Beautiful Walk. ITs an Hr and a half walk around the gardens. You can find a pond, cafe and benches to laze around. If its a sunny day, am sure you'll love it.

A great walk. We walked from the Opera House through the Botanical Gardens - we were following a route in a Sydney Guide picked up at the airport. We did get a bit lost in the Botanical Gardens - try and get a map of the gardens as there are paths going everywhere and on the local map I had the exits weren't named.
These boots are made for walking. Just lovely lots to see and immerse yourself in the delights of Sydney. Walking is not to difficult and many photo opportunities for the photo albums.

Beautiful Gardens against the Opera House Backdrop. The Botanic Gardens stand up in their own right but walking from the Opera House along the water to the Botanic Gardens means you get a beautiful view of the Opera House. Most people seem to rush up to the Opera House, photograph it, then leave. You get to enjoy it for much longer if you take this walk.

Beautiful Sydney. We went on a really pretty walk from the Royal Botanical Gardens, past Government house and down to the beautiful Opera House. The Bot Gardens are really beautiful to spend a few hours relaxing or exploring. There are very nice eating and drinking places around the Opera House to enjoy the view and watch the world go by.
Beautiful Walk. We walked from the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens along the waterfront. It is an easy walk and leads into the various areas of the Botanic Gardens.

Nice walk. The Royal Botanic gardens were full of many weddings happening while we walked through. So it made the trip a little extra special with all the love in the gardens. I was disappointed to see a sign asking you not to take the plants. I guess the beauty is not good enough to just leave here and enjoy for all, but those new mini-cameras located at each entrance should help stop the plants from walking out. If you start from the Hospital end and work your way towards the Opera house makes for a nice view when you come around the walk and see the Opera house waiting for you. We missed going into the Government House as by the time we arrived they had already closed.

walk your feet off. If you are looking for a beautiful walk downtown, spend some time in the gardens. You get beautiful shots looking back at the Opera House and the Bridge too! There's so much to see around this side of the Harbor, you won't be bored. Lots of seasonal planting and special exhibits too.

magnificient landmark. unique building but the nicest view is from a distance; inside a litte bit disappointing (as well the infrastructure as the event of top hits - too touistic
if you like to enjoy take a real classic opera in the opera house
Peaceful sights. always a nice walk and gets you away from the sound of traffic in the city. nice and relaxing walk and also great for family or couple pics while taking in the view
Beautiful!. I think that the Opera House and the Botanic Gardens Walk speak for themselves, when I go I walk through the gardens and then along the Sea Wall, what a view! What more can I say?

best place for antsy kiddies who need to get out. Plenty to look at on this cool trek- landmarks- opera house, harbour, native birds, fish, eels, crazy plants, beautiful flowers and incredibly old trees AND gorgeous historic buildings. If you have time the art gallery is at the top of the hill and on weekends they have lots of kids tours and kids entertainment- often for free!

Sydney at it's best. The Opera House is obviously a must see in Sydney but so is the botanical gardens. You can see hundreds of giant flying fox bats hanging from the trees, large eels swimming in the fountains plus all the different brightly coloured birds. The walk to Mrs Macquaries chair is so lovely and you get a really different perspective of the Sydney skyline.

Iconic venue and beatiful Gardens. What a fantastic venue the Opera House is on the waterfront and some great shows to see. The Botanical Gardens are beautiful and with some great exhibits. Sorry to hear the bats have gone but understand the damage they were doing.

Such impressive trees.. The botanical gardens are on the hillside and run along the coast line beyond the opera house, huge trees, smooth grass, and patches of beautiful flowers. Flowers bloom in profusion and obviously enjoy the climate. Agapanthus grow like weeds, oh how I wish my garden was as fertile. The harbour views are particularly beautiful when set against the skyline of large trees and the greenest of grass.
Peaceful and scenic. It was a lovely walk, unfortunately glass house closed for refurbishment and it looked as if everything inside was dying

Urbane and beautiful.. What a lovely morning walk, from the spectacular Opera House around the giant Botanical Gardens (think of New York's Central Park with wild parakeets and ibis wandering around) along spectacular Sydney Harbour. It's about one half to three quarters of an hour. You never feel alone. Sydney's health-conscious denizens are running and walking all around you. Fun.

Stunning walk. This is a great walk through beautiful foliage, lovely exotic birds and their birdsong and great views. Good pathways not hilly easily walkable. You approach a bend & there it is in all its glory - the opera house & beyond it the bridge!!

Opera House tour and the Botanic Gardens was great.. We paid for a private tour of the Opera House and it was great. From the basement, where the sets are delivered, to the top floors where the shows are put on, we saw it all. The tour included a fine dinning experience before the Opera and the Opera, "Tuscan". The show was OK, but the whole experience was great. We also walked the Botanic Gardens next to the Opera House. It's a beautiful park but the season was wrong. We were in their summer after the flowers had bloomed. It was a very quite and peaceful walk. Their is also an Art Gallery right in the middle of the park.
good walk and fantastic view. very nice to spend for quality time with your partner, long walk and the view is fantastic can see opera house and harbour bridge, for photo is perfect.

Excellent walk. we had a free day on our trip so we had a walk around the opera house . then up to the Botanic Gardens , yes we had a little rain shower so we had a cup of coffee in the café in the gardens until the rain past , we had an excellent couple of hours walking around the gardens

Great walk taking in Sydney history and culture. If you've wandered around the Opera House early morning or pm and are thinking, what next, then continue on around towards Mrs MacQuarie's chair (well signposted) and the Botanical Gardens, Domain area. You'll pass beautiful parkland, whilst hugging the bay, and if it's sunny, it's stunning whichever way you look. You'll also take in Government House, the Conservatorium of Music, and if you venture far enough, the Museum of NSW. There are a lot of interesting historical stop offs and statues along the way. No point in going into them here, just grab a free park map. Allow a couple of hours to stroll, and you can actually come out in the heart of the city's shopping district if you desire. All in all a greT entertaining and beUtiful walk.
Great views. The gardens are beautiful. There are birds, flowers, and at one point, you can see the opera house and the harbor bridge. Great place to walk through for free.

Leisurely stroll along the waterfront. From the iconic Opera House to the quiet serenity of the gardens. Take your time to wander around and picnic on the grass with the birds. So nice to have a green oasis in the centre of the city.

Get Up close and Personal with Sydney Icons. A leisurely, flat walk around the Sydney Opera House and through the Botanical Gardens is a breath of fresh air for both Sydney-siders and visitors alike. Even on a warm day, the sea breeze will revive you. Bring your joggers and make it a work out with spectacular views that'll make it seem like an exploration rather than a fitness session...
A walk in the park.... A pleasant walk for all abilities with grand coastal views and varied flowers and trees in the Botanics. Pity the coffee shops in the Botanics close so early.

Classic photos from so many angles!. Beautiful, iconic, doesn't disappoint, at least in the sunshine! Lots to look at and take photos of and, if you do it in reverse, it is magical to see the Opera House and famous Bridge emerge through the trees.

Singing its praises. The building itself is something to marvel at, but the beauty doesn't end there. A tour is a must, the food outlets are a delight, too, and those gardens are a haven of peace and tranquility.
this is a must do!. not a gardens fan particularly but the views over the harbour from here are fab as is the wildlife. parakeets everywhere!
Essential Sydney experience. The view, the walk, the gardens, the harbour, 2 icons - everything a Sydneysider, visitor or tourist could ask for. Love.

Beautiful place. Nice walk during the warm weather. You can loose a lot of hours inside to walk, to sit, to read....to love. Nice promenade between opera and wooloomolo, not too long or to go in the center parks.
Peaceful, pleasant. Great way to spend an hour or so soaking up the view, admiring the view, hanging out on the grass with the locals. good birth watching too.

Lovely, peaceful walk. Relaxing romantic walk with a view of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. You can have a lot of photo ops along the way or can simply sit down and enjoy looking at people walking around.
Easy walk so close to the cbd. A beautiful walk when you want to have a break from the busy cbd. the path make it easy for baby strollers or wheel chairs.

Botanic gardens... Opera house. BOTANIC gardens..
Beautiful walks along sydney harbour, looking across to the zoo, ferry boats crossing and many other beautiful buildings. Very tranquil.
OPERA HOUSE.
A lot smaller in real life.but has a charming atmosphere, people gathered from all over the world. Very expensive to purchase something in the cafe, bars or shops along the strip.
Superb Views. This walk offers some of the best views of the Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge, as well as the central Sydney skyline.
Green heart of Sydney. The walk from the Opera House to the Botanic Garden gives the chance to wind down and relax. In combination with the harbour itself it delivers just pure holiday feelings!
Lovely Setting. Situated beside the always busy Opera House these gardens provide a haven of tranquility. Walk out the sea wall route and return by the Government house and gardens.

Top!. A must do during your trip to Sydney. The Walk along the farm cove is beautiful and once you get to Mrs. Macquaires Point you are rewarded with the prettiest view of Sydney Harbour and the best picture spot you can find. You will see the Opera House with the Bridge in the background! What more can you ask for :)

Sydney Opera House. If you're into architecture (I am completely clueless) I guess this is something to see. Best part about it is the views of the city from this vantage point. If we had had more time, I would have returned in the evening and eaten at one of many small sidewalk cafes overlooking Sydney, I could while away lots of time with a beer in one of those
Brilliant. This is another must do for a first time visitor. The Botanical Gardens in the heart of the city is amazing and the walk a breath of fresh air for all visitors!

envious green. the beautiful flora and the abutting soothing sea makes this place enchanting. a dream come true for any fitness freak. the lotus pond and the rain forest walk are splendid. the open air theatre on the sea front must be a fantastic experience. the walk to the Macquarie Seat is a nice experience.
Cockatoos. Our apartment was just on the other side so we walked this way every day. It was a little warm for us.
Lovely walk. This is such a lovely walk in Sydney. You tend to forget that you're in the middle of a large city - it's just relaxing.

Lovely walk. Stunning gardens,so much to see,could spend hours in the gardens.walked all round the gardens then onto the Opera house took around 2 hours but should have spent more time,but we were limited with time.A lot of people running,very clean and safe .

Every week walk. I had the luxury to have a job closeby so I was able to have this walk almost every week. The view is excellent and especially you can find very peaceful spaces there during lunch time or weekday afternoon.
Walk in peace. Lovely walk from Opera House through Botanical Gardens well worth it.There is an entrance up stairs in building near to Central Quay which makes nice round walk

Great relaxing walk. The Botanical gardens are beautiful, located next to the opera house and free to walk around. nice way to get away from the madding crowds!
Loved the whole experience, nothing not to like!

Great views of the bridge and the Opera House. This walk is popular for postcard pictures. That should say a lot about the views. It's about a 15 minute walk. I walked it once in each direction on separate days.

Must See!!. Don't just visit the Opera House...book a performance. I am glad I did. I saw the Sydney Symphony perform pieces from Schumann and it was one of the most memorable events of my life. The Opera House itself is a marvel but watching a performance within the Opera House is even better. You must walk through the botanical gardens too...I even got to feed the cockatoos!!

Amazing walk with great views. This is a wonderful walk. With the time difference and waking early I went each morning around 7:30 before it got too hot and it was beautiful. There are excellent paths through the gardens to see cockatoos and other birds and the walk along the water watching the ferries and seeing the Opera House was lovely. One of my best photos of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge came from the Botanical Gardens with beautiful red flowers in the foreground.
Great Photos at the opera house. Brillant day lovely food and nice walk. Enjoyed the spetacular views of harbour , brigde, and northern suburbs .

What fun!. I took a tour of the Opera House and yhis was well worth it. Our tour guide had much to share about the history. The Gardens are magnificant. We took the coo choo train and could stop at different locations, allowing us to stop in at the museum. I loved the garden and will return for a longer visit.

Lovely for a Morning Stroll. This is a great walk in the morning, strolling from the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens. Some entrances may be closed in the early morning, but everything is generally open if it's daylight.

Walk on a sunny summer day in Sydney. The walk from the Sydney Opera House to the Darling Harbour area is amazing in the right weather. You will pass through the original beginnings of Sydney's history and learn so much about how the area came to be. The walk is an easy, fairly level trek, so other than having a good pair of walking shoes, nothing else is needed. You'll find lot's pubs, restaurants, shops and sights to see. Check it out. I highly recommend it.

Lots to see and do so allocate plenty of time. We set off early in the morning for the Opera House. Tours around the inside are good but quite expensive. Botanic Gardens on the other hand are free and spread out over large area hence allow plenty of time to explore. Mrs Macquarie's Chair is worth a visit and there are good views of the Harbour from the headland nearby. If you want to take loads of photos the lighting is likely to be better in the afternoon.

Peaceful, pleasant walk ............. Gem of a walk so close to a city centre. Lovely to stroll alongside harbour watching ferries and boats come and go. Beautiful scenery - iconic Opera House and Bridge, flowers, plants. Loved it and did it a couple of times whilst in Sydney.

Opera house and soothing gardens. We actually took the tour of the opera house, which was good and informative and then choo-choo train through the Botanic Gardens. There is enough walking already in the opera house, but it is a must visit, because it opens up the story behind scenes. Gardens are really big and in warm weather, walking might be a little too much, so think about this alternative.......
Mornings are the best time. The best time to walk around is in the morning. By about 1130 the place gets crowded and the joy of walking is all but gone.
Circular Quay. It is always interesting to take a walk around the opera house and also to do a tour of the opera house. A nice walk to Botanic Gardens while in the area.
Nice Place to Stroll in the City. This walkway is a very nice place to tour downtown Sydney on-foot. It connects two of the top attractions in town. Do it in Sydney.

Must do from the USA!!!. Coming from the USA you will wake up early because of the time difference. Get up & walk around the Circular Quay to the Opera House (you'll have it all to yourself) Its just a short walk. Then continue into the Botanic Gardens. Don't be afraid of the wild Cockatoos, the Lorikeets or the Flying Foxes coming home to roost. Just enjoy the beauty. It's perhaps the most beautiful urban setting I've ever seen. There are so many views from here & so much to see. It is a must do.
Lovely walk. We strolled through the botanic gardens before a tour of the opera house. Nicely laid out pathways with gardens of all kinds including a rose and herb garden. Very peaceful.

A Sydney Must!. Really enjoyed our walk down throught the Gardens to the Opera House... Lots to take in & just so peaceful... Love how the skyscrapers meet the garden on one side & the ocean on another...

Potts Point to Sydney harbour.. We walked from our hotel in Potts Point all the way round the coastline, through the botanic gardens and on to Sydney harbour bridge. Took about two and a half hours. You can do it quicker if you walk more direct and not sight seeing. This area is so picturesque it is impossible not to fall in love with Sydney. There are areas just off from the botanic gardens, towards the city, to get something to eat. There are a few smaller eateries on the edge of the gardens. Once you get round by the opera house and ferry quay, there are lots of places to eat while you take in the sites.

Must visit!. There is so much to see here and it is really nice to walk around at your own pace and see what the gardens have to offer. If you are looking for something peaceful to do, this is the spot for you.

Late afternoon on the Botanical gardenheadland.... What a delightful asset to the city. Grab a map and have a good look at what is on offer in the Botanical Garden and the Domain areas, there are so many paths to explore and experience. Witness the fantastic and advanced samples of Australian fauna and garden vignettes. All kinds of birds can be found feeding and roosting in the trees and ponds. Walking around the headlands is a great way to take in the scope of this complex harbour scene, the opera house, harbour bridge and many bays filled with an assortment of ferrys, tour boats and yachts create never ending stream of movement upon the water. Well worth it if you are wanting some time out from the busy-ness of the city.
So Much to See. It was so nice to be able to combine the two sites in one morning. A lot to discover in the gardens and amazing views of the water, the Opera House and of part of the city
A must. This is a must walking from the Opera House through the Botanic Gardens around to Mrs Macquaires Chair and beyond, a great way to see Sydney from the Waterside

Good walk through the garden. We started walking from hyde park through to botanic garden to Opera house, Circular Quay, The Rocks and Sydney Harbour Bridge. It was great. Hyde Park is good and so is botanic garden. Weddings keep going on here. We spotted at least 4 couples in our 1-2 hour walk. If you like walking around greenery in serenity, go for it.

No more spectacular view than this. I've walked this many times, it's stunning in all seasons, has a beautiful view of the gardens, and walking back, to the opera house. There's a little train if you don't want to hike uphill, and it is steep. It veers off into a number of directions to the Art Gallery of New South Wales the main one. Bear in mind this walk is only 1/5 of the gardens as a whole. If your lungs and health are good the walk is great, otherwise grab some lunch and sit under some of the most amazing specimens of fig tree and imagine what the view would have been like 200 years ago. It's stunning.

gorgeous. Is soo nice to walk around and relax in this beautiful big, lush green park. Is great to spend all morning, relaxing, taking pictures; great views is the Sydney Opera House and the bay. Also has gardens with different flora from around the world. Be careful with the big spiders on the trees do!
Nice walk in the freshness. The walk provides for many photo opportunity. There are plenty of nice spots for resting on a sunny and warm day overlooking the harbour.

Beautiful views, flora and fauna, a quiet oasis in a busy area.. We walked from Circular Quay to Woolomooloo bay to teh wharf area via the botanical garden in the evening and were rewarded with great views of some rare plants, cockatoos, ibises etc. The gardens have different areas and paths to enjoy the foliage. Definitely wotry a visit.

Didn't wow me!. Walk was nice and pleasant. My first visit in Sydney. Started at the Harbour with the view to The Bridge and Opera House. Bridge was amazing Opera - not really. Busy place. at the end did enjoy my walk. Superb views and great garden with flowers, trees, birds and landscaping.
Good Views, refreshing. Walk on this is greatly refreshing because of Water views, high high buildings on either side of the walk, greenery and lively.

Add this to your routine. What a great place to run!! As a frequent visitor to Sydney for work, i always add the botanical gardens to Opera House part of my morning runs. It's the best way to start your day on the right note!!

Great way to enjoy Sydney. I did this walk mainly to get a photo of both the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge in the same shot. It was hot, but I got the photo I wanted. A very pleasant walk in the garden, while overlooking the beautiful harbour.
Big trees and lots of birds. Nice shades and perfect view of the harbor. Lots of native birds. A very nice afternoon walk. A perfect place for picnic.

Beautiful walk. This is a very scenic and beautiful walk. It can get very busy but it still feels relaxed. The gardens are lovely. Even if gardens are not your thing; they are a great place to sit and read a book for a few hours.

Botanical Gardens. This beautiful part of Sydney is like a tropical paradise, like old England used to have beautiful kept parks these are now a thing of the past, the Botanical Gardens put us to shame, beautiful trees and shrubs from all over the world spread over a huge area of blissful tranquility. The parrots and birds are very used to people, it's a privilege to be among them.Find your spot and take in the smells, sounds and watch the people walk happily by.
First view. We walked this way to the harbour and were delighted with the stunning view when we turned the corner. It is a truly amazing place.

Nice walk. There are plenty of opportunities to take photographs here, in fact, it is a must. The Opera House steps give one an opportunity to see the spectacular architecture up close. The Botanical Gardens are very close although there is also a walk all around the promontory which takes around 25 minutes and gives a wider view of the harbour.

Lovely way to start the day. The gardens are a must and for international travellers even some Australian birdlife present. A kookaburra, cockatoos and rainbow lorikeets, just to name a few. Lovely outlook and the walk takes you to the opera house.
Awesome short walk. Lovely walk round the bay with the botanical gardens and city in the backdrop. See exotic birds and cuckatoos in the trees as you share the route with joggers and locals.

Beautiful. We stayed at the Holiday Inn, Potts Point, so the walk from the Quay past the Opera House and thruo0gh the Royal Botanical Gardens was a natural path for us. The Gardens were, of curse, beautiful. They weren't as tropical as we had expected, but had much more of an English Garden look to them. Definitely a worthwhile walk on a leisurely afternoon.
Pleasant Walk. Lots to see on the way and a huge variety of trees & plants to exam. If its a hot day then there is a small / hop on / off train to help with the journey.
Beautiful. Make sure you have a free day in sydney to walk around. There is so much to see and we are so glad we did this.

AWE INSPIRING!. The Opera House is truly a MUST for anyone. You should definitely take the guided tour, although it is a little on the expensive side at AUD 37. But considering what they show/ inform you, well worth every bit of it! Lovely restaurants at the lower level, more like street food, which I love. Plus you get discount coupons with your tour ticket on purchase of food and beverages. For music/opera lovers (like me), the full price of the tour ticket is refunded on purchase of a concert ticket! Unfortunately it was raining pretty hard, so couldn't go on the Botanic Gardens walk! But, you have to leave something for the next visit!!!!

Beautiful and refreshing walk. We actually walked from the Botanical gardens to the Opera House. Its a beautiful walk with great views of the garden as well as the opera house. We also happened to encounter a wedding being held at the Botanical gardens at the same time and got to take great pictures...Best part?..its free!
Not to be missed while in Sydney, top spots to see!. Beautiful area with the Sydney Opera House in plan view, can get quite crowded though, either come early in morning or later in the day!

Takes effort to walk up the hill but the walk is lovely and peaceful. Lovey and peaceful. Didn't like the walk up the hill from the opera house. Very close to hotels, bus and taxi service once you complete the walk
Great views and gardens. An interesting, visually stimulating walk, with a magnificent Botanic garden to reward you again and again for the effort, good exercise for all your senses!!

Such a Beautiful Walk. We enjoyed the walk from the Opera House through the Botanic Gardens to Mrs MacQuaries Chair. It was a beautiful day and the only disruption (on a Tuesday around 1pm) were hundreds of runners in groups who had no problem running over the walkers strolling along this walk. That is unfortunate but it did not spoil our leisurely stroll.
A GREAT WALK. Watching the world go by Gardens EXCELLENT so is the shop and the RESTAURANT there was nothing to dislike

Great walk path. After you visit great architect, you walk along the coastal side of the park, then you can reach Botanic Garden. So comfortable and nice. You can also do exercise here. There is just around 20 mins walk. quite good. I like it.

Chill Zone. After the mayhem of Circular Quay and the Opera House areas, the stroll in the Botanic Gardens up to the Sydney Hospital soothes the mind in preparation for the next lot of mayhem of the CBD
Memorable walk. The view of the ocean while taking in the Opera House and outdoor art was unforgettable. Great for people watching. Perfect for families with young kids.
Beautiful. A beautiful morning walk! But the coffee shop in the gardens I was not go for breakfast so we went to Opera Bar which was wonderful.
Some tranquility in a very busy city.. Great place for a great walk for nature and tranquility in a busy city. Great views of the Sydney Harbour bridge, the Sydney Harbour Bridge, and the harbour.
Beautiful for pictures. The Garden is so clean an very active. A lot of places to sit and enjoy the weather and the scenery. A popular area for tourist and active locals.
Nice view of the bay. A beautiful walk around the bay. A really nice scenic walk. Another great way to get to Woolloomooloo

Avoid weekday lunchtime - Jogging Hell. This is a great walk giving good views of the harbour and the city when you get round to Mrs MacQuarie's Chair end.
