Favourite ....!. This has to be one of the best short walks in the world. The harbour, early morning when it sparkles, ferry boats dashing, chugging, ocean liners. And the the birds in the gardens, galahs, parrots, cockatoos, currawongs. The view of the bridge, the opera house sails, people watching. Plenty of seats in the shade if you're that way inclined. On dull days almost as interesting ....! Walk to the Art Gallery, the Andrew (Boy) Charlton pools and cafe which serves the best coffee in Sydney and a view out over the Naval Dockyards.
CONTEMPLATE. Just walk here and try to imagine when the First Fleet saw it! It is now filled with people but still quiet and a place to relax.

Get on your walking shoes. The tour of the Sydney Opera House and its colorful history is a must. It is right next to the Botanic Gardens which will take an hour or more to traverse. Try the tram for a good tour.

Can't believe you are in the middle of a huge city. I meet friends and we walked around from the Opera House - had a picnic and then walked to Lady Macquarie Chair. It is such a beautiful spot with the gardens and the harbour as well as the Opera house. Sailing boats were in the harbour - could not believe you were in the middle of the largest city in Australia

Wonderful view a must do when in Sydney. I did this walk (actually I started from just after darling harbour as you can walk around all of the foreshore apart from where the big construction site is) it's free and the view is WONDERFUL. Go in the afternoon and you will get some beautiful sunset photos with all the great colours of the sky here it's really beautiful and of course you manage to get a bit of exercise in the process :)

Very Pleasant Walk. After visiting the Opera House, the walk along the waterfront and through the Botanical Garden was delightful. Happened on a class of youngsters being mesmerized by their teacher acting out a children's story!

A gem within a city.. Fresh air, harbour breezes, history, culture, views, tranquility. It's hard to believe that this walk is within a stone's throw of a major capital city. Easy to access and a million miles from care.

Beautiful Gardens.. Whenever I'm visiting Sydney I run past the Opera House and into the Botanic Gardens. Being located on the harbour I find this area great for running and walking or a leisurely stroll.
scenic. A must walk , it takes you past the opera house , great views of sydney harbour , the botanic gardens were spectacular , greya pic ops .

Amazing views, stroll & relax. It's a must to take this walk if you are visiting. You'll need your camera as the sights are amazing & iconic. The Gardens are beautiful and the sights of the Opera house & Harbour Bridge cannot be described.

Supurb. Great exercise while not over extending yourself. Walk around the shore line for great views of the bridge and Opera house. Around the point Mrs Macquaries chair has an interesting story liked to the way Sydney developed the way it did. Continue around and stop for food/ refreshments at the beautiful restaurant at the Boy Charlton pool. On the water overlooking the naval base and a beautiful pool. Boy was one of the most famous swimmers in the world in his day and the darling of Australia. His story is a wonderful one.

Nice walk in the gardens. The gardens are beautiful. Many fountains, flowers and statues. Enjoyed watching locals do their daily workouts in the garden area. Nice to see locals and tourist enjoying the beauty and function of this jewel. Saw many different types of birds while strolling through the gardens. Opera House was all that I thought it would be, again tourist and locals enjoying the nice spring day at this attraction.
Scenic walk around the harbour. This is must do , walk around the harbour to Lady Macquaries chair , great views of opera house , botanical gardens

Walkers Delight!!. The walk from the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens is a level walk by the side of the harbour, it only takes about 10 minutes to walk there, and once at the gardens there are so many lovely flowers, trees and shrubs to see. Inside the gardens there is a gift shop and also a restaurant. The gardens are free to enter and there is a land train available for less mobile visitors and children, for which there is a small charge.

An easy walk with stunning views. This is a level walk round the waterfront from the Opera House. It provides stunning views of the harbour and the bridge. The views are even better if you walk up into the botanic gardens, but the coastal path is excellent.If you need a break there is plenty of shade in the garden. Drinking fountains are marked on the map - these tend to be on paths aboth 30m into the gardens
Opera House Tour. It is a very impressive building. I found the total structure fascinating. Enjoyed the story about how they were able to overcome problems that seemed impossible to construct

Easy to get around. Brillant time viewing the surrounds of the opera house as with everything nowadays it costs money for a tour and when travelling with kids it soon adds up, gone are the days of free admission to the opera house sadly.

Great stroll. The Opera House is interesting up close. It makes so much more sense in person than in photographs.
The botanical gardens aren't as densely planted as many, but make a great walk, and give a good survey of regional plants.

The Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney Well Worth A Look!. The Royal Botanic Gardens are next to the Sydney Opera House and Sydney Harbour. It is a cool refreshing place to be in the hot summer heat. There is a lot to see and do and they cater for all ages. We walked around on our own for a wile taking in the delights of the aromas and plant life. There is a free-guided tour of the beautiful gardens if you fancy that where you can discover the history of the original people of Australia. We decided to take the Trackless Train Scenic Tour, which was very enjoyable. Ending our adventure in the Botanic Gardens café where we savoured very yummy afternoon tea and cakes. lovely experience.

Best view of the harbour. This place would be best visited after you have done both the Harbour Bridge and Opera House. The Botanic Gardens is an oasis of calm in contrast with the otherwise frenetic pace of life happening outside its gates. We came after a bout of afternoon showers, and everything inside looked crisp and fresh. The best part of the walk was at Mrs Macquaries Chair, the only spot in the whole of Sydney where you can have both the Harbour Bridge and Opera House side by side each other. A photographer's dream location!

These are world class landmarks you need to see.. Not much to say, except you have to see them. Better than the photos you probably have seen. Not that I'm an architecture critic, but the Opera House is a sight to behold. The Botanical Gardens, which sit next to the Harbor, are wonderful.

An add on to you opera house visit. After seeing the opera house go for a walk in the botanical gardens which are an oasis in the centre of the city ,with fabulous views magnificent plants & trees of all types ,especially Australian . .It is a place for a picnic or for lunch,a place you can spend many hours

Opera House to Botanical Gardens Walk. After a hard days sight seeing or shopping in Sydney the Botanical gardens are a welcome haven of peace and quiet from all the hustle and bustle . A short little walk from the Opera House , the gardens are beautiful with many lovely horticultural and botanical features . Great views of the Opera house and bridge and be seen and admired and you can just relax and enjoy the quiet and the sun.
Beautiful walk, nice views. Very relaxing walk with nice views. The Government house hours were limited so we were unable to visit.

Walk and Talk. A stroll around this path passes the World Heritage Listed Opera House and then heads into the beautiful and peaceful Botanic Gardens. The Harbour laps at the edge of the stone wall as the walk skirts the edge of the cove and on to Lady Macquarie's Chair. It is an iconic section of Sydney and is absolutely worth a look.

The best way to see Sydney Harbour and the city. If you plan on visiting the Opera House most visitors arrive from Circular Quay. If you're staying in the city it's an easy walk to the Quay or there is the Circle train line. The view of the Harbour Bridge and Opera House as you arrive at the Quay still excites me after living near Sydney for over 40 years. It's just an amazing sight! You may be lucky enough to see a cruise ship at the Overseas Terminal - Sydney is a huge cruise destination with many ships leaving and departing each week. The ferries to various Harbourside locations including the zoo, go from Circular Quay. If you plan on taking a tour of the Opera House you should book in advance online as occasionally you may not be able to get a tour on arrival. The promenade from Circular Quay is wide and passes numerous cafes and restaurants. It can be very hot so take a hat and make sure you have sunscreen. The promenade continues around the base of the Opera House and at the far end there's an area where seals like to come ashore on the steps. Continue around the base of the Opera House and you will end up at the Royal Boranic Garden gates. The walk continues around the harbour to Mrs Mcquarries Chair a headland in the east of the park. You can also head off into the central area of the gardens if you'd like a shorter walk. Maps are usually available in boxes throughout the gardens but it's easy enough to find your way around. There are great views of Sydney's skyline and harbour so make sure you have your camera. You can wander through many different types of gardens, take a break at the cafe or buy souvenirs or books at the Garden House. A colony of fruit bats resides in the central garden area so look out for them. There are several exits - one leads to the art gallery and others directly into the city so there are several options where your walk will end. Make sure you allow at least 2 hours - more if you have the time available, and enjoy the walk from Circular Quay to the Opera House and into the Botanic Gardens.

Wonderful Walk. Brilliant walk, easy & enjoyable with fantastic views around harbour and along botanic gardens, well worth the effort. So many times I have been to Sydney and never stopped to do this, so glad I finally did and would do it again in a heart beat so very pretty and well worth stopping to do. Totally recommend it if you have the time.

Opera House to the Botanical Gardens Walk. It's a nice walk, with harbour views and a park land setting. You can go along the water edge at Farm Cove, or via Government House, and the State Library to the south of the Gardens.

Excellent view on the opera and the harbor. The Botanic Garden is just wonderful!A great place to go for a walk, to take pictures, to watch residents of Sydney... just enjoy Sydney. It´s much more quiet than the business district...

Easy walk!. This is an easy walk along the water.. It's very pretty in this area and well worth taking the time to follow the path.. Once you get to the gardens, you're in for a treat.. It's BEAUTIFUL!

Unusual peace and quiet. You'd be surprised with the peace and tranquility that the walk can offer, while enjoying the Bridge view from the Lady Macquarie's Chair. Yet, you are no more than 1 km away from the CBD.

Photographer's delight. The iconic Sydney Opera House, with views of the Harbour Bridge, is a beautiful way to begin the walk. The Botanical Gardens provide a water-side walk around the harbour with lots to see in the gardens themselves. If you're keen on photography you will have lots of great memories to capture here.

Always good. This is one of the more beautiful things to do in Sydney City. Relaxing and very pretty. Better of course on a temperate but sunny day. Watch the boats come and go and enjoy people watching. The gardens are always worth a visit. A haven in the city.
great place. the foreshore around the harbour is great ,the opera house is beautiful to go inside and walk around

Great Views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. This is a hidden Jewel, it's a must see if you visit Sydney Harbour, lush Gardens, great photo opportunities for of Sydney Harbour. it's just a hop, step, and a jump from the Opera House. Do it you won't regret it!
Peaceful and beautifull walk. The gardens are excellently maintained with lots of wildlife if you look for them. The cafe was a nice mid-point resting place.

My favorite walk. In our 2 months of travel, walking from the Opera house to the gardens was a highlight. Very lovely walk and if you do the walk, there is a train you can take around the park. We didn't ride it, as the walking was great.

A Photo Op Walk in the Park. The Botanic Gardens are huge, and right on the water. You round a bend, and there's Sydney Harbor Bridge or the Opera House or Dennison Island. There are ibis birds and cockatoos wandering around loose...amazing! Of course, the flora itself is quite interesting.
Great for People Watching. Get a different view of the Opera House. Sit and watch the people, ferries, boats, etc. Check out some of the old trees and Mrs. Macquires Folly.

Opera House to Botanic Gardens walk & to Mrs. Macquarrie's Chair etc. Walk around the Opera house and then continue past the steps of the Opera House along the edge of the Harbour. You can sit and enjoy the view or continue on into the Royal Botanic Gardens which are very nice.If you walk along the waters edge you can walk around the first bay to Mrs. Macquarrie's Chair carved out of the rocks that existed there. She used to sit there after creating it to enjoy the Harbour views - so they say and yes the view is very nice from here as well.From there continue along the waters edge to see Garden Island Navy area. If you are lucky you will see at least several Navy Ships. We saw the new LHD Helicopter landing ship The HMAS Canberra as it was named today. A magnificent ship built in Melbourne with work carried out by other states as well, like SA - for software/firmware delivery and installation. Something Australia can be proud of.Then when you get to the finger Wharf area, decide to go there for lunch or walk back into the Botanic Garden and enjoy walking through that once again. A couple of exhibits were under re-construction but we still enjoyed the walk through this lovely area. Well worth doing :-)
Good for running. Running along the bay with a Opera House view. What else? Very motivating run but busy on weekends. All the old three are handsome.

Great garden and relax atmophere. A lot of people running in the garden, make you feel so healthy and sunny. The garden is well maintained, there is a train lead you go through the whole garden in a easy way, you can drop off in one station and drop on again.

Opera Bar closed!. Damn, so looking forward to having a drink at the iconic bar, but it closed the day before we got there, for renos for a couple of months. Be careful not to get bowled over by the thousands (no exaggeration) of joggers who make walking really difficult.

Opera house and Australian Chamber Orchestra. The Opera House is impressive and certainly worth to see both from outside as well as inside. We attended a concert by the Australian Chamber Orchestra and despite a big buzz I can tell we were disappointed - though technically they play fine they do not interpret what they play and audience literally falls asleep while listening i.e. Beethoven. So next time I would prefer a visiting artist.

nice walk. this was a nice little walk. while we were there they also had a concert so that was good. One thing to remember is that they do lock the gates so make sure you know how to get back to your car
Iconic Views. Perfect for a wander past the Opera House and take in the views as you go on to the Botanic Gardens. The Gardens are just lovely taking you round by the harbour. Not to be missed.
Good views there. Botanic gardens really worth visiting, the walk is also a good coast walk with views to the Opera and the bridge. Not so many people there, we liked it.
afternoon stroll. enjoyed the nice stroll through the gardens and by the Opera House, nice to see the nicely mown lawns and the old buildings surounding the Gardens

Lovely walk. A lovely walk through the gardens, with various wildlife wandering around. It is a large open garden area with lots of nice parts to walk around. There is also a good café in there for a rest stop with a drink and cake :)

Peace in the City. I have just spent the most relaxing time, in the middle of Sydney Centre. After leaving our hotel I wandered through Hyde Park (with all its gorgeous fountains and flower beds) through the Botanical Gardens and then along the Harbour to The Opera House. Not only was this a highly relaxing walk - it was simply stunning as well. The view of the Harbour is obviously breathtaking, yet beauty for me is also in the small details. I loved seeing all the different flowering specimens in the Park and just loved laying on the grass looking up into the branches of a high Fig Tree. It is also a great place to sit and people watch - with tourists and locals enjoying gorgeous harbour. When it finally came into view, it literally took my break away - it is such an iconic building - the scale and detail of the building is something to awe at. There is lots of construction at the Opera House at the moment, but there are still some great photo opportunities, including panoramic views of the Harbour Bridge. Sydney, I love you. Beauty like this resets my mind and my soul.

Gorgeous scenery, lovely walk. We walked around here on a lovely (but very hot) Sydney afternoon. The gardens have been very well looked after, it was so clean and tidy. There were benches placed around the gardens for people to sit down. It was so relaxing to walk around and soak up the views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Opera House. Could easily get lost in time with the view, just lovely.The only thing I would have liked was a drinking fountain or something as being a 40 degrees day it was very hot and it would have been nice to have got a drink of water.

Free and breathtaking. Doing this walk you will really feel like you are in Sydney, the perfect way to get rid of the jet lag and see the city. The botanic gardens with the city landscape in the background is extremely peaceful and you will get some great pictures of the opera house and bridge together form Mrs Macquarie's chair.

Beautiful views of the Harbour. Great way to spend an afternoon. Fantastic view of Sydney Harbour. Great photos can be taken of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Opera House in the same photo from the gardens. If you don't feel like walking there is a little train that you can take and get on and off on as it goes around the gardens.
Great. This is a really great place for a stroll, walk, jog or a run, depending on your style. Sydneywouldn't be what it is without its harbor, and this walkway really emphasizes this.

Lovely walk. We enjoyed a lovely walk along here and into the Botanical gardens. There are plenty of spots to take good photos of the Bridge, the Opera House and the gardens. The only downside is the lack of shade on the walkway itself.

Stunning walk. Water on the one side, beautiful gardens on the other, well worth taking the time. The gardens are extensive and will take a good hour or two to see around then. Coffee shop in the centre well worth a visit.
Paved walkway. Wow! the views are magnificent as you walk to the Botanic Gardens. It is a pleasant walk for any age. Since it was late spring/early summer we saw lots of flowering trees and plants.
Amazing from both outside and inside. A great place to vist. Best viewed from the ferry as it approaches circulr quay. Adjacent to thr botanical gardens. Plenty of restaurants in the vicinity.
Scenic walk to opera house and sydney bridge. These gardens are a must see, a haven in the heart of the city and you get some great views of the opera house as you walk round great place for a picnic

Best free views of the harbour. The Botanic Gardens are a delight to wander around. More of parklands though. The trees are magnificent. Definitely walk around to Mrs Macquiries Chair on the peninsula & take advantage of great photo opportunities to get the Opera House & Harbour Bridge together. Best to avoid lunch time as you will have to contend with the influx of Sydney's fit fanatics jogging around the park & up & down the steps and it will be up to you to get out of their way!
"Need to walk off dersert". Busy little stretch with lots of goings on around the water with good view to navy ships and great great looking gardens ,afternoon is best to avoid full sunlight

The botanic gardens are great, and free. This huge 'park' is a great way to spend half a day. You don't have to be a plant lover to really enjoy the beautiful immaculate grounds. We thought we'd just do a quick walk through, but we stayed until they kicked us out at sunset.
What's not to love .... Walk Sydney - harbour, Opera House, flora - glass of wine at the outdoor Opera Bar - take a selfie. It's all here for the taking!
Amazing site. Top spot to walk around always something to see happening in the Harbour. Enjoy the outdoor bars & restaurants. The Opera House is a flash venue for performances.

Nice walk in the beautiful gardens.. The gardens are wonderful, you can walk around as you like, no need to follow a designated path. You can decide to walk along the water or directly through the gardens. Many birds, many beautiful plants and rare trees. And free. A must in Sydney.

Great harbour views. This walk along the harbour from the Opera House to Lady Macquarie's Chair isn't too long and gives some great views of the harbour and the city. If you're fortunate enough to visit when the weather is good then you'll return with some impressive pics of Sydney.

Fabulous Botanic Gardens and Opera House. The Botanic Gardens remind me very much of San Francisco's garden areas - very pretty, very well structured. The Opera House - amazing structure and acoustics were beyond incredible.
Amazing relaxing place. Amazing relaxing place, full of difference kinds plants. Really nice view, perfect for sports or pic nics!
Beautiful views. It was an easy walk to the Botanic Gardens from the Opera House and very scenic. The gardens are very well cared for and very pretty.

Great walk ;). Nice walk with some striking views over the harbour. The park is set out nice and is very well looked after. A good way to waste two hours here unless you bring a picnic. Then you can spend all day relaxing. It's a good place to have so close to the city and feels a million miles away fromThe hectic city life.

Take a stunning walk from Circular Quay. If you are staying in the city or travelling by train, start at Circular Quay make your way around to the Sydney Opera House and then the beautiful and relaxing walk around the Botanical Gardens. Just remember to wear your walking shoes and sunscreen. If you are driving, park at The Domain and start at the Botanical Gardens. If you have time you can look through the Art Gallery of New South Wales either at the start or finish as it is right near the Domain parking.

Nice place for a picnic or some solitude. So close to the Opera House ! Nice place to relax and chill out away from the city. Train rides for the kids, and the big kids. Plenty of areas to enjoy the beautiful views without crowds of people
loved it. Very pretty scene, very clean and green, lots to see and do around here, gorgeous photos to get, must do
ALL GOOD. liked everything except jaywalkers and mad cyclists.love the view of the opera house and bridge from Mrs Maquaries chair
nice walk. We stayed in kings cross so going through the gardens is actually the fastest way to get to the Harbour! Very convenient and lovely gardens to walk through. Nice way to see the city!

Best experienced walking to the Opera House from Mrs Macquarie's chair. I'd recommend starting your walk via the Domain, down past Mrs Macquarie's chair and then through the Botanic Gardens round to the Opera House for the best views.
Tip - if you enjoy walking you can continue your walk through Circular Quay, The Rocks, Walsh Bay and Barangaroo to Darling Harbour and beyond... all the way to Glebe).
Take a picnic. Will take up a full day so go prepared and have rests and a picnic and watch the hundreds of lunchtime office joggers

Beautiful walk!. This is once of the best city walks you can do especially if you go through the botanical gardens which gives you a chance to land right on the doorstep of the Opera house with the views of the bay - a must do in Sydney!

A little piece of heaven. I love this walk. Stunning views, beautiful sunsets and just a lovely place to relax and walk around. It is too beautiful for words. You have to go and experience it for yourself. Have a champagne picnic and enjoy the sunset and the sea breeze, nature and views.
Peace. This is a really terrific way of getting away from he bustle of the city, the Gardens are an oasis of peace& calm, while having excellent views of the Opera House & Bridge.

amazing. it´s very nice here, espicially in the late afternoon before the sun will set.
made some nice photos there. I will do it again definitly

Relaxing stroll. After imbibing the fantastic beauty of the famous Sydney Opera House, it's worth one's time to take a walk to the Botanic Gardens along the walkway by the water. Discover well-taken care of flowers and other plants which are more vibrantly in bloom during Spring. Explore the Green House that stands as a glass pyramid along vast truly green lawn. Sit with your special someone on benches scattered around for some quiet and intimate time with each other as you commune with nature.

Stunning contrast between natural beauty and man-made splendour. We walked slowly through the Botanical gardens, stopping and admiring trees and vistas, browsing in the shop and finally emerging on to the harbour-side. We followed the path round to the left until the Opera House loomed into view, like a great ship floating at its mooring in the brilliant blue scene, surrounded by swirling sea birds in the air and swarming people on the ground. The gardens are beautiful and peaceful. The Opera House is equally beautiful and, of course, iconic and has always been thronged by sightseers whenever I have seen it. I recommend spending time in the gardens first, then rejoining the world for a cold drink beside the water, soaking in the spectacular scene of Bridge and the Opera and enjoying the contrast. You could always do it the other way round, though.
Lovely walk. Lovely walk, well paved with great views to keep you going. Plenty of seating along the way to soak up the views and the rays.

Blustery walk. I love this walk, although it was blowing a hot wind on the day. We love the gardens, the amazing trees for which we are so grateful, Iimaging someone planting these seeds and watching them grow!! Wonderful. The Opera House looks stunning as the sun goes down and the bars on the front offer a huge variety of drinks and food. Who could fault it? A must for visitors.
Great views. A lovely walk a great way to see the sites - getting up close to the Opera House and time to enjoy the beautiful gardens. We took a picnic and enjoyed it in the park.

Walked from Potts point to Botanics. The gardens are brilliant so much to see and observe. Was wonderful to vist mrs Macquaries chair. I got a real understanding of native plants and loved the veggie/herb garden

Heavenly. I was training for a marathon when I visited so I made this part of my daily run and it was beautiful. There was nothing like getting up early when the city was shaking off the dust of sleep and beginning the day. The Botanic Gardens was an amazing place to job through, although the bottle trees, the tropical birds and other flora and fauna caused me to slow my pace considerably. It was like jogging through a Disney movie, I kept expecting the trees to begin to talk and eyes to appear in the ancient bark at any time. It's an enchanted place.

Breath taking views. It is a bustling area with so many things to look at. yet if you have been in Sydney this is an easy way to get some fresh air without going far from the city centre. When you get to the botanic gardens be sure to look out for the fruit bats hanging from the trees.

Such a contrast of views. Not a huge walk but lets you see a contrast between a major vibrant CBD with iconic buildings like the Opera House through to the wonderful gardens with a backdrop of the harbour and Harbour Bridge

Crowds. It's a very scenic walk that links one attraction to another, but be warned, there is construction going on at the moment, and it can be very crowded. Also, it's a route where runners do tend to frequent - personally am guilty of running this route myself - but runners do tend to keep out of the way as much as possible.All things considered, it's definitely worth doing the walk.

Such an Amazing Building. We toured the Sydney Harbour Bridge. This is just the most amazing piece of Architecture sitting in a Pinnacle spot on the Sydney Harbour with views of the Bridge close by AWESOME

Do this to get nice views of the whole harbour!. Take this short wall and you will get to a point where you see the Harbour, the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge: a perfect picture spot!We did this walk during sunset and it was very nice, totally recommended!
Peaceful in the heart if the City. We walked through Hyde park, around the Botanical Gardens and ended up at the Opera House.Totally relaxing a must if you are in Sydney
great view. went at night to the opera house and had views of the city. The gardens were the next day .couldn't see everything as we had limited time . Would of liked to see the herbarium.

To be or not to be!. The first time we visited tow year ago part of the promenade was closed to the public and the view of the building was too distant and we were somewhat disenchanted . However, this time we were able to walk all the way through the end of the promenade next to the Park Hyatt and the view was magnificent. Do not miss it!

A lovely walk. There is some construction going on around the opera house walk to the botanic gardens. And on such a hot day there were very few seats to be had in the shade, those that were seemed to be roped off, not sure if there was some grass reseeding going on. But the walk is very pretty and lots of opportunity to takes scenic pictures of the Opera house
Beautiful Gradens. Whenever we were making our way to Opera house always via the Botanical gardens they were just beautiful with Cockatoos and Ibis a plenty

Peaceful.. The walk early morning, mid and late afternoon is just beautiful. Really peaceful and very relaxing just strolling through these beautiful gardens but best avoided between 12 and 2 when the the walk way becomes a running track and just about everyone including the world and his wife just runs. Does get a bit much but otherwise really peaceful.

W O W. What eva hotel in the CBD you stay in, you can take this walk and look at our magnificent Harbour, on a gorgeous morning its our wow factor of Sydney, you might even see a wedding while walking thru our beautiful kept gardens.
gogogo. there hav a lot of plantu go there u will learn a lot thingsso u must gogo go go go
Opera house. Saw a show there, loved the show but was very perplexed about amount of stairs the had to be navigated.....otherwise very very happy with visit

Natural Beauty in the best city on Earth. We picnic in the Botanic gardens once a year. The children love it. It's their favourite thing to do after a trip on the Manly Ferry and a show at the Opera House. There are amazing trees, a wonderful harbour to gaze at, loads of lovely places to picnic and people watch. It's an oasis when you need time out from the busy city of Sydney.
A world icon. Beautiful and one of a kind, must see! Many places to take photos. The walk around the opera house and gardens is very relaxing.

A walk with Sydney's history. This walk is one of the joys of Sydney because you experience some of our beautiful harbourside parks and gardens as well as seeing the layout of the land much as it was when the colony began.Start at Circular Quay and walk around the Sydney Opera House. It was designed by Danish architect Joern Utzon, and later finished by Australian architect Peter Hall and others. It was completed in 1973. Then follow along the water's edge for about 1 kilometre until you come to Mrs Macquarie's Chair which was hand carved in the sandstone by convicts in 1810 for Governor Lachlan Macquarie's wife Elizabeth. Read the inscription and look towards the Sydney Harbour Heads, where Mrs Macquarie would sit each day and gaze out to sea waiting for her husband's ship to sail home around the point. Then you can walk another kilometre or so to the Art Gallery of NSW. You are following a foreshore which is the much the same shoreline as it was when Captain Arthur Phillip first landed here in 1788. In the distance of about one kilometre you will have seen what happened over about 160 years.On a sunny day you will see one of the great harbours of the world in all it s finery, with the sun glinting on the water. The old fort you can see to the North is Fort Dennison, built by convicts about around 1796 as a place to house any hapless convicts who broke the laws of the fledgling colony.By the time you round the point, the path takes you up from the water's edge to a spot much prized by tourists newlyweds to take photos with the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge both beautifully framed in the one shot. The Sydney Harbour Bridge (affectionately known by many Sydneysiders as "the coat hanger") was completed in 1932.You can either take a picnic lunch to enjoy anywhere sitting on the grass and watching ferries and ships bustling about on the harbour. Or you can stroll to an excellent restaurant opposite the Art Gallery of NSW, or another in the Botanic Gardens themselves.

The Opera House to the Botanic Gardens Walk. Don't stop when you get to the Gardens as it is very pleasant strolling through. There is always an interesting exhibition on at the Palm House Exhibition Centre (near the Information Centre). There is also an excellent restaurant if you feel like a special meal in a lovely setting.
Amazing walk. I recommend starts at Woolloomooloo and find your way back to the Opera House through the Botanical Gardens and finish at Opera House grounds.

Opera House to Botanic Gardens. From the trains at Circular Quay a 5 minute walk to the Opera House. Down under on a lower level are shops, coffee bars, and wine shops so the walk can take a couple of hours if you wish. The Opera House is a great place to visit, to tour or just to wonder around, one of the world's most creative performing arts centres. Right next to the Opera House is the Botanic Gardens with beautiful gardens to wonder in/around, to sit and bake in the sun or in the quietness to read a book. Proceed through the gardens to Lady Macquarie's Chair which is the point to look out into the Harbour and take some great photos.
Lovely Stroll. We walked from Darlinghurst road, through the Botanic Gardens then over to the Opera House, was a lovely walk with beautiful scenery

Best views in town!. This is a wonderful stroll through the heart of Sydney. Observe the sunlight playing off the white roof tiles of the opera house as you walk along this peaceful path. Then enjoy the natural beauty of the (free!) sprawling botanical gardens. Very nice.

Must see for all Sydney travellers. Even if like me you aren't a horticulturist or plant enthusiast, the scenery and beautiful scents around the gardens will take your breath away. A picnic in the gardens while watching the boats in the harbour is the perfect way to relax
Wedding in Botanical Zgardens. Attended a wedding in the gardens so did the walk from gardens to the Opera House. Absolutely beautiful o f the most spectacular walks in Sydney nor to be missed.

A nice walk. I love the green and the grass along the curvy surface in the botanic park was just so lovely that my little kids decide to roll down the grass instead of walk :-DThe more we got close to the Opera House, the more we could see different kind of strange, beautiful trees. Really worth it!

Natural bliss - walk around Opera House. If you stay around Sydney Harbour area, be there for a morning walk or jog along the Opera House. You can see the sunrise, which is a wonderful experience and you can see lot many people cycling, walking & jogging. Do not miss the sunrise from the opera house. From the Opera House, keep walking to the Botanical garden. Please check the timing of the garden. You will relish walking through the path from Opera House to the Botanical garden.There are lot many places and varieties of plant, herbs and trees to see. For a botanical lover, it is a paradise.

Wonderful view. Stayed at Shangri La hotel and enjoyed and early morning walk around the harbour, passing the beautiful Opera House. The weather was magical and the views spectacular. Glad to be alive experiencing such wonderful natural beauty of the Sydney harbour.

Beautiful. A great walk with amazing scenery. Easy paths & lots of signposts.
Pleanty of places to sit & watch the world go by.

Best photo of Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Lots of walking tracks through the gardens. We took the train though the gardens which was fun. Walked round to Mrs Macquaries chair which gives the best view point of the Opera house and the Harbour Bridge - the best spot for a photo.
Lovely walk by the harbour and the park. Lovely to walk from the Opera House along by the harbour in the botanic gardens. The Governors House there is well worth a visit.

A gorgeous walk. This walk is lovely...nice and flat and the views are breathtaking. The Botanic Gardens are glorious at any time of year but truly special in Spring. It's so relaxing it doesn't feel like exercise!
weather was perfect and so relaxed. The view is amazing and I love looking at the Opera House. Just looking at it makes me so relax~~ Nice to be able to get away from the chaos within the city :)

Fantastic Walk Along the Harbour with many other auxiliary sites on the way. Set aside 2-3 hours to best experience this walk. This will allow you plenty of time for selfies with the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge as well as a bit of time to visit the Art gallery, library and government house building (all subject to opening times). This walk really is a combination of many attractions in one but is a good way to see all the tourist attractions people rave about in Sydney. The walk itself is pleasant and can be enjoyed by people of all ages and fitness levels.

What a great way to spend a day - free. We walked over the Harbour Bridge, past the opera house and to the botanical gardens. Absolutely stunning. You can walk free the whole way. Views are amazing. The Botanical Gardens are gorgeous with heaps of space to lay out or park chair to sit in. Would be a great spot to spend an afternoon having a picnic. I highly recommend doing this walk whilst in Sydney,

A Sydney must do. Pick a nice sunny day, not too hot to tackle this very pleasant walk. Also have a stroll thru the botanical gardens, a nice cafe in the middle as well. If hot, take your swimmers and have a dip in the lovely Boy Charlton pool.

A must do in Sydney for the famous views.. A must do in Sydney for the famous views.Taking this walk you get the feeling that you have seen this view many times, be it on film or in photographs, but this allows you to take it all in real life. On the weekends you see a lot of locals doing exercise/yoga etc and get a feel for what its like to live in Sydney, which i really like.
very short walk. it's a very short walk for the lazies :-) if you like some laid back walks, this one is short and sweet

The best walk in the city. We started out at "The Rocks", shopping and eating along the way. Passing the Opera house, we got our needed "selfies" you need to have with your travel photos. The main aim was to see the Botanical Gardens. We started at the oldest trees in Sydney and went down the slope past huge fig trees, populated by a variety of birds. They did not worry about us and we were able to get some great photos. The various gardens were wonderful and mature. Great big examples of the plants made it great. Also, listening to the flocks of Cockatoo flying about made me positive that I will never own one. They are raucous. There are also sculptures scattered about that have some age to them. We had a cool, drizzly day, but it only served to intensify the colors. Great place for a walk.
So Beautiful!. I loved taking the scenic route, kind of away from things, but close by everything. I felt like I was walking through some secret garden area!

Like walking, this is a good one and not to strenuous. I love this walk cause if you keep walking along the harbour on the edge of the garden you'll eventually after half an hour or so reach the art gallery. Then you can cut back through the gardens back to the opera house. Near one of the entrances to the botanical gardens that is in art gallery side you may get to see a hoard of cookatoo eating off the ground. Some off them will eat out of your hand. They are gorgeous cute and very vocal. It's an enjoyable experience. The gardens are lovely and you can always find a spot to have a nana nap

The best place to get photos in Sydney Harbour. I've lived in Sydney for 28 years and this walk never fails to remind me how beautiful the harbour views are. From the Opera House walk around to Mrs Macquaries Chair for the best photo position on the harbour. You can get the bridge and the Opera House on your selfie. The botanic gardens are worth a stroll on a sunny day, you forget that you are in the middle of one of Australia's biggest cities.

Must See. The Opera House tour was good and worth seeing. It last a reasonable time and you see nearly all the venue.The gardens are also a must see especially the governors house which is fascinating and set in beautiful surroundings with great views of the opera house.
Nice stroll in the park!. Take any path from the Opera House round the gardens and enjoy the flora.fauna.birds and the views. You could also visit Government House. Very pleasant.

Good place to spend a day.. If you want to relax and walk around with nature, this place is the right spot. The Botanic garden is very spacious. In fact, you can ride a carriage or a train to see around the garden.

Awesome.. Both spots well worth a look. The OP is awesome - but the Botanic Gardens are too. Take your time and allow a few hours. Maybe a bite and/or coffee too. Relatively easy walk - if you take it easy.

AUSTRALIAN PARKS ARE GREAT. Botanical garden, with the Opera House skyline on the back, are gorgeous. Simply great the attitude that australian people manicure the gardens. This kind of good preservation of nature is shared by tourists, that thanks for this magnificent present.
Great Walk. Was a very lovely walk until the storms unleashed rain on us. Check it out and just take an umbrella just in case - very beautiful.

beautiful views. Really nice walk along the promenade to the Botanic Gardens, you can enjoy walking or jogging with a number of others. Usually you will see a wedding happening on the rock ledge near the Opera House.

Wonderful building, scenery and coffee. Opera house is just like a graceful woman sit in there, rely on the Harbour Bridge, with a lot of tourists and sea gulls surround, the cafeteria aside provide us a very relaxed moment and we can save our sight and enjoy the beautiful scenery.
to visit. Another nice place to spend the whole afternoon. There is so may things to do and see in that area plus it's a nice place to have lunch. It was a vey busy place when we were there
A lovely area. Hard to believe the Botanic Gardens are so close to the city, well worth the walk. Stop and look in the lake to see the large eels swimming around.

nice views. Nice for a few km walk if you go all the way around. Great views of bridge and opera house from the spit opposite the opera house. Enjoyed seeing the birdlife in the gardens including baby ducklings. Path was mostly even (accross the water front) and there is a train for $10 if you can't walk but would still like the view.

A must in Sydney!. Visited the place at the occasion of a biking tour. Clearly a must in Sydney. Great variety of plants is a primary reason to come but the cherry on the cake is the views you get on the Harbour and the opera house

Beautiful Walking area. Obviously, the walk around the Opera House is quite spectacular with the views of the water. If you continue around you will enter the Botanic Gardens which are just beautiful. The flowers and plantings are quite lovely. Definitely a great way to start off your day if you are at a hotel downtown.

IT IS A LANDMARK. When coming into Sydney Harbor at 5:45am in the morning, there it is as big as life, greeting us on board the Carnival Legend. I was there 28 years ago and took the tour inside, this time after I left the ship we did the tour outside. If you don't go here it is like going to NYC and not seeing the Empire State Building or Central Park. So this is a must on your to do list.

Sight to remember. Seeing the Opera House from the front steps to being inside is a wonderful experience. Loved walking though the lovely Botanical Gardens and into the different areas even the flying bat area and hearing them! The walk along the gardens and harbour is very enjoyable seeing the sail boats on one side and the gardens on the other. Too much to see to write about and all more than worth the visit! There is also a trolley that goes through part of the gardens for a small fee.
Pretty views, and great for photos. Attractive views, easy to reach from upriver if you're coming in by boat. Good walk to get photos of the opera house and gardens

Fabulous walk. A very spectacular part of Sydney attractions in the central sector of the city. If you have the time to spend wandering around Watson Bay on the outskirts of the Botanical Gardens to the Opera House, you will not be disappointed. Your walk should take you past Mrs Macquarie's Chair at the point of the gardens. From there you get the optimum outlook back to the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. You will not be disappointed. Peter, Brisbane 19Oct14
A must see.. Good photo opportunity of the Opera house and Sydney bridge.. there are also plenty of cafe's to relax at and take in the view.
Probably the most refreshing moments. Just walk through from The Opera House to Botanic Gardens - unforgettable experience. Amazing to have such a sanctuary in the center of town

Spectacular and One of a Kind. This is a must visit if you go to Sydney. This structure is like not other in the world. Taking a tour is a great idea if you want to listen and see the history behind this amazing building.

Well worth making the walk. Superb walk, paved the whole way, you can walk as far as you like, all the way round the headland if you wish. Super views and a wonderful coast path or garden paths, up to you. We love this park.
Best Free Attraction in Sydney. Beautiful walk that includes Stunning Sydney harbourview and the Botanical Park. Take the Government House tour. It takes an hour and is free.

A lot to see. The Opera House is so amazing in person..There was renovation going on at the time of our visit , so there were parts that were off limits..The Botanic Gardens walk was fantastic but the signs that are to guide you to the different sights in the Garden are confusing..We had to circle back on occasion because me missed what we were looking for.
Very nice day. I recommend visiting the opera house, as an iconic image of Sydney, as well as the botanical gardens. It's a beautiful stroll and certainly a must do if you have some time.
Wonderful views of the Harbour !. Great walk to soak up the life of Sydney harbour.Good walking track...easy walk.Worth the time to take in the views.
Nice and romantic. Well paved walkway all the way to the art gallery. Can get a bit windy so bring a windbreaker! Definitely child-friendly and not a strenuous walk at all.

This garden is amazing. .... and so noisy ;-) with all the birds.
I just love this place, quiet, peaceful, and so many different varieties of birds. Great for kids to play with birds and animals or with a ball, climbing in trees. Great for adults to enjoy the walk or to rest with a book, to jog. My favorite spot in Sydney

Stunning views. I had travelled to Sydney many times and never actually done this walk before. OMG - it was fantastic! I would do this again and again! Absolutely beautiful views of the harbour and Opera House. We took so many photos! A wonderful place to have a seat or rest and relax. A sensational tourist spot and the best part is it's free. There is a train that you can take to explore it without walking if you wish. We were just a bit disappointed that the cafe was not open to enjoy a coffee in the afternoon.

The iconic Opera House. A must to walk around the Opera House and see it in all its glory, look for the basking seals on the steps into the harbour.The Botanic Gardens are large but only a small part is set aside for plant lovers, but well worth a visit.

Only one like it in the world. It's well worth your time to walk from the SOH through the Botanical Gardens. First it curves around the Harbour so both the land and sea views are spectacular. If you go inland a bit, you will experience bats in the open as you have never seen them and if you walk the entire perimeter, you'll end up at one of the most gorgeous public pools that sits above the Harbour.

Worth a visit.. Well laid out with amazing plants, shrubs and trees. Lovely escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. Good interesting views across the harbour as you leave the gardens alongside the Opera House.

Good. I had heard a lot about Opera house and had lots of expectation. I am traveling with my family. We all liked the Opera house but as it has been talked about. We didn't have opportunity to see opera night as no ticket was available.

I LOVE Sydney. This is my favourite city in the world.The Opera House is iconic. You should see a show here if you can - book ahead. Treat yourself.The views of the harbour bridge and across to Luna Park and Lavender Bay are beautiful. The walk through the botanic garden also give you AWESOME views of the bridge and the opera house. Be here for sunset.Walk through the park, Bring a picnic. Enjoy!Do some coastal path walking - I think it's the best and easiest to follow in the world.

One of the great free experiences in Sydney. An only in Sydney opportunity to walk or run around The Opera House, beside the harbour through the Botanical Gardens and into Mrs Macquarie's Armchair for a spectacular view of what is arguably the greatest harbour in the world. Do it in 20 minutes or take 2 hours, the experience will be yours to treasure and a fabulous experience for locals and must do for visitors. A great way to access the Art Gallery from the city.

Perfect. I have done this walk many times,and i never get sick of it.No matter what season it is just the perfect place and one of the best views in Sydney.It is a flat walk if you stay on the footpath..But it is the views that is beyond amazing.

Amazing views in the heart of the city. Being close to Circular Quay this walk is easily accessible to anyone. Most recently I took my friends who were on holiday here to take some pics for their trip album. The views of the harbour along the walk are amazing. I am sure every one who visits Royal botanical gardens will take a pic at the Mrs Macquarie chair with the Harbour bridge and Opera house in the background.
Lovely. Great weather to take a walk to the Opera House and Botanic Gardens from our hotel. What's not to like about beautiful views of the harbor, birds and trees and people enjoying themselves?
Gorgeous spot. We would advise strolling aimlessly throughout the lush gardens. The vistas are to die for and taking your time will reward your efforts.

The King And I. We had a special evening seeing the above show in one of the most original and famous buildings in the world . The show itself was excellent , the costumes spectacular and the acting of the children (. And adults ) perfect
Very scenic and peaceful. A relaxing walk around the gardens in full bloom, Nice quiet and shaded places available to just sit and enjoy the surroundings
lovely walk. What and enjoyable walk in a beautiful atmosphere. Many plants and trees to enjoy. Always plenty of company in this beautiful garden. Wonderful place for a picnic
Peaceful and great scenery. Walk along the gardens was lovely and peaceful until the chair when it's packed with tourists. Very tranquil garden well worth a visit.

Enjoyable morning stroll. Walking along the harbor from the Opera House to the gardens was a relaxing way to spend a morning. Seeing the Opera House in person was exciting, as was watching all of the Cockatoos flying around the gardens.

Perfect morning walk. This path is well made, paved and wide, easily accessible by wheelchairs. It's not well covered by trees, though, so if it's warm, there's little shade. The views once you reach the other side are stunning. You can get a beautiful picture in front of the Opera House and Bridge, together, without huge crowds or random people photo bombing you. It's definitely worth a walk over, and then spend some time in the Royal Botanic Gardens while you're there.

A splendid tour, a MUST do in Sydney. If you come and visit Sydney, you must do this tourYou will have an unforgettable view on the Opera (which is really one of most, if not the most beautiful building I've ever seen) and at the Harbour Bridge. I think this is the place where nearly all the pictures of the Opera + bridge were taken fromThe botanic garden is a quiet place to visit, if you have the opportunity, try to have a free guided tour in the garden, you will see it with totally new eyes afterward

Wear comfortable shoes. My legs were kind of tired towards the end of the walk so be sure you've got comfortable shoes to start with! It's a peaceful and enjoyable easy walk with all kinds of trees and vegetations tagged. Can be educational for school children.

Great view over to The Opera House. Great walk with an amazing view over to the Opera House, and a beautiful park, this is one of the best places to take the mandatory picture of family/friends in front of the opera, without a 100+ other random people in the frame!

An amazing park a hop and a skip from central Sydney. Beautiful gardens with an array of plants and art throughout. Well signposted, and much of it provides breathtaking views of the sea or the Opera House.

Great views and interesting gardens. The views alone are worth visiting but the gardens are what is the most impressive. The trees and flowers in Australia are just unbelievable and so interesting. I never thought I would spend so much time looking at root systems on trees or the incredible flowers with birds singing in the background. Australia is just an amazing place. Clean, well marked signs to help you navigate thru the gardens and really clean bathrooms.

Very nice and colourful. It is spring Time now in SydneyYou can see some of the most beautiful roses and flowers in the worldand do not forget the exotic australia native flora and the Japanese Greden

Opera House to the Botanic Gardens???. It's about 25 yards from the Opera House steps to the gates of the Botanic Gardens. It's not that spectacular!But... The Opera House? Just incredible. I've missed seeing it from the Ferry on the way to work every day for the last 11 years. The Botanic Gardens? Just gorgeous, peaceful and idyllic... As long as you don't get run over by the annoying mini train!
Just beautiful. The walk was so relaxing with spectacular views of the harbour and gardens. A must do on your sightseeing list of Sydney.
wear comfortable shoes. Do they entire walk around each corner is another great view. Some great photo spots of the bridge and Oprah house.

Great views along the harbour. If you're keen to do a bit of walking and want to take in the scenic views of Sydney harbour, you have to do this walk. You get right up close and personal with the opera house and then take a great walk along the shoreline past the botanical gardens. Amazing views up and down the harbour, makes for some great photo opportunities too.

Walking the botanical gardens. We took a leisurely walk through the gardens. Very well maintained. It was spring so not much colour yet. We also walked through after the marathon which ended at the Opera house. The gardens were well set up for the finishers with easy access to get back to public transit

Beautiful. Beautiful walk, easy to take some time out and reflect with a peaceful stroll that's not too busy. It's an easy walk that you can take at your own pace. Pretty view, great photo opportunities and a lovely sea smell.
Worth the walk. The walk to the botanic gardens is really worth it, just seeing another aspect of the wonderful city is worth it. We were so lucky with a beautiful sunny day certainly a plus.
Best views in Sydney. Great walk take your time and camera so many photo ops, on sunny day why not have a picnic in the gardens
I can smells te freedom. Sydney's community are so lucky! I just can't get enough of Sydney.so Little time and yet Plenty to see in Sydney. Not the pub or the club but the scenic just awesome!!!
Lovely. Very nice walk, you almost forget you're in a city. You get some lovely views and great photo opportunities.

perfect for a pleasant walk. if it is sunny and lovely weather, this is recommended to spend a pleasant afternoon on weekends. you can enjoy the quality fresh air while being close to the water. Very soothing.
Just taking in rhe sites. While the teenages climbed the sydney harbour bridge we went walking and stop for coffe cake ... Enjoyed a ferry ride on rhe harbour just chilled oit 😄

Iconic walk. Start your morning at Andrew "Boy" Carlton's pool with a morning swim ($6). Stroll through the botanical gardens and take in the views as you turn around and have both the Sydney Opera House and the Harbour Bridge in view! All for free... The dollars saved you can spend having a drink at the Opera Bar overlooking the bridge and the busy harbour!
Must see!. Beautiful and a must-see places in Sydney! You haven't visited Sydney if you haven't visited the Sydney Opera House
Great walk through gardens with views of the city and harbour. The palm garden is excellent as is the herb garden - very enjoyable. The day we visited was cool but sunny. This was ideal for walking.
Nice walk. Took a lot of photos in the garden. I enjoyed the rainforest walk in the garden because didn’t expect to find a piece of rainforest in a city.

Wonderful views of a gorgeous harbour, and it's free!. Sydney is an expensive city. This walk however is free and an absolute must. We hopped off the train at Circular Quay and walked around to the Opera House. We Walked right round the back and kept following the the path with the water on our left. Walked all the way to Mrs Macquarie's Chair for a staggeringly beautiful view.The walk itself took us a good hour as it's a stroll. On the way back we cut through the botanical gardens as they are beautiful also. In an expensive city, this free experience is a must do. Remember the camera and look out for the joggers.
Mmmmm. I'd say yes, walk around the opera house at your own pace, no need to pay 40 dollars to be led and told how to book seats. Best book a show for the inside experience
Best view and iconic sight. Spring is a great time to visit here as temperatures of 20ish allow you to walk and take in all the sights on offer. Don't miss the bats!

Wherever you look the Views are Stunning. This is a walk to be taken slowly so that nothing is missed. The Opera House itself, the Harbour Bridge, the river looking towards Manly, the massive buildings of the Sydney CBD and the calmness and beauty of the Gardens as the water laps softly against the garden wall. All round beauty!

Sydney in a nutshell. Beautiful walk. It starts with the Opera House, which you can walk around and admire, and then it continues through the botanic gardens. They are amazing: you'll see plenty of beatiful trees and plants, giant eels in the main pond, plenty of birds. You end up the walk at the Mrs. Macquarie's Chair, where you can take great pictures of the bay. Highly recommended.

Lovely relaxing walk. Lovely walk, relaxing surroundings, some beautiful trees and shrubs to see. Walk from Circular Quay and the path will take you around in a circle around the gardens. On a warm day we had a nice cooling breeze blowing from the harbour.

A must-do for any Oz visitors. I didn't realize that you could walk right up the steps to the Opera house and not have to pay a thing. Amazing architecture and will be wonderful for all ages. Botanical gardens are beautiful, wonderful smells, and plenty of open grassy areas to enjoy a packed lunch or play with children. Absolutely amazing. could have stayed all day.
Not what you expect of a botanic garden. Great eclectic landscape, beautiful views, amazing picnic spot, bring a rug enjoy the sunshine visit the art gallery, opera house.

Scenic. Took tripadvisor's advice and went on this really scenic walk and it is definitely one the best things to do !!Take the time to stop and enjoy the views.. Stop at Maquarie's point and take picture with the iconic opera house and harbor bridge Continue all the way to skypoint via Hyde park !

Perfect Way to Start the Journey. You have probably arrived at Circular Quay and are now wondering where to start your tour of the city. Well this is just the perfect spot for that.This relaxing walk will take you through this beautiful area of the city where you can admire the fantastic views or just sit down and relax on the grass. The place is full of joggers and middle school kids at lunchtime, gives you a very unique feeling of the city.
Early is good. What a great walk, we did it all 4 days of our stay, and really enjoyed sydney when quiet on weekend morning.
Wonderful. After a very very long flight from Seoul to Sydney, it was fabulous being out in this beautiful park, with spectacular views. It wasn't too crowded either, during winter.
Beautiful Walk. A fabulous way of seeing the opera house and harbour bridge from a different perspective. Avoid the crowds and see an icon from a more peaceful perspective!
Nice walk nice photos. Expect to walk. But you'll be rewarded with a nice view and a pleasant day. We enjoyed people watching along the way and also taking photos!

Did someone say Picnic?. Pick up a sandwich and walk over to the Botanic Gardens near the opera house. The green lawns are just begging you to sit and relax awhile. Take time to relax and enjoy the view.

A Beautiful City Park. It would be a great shame to visit the Opera House and miss out on the walk through the Botanic Gardens. Even if you're not interested in what's growing there, wandering through this green space with the harbour on one side and the towering skyscrapers of downtown on the other is a sublime experience. The cafe in the middle does have a slight air of a motorway service station about it, but it's still a pleasant spot to stop for coffee on your way round. A stroll from the Opera House and back will take you 1-2 hours including the coffee.

Botanic gardens a pleasure to see in the spring sunshine. I always enjoy a walk through the botanic garden when in Sydney, the walk from the opera house to Chair is a pleasure in spring with so much to see in this well kept garden.

Botanic Gardens is a really nice walk. Don't miss the walk through the Botanic Gardens when you visit the Opera House. The Opera House is so crazy, and the Gardens provide a nice break from that with wonderful views of the bay and city.

One of the great urban walks. I walked from the Art Gallery of New South Wales to the Opera House through the Royal Botanical Gardens. What a beautiful--and, thankfully, flat--walk on paved paths through gorgeous plants and trees. Well labeled and well sign posted. Could have spent hours. Picturesque scenes of Aussies at exercise. (You also glimpse Government House, where Wills, Kate and George stayed.) I understand that there is a 1pm docent tour of the Gardens and a (commercial?) trolley ride, if you don't want to walk. One of the great urban walks.

AMAZING. OMG first time in Sydney and i finally saw the Opera House! The structure is very beautiful and so huge! I was not expecting the Opera House to be so huge.... something to know: it was designed to looks like clouds of the sky, not sails. Botanic Garden is huuuge.. beautiful and very relaxing.
Bring a lunch. Plenty of grass and shady places to picnic, relax or nap. Keep an eye peeled for a kookaburra or cockatoo.
Very memorable. This place is certainly very memorable. The opera house is great and the Botanic Garden is very nice and there are plenty of stuff to see.
walk in heaven. walk into heaven at the botanic gardens.. lay a blanket down and enjoy the wildlife or walk around and take in the beautiful nature.
a must for Sydney first timers. The short walk from the harbor to the opera house and then to the botanical garden takes about one hour and is a must for everybody being first time in Sydney

Everything you could ask for in a city walk.. This walk has everything. It's flat, has the harbor on one side, the park on the other, and the path leads to the botanic gardens which are slightly elevated and have good coffee and washroom facilities as well as a great range of plants and water features.
Opera House. Enjoyed walk around Opera House with the Beautiful Views. Enjoyable lunch and eating area at the Opera House.

Hada good walk. Sydney's sunny most days and this park offers a scenic path as you leisurely walk and read about the names of plants. Great photo spot at Lady Macquire's Chair that overlooks the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge.

Lovely walk, watch out for the birds. I thought I would enjoy a sandwich in the park. The birds that I had a great idea. They did not wait for a crumb to drop, but rather tried to help themselves (repeatedly). :-)
Renovation. Lots of renovation work limited access to all areas. Sorry - don't know what the fuss is about. Certainly wouldn't put it on top 100 places to visit in australia

Favorite Walk In Sydney. The more I think back on my trip the more I think about this spot. It was one of my favorite in Sydney. Had an amazing view of the city and the classic Opera House view. The gardens are wonderful (and free, which is great for a college kid). Went several times while I was in Sydney, and would go back again in a heartbeat.

Loved it. The garden is so beautiful a nice afternoon in the garden is priceless and by reaching the opera hourse from it you will get a nice walk and some amazing views of the Opera house, bridge and the Habour

Beautiful gardens, but a long walk. We hiked the entire length if the gardens to the Opera House. In late summer, it was quite hot and not all of the paths were clearly marked.
The gardens are beautiful and the approach to the Opera house from this position is excellent despite having to weave your way around unattractive construction.

Opera House Tour. There are a few different tours of the Opera House. We (family visiting from the USA) did the short tour and it was wonderful, informative with no time wasted in any one area.There are longer tours and tours that take you back stage.I strongly recommend a visit to the Opera House tour website to decide which tour and to make a booking; that is right, no booking no tour.Do not get sticker shock at the cost of the tour, even the short one. You are provided with headsets that link to your tour guide and it is all extreme value for money by the end of your visit.Once you have been up through the House and seen where you are it is quite easy to work up the courage for a self guided tour back out throuhg the Botanical Gardens that spill right into Farm Cove.Really enjoy walking? This is for you.Be sure you walk far enough around to 'Mrs Macquarie's Chair' and maybe even have a swim at Boy Charlton Pool.............a 'saltie right on the harbour on the Wollomoloo side of the Gardens. (minmal surcharge to swim and sun)We dont have Disneyland's, or Six Flags, but we have natural beauty by the FREE tonne full...................if that sounds like you then what are you waiting for?

Wonderful walk despite the windy weather.. This was a great walk with wonderful views and tremendous variety of plants and trees. The walking track was well done and well signposted. Even on a dull windy day it worth the walk and visit

Nothing better than a walk. This is an easy walk flat. Grab a packed lunch and stroll along the foreshore. Nothing better on a sunny Sydney day. Plenty of area to let the kids run. Sit at Mrs Macquarie's chair and look at the harbour.

A delight for the eyes. With so many different gardens of flora to discover, it's hard to determine where to start. A great way to spend a day, clear your mind, or simply enjoy the beauty that nature provides.

Breathtaking. The Opera House is very nice,and it is not fair from the water.Youcan go inside and take a look around.They have plays,people thatcome over from differnt places and play there own kind of music.

Blessed. Having this in the city is just incredible.It is quite a long walk but an easy walk if you are healthy with mid range fitness. If you have a disability walking or in a wheelchair it could be a challenge. The gardens are beautiful having an array of water features, statues, wild life and of course plants.There is no time limit to this activity. If, like me, you like to read most of the informative information dotted around the gardens you will need to have many visits.The restaurant near the Art Museum is very good. We had breakfast which was brilliant!

Must go for Photographers!. Amazing walk featuring both the Opera House as well as the well kept Botanical Gardens. The train could also be used to roam around, but it stops operating by around 5 pm in winters. For those who want to take classic pictures of Opera House in the background of Harbour Bridge and the sunset, make it to Mrs Macquarie's Chair, but you will need to walk about 15-20 minutes as the train stops operating well before the sunset

excellent and easy walk. enjoy the opera house from a different angle and the beautiful botanical gardens!! loads of different trees and flowers and in the heart of the gardens there is a nice shop and restaurant.

Fantastic view at sunset. My husband and I walked from the Opera House through the Botanic Gardens to Mrs. Macquarie's Point. The weather was very fine despite of a winter and we enjoyed the exquisite building of the Opera House, walking though the quiet Botanic Gardens with trees and birds which are unfamiliar to us and the fantastic view of the Opera House and Harbour bridge at Mrs. Macquarie's Point. I was impressed with the interesting rock which looks like a natural stage near Mrs. Macquarie's Point.

walking with pride. Walking from Opera House to the Botanical garden gives a feeling of pride. having had a chance to do the walk with my son . The flowers are in bloom as it is spring time. There is a lot of shade to walk through. Opera House is such a nice palce to visit over and over again. It is the pride oo Sydney and is a must for every tourist to see
Best Views. Take time out to walk from the Opera House to the Botanical Gardens, best views / photographs of the harbour bridge & opera house together.

Great with kids. Easy and cheap day with teh kids. Catch a ferry to circular quay and walk around to Botanical gardens. Have a picnic in the gardens and the kids can run around all day. Feed the ducks the left over crusts

Spectacular view and atmosphere. Nothing is more lovely and enjoyable than a walk between the Sydney Opera house and the Botanic Gardens, right on the amazing Sydney Harbour. I have taken the route both ways endless times, and it is always one of the most beautiful walks in the world.

A great way to pass the time when you arrive early to Sydney!. We arrived in Sydney quite early in the morning, and our hotel room was not to be ready until the early afternoon. We dropped off our luggage for safekeeping and found our way around Circular Quay, up to and around the Opera House and on to the Botanical Gardens. It was a gorgeous sunny day and we had a very pleasant walk with beautiful scenery. My 89 year old father accompanied hubby and I on this trip, and we had a wheelchair to use as he has difficulty walking long distances. We were glad to see the pathway in the Botanical garden was wheelchair friendly, although the slope of the path in places made for a strenuous push! The price was right (FREE!) and we spent a few hours just looking around! There was a train you could take (for a fee) but we chose to walk.

Excellent easy walk. Walked from Darling Harbour to Circular Quay, Opera House to Botanic Gardens. Very easy walking, lots to see. Stopped off at The Rocks markets, as a weekend. Lots to see, eat n drink.

Great for running or strolling. One of my favorite activities in Sydney is to run the Botanical Garden in the morning. It's a great way to beat jet lag and there is always something new to see with the views, animals, birds, people, etc. It is a highlight of my trips to Sydney.

Train ride. It was a warm Sunday after much walking to the Rocks and Opera House and decided to take the small train ride (a fundraiser for a school) through the Botanic Gardens. Lovely place for families to relax and picnic near the water and in the grounds.

Beautiful gardens in the heart of Sydney. Stunning gardens and a great escape from the city and easy access from Sydney harbour. A great way to walk from the Harbour to many of the entertainment areas the other side of the park.

"A Must To See". So much to see in a short stroll. You can enjoy the beautiful architecture of the Opera House, then have a lovely walk through the Botanic Gardens. The day we went it was slightly overcast with a few showers but it didn't take away from the visit at all. Be sure to wear good walking shoes because you'll want to stay all day. Next time we'll be sure to pack a picnic lunch.

I could have stayed all day!. The Botanic Gardens are amazing, and I thoroughly recommend the free guided walks given there by enthusiastic and knowledgeable volunteers. It's worth walking all the way to Macquarrie's Point for the view
Small walk to see best view on Opera House. Walk from Opera House to Botanic Gardens to have the best view. Be careful: many locals use the Botanic Gardens for exercise!

best walk ever. it is a bit far walking from the opera house to the garden but it is all worth it. with a lot of interesting things while you walk past to the garden, the pathway is clean and the the scenery is refreshing
Great for a break from the city. Loved the Botanic Gardens with their plethora of plant and bird species.Great views of the Opera House too
iconic. Was a great walk , exciting to see the opera house for real , a magnificent site on the waterfront , the botanic gardens were beautiful and well signed , a great variety of plants and trees .
Go for a walk and finish at the Opera. Go for a walk at the end of the day on the weekends and finish drinking a beer at the Opera bar. Very nice place to be.

Absolutely Amazing!. The Opera House is an amazing feat of engineering and very picturesque but we were more impressed by the Botanical Gardens, which we hadn't even heard of and stumbled across almost by accident. The Aus$5 train took us right round the park and up the hill to the cafe and gift shop. We had a full commentary about the plants and sculptures and would never have seen so much if we'd tried to walk it. It's a very worthwhile place to visit and is beautifully maintained and planned. You could spend a whole day there if the weather was good and would never be bored. The food is reasonably priced and beautifully prepared and the gift shop is not overpriced either, with lots of souvenirs and unusual items of interest. We were very please we went there. It is a peaceful haven amongst the hustle and bustle of a very busy city.
bai. This was a very pretty walk , very exciting views and great to see the opera house up close , the gardens were beautiful , so well maintained .
Sydney Iconic Place. This place is very popular, you havent been in sydney if you havent been to opera house.There are restaurant and bar so you can relax at this place.
nice relaxing walk. walk with a nice view ;), nice pathway along the waterside.wheelchair/bicycle accessible.signs are clear.

Perfect place for scenic view of opera house and harbour bridge. This walk is perfect with bright scenic views, and in the end, its the best place for photoshoot for sunset. Unfortunately this walk will be closed down at 5PM ( on certain seasons ), and we couldnt make it for the second day evening.
beautiful. great little walk which takes you through asian gardens, road gardens, with the water next to you and beautiful plants it was great, go on a weekend so you can do the house tour too.

great walk with scenic views. The Sydney Opera House is one of Australians best known buildings and the views are amazing, but make sure that you also take the walk to the Botanic Gardens Walk, you won't be disappointed.
Great walk!. In my opinion, the absolute best way to see the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. I didn't truly appreciate how fantastic the two are architecturally until I got these views.

A 'Must-do' walk for all visitors. Don't visit Sydney without enjoying the beautiful views of the Harbour from the excellent walkway that meanders along to Woolloomolloo from the Opera House. On the return trip it's a good idea to cut through the centre of the gardens where there's beautiful trees, flowers and everything in-between. Won't cost you a cent for a terrific experience. 5 stars
good. . It allows you to take photos of the very the real Sydney landmarks, the opera house and the harbor bridge. This really is a must!!!!

A Walker's Delight !. The walk from The Sydney Opera House to the Botanic Gardens is delightful and exhillarating. It is a steady incline so can take one's breadth away ! But if done in the evening,it is very refreshing as the oxygen from the trees & plants of the Botanic Gardens fills ones lungs !
Surprisingly peaceful. We did this on a Monday morning. It is not long before you leave the crowds of Circular Quay behind and find yourself in lovely gardens with stunning views.
Fabulous. Such a wonderful walk. It allows you to take photos of the very the real Sydney landmarks, the opera house and the harbor bridge. This really is a must!!!!

Amazing building. Took the guided tour around the opera house, wow, amazing views. The gardens are so special, well worth a walk, or two, or three around. I am not a gardener, but to we all the different plants etc such a lot of time and effort

stunning. This is a must do in Sydney. The gardens themselves are simply stunning but the best bit comes at sunset. If you walk around to Mrs mqueirees? point the views across the bay toward the opera house and bridge are unrivaled. you can sit and watch the colours change as the sun goes down; fantastic!!
