Iconic.. No trip to Sydney would be complete without a walk round the opera house and botanic gardens.we walked to Mrs Macquarie's chair for sunset. The views of the bridge can't be beaten, it's the perfect location for photos.

Jawdroppinly beautiful. Nothing bad to say about the gardens and opera house. Whole area was spotlessly clean with amazing views and vistas. A great relaxing area for a picnic and let the kids run around. The opera house is so much more impressive in real life, the open air bars that skirt it are perfectly placed for a cold glass of VB or bubbles.

faboulous views of iconic sydney. Get the bus into Woolloomooloo and walk upto towards Mrs Macquiries chair and follow around the harbour into the Botanic Gardens and watch Iconic Sydney unfold in front of you. Wonderful
Delightful. Brilliant little walk, gardens are so manicured, great work Sydney I could of stayed for hours! Can just relax on the beautiful grass, in the sun
Great views. Really nice walk along the edge of the harbour. Found a lovely little cafe/bar at the swimming pool just outside the botanic gardens.
really good walk. this walk was really good. you get to see a good amount of scenery that sydney has to offer. worth your time to do.
Awesome scenic walk!. Not as difficult or far as you might imagined. Lots of oohhs and ahhs as you take in the sights on this walk.

Architecture, history and plants, with swallows chasing us. It is so easy to spend several hours walking round the harbour area and enjoy the architecture of Sydney Opera house and the gardens at no cost. You can sit and rest in lots of places and take in breathtaking views the entire time, and the hotels and cafés are never far away if you want to stop.
Enjoyable. Walking through the botanic gardens is lovely and you can take some good photo's of the harbour bridge and opera house.the walk is not that long and its average.
the walk in the gaedens is aight to behold. we enjoyed the gardens and ended up at the art galley great walk many places to sit and admire views

Enjoy a leisurely stroll and great views.. A lovely flat walk along the edge of the botanic gardens that leads to Mrs Macquarie's Chair. Great place to enjoy the scenery and views and to take photos of the Opera House with the Bridge in the background. We did it a couple of times.
Great to see but you only need to visit once. Is a wonder of the world. If you're in Sydney then yes go and see it but it's a 15-30min job and you're done.

Choo... Chooo!!!. We toured around the Opera House, and walked into the gardens and that is where our "walking tour" ended. Hop aboard the train and get a much faster view of the gardens. The train offeres several stops and gives tons of information about all kinds of things seen in the park. Well worth the price tag if you aren't able to walk far/fast, and want to see important details.

Better at Melbourne. This was a pleasant walk but was far more impressed by the botanical gardens in Melbourne. I liked the easy pace of the garden and watching the runners who sometimes became a bit of a hazard en route!
Could do this every day. This walk is absolutely amazing all year round. It's a very scenic stroll and I highly recommend it.

Fantastic. Iconic views and fantastic gardens. Could lose yourself for hours taking in the harbour views and exploring the gardens. I suggest starting at the domain and finishing at the opera house via the nsw art gallery. So much to see. An easy walk for all ages, wheelchair accessible and lots to see for everyone. With ypur pick of places to eat and drink with a view in circular quay to finish it off.

Amazingly entertaining show, amusing, fresh, creative.. Loved the idea of it, intimate theater, very well presented! The gardens in Australia are so unique, the vegetation and flora beautiful, and so unique!

Beautiful views. We walked from the Sydney Opera House down to Mrs Macquarries Point. The sun was shining, lots of people are running and walking. Its such a lovely walk right in the centre of Sydney. We went as a family and really enjoyed it. We took lots of great photos with the Harbour, Sydney Opera House and the Bridge in the background.

A "must-do" in Sydney!. Weave your way through the crowds around the Opera House area (in Circular Quay), then the HUGE gracious wrought-iron gates to the Botanic Gardens awaits you. You find yourself in tranquility, surrounded by immediate calm. Turn in any direction, and you will be rewarded with an expanse of wonderful scenery: Sydney at its best!

In reverse. We walked the other way. Down from Potts Point, round the Naval Base, (past Russell Crow's apartment!) into the gardens to the Opera House. It turned out to be a great idea, looking at the lovely properties on the hill, staggering down the numerous steps, then arriving at the relaxing gardens and the wonderful trees, with the stunning view of the Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge. The gardens were beautiful as city gardens are, with many people relaxing and enjoying themselves. We wandered around then had a very nice lunch, a little shopping but needless to say, we didn't walk back. Thank goodness for taxis!It was a lovely day.
Extremely crowded. As expected, the place is very crowded. But it is still a must-see. Don't forget to visit the Governor's House, which is free and very beautiful.
Magnificent moments. One of the most inexpensive and enjoyable activities that you can have in this very expensive city. I still strongly recommend it.

The best walk. This is one of the best walks we've ever done. Make sure you do it on a sunny day and start from the early morning, Sydney gets very hot during the day so it's better to do it in the morning or evening. Botanical gardens is so beautiful. Our kids didn't want to leave. They run free tours there, which was very interesting as well. Learn a lot about Australian plants and trees. Loved it!

Ordinary. I really can't work out why this walk is titled. I started from my hotel in Pitt Street, I went along Alfred street up to the park where the Governor's Mansion is. (Open at Weekends). I then carried onto the Botanical gardens and had a wander around, it seemed to me that it just blended into the public park. The Fauna exhibit was closed for renovation which was disappointing. I then went back to the main road that led to the Opera House. This had nothing in particular to note apart from it felt like being in a freezing wind tunnel, the wind comes up from the Harbour and is funneled through the high rise buildings on the left and the rockc/cliff on the right. I'm sure that on a lovely warm day its a pleasant enough walk but nothing of any real note.

Harbour views from a beautiful garden.. I recommend taking the time to walk from The Rocks under the Harbour Bridge, pass Circular Quay and around to the Opera House, then follow the foreshore through the Royal Botanic Gardens all the way to Woolloomooloo.It is a long walk but well worth the time. Take water.
Beautiful walk. This is a beautiful walk among flowers growing wild in this park that we pay a fortune for in Europe. It overlooks The Opera house and with a great view if Sydney Bridge
Prettier than it even looks in pictures. The opera house is a stunning architectural design. And it was a very sort distance to our hotel as was the botanical gardens.

Most beautiful harbour in the world. Sydney harbour is not called the best harbour in the world for no reason. Beautiful walk. It is well worth the walk through the botanical gardens, they are very serene.

On the way to The Art Gallery. We walked from our hotel through The Rocks, past Circular Quay and The Opera House, up through the Botancial Gardens to The Art Gallery of NSW, 20 minute walk but fantastic views.

beautiful. Sydney put on a beautiful winter day, bless it. The harbour was blue and calm, the walk was gentle, so many people out enjoying the winter sunshine, interesting trees and birds and of course, the wonderful Botanic Restaurant.

One of my favourite things to do in Sydney. Whether you are in Sydney for sight seeing or you live in the CBD, it's never gets old. Enjoy the morning or afternoon stroll along the pathway and observe the people and harbor view.

A must see. A visit to Sydney, not be missed, by water or a tour through, the history, all a must to see and do. A great place to sit on the steps outside and people watch. Thousands of photos must be taken here each day.

Botanic Love Garden. Spectacular garden. Walking around the garden is relaxing and breath taking. The view is spectacular.You can see lots of species and trees from around the world. Properly planted and taken care off. The Garden also leads you to Macquarie Point where you can enjoy the view of both the harbour bridge and opera house at one goal. Remember to take pictures and get yourself a drink when you are at the Point. Sip slowly and wait for the sunset. Wow!!! The rest is history.

First time look at Opera house. It was great looking at the opera house.All the while we have only seen it in pictures.Now to be physically there and viewing it was great.Walked up to the steps and sat down.Enjoyed all the scenes and took some photos.
Easy and quiet walk. It is very close to the city centre and it's a very easy and plasant walk. The view to the opera house is amazing.

Gentle stroll along the Harbour. This walk gives lovely views of the harbour and gardens. Look out for fruit bats if you do this in the evening as they return to gorge themselves on the fig trees! During the day the walk is just lovely.
World Class attractions.. A day spent exploring these two neighbouring attractions is a good way to both relax but be at the heart of things.
What you do not see. The Opera House was at one end of the Botanic Gardens and my hotel at the other so I often made the walk as it was aw inspiring and very relaxing.

Abundant blooms. This was a wonderful day. The gardens are extensive with many different gardens to look at & enjoy. We opted to take the small train around so that we could cover the whole place & then decided to visit areas of interest to us. We enjoyed our day & we're not disappointed. Would recommend this highly place on your to do list.
If you love walking and the outdoors..... ....then this is a must walk while in Sydney. Plenty of things to see along the way. From city scape to the harbour scape.
Flowers & statues. Great place to walk on a cool wintry day. Walked from The Domain end to Opera House. Went to see Mrs MacQuarie's Chair.
Stunning Walk. This is a beautiful walk with lovely lawns, garden, magnificent trees and amazing bird-life. An easy walk with spectacular scenery
Amazing. Surprised that we can walk to the Botanic Gardens after taking a tour of the Opera House. Great view for photos.

Awesome Views While Strolling. Having a leisurely walk will bring you excellent views of the city, the Opera House , and the Harbour Bridge going to the Botanic gardens which is also a sight to see. It is quite a long walk , and reaching Mrs Macquaries chair monument would be the highlight with stunning views of the bridge and the opera house captured in one photograph . Be ready to take lots of good pictures.

Stunning Views, Great for taking photos and Free!. We started at Circular Quay and via the Guylain Cafe ( so tasty!) we walked the short distance to the Opera House with great views of the Harbour and the Harbour Bridge behind us.The Opera House is an amazing sight from all sides and angles and tours go on throughout the day of the inside and outside if you want a complex tour. We were happy with walking around the outside of the Opera House and along the waterfront to the Botanical Gardens. The opportunities for photos is great and if you carry on the path you are in the Gardens which are lovely to amble around and fifteen minutes walk from the Opera House is Mrs Macquairies Chair, a historical monument worth visiting!

Average. passed by Government House, quite a nice castle looking building. Free entrance. Was expecting very nice floras and a wide variety of beautiful flowers, but no, you don't get that. either that or i went during winter :/

Very scenic with local wildlife. This walk from the Sydney Opera House via the Botanic Gardens to Mrs Macquarie's Chair is beautiful and relaxing. Water views abound while the gardens, although not as extensive or good as the Royal Botanic Gardens 900 kilometres south in South Yarra (Melbourne, Victoria) are nonetheless quite interesting.There was a poor amount of public (non cafe) seating but we found one. It had recently rained so a few sheets of newspaper came in handy.The native ibis (birds) got a bad writeup in a local paper that day as being aggressive and pests but I found them amusing. Even better was an acrobatic noisy miner (a smaller native bird) who continually swooped past my hand and was suitably rewarded with me throwing a bit of my roll (although bread is not good for native birds or animals as far as I know.)Seagulls and some pigeons were pests (non native) and ought not be fed anything.Unfortunately the Australian native garden near the entrance is closed as the soil is infected with a cinnamon fungus that causes dieback, but one could still view a bit of it.There were toilets near the Gardens cafe. The site is an easy walk from Circular Quay railway station.

Glorious views of the harbour and beautiful gardens. An easy stroll giving different views of the harbour ending in the lovely botanic gardens, where even in winter there is colour and interest throughout the gardens, a lovely way to view the splendour of the harbour and gardens.

beautiful views. This was a very colorful and beautiful walk from the Opera house to botanic gardens. I have done this a few times and loved it each time. Great cool breezes crossing through. Totally a photographers paradise. It is good to do this when the sun sets or else it can be burning hot in summer.

Wonderful View of the Harbour.. Lovely walk from the Opera House with beautiful views of the bridge and the harbour. The gardens are magnificent and provide a lovely backdrop.A level walk all the way round. Keep going till you get to Lady Macquarie's Chair, a rock formation looking out over the harbour used by the wife of one of our early Governors, Keep going up the hill and you will reach the Art Gallery, If you have time, stroll up through the Botanic Gardens and enjoy the atmosphere. You can also see the recently discovered Wollemi Pine.Great way to spend an afternoon.
Must see. Would have liked an "unguided" access to see the interior of the Opera House. Unfortunately, must take a paid tour only. The Opera House area is great for photos.
Show at opera house. Went to see Barmy Britain at the opera house with the children they really enjoyed the performance. And were impressed with the inside of the opera house
Perfect way to enjoy million dollar views. This is a great cheap way to enjoy million dollar views of the harbour and there are many cafés along the way to site and enjoy the views.
Do it. Easy walk around harbour shores with nice views of water and city and see opera house, it's a good way to enjoy the city.
Really nice views abound. You can find some serenity on this walk. Circular Quay can be a zoo at any time. Escape the madness and regain your sanity on a walk that gives wonderful views.

Best for views of Harbour Bridge and Opera House. When you walk around to the opposite side of the rock wall from the Opera House, you have magnificent views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. It is great to stop here for the tourist photos.The walk is lovely and the views are fantastic. Wheelchair and stroller accessible too.

So nice. I went in winter and it was wonderful it is so pretty and the view to the opra house is spectactual :) everyone should do this walk and see it :) but it seems to be the running place... Everybody is jogging there :)

a lovely walk and magnificant views. a lovely walk for tourists and locals alike. world class views, beautifully kept gardens. close to bars and restaurants and the iconic opera house. A great walk and place to take family and firends for a picnic.
Beautiful. Check out the trees at the botanical gardens, these are awesome. There's lots to explore if you love the garden.

Beautiful, scenic walk.. We walked from the Rocks, through the gardens and Government House, over to the Domain, to MacQuaries Seat and around through the gardens at the waters edge around to the Opera House and back around to the Rocks. It was fantastic weather, walk ways that are plenty wide enough for 10 abreast, and all in good condition. A lovely area for a short stroll or a jog. Bikes were not permitted in the Botanical Gardens. There were plenty of seating available looking out to the Harbour in lots of hidden nooks and crannies, that provided privacy, even though you were surrounded by others. A lovely area.
peaceful. beautiful view and well kept. on a nice weather this place is stunning during sunrise and cafes are available nearby.

An easy stroll with great views of the harbour. The walk around from the Opera House to the Botanical Gardens through Farm Cove is an easy stroll that provides great views of the harbour and Sydney itself.

Stunning. The views , coastal beauty , endorphin rush - pace yourself or make it a workout to suit your fitness . Quality catch up time with our son recently . Do the walk each time we are in Sydney - very popular weekends .
Beautiful Seawall. Such a beautiful easy scenic walk along the ocean. Bring a blanket and have a pic-nic, or peek over the edge and watch the puffer fish milling about in the seaweed.

It's a Park!. I'm use to botanic gardens being full of flowers. To me the Botanic Gardens throughout Australia are just parks. The two buildings that would have housde some flowers at this "Botanic Gardens" were closed until 2015!

Great views of Sydney. This is a relatively quick walk (about 20 minutes if you take your time) and is probably one of the most efficient, enjoyable ways to experience the city. The gardens are wonderful almost any time of year and you'll see almost every major city landmark on the short walk. A great place for a run if you want some exercise.

Paradise on earth. If peace and quiet is what you want, you definitely have to check this place out. amazingly serene in spite of it being in the city itself, jogging at Lady Macquarie’s Chair is a most. The Sydney harbour bridge and opera house are best viewed from a distance here

Enjoy the walk. The garden has been well maintained as usual. Beautiful landscape garden making you feel relaxed in such a quiet environment.Only drawback is that the route along the seashore is closed for maintenance.
nice views. very nice coastal walk of around an hour and a half, highly recommended to stop in Bronte for lunch at Three Blue Ducks!!

A walk you must take when in Sydney.. From the harbour around the Opera house and along the walk of the Botanical gardens - fantastic views of the city, wonderful trees, flowers and birdlife - not to be missed. As a photographer, there is no better place to get wonderful shots of the city, the Opera house and the Harbour bridge.
cenery in a city,. great place, good getaway from the concrete for a moments peace, great surroundings, central to transport and shops
Great free attraction, though avoid the coffee. Loved walking around the gardens, enjoyed the different herbs especially! I would ask for tea at the cafe as the coffee was a little bland.
Walking by the water. Really great except in March 2014 they were doing a lot of work around the Opera house which made some photos difficult
Beautiful. Really relaxing and the gardens are a lovely area to walk though and relax in. If you want to go to the Governor's Mansion you will need photo ID with you.

Magnificent Views of the Harbour. This is a walk which leaves you feeling on top of the world. The iconic views of the Sydney Harbour and Bridge, the Royal Botanic Garden and the Opera House are inspirational. It's suitable for all fitness levels and safe anytime of the day, but particularly stunning first thing in the morning. It's very popular with walkers and runners alike.
Nice place. When I do itinerary on our travels, I always look for those free but worth-to-see attractions and this walk from Opera house to botanic garden is one of those.

Great views of Sydney. The Botanic Gardens and the Sydney Opera House are must visit places in Sydney, so taking the walk is definitely a nice way to relax. The walk is easy to follow and provides amazing scenery throughout the whole trail.
beautiful walk. So much greenery in an urban setting is always beautiful. Very nice for a quiet relaxing walk and beautiful city skyline views. Lots of interesting trees, if your not from Australia.
Worth the walk!. The gardens are beautiful and when you emerge from them onto the Harbour and the Opera House it is just magical. Great photo opportunities.
One of the wonders of the world. Great tour of the Opera House don't miss it and gardens and park was beautiful as well. The entire city is a wonder!

Reward yourself with a pie. Either start or end this walk at Wooloomooloo (its a real place) wharf and stop at Harry's Café de Wheels. Fantastic pies, mushy peas and mash is my recommendation. The stroll itself through the gardens is lovely, glimpses of the harbour, city, and culminate at the Opera House and Rocks.

Peaceful Sydney. This is one of Sydney's peaceful walks, along the harbour waterfront... but you may also diverge onto other paths through parkland. It is surprisingly quiet, even though so close the City centre!

Just beautiful. Buy a coffee from a vendor and just stroll. This a tranquil hub in one of the world's oldest botanical gardens. You are getting from point A to Point B but literally stopping to smell the roses.
Beautiful walks. A great way to spend a few hours and it doesn't cost a cent. Some of the best views of the Opera House and the bridge.
Nice short walk. Beautiful gardens. Great vistas. It is such a lovely walk, such a great way to get from point A to point B.

Iconic Sydney Harbour walk. No one visiting Sydney for the first time should miss this walk ( or even the second,third...time). You can see all the iconic Sydney attractions, and enjoy some exercise too!
Walk to Mrs. Macquarie's chair. The weather was great when we did the walk - not too hot or cold. Beautiful views of the harbor and the Opera House. It is a long walk so wear good shoes.
relax, nice. It's just NICE! Great view all along! We saw many couples taking wedding pics there, that means something! It's great for family and couples to have relax afternoon there.

super views. I visited the walk while in the city and found it to be really relaxing and a sanctuary in the middle of a bustling city.
Try and walking all the way to ms Macquaries chair - super views of the city

Hit or Miss. This is a pleasant walk if there are police in the area and if the drunks are staying out of the area. It is physically beautiful and should be undertaken by all ages. It is not physically trying.

Abliet grey skys it was still lovely.. Even though it was grey and raining on and off this was still a lovely walk. If anything it made it less busy. This walk also gives you a good photo opportunity. The bridge and opera house in the backround is a classic.
Pleasing walk. This is a relaxing scenic walk with views to die for. Fabulous backdrop and I love the statues and different sections throughout the park.

Amazing architecture. Seeing the Opera House is a must! We got lucky and got to see it when the "light show" was in progress. The shell roofs were lit up with amazing changing colors which were beautiful. Right by the Opera House is the entrance to the Botanic Garden Walk which is also a must see.
Lovely gardens. Plenty of space to wander, different tree varieties and seating scattered around for those rests to sit and contemplate the views

Great views, lovely atmosphere. This walk and whole area is very pretty and the views are great. I wandered this slowly to take all in with my girlfriend and got up to jog one morning and enjoyed both thoroughly. There are plenty of people about but I didn't find it too busy mid to late morning.

Scenic walk !. We walked around circular quay around the opera house and ended up in the botanical gardens. A lovely walk on a sunny morning. Lots of people out but nothing seemed to congested. The shop at the botanical gardens is worth a visit!
Perfect!. Love this walk. Went right around to Mrs Macquarie's Chair and back to Circular Quay. Best views of the Bridge and Opera House.

A Must. This is a big must when in Sydney, I was here 20 years ago and have been here for almost two months now, and every time I go downtown I find the views awesome, either if you walk, take the bus or the ferry
Opera House tour. Good guide with interesting information about the construction, design, and history of this iconic structure.

Such beauty!. Of course, the Opera House is exquisite. And the walk from there to the gardens quick and easy. Even in the winter, there is so much to see - and hear - in the gardens. The trees and ferns and gigantic leaves of some plants were wonderful. And the birds created a symphony I did not want to leave.
A lovely morning before boarding ship. A perfect send off before starting our 18 day cruise. Opera house is fabulous and the Botanic Gardens beautiful.

very pleasant walk. Easy walk from hotel, Botanical Gardens shop worth a visit for quality gifts and very helpful staff
Great spot for photos

Exiting. The View from the opera house is beautiful. I recommend to visit during the day and night. However the tour inside is a bit expensive.On the other hand, The botanic garden behind the opera house is very nice and for free.
very relaxing. A walk around some of the best views in Sydney. Always worth a walk and relax when you are in sydney

A beautiful walk around the Sydney Harbour's edge. This is a sealed path of easy gradient. Suitable for wheeled buggys and chairs. I love the opera house and the view from Mrs McQuarie's chair. The art gallery is in close proximity.

A lovely walk. An easy walk from the Quay into the gardens with the most spectacular view of Harbour Bridge when you get to the far side. Not too strenuous and can be extended to take in the beautiful gardens and Mrs Macquarie's Chair.

Great walk with lots to see!. Very relaxing walk from or to The Opera House from the Botanic Gardens. The gardens are great to sit back, relax and unwind. The walk along the water front is serene and spectacular.
Great walk. We walked from the opera house to the botanical gardens. Amazing and unique trees and flowers. Very peaceful, and easy or get around

A world icon. One can never get tired of the Sydney Opera House and the Botanic Gardens walk. I have lived in Sydney and even then this is one of my favourite places to visit. Despite the crowd, it is an amazing feast for the eyes and soul. A must see, sit and do place.
Walk. Was a lovely walk not too bad except for a hill in the middle but tKe your time and you will make it. The gardens are beautiful. And you always visit the art gallery of NSW too.
Walking Sydney. Great way to see the harbor, the Opera House and of course the gardens. We were staying in Potts Point and walked from there.

Good Exercise. I did the walk from the Botanic Gardens to the Opera House. I started with a free guided tour of the Gardens that was excellent. The views from the gardens to the Opera House are spectacular and offer great photo opportunities. Watch out for the joggers who make the Gardens part of their run.

Fabulous Walk !. Brilliant lovely green well manicured lawns - the option of a people mover train ride - places to sit and contemplate or to run around and play ninja's which is what my children did while enjoying the beauty of the Opera House, Harbour and Gardens, well worth a visit.

Botanical Gardens - peaceful in the city. Loved this. Amazing plants and it was just so relaxing walking through the gardens. If you want to get away from the noise and activities at Circular Quay this is the place to be :)
An excellent walk. A great walk over the week end with friends and family. Kids loved it as well. Variety of restaurants and cafe available.
Boiling in the Botanical Garden. Beautiful gardens and the Opera House is picture perfect. We were in the gardens on a boiling hot day so it provides the perfect shade!

Great place anytime day or night. Love running around here when in Sydney.
Great run and beautiful view how can you go wrong and add in the view of the harbour bridge as well. Awesome.

good exercise. Come here often for a jog with friends and its agood walk/jog and you get great views of the oprah house. Not only that but as you go through botanic gardens tou may discover australias native plants and animalsas well as plants and animals that have been introduced to australia. The plants are all labelled so you can get fun facts out of it
Good walk for an amazing view. The walk is cool, but the end is definitely the best: a landscape with the Opera House right by the side of the Harbour Bridge.
A must do!!!!. Well worth walking through the botanical gardens. Paying a visit to Mrs McQuires chair and getting the stunning views across the bay of the harbour, opera house and bridge.

A few minutes walk from the Opera House. You can spend a day just walking and viewing the sites of the Opera House access inside the opera house also.Just walking the steps is magnificent but there are lifts available.Botanic gardens are a few minutes walk from the Opera House steps well worth a walk through the gardens and respite break a the lovely Cafe within the gardens.

A walk worth doing.. We had a Studio breakfast tour at the Opera House at 7am. The botanic gardens was just next door, so it was a peaceful and beautiful walk. Especially when I needed to walk off the breakfast that I just ate! The gardens are lovely, but if you don't have time for a pleasure-ly walk, then there's not much to miss. We walked through the botanic gardens from the Opera House as it was also the way to enter the governor's house.
a good walk.. we had lunch at a restaurant bar close to the piers. beautiful sight. good food, great price.botanic gardens is just like central park in NY with less people and quiet surroundings.

Check out the Government House too. We did this walk and stumbled across the Government house, which has free entry on a Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday- its so good, made so by our guide who was soooo enthusiastic - someone who loves her job and clearly gets a buzz out od showing people around. Excellent!

Another classic of sydney. The whole harbour Historic area of sydney is a great place to sight, stop by, rest, take pictures. The view from the botanic garden onto the opera house and the harbour bridge is great. In summer, takes place the open air cinema ( after January).
peaceful walk. Walking through the Botanical Gardens makes you forget that you are in a city. The well kept gardens, foreign plants and government house is a must on the Sydney 'to do' list.

Pretty and peaceful. It is hard to believe you are in the centre of a big city when you are in the gardens. The paths are well used by joggers and people strolling. Had a great coffee in the café in the gardens.

Beautiful. Actually, we went backwards, from the Botanic Gardens to the Opera House. We followed the signs and still got lost, ending up in the gardens of the Government House and unable to get over the fence to the proper walkway, where we could see everyone else, without going back to the entrance. We did that and were able to view the Opera House with the Harbour Bridge in the background. A lovely sight. We had seen it before from the other side so this view was new.

A Walk to Remember. After visiting the Opera House and taking the obligatory photos of the exterior of this wonderful iconic & architectural masterpiece with the wonderful backdrop of Sydney Harbour, have a wander inside then continue back outside and onto the Botanic Gardens. To stroll along the harbour foreshore and then through the gardens is very peaceful and there are a wonderful array of plant species and trees etc for those interested but for others just stopping at one of the cafes or kiosks to take in the scenery and views is a very peaceful experience considering you are such a short distance from the city centre. It does look much better on a sunny day of course!

Nice walk on a pleasant afternoon. Some more maps on the walk might have been helpful. We ended up meandering a bit and probably missed some of the highlights of the garden because we weren't quite sure where we were going. The gardens are certainly in a lovely location right by the CBD

Another obligatory 'selfie'. Sydney Opera House is so internationalized that everybody goes there. If you want a good picture, go early when there's not too many people. You could even book a tour at 7am and enjoy this place relatively 'alone'.

Sydney Vivid Festival in late May.. This light and music festival colorfully illuminates Sydney's iconic buildings near Circular Quay, the Opera House, and Martins' Place. No matter how tired you may be towards the end of the day, do bask in the glow of this light show - easy to enjoy + it's free, outdoors, good for all groups, wholesome, lighthearted, and gives a sense of awe and community. You'll sense why hundreds of thousands of people enjoy this annual festival. Worth going out of your way to attend.

An Icon that is simply beautiful.. The design, the architecture,and the everchanging VIVID color and designs added each night...made seeing the Opera House even more memorable. Do not go to Australia without taking the time to go inside. If not for a concert or performance, at least, take a tour. There is a reason this is an image that represents Sydney.

Stunning views. As you walk around the boardwalk you have ever changing views of both the different parts of the Opera House and across the harbour to the bridge and other parts of Sydney. The refreshing breeze off the water was very welcome on a hot day and as you head along the Gardens walk to Mrs Macquire's point there are many benches - some with shade to just sit and relax and let the world go by.

Fresh air and scenic. Once you've seen the opera house and taken photo's with a million tourists in, you immediately think 'great, what next". Much better to take this walk, extending right through the scenic green botanical gardens and you get a much better perspective of the Opera house. You also quickly forget that you're in the middle of the biggest city in Australia. Very peaceful and relaxing.

Iconic views of Sydney. Offers one of the best views of Sydney and its FREE. You can take the short route from the Opera House along Farm Cove to Mrs Macquarie's Chair on the point and return or loop thru the Botanic Gardens for a longer, very pleasant stroll. We've had numerous family and friends join us on this route and have never had anyone want to cut it short. Coffee, cake or lunch with stunning views can be had at the Art Gallery in the Botanic Gardens or at a number of kiosks scattered thruout
fab walk. Plenty of open space for walking, picnicking and being in the heart of the city.easy distance from most cbd hotels.

Iconic views. This is a must do when visiting Sydney..the views are spectacular! We love the Botanic Gardens, it is a wonderfully tranquil place, with plenty to see, and a lovely walk. You can take a picnic, or eat in the cafe, either way, you will really enjoy the experience.
Amazing in person!. There's nothing like catching a first glimpse at the opera house. What a sight and architectural marvel. The gardens are spectacular and Sydney is just an overall amazing city.

One more tic to my trip adventure!. Finally I could reach one of my dreams. The opera house looks awesome night or day. I really recommend to visit. To take a ferry give you the chance to have a beautiful view from the harbour too.
The Gardens. What a walk, sun views food and relaxating time to be had, even nice on a warm sunny winters day. Try the guided tour if you want to know about the plants, or just walk around yourself.

Beautiful views. This is a lovely relaxing walk along thre foreshore from Opera House to Mrs MAcquaries Chair. There is atrain that can tak you around the are for i fee. But the walk is lovely, we took a picnic lunch and sat over looking the Opera Housse and Harbour Bridge.

Lovely area in wonderful weather!. Lovely meander, beautiful gardens and plenty of lawn for a good picnic.... also lots of waterside and garden cafe's offering good food....you cannot go wrong here! Saw the Vivd lights on the Opera house at night, very nice and fantastical, worth a visit for anyone who has not seen it!

Loved the Opera House. Beautiful at night. It glows in the dark. WE saw the show Chroma. Nice performance. The theatre was quaint. Adult beverages are served. Busy place but worth going to and seeing. Highly recommend seeing a show and enjoying the ambiance of the area. Love it!!!
Lovely walk. They are doing some work in the opera house so we walked at the back of the opera house to the botanic garden. It was a very lovely walk specially because of a very nice view.

Beautiful Gardens. What a cool walk this is. First you get up close to the world famous opera house then you get to stroll through an amazing park/botanical garden. A great way to spend a few hours in Sydney.

The most beautiful building in the world. The shape, location of this magnificent building & adjoining gardens are spectacular. The tour was very interesting and pics at end were very clever, wrll taken and worth the extra cost. You cant do Sydney without a visit here.

Lovely, romantic. The garden is big, and features many different plants and flowers. We even spotted wild parrots on the trees and grass. You can catch a good view of the harbour bridge and opera house together from botanic garden

Great walk with beautiful gardens, tress & fountains.. This is a lovely walk starting from the city and making your way through the gardens and eventually down to the Opera House. They are doing a bit of work around the Opera House at the moment (May 2014) but you can skirt all around the back of the Opera House to avoid all that. Then walk on around to Circular Quay and then back through the city or up to Darling Harbour. Plenty of places to sit and rest such as benches. Some lovely elevated views of the Opera House and Bridge.

Breathtaking Views. This is a stunning walk with so much to look at and photo ops galore. We started from the Art Gallery of NSW and walked through the Japanese Tea Gardens, which are stunningly manicured and a great contrast to looking over the water at the naval ships. Take the upper walk and see Mrs Macquarie's chair andround the corner to simply incredible views of Sydney Harbour. There are plent of places to take photos and none will disappoint. From here we walked through the botanic gardens and they are beautiful, but nothing beats that first sight of the harbour.There were lots of people jogging and it was quite busy but the walkway is wide and there are plenty of places to stop and have a picnic whilst enjoying watching the world go by.There is also a little 'train' (wheels not tracks) allowing those with children and the less mobile to enjoy the surroundings.We took a half day to do our walk, but this was from CBD, and included stopping for lunch overlooking the harbour, plus loads of photo stops. I'm sure you could allow a couple of hours and still havetime to properly appreciate all the sights. I'd highly recommend the full walk as the views as you round the corner of the harbour are breathtaking.

Walk along the habour. I think the best thing about this walk is that you can take a photo of the opera house and the bridge at the end but I would highly recommend a walk through the botanical gardens as well. Easy walk and doesn't talk long but there isn't really any shade so take a hat and sunscreen.

Beautiful Walk. This walk was just wonderful, it is an easy walk for anyone and your see the harbor from a so many views. The botanical gardens were well taken care of and quite enjoyable to walk through. You wouldn't even know you were in a huge city when walking this route.

Great and Easy Walk. This was an easy but very pretty walk which allows you to see a good deal of Sydney from a unique perspective. There are great views of the gorgeous harbor from different vantage points. It is especially peaceful in the early morning and later in the afternoon. All in all, a great park in the midst of a busy and energetic city.

Went around the Gardens and Opera House walk on our first day. Once we had caught up on our sleep after a long flight. We walked into down and went in to the Botanic Gardens and it was lovely. The gardens are well kept, quiet and we walked all of it stopping off and chilling out on the grass and taking in the stunning views. If you have just arrived it is a great start to your stay in the beautiful city of Sydney.

Immaculate Gardens. What a delight to walk through such inspiring and beatiful well maintained gardens. The variety of plants, trees and flowers was amazing with plenty of people just enjoying the sunshine around them. The botanical gardens have toilets and also a small cafe eatery which we found reasonably priced. The garden walk also takes you to other tourist locations and is well worth the wander.

Waterside stroll in heart of Sydney. Very easy walk around by the water, great views of the harbour. If energetic you can walk right around to Lady Mcquaries chair then down to Woolloomooloo. There is a cafe in the centre of he gardens for light food & drinks. Lovely to just lie on the grass and watch the world go by!

If you are in Sydney, You MUST do this. .. this is the easiest attraction to get to in the whole of Sydney. When you arrive by train bus or ferry at circular quay this walk can take anywhere from 15 min to being lost in the botanical Gardens for a whole day. When the sun is shining it is difficult to leave the gardens to return to the high-rise buildings that overlook the area.This walk is the historic location of Mrs McQuarrie's chair one of the early governor's wives, who took a particular liking to this as a morning constitutional stroll

Beautiful walk. WOW - after taking a tour of the Opera House we meandered north - walking through the botanical gardens - where we wee invited to walk across the grass. The cockatoos were happy to ride on our shoulders - gardens lush - provided a very lovely way to get fresh air and a bit of exercise.
Fabulous gardens. Fantastic place to relax and chill out in a wonderful climate, beautiful gardens with spectacular views

Amazing walk right in the city. This walk was just perfect early in the morning before the city started to really come alive. Wonderful views around the opera house and all through the park with lots of local birds flying around for added enjoyment.

Excellent!!!. It's a great walk. I recommend planning a few hours for it too. Give yourself enough time to walk around and see the whole garden and then just relax and enjoy the scenery. Trust me you won't get tired of it.

Perfect Autumn stroll. Now is the time to stroll around Sydney Harbour starting from the Sydney Opera House and finishing up at Botanical Gardens cafe. Look past the renovations around the Opera House and take in the harbour view, give yourself plenty of time to explore inside the Sydney Opera House, maybe take in a free tour, there is also a paid tour which is more indepth. Once you are finished there follow the path into the gardens.Once inside the gardens there are various paths to take, some following along side the harbour wall and the others taking you up past Government House but it doesnt matter which path you take as all are interesting. Follow the signs to the cafe and restaurant, food is good at both places and well priced. Behind the cafe is a gift shop which is well worth the visit. Find time to take in lunch before leaving the gardens and heading off to NSW Art Gallery.The Botanical Gardens are well sign posted and majority of the plants have name plates to assist you. The Gardens are divided into different "themes" and also contain the oldest bridge in Sydney as well.

Amazing walk. This is another of the best walks in Sydney. You can enjoy magnificent views of the Harbor, the Opera House and the City. The trees and flowers are gorgeous. Fantastic photo opportunity during your walk.

Exceptional not to be missed. Every time I walk through the Botanic Gardens in Sydney it always amazes me with it's changing flora. I have visited scores of gardens throughout the world and Sydney's is one of the best maintained gardens I have seen, a credit to the Hardworking staff. Spectacular location on Sydney harbour and next to the Opera house.

Wonderful. Just a great walk to do. I've been to the Royal Botanic Gardens in Melbourne and this one is definitely better. Just huge, and everything is well separated! Great walk to do, to get an other angle of the opera house! Plan to take a few hours to do the whole park and walk all around!

soo pretty. this is one of the prettiest walks especially in the weather we are having in Sydney a the moment - enjoy a coffee at the gardens cafe but watch out for the ibis they can be a little invasive.. Walk over the bridge my kids used to play pooh sticks here heaps of fun

Glorious Harbourside Walk. On a sunny day in Sydney, beside the most beautiful harbour in the world you can walk around the world-famous Sydney Opera House and cross into the Royal Botanic Gardens. The Gardens were set up in colonial times in the early 19th Century and have been maintained ever since to showcase thousands of plants and trees from Australia and from around the world.

Botanical Gardens and Opera House, Sydney. When we have overseas visitors , we always take them to see the Opera House. You can walk around the building whilst getting great photos of the Harbour Bridge in the background. This walk is wheel chair friendly except for getting up the steps to the entrance but if you're really keen to do this then there's a lift somewhere.Then we walk around the harbour wall in the Botanic Gardens all the way to Mrs. Macquarie's Chair as this gives you a great photo of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge together. We then walk back to the pond whilst getting great views of the harbour and the ferries. We usually stroll around the paths admiring the gardens then have lunch or refreshment at the cafe in the centre of the gardens. There's also a restaurant for those who need something more substantial.From there you can go back to Circular Quay or head south west to Macquarie Street and see all the old historic sandstone buildings.

Beautiful introduction to Sydney. Working at a client site in the CBD, I found some cheap accommodation in Potts Point and as a bonus got to walk to work each morning past the Woolloomooloo harbour (seriously - try getting _that_ to spell check!) and up through the Botanic Gardens.Great little walk that takes you over the top of some apartments and shops, and on past an outdoor swimming pool - Andrew 'Boy' Charlton Pool - awesome facility overlooking the harbour; kind of an 'infinity pool for the massses' :-)And then take a turn up through the gardens. It pays to plan your walk a little. Some paths can lead you to a dead end due to the freeways that are underneath the gardens. But beautiful and relaxing

GREAT SUMMER WALK. To escape the heat of the suburbs catch the train to circular Quay and begin youre nature walk from the Opera House - plenty of shady trees and great harbour views -take sandwiches and just lay onthe grass and watch the ships go by

Great little walk.. Ok, let me start by saying tha I'm not a garden/park sort of person & I'm into older architecture than the Opera House offers, but... This is a really nice walk, on the edge of the harbour and the gardens, it offers up great views, an up close look at the Opera House & somewhere shaded with a nice sea breeze when it gets hot.If you not gardens, these are a nice mixture of formal & natural, introduced species & native plants, and the old, old trees and new, seasonal plants.
Great walk. This walk rates as one of the best, the views of the harbour are stunning. You can spend hours just mooching.

easy walk with great views. The walk from the Opera House along the sea wall and through the Botanic gardens is a lovely free outing. The gardens are huge with lots of places to sit and watch the world go by. Great views of the Harbour Bridge, Fort Denison and the Opera House. The path is flat and easy walking or take your shoes off and feel the soft manicured grass beneath your feet. There is a coffee shop which sells sandwiches, cakes etc. and plenty of places to sit and relax. Wonderful if it is a sunny day and just as beautiful if its raining and you have an umbrella. Good photo opportunities of the harbour and ferries, flowers and trees.
Not to be missed!. This is such a beautiful walk, everyone should get out there and do it whether a local or from out of town.

OperaHouse to Mrs Macquarie's Chair walk thru Botanic Gardens. Awesome views of Opera House with The Harbour Bridge in the background. The walk offers a great photographic opportunity to create wonderful images. Mrs Macquarie's Chair offers additional views of the entrance to the Harbour. Also on the way are the Historic Fleet Steps.

Outdoors + Gardens. Stroll from Circular Quay past boutique shops and harbour views to Opera House and admire this magnificent buildings up close to view the beautiful tiles and window shapes. Whilst there take a great picture of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Continue on around the foreshore to Botanic gardens. If you are exhausted from the walk there is a small train at a cost to enable you to enjoy these incredible gardens with great views on the harbour. Beautiful grassed areas to enjoy a picnic lunch.

The most Sydney of the Sydney views. You can understand the magnificence and humble of Sydney walking between Opera House to Botanic gardens; from the only 40 years old Opera house , after only 5 minutes walk , you will discover an immaculate garden surrounded for a beautiful blue harbour..... with a privilege view of the tallest and more modern office building in town. Some of them quite new,,,with the most recent environment technology, reflecting the water .... to just finish the road in the paradice-Boy Charlton pool ( open only six month per year ) just meters away of NSW Art Gallery / All in one.......History, Nature, Modernity and Art. Sydney is waiting for you!

So impressed. Sometimes touring a landmark can be a bit boring, go for the sake of 'we did it'. But in this case we enjoyed every aspect of the tour and the gardens. It wasn't over crowded (end of April) there were like 6 people on our tour and we had a young enthusiastic and knowledgeable guide. We soaked it all in. The gift shops were great. The gardens are amazing, for a casual stroll or for your morning run.
Amazing. Probably my favourite walk whilst in Sydney. I went to Opera House most days, just loved it. Lively, vibrant and fun

..a lovely walk to stretch your muscles after a 22 hour flight... ..with fantastic views of the Harbour..all the ferries that scurry in and out..the wildlife of the area..and fresh air in abundance..it is difficult to find a better place for a stroll..completely flat all the way..

Good walk. If your time is limited, the best part of the walk is to see the view of the Opera House and Bridge in one shot. You start at the Opera House and continue walking until you see the Garden. From there you walk until the end of the path on a hill where you get a great vista of both iconic structures. Afterwards if you have more time, definitely enjoy the Gardens as it's beautiful. We were in a time crunch so we walked back to the Harbour to catch a bus.

Nice afternoon. Walk around the ferry area and the opera house. Have a drink or a snack at one of the opera house bars/restaurants. Great views of the harbour and the bridge. Walk through the gardens to Art Gallery of NSW.
Lovely walk.... It's best to do this walk in the morning when the parrots and cockatoos are active! The gardens are expansive and you are able to avoid the crowds.
Don't miss it!. Fantastic buliding. Take a guided tour so you can fully understand the history of one of the icon buildings of the world. If possible, enjoy one of the several shows

Highly recommended. The gardens are very well maintained and they provided an oasis of green and shade not to be missed, especially on a hot day. Nice views and pictures opportunities with the Opera and the bridge.
Relaxing and good views. This is a good walk for an evening before dinner. Relaxing with good views and then you end up in a restaurant precinct!

Countryside feel at the heart of downtown.. I have visited few of great cities the world including big apple but Sydney rocks. No wonder its highly rated as one of the greatest cities in the world. The Royal botanic garden is indeed well maintained and its in Sydney downtown. Beautiful landscapes and stunning harbour and downtown views makes this walk refreshing. A must have walk on your visit to Sydney.

So quiet in the middle of Sydney. You would not realise you were in Australia's major city,whilst walking the beautiful Botanic Gardens. Historic statues and plaques at various stops along the way, make the visit most enjoyable.

Great walk. a great walks in perfectly maintained gardens. Have a coffee and watch the world go by. Easily accessed from teh side of teh Opera House and is surprsingly large with a wide variation of plants, trees, shrubs etc. a great place to visit

Just simply beautiful!. We started at Hyde Park and walked our way down to the Opera House, which was just fantastic! I recommend you start at Hyde Park, Walk through the Botanic Gardens and end your day at the Opera House, as once you arrived there you really do not want to leave!
Beautiful Sydney. This is the perfect way to see the Opera House, harbour sights and the wonderful Botanic Gardens, and it's all free! Highly recommended for visitors and locals alike.

Orientation Walk. Our first walk while staying in Sydney and a great way to get orientated. Make sure you take in the ANZAC memorial - very poignant. Watch out for the large floating sculptures close to the water's edge on Mrs Maquaries Road - not sign posted but worth a look.

Beautiful. To colour-starved Canadians after living through 6 months of snow being in the botanical gardens and walking towards the Opera House was literally being transported to another world. The scents, colours, the birds and sights! A wonderful way to spend a few hours on a Sunday morning watching the city come to life.

Lovely way to spend a morning or evening. A nice easy walk for anyone of any age! Just walk around and enjoy the view. Early morning is best for the lack of people and better photos with the sun behind you!

View that worth to spend an afternoon. If you would like to travel to the Opera House, I strongly recommend you to start from the Mrs Macquarie's Chair Road. Walk along the coast gave me an unforgettable afternoon!
Easy walk. It is an easy walk from the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens and, once in the gardens themselves, there are many vantage points from which to take that special photo.

The Opera House to the Botanic Gardens Walk. This is a great walk along the water through the Botanic Gardens. It is a great way to get shots of the Opera House and the Harbor Bridge that you can't get anywhere else! Definitely worth taking.

Great start to the day. I do this walk often at all times of the year. It is very easy to do if you are visitor to Sydney. Great place to run but also nice for families and of course lots to see if you have an interest in gardens. Brilliant for photographs of Sydney Harbour as well

Panoramic views. Walking from the Sydney Opera House to the main gate of the Royal Botanic Gardens via Farm Cove, Mrs Macquarie's Point and the Boy Charlton Pool offers some of Sydney's best views. Along the way you can see an interesting folly structure, a delightful horse and foal statue, the tree planted by President Bill Clinton, the place where Queen Elizabeth first set foot on Australian soil in 1954, Mrs Macquarie's Chair, plus lovely harbour views. At a leisurely walking pace with time for photo stops, allow 90 minutes. It is an easy walk on paved surfaces.
What views!. We did this even in the rain and enjoyed it, which says it all. We loved all the birdlife and watching the ferries going back and forth.
The World knows it. The Opera House is known around the world, so how would it be if you didn't go and see it?Certainly great for photos

Nice place and so many things to see while walking.. Its a great place the symbolic land mark of Australia - The opera house. i was really lucky to go there and walked there passing the Sydney bridge and Ferry Terminal. That was nice scenery and evening the place is bid crowd but lot of cafes ,bars, resturents and sovenior shops to visit and satisfy your taste buds while the cold wind blowing from the Sydney bay.

You must do this , so beautiful. This is a beautiful walk, start off at The Opera House and look out to the magnificent Harbour, then walk across to the Botanic Gardens. These Gardens are so beautiful, lots of places to stop and rest or take in the view. Lots of wonderful photo opportunites
Beautiful. Great walk around the point - as of April there is a bit of path maintenance but don't let that stop you; a must-see whilst in Australia.

My favourite walk in Sydney city centre. If you want to get a real sense of Sydney go for this walk around the botanical gardens towards the opera house it's breath taking. And great to see the opera house from different angles.

A quieter aspect of Sydney. This is a well paved are and is easy to walk along. We were there in March and they were doing repairs and we were diverted through the gardens, not that his is an issue. It's a lovely walk around the waters edge and with the gardens being one side of the path and the water the other, there is a sense of not being in a big city.
A MUST!. I took the walk, and was amazed by the view (Opera and bridge) and by the atmosphere. you will not be able to resist for short stop in the gardens after that.

Peaceful. Doesn't feel like you are in the centre of one of the world's major cities. Amazing plants, sculptures, wildlife and so peaceful. Wasn't very busy either so you felt completely free to wander around and relax in this beautiful space.

quiet oasis in a bustling city. The Botanic gardens are a great place to visit to get away from the hustle bustle of the city. Allow plenty of time and take it easy as you meander around the garden paths. If you are a plantsman you will enjoy the wide variety of flora on display. The views over the harbour are fantastic. On a hot day take plenty of liquid. There are a few cafes for refreshments. Arachnophobic? There are some pretty big spiders in the park which weave their webs in the trees and sit in the middle enjoying the reaction they get from unwary visitors. These boys are big (compared to our British house guys) but they are located in very specific locations. This is not a zoo, these are the locals.
Shame about all the building works. A lovely walk, spoilt a touch currently by the amount of construction work going on. Guess the timing of my visit was unlucky

Nice walk to experience Sydney. The walk from the Opera house to the Botanic Gardens is quite nice and peaceful, leading you along the water. The gardens are very beautiful and a perfect place for jogging. It's a nice stroll in a big city, showing you another side of Sydney apart from the sky scrapers.

Not to be missed. This is our 7th trip to NSW. We always include a few days in Sydney and always walk through Hyde Park and the Domain to The Botanic Gardens. There are so many different paths to take an things to see. The flora and fauna are always different and there is always something new to see. We then end up at the Opera House which is spectacular. Always a pleasure just to be there. The guided tour is very worthwhile and most interesting.

The best of Sydney's sites in a short walk. The new lift between Circular Quay and the walkway to the botanic gardens is great for those with limited mobility, and leads to an entrance close to Government House. The Government House architecture and surrounding gardens is a must to check out, and includes some of the best views of the bay. Government House gardens close before 4 pm, though, and the cops on the beat don't appreciate people stalling, so try to get there early! The botanic gardens includes a range of themed gardens, or fantastic greens for picnics etc.
Good value. Too much to see and so little time so the little guided train trip around the Botanic Gardens was perfect, Saved a lot of walking and we got a botanic lesson to boot. Recommended.
Gardens are a feast for nature lovers. Visited these gardens many times before but there is always something new to see when we come from the UK to Australia

Loved the walk.. Didn't bother with the Opera House tour although by the looks of the crowds we were in the minority. On the expensive side. Enjoyed tea in the restaurant on the ground floor. Obviously magnificent structure and the view was outstanding.Thoroughly recommend a walk through the botanic gardens. Beautiful and relaxing.
Tranquility in the City. Beautiful gardens and just a beautiful walk on a nice day. There is also a lot of native birds in the trees and it makes a lovely place for a picnic for a family.
Relax and Animal Sightseeing. You enter the garden and you feel like in a different world. Things slow down and you can enjoy to hang around or watch the different birds, fish and ducks. Great day

Walk on the wild side. The Opera House in the sun is spectacular and the walk round this to the Botanical Gardens was beautiful. The Botanical Gardens were relaxing and pretty. One surprising thing was the birds flying free in the Gardens. Colourful Parrots and Cockatoos flying freely and feeding with the locals and visitors. This a relaxing park and has excellent views across Sydney Harbour to the famous Bridge and Opera house. Visitors from around the world were enjoying the relaxing park and views, all for free.
Lovely walk. Awesome views. Love this place. Lots of places for the kids to explore and stop and rest. Love the view and tranquility.

Walk around the Gardens. The entrance to the Gardens is at the Opera House. A Walk around the gardens from the Opera House takes you around the harbour and then into the beautiful gardens originally laid out by Lady Macquarie
Beautiful walk. The walk from the opera house in sydney to the botanic gardens is a short and lovely walk. Beautiful views of the water, it's worth taking the time to walk this short bit.

Beautiful place to stroll around. Such a beautiful back drop and views from the Opera House and the Gardens. We walked for miles and were fascinated by the amount of fitness conscious people there were about in the park, which was great to see; from school children to the office workers lunch break. What a place to live.
Amazing. Its free, romantic and you feel alive and happy just wandering around this great building and then into the gardens with views to die for.

Great views at a peaceful pace. A beautiful area of Sydney centre. The gardens are beautifully kept and are a real pleasure to explore. The views are breathtaking especially when you get closer to the opera house. A very well worn piece of grass marks the best spot for a fantastic picture of the Opera house.

Brilliant. We walked from our hotel to the Opera House what a view and then on to the Botanic gardens.The Botanic Gardens are worth a visit if in this area, so beautiful and well kept plenty of places to sit and sculptors to see in amongst the shrubbery, well laid out with lovely view of the harbour. Government house is in the grounds which you can tours round, we didn't do it as it on certain days.

Amazing building & fab tour. Loved the building, definately advise that you take the tour of the Opera house. Our guide was very informative & we even got to see some of the artists in dress rehearsal. The botanic gardens are located right next to the Opera house & are absolutely stunning.well worth a visit.
foreshore walk extraordinary. See the best of Sydney, its attractions & its harbour while walking or jogging through beautiful parklands along our beautiful foreshore

Best of both worlds!. Here you will find the best of both worlds - the exhilaration of exploring the Sydney Opera House and the soothing elixir of a walk through the Botanic Gardens. There is so much to see and do whilst taking in the breathtaking views of the harbour. Sydney has one of the most beautiful harbours in the world and there is no better way to experience this than standing in front of the Opera House and and capturing those outstanding photo snaps to take back home. The Opera House has many nooks and crannies to explore. The kids will love it and the memory will last a lifetime. After this you can indulge in a gastronomic delight at one of the many, many restaurant/cafes lining the foreshore. Then, it's time to walk off those calories so get on your walking shoes to visit the Botanic Gardens. This is a lovely way to spend an afternoon. Experience the tranquillity and serenity of nature at its best while drinking in the beautiful flora and fauna that the gardens have to offer. Maybe you can find a nice spot just to sit and possibly read a book or simply enjoy the calm as you gaze out across the harbour. A memorable day and a must to put on your 'to do' list.

Invigorating Walk On The Wild Side. The Botanic Gardens are a serene oasis in a bustling city .There are many attractions ,the Cacti Garden , The Green house ,The Tropical Centre and of course towering trees ,indiginous plants ,rare plant specimens ,a gorgeous lake with assorted aquatic animals and plants .The setting is magical with paths meandering along the water,s edge and gorgeous views across the Harbour and grassy areas perfect for alfresco dining . If you are travelling with children there is a cute miniature train that takes you all around the gardens , it is a lot of fun !
Great. I must say it's quite a walk so get yourselves prepared.... but not to worry there a benches and nice grass to sit on, it's an experience go try it if you have time to spare... I did :)

My favourite botanic gardens!. Situated on Farm Cove, these gardens are unlike others you've visited. Walking from the Opera House gives you the best aspect of them.I love it. From the arboretum to the cactus garden, the fern house to the cafe on the ponds. Prairie garden to tropical pyramid. It's just beautiful. I challenge you to find all the fountains.

A pleasant stroll when the weather fine. This is a great vantage point to see a great deal of the inner reaches of Sydney Harbour. There are great views of the Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge. The Botanical Gardens, the Domain and surrounds are a great place to feel the breeze in your face and get some fresh air - only a short step from the middle of the CBD.

beautiful. If you have free time, go for a walk beween the opera and the botanical garden especially in the early evening and watch the colors of the sky till the night. The cafe and restaurants are very good ,all have the nicest view

A fantastic experience. Along the edge of the Harbour for what took me around 20 minutes, this walk was a fantastic experience from start to end. In reality, all you are doing is walking through the Botanic Gardens front to rear, but because of the location you get amazing views of the opera house all around. There are many seagulls on this walk, so watch out above you! But in all seriousness, most of your staring will be done at the foliage of the gardens and of the shimmering harbour waters beside you. There are quite a few great walks in Sydney, but if you are short for time, then this one will probably suffice. An Opera House tour, this pleasant walk, topped off by tea in the Botanic Gardens restaurant, is a fantastic way to spend half a day!

Fun for the family. We all really enjoyed the beautiful walk. We took lots of photos of the harbor, the bridge, and the opera house from Mrs. Macquire's Point. If you can, bring some seeds to throw to the cockatoos in the park. They will come eat out of your hand if you let them. So cool!

Great walk. I took a walk from Potts Point to the Opera house last week end and it was so great. You go from 'busy city' to a peaceful area. You will find a lot of people, families, joggers and just being lazy and lay on the grass
Sydney botanic gardens. This is a beautiful park that will take you directly to the Opera house and Circular Quay. No need to pay for a tour, just go on your own

Fabulous views and landscaping.. Within easy walking distance of Circular Quays, a highly manicured and interesting walk. A tribute to what the state can do when money is no problem and they own this premium land bank.

A break from the Hustle and Bustle. Getting off the ferry at Circular Quay you can stroll around to the Opera House, taking in refreshments from the harbourside restaurants or from the Opera House open air bar.Moving off down the famous steps (be careful of the work being carried out at the bottom of the steps) you can walk straight into part of the Botanic gardens. The gardens itself is huge, but very tranquil and there is always a photo shot to be had with views across part of the harbour.There are some wonderful shaped trees and pretty flowers around and you can stroll up to Government House (which is usually open to the public).You can stroll around the whole of the gardens or cut across the pathways back to Circular Quay via a different route ready to catch a ferry on to another part of the harbour.Always seems to be something different to see or capture from a different angle, Never tire of going around on the ferry.
Gentle stroll with iconic views. Easy walk from our hotel to the Opera House through the immaculately kept Botanic Gardens. The tea room in the Botanic gardens is worth a visit.

Worth to take a walk when waiting for your show to start. It's actually good to take a later show and have a longer walk here. We didn't expected the Botanic Gardens to be so big, we only had about less than a hour to walk around here, and ended up we didn't manage to go into the gardens too deeply. Worth a visit, very spacious and nice nature scenery to take in.
Tranquil. I was pleasantly surprise by the tranquility of the gardens since there was a nearby expressway.Pros:good views of the harborbeautiful flowerssome nice stone artworks

Lovely walk but careful of construction. I was staying in Surrey Hills and was attending a performance at the Opera on a Tuesday night. That afternoon I walked to the Botanical Gardens from my hotel and then over to the Opera for a dinner before the show.The botanical gardens were different from many I have visited. Because the gardens are free to enter, they are as much a park as formal gardens. There is a lovely Japanese garden as well as a rose garden; there are 19th century sculptures of AU founding fathers but also very wonderful modern and aborigine-based sculpture. The trees are simply magnificent and many are very unusual.If you are looking for lots of flowers, this may not be to your liking. But if you are looking for a beautiful walk along the water and then venture deeper into the gardens, you will not be disappointed.

beautiful and relaxing. Enjoy lovely views and vibrant foliage in this large botanical area. Word of warning: depending on the path/direction you take, there are some inclines and areas that may be challenging for some people and there were not always benches to stop and rest.That being said, it is worth the time if you can do it.

Beautiful Gardens. Extensive Grounds to walk around with beautifully laid out gardens, government house and waterside views leading eventually to the Opera House. Saw lovely birds, wonderful flowers and trees, peaceful and quiet.
The walk of a life time. Start at the main entrance and walk through the park finishing with the path by the harbour down past the opera house and leading to Circular Quay

Pretty walk. It is only a stones throw from the opera house to the botanical gardens - so I would not really call it a walk! the actual walk through the gardens is lovely and well worth the effort. This is where I first noticed the ibis, which are quite tame and behave a bit like pigeons and sparrows etc. in that they will come to your table at a cafe much like the other types.
Nice pleasant walk, about 20 minutes. From our apartment at the World Tower, was easy walk through Hyde Park and Gardens to he Opera House.

Great walk. beautiful gardens and very peaceful setting for a walk.m We had a great walk from the opera house to Finger Wharf for coffee. the day we walked was really warm and the gardens are well equipped with drinking water fountains.

Best Place to Start in Sydney. From our hotel, we did this walk in the opposite direction, through the Botanic Gardens all the way out to McQuarries Chair and gradually turning the corner to the stunning view of Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House, set against the backdrop of downtown Sydney. Botanic Gardens are well worth the wander, lots of different birds strolling around and look out for sculptures dotted around too.

Perfect to take a stroll. Great way to take in the beautiful views of the harbor and have a nice respite from the city bustle. Plenty of great picture taking opportunities and catch the local joggers' circuit.
Both are wonderful. What a great walk do on your own or with one of the many Tour Guides. There are free tours as well as paid ones. Ask your concierge
interesting tour. Our tour guide was excellent as she informed us of the history of this magnificent building.Would recommend to all

must do. the whole precinct is a must visit just to savour the sights, sound and atmosphere. Take time to sit on the grassy know at the rocks end, walk along under the subway bridge and enjoy the buskers and people moving about doing their daily routine, teas at the operat house café and walk off the calories in the gardens

Suprisingly peaceful. Given that the Botantic Gardens are right next to Sydney CBD you could almost be forgiven that your in a village park. It was nice to get away from the hectic city streets for a while and its a great way to see the Opera House and Bridge without people walking into your photos

Meander a little. Having done this walk many times, I can't recommend it enough. On a fine day or even a not so fine day, the sights, sounds and smells of the harbour, the bridge, the SOH, through the Botanic Gardens to the Seat, is gentle, you can do it at your own pace, and then meander through the Gardens. My favourites are the Herb Garden, and the beautiful Rose Gardens, where my brother was married. Then grab a coffee at the Cafe in the Gardens, then turn right and tackle the hill to find the Art Gallery and Museum up on the ridge. A great way to spend a day in the City.
A different perspective of the harbour. Great harbour views and a peacefull oasis away from the bustle of the hourbour. Its a short easy stroll but most people seem to miss it.

Bring your camera, a picnic, and your loved ones.. There are no words to describe the beauty of the Botanical Gardens. Make sure that you have a memory card large enough for your shooting.
I'd highly recommend bringing a picnic and spending time with your significant other or family. The rose garden in the shade of hundred year old trees is something to see first hand and enjoy.
Lovely Park. Because it was so hot it was pleased that this walk could be done in fits and starts. It is a lovely garden.

Opera House Tour. At around £10pp a short tour of the Opera house is recommended with a good and friendly guide. the tours are time scheduled so it is an advantage to book an hour or two ahead of the time suitable for you.The Botanic gardens are just a short walk away. These are ok but not really much to shout about. We were glad we took the Dotto Train @ $5pp as this covered the majority of the sites to see.

Million dollar views. This is a great walk to spend some time extending from The Opera House. The Botanic Gardens are a great respite from the hubbub of Sydney City with some a cafe/gift shop and well signed paths with various flora.

Watch out for the friendly Ibis's. The botanical gardens are quite expansive with wild Cockatoo, Ibis and water eels in the main pond. The walk to the Opera House is fairly short and scenic. Delightful !!!

Unmissable. Something you have to do absolutely while in Sydney. It's a little crowded around the Opera but once you've entered the gardens everything suddenly turns out so quiet. Hard to believe you're still in the city but yeah, you're still there.
Botanical Gardens. No matter what time if year this walk always delights with it hugging the water.There are many lovely tall trees and if you go in the evening you will share the area with the bats.

easy. This is just the typicall walk to do, start by the opera house, take photos of it, as much as you want and then walk 20 mins max to the botanical gardens. Their wildlife and beautiful landscapes will just amaze you.
Superb. Great walk. Clean, broad pathways. Amazing view from every angle. Perfect to sit and relax in the garden with a baby.

One of the most beautiful .... ... yes, this must be one of the most beautiful walks in the world. Strolling along the quay towards the opera house, having a drink there, continuing towards the Royal botanic garden and just relaxing, looking at the beautiful plants and trees. One of my favorite pastimes in Sydney.
Good place for a walk. Nice location , jolly crowd and a good place to just hang around. The Botanic garden has huge lawns , good for picnic or trips with your friends

Oasis in the city. This was a good walk in the park, especially if you go up a little way away form the harbour front. There are many intereting trees and plants if you are not from Oz along with plenty of interesting bird life. There is a very nice cafe in which to take a break in the middle of the park.

Fantastic. The best way to enjoy the spectacular view of the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Do visit the Mrs Macquarie's Chair for the unsurpassed panoramic views of Sydney Harbour.

Great location. Right by the Sydney Opera House, this outside bar is a great gathering and meeting place for Aussies and others. Drink prices are as high as most places in Australia.
Location is amazing.

A visit to the opera house is a must. To see an opera in the opera house has been a longing of mine for some time. The production was not really to my taste but the orchestra was superb and the experience not to be missed
Fascinating. Amazing building, great tour inside. The botanic gardens are lovely with fab views of the opera house from the point.

The Opera House and Botanic Gardens. well worth a visit to these two places, The Botanic Gardens are spectacular I wish we had had more time to see more of it but unfortunatley time was limited, you can also do tours of The Opera House which we did
