Special evening. Despite never having got to the last night of the proms at the Albert Hall we managed it in Sydney. What a great evening!It is much smaller than I had imagined. We were in Box A at the back (44/45)and got an excellent view.The soloist would have benefitted from a microphone, but, that aside, it was as good as anything we've seen elsewhere.Bar prices are sensible ( unlike London) and, if you buy a bottle prior to the start, it is there at the interval ( 6 glasses for the price of 4)You can get a tour without going to a show, but I would certainly recommend doing the show and having a private walk aroundIf you get your tickets in UK before you go, try to pick them up early because the queues before the performance are horrendous!

Great peaceful walk along the edge of the water. I love city parks and always visit them when in a new city, I think you get a good feel of the local area and people.Nice walk along side the water and places to just sit and relax

Beautiful area to walk and run!. Such an amazing place to walk around, I wish Boston had such a great place to walk. I walked through it in the evening and got to the point looking back at the Opera house and the Sydney Harbor Bridge right at sunset. It couldn't have been more picturesque!

Great walk with lovely views!. Nice views of the Opera house and Harbour. The Botanic Gardens are well maintained with plenty of places to sit and relax. The shop and cafe are well stocked and maintained.

Beautiful Area!. Many days were spent lazing about in the gardens, was a lovely place to be, and you could easily get away from the busy city feel just by entering the gardens looking out over towards the harbour, it was a good walk towards the opera house, it gets real busy as soon as you hit the opera house though!

Still the number one favourite for us. We often do this walk and have never tired of the mix of the bustling harbourside and wonderfully serene walks around the Botanic Gardens. It has been our first preference for a relaxing day out for many years, and we have never been disappointed.

Beautiful on a sunny winter's day. Really enjoyed this walk. Look out for the artworks on the way, particularly the delicate 'pavement art' by Brenda L Croft, more of whose work was in the excellent NSW Art Gallery when we visited.
Iconic building. Magnificent, everything you expect and more. A walk through the gardens, by the harbour side is truly stunning. We also went to an opera, La Traviata which was unforgettable.
Couldn't be better!. I don't know which is best: the excellent botanical gardens or the impressive opera house, but the walk in between those two will get a smile on your face!

The best of Sydney Australia. Arrived in Sydney a beautiful sunny day in November 2011 to board a RCCL ship for a cruise to celebrate my 60th birthday. After boarding, I had a whole afternoon ahead of me before the ship was to leave. So on the advice of my daughter the RCCL shore excursions mgr I decided to visit the Sydney Opera House. What a work of art. Every curve, every concept put into this magnificent building was awe inspiring. This is truly a jewel that can be enjoyed by all ages and that still has more possibilities to be realized before they are finished with the original dream started many years ago. At the doorsteps of this monumental building is the Sydney botanical gardens, where I sauntered for the next couple of hours on my way back to the ship. It is always so educational to explore different cultures and Australia has some trees and fauna not to be found elsewhere. After the cruise in the South Pacific islands before embarking on one of the coast of Australia I was lucky enough to spend another in Sydney this time exploring the city with a friend in a walking tour discovering it's history. What a memorable experience!!!

Stroll in the park. Beautifully kept gardens along the shore of Sydney Harbor. Take a walk from Circular Quay around to the Opera House, and then follow the path to the Royal Botanical gardens. Look up in the trees and you will see fruit bats, and maybe some cockatoos, and best of all its free.

This peaceful walk can take you all the way to the Art Gallery. Starting this walk at Circular Quay you can either walk around the Opera House or up the stairs and over the top of the construction site. Follow the signs to the Art Gallery and you will also come across the cafe, restaurant and Botanical Gardens gift shop; a good place to stop and enjoy the gardens. Continue on towards the Art Gallery and you will find an avenue of tulips in flower as well as other flowering plants and water fountains. As you leave the Botanic Gardens you will see the Art Gallery just across the road to the right. The Botanic Gardens Herbarium is to the left as you leave the Gardens. Unfortunately visiting the Herbarium is by appointment and guided tour only. The Art Gallery however is free and absolutely amazing.
Fantasic Walk. I love the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens Walk taking in all the sights sound an smell of the harbour and the gardens.

Don't miss this one when in Sydney. The Botanic Gardens truly are one of the best places to visit when in Sydney. Gorgeous to go for a run, have a picnic or just chill and enjoy the views of the harbour. The different gardens are well worth having a stroll through - especially in springs when the colours of the flowers are at their best - and the view from Mrs Macquarie's Chair is beautiful. Take at least half a day to fully enjoy the gardens. There's a restaurant that serves nice coffee and lunch as well.

Opera House and Botanic Garden Walk. It is a beautiful structure to visit and take some awesome pics.The entry to the site is FREE. Unless you want to go in and visit the opera house. The entry to botanic garden is free. It is a lovely place to go and chill or have a picnic.

Exellent for visitors. Nice view, good for visitors and locals. Especially should visit gardens in spring - can see cherry blossom and other spring flowers and in summer - roses. Good for walk with kids, couples, etc.
In love. I'm in love with Sydney and the beauties the city have to offerSee the OPera house was amazing, Just a little bit up set because is not light on in the night I went to see that
Great walk. Good am walk but only opens from 7 am closes 5.30 pm however if u have knee probs be aware of stairs
Stunning. Parts of the boulevard were closed which meant one had to walk through the Botanical gardens and I discovered little delights every time I did the walk....

Beautifully relaxing. Definetly a must do! It's a very relaxing and easy walk through the botanic gardens to the opera house. Sydney is such a beautiful city and this walk provides great views of the harbour and the harbour bridge. To see the iconic Opera House up close is awesome.

Beautiful walk, stunning harbour. There are a lot of beautiful harbours in the world and Sydney's is definitely up there with the best. A must do walk around the opera house to botanic gardens for any visitor to this beautiful city. Once you are around the opera house there is shade to be found in the gardens as well as seats to sit and admire the harbour and gardens, and plenty of drinking fountains also. Lunchtime is packed with locals out running in packs, if crowds aren't your thing, try and time it earlier in the morning for a more leisurely stroll.
Fabulous building. The opera house consists of 'tiles', not what I expected. The gardens are relaxing, especially after being in the city.

Beautiful views. What else is there to say - if you're in Sydney, you have to walk around the Opera House and when you do, take a little extra time to walk around the Botanic Gardens which are right next to the Opera House and free to walk. Beautiful views and quiet pathways make this a quiet retreat in the city. Lots of open space for the kids to run and play too if you're travelling with family.
Lovely walk.. Great way to see the harbour and get exercise at the same time. Lovely gardens and the Opera house is magnificent.

Serenity with a view. I enjoyed this walk quite early in the morning the first time as the city was waking up. Delicious smells and quite until the birdsong came. What a treat! Had the opportunity to visit a few times during my stay in Sydney.
Just Beautiful. A mixture of stunning. When it is in the evening, there is no escaping of its beauty. It is historical, beautiful and majestic, it is a reminder of previous era of history.

Breathtaking views during the walk. I did it the opposite way. From botanic garden to the opera house. Either way is still an astonishing view during the walk. Harbour on one side and garden on the other side. It can be quite packed with the locals doing their commuting on this path and aswell people use it for jogging track.. But don't worry it is still a wide walking path designed for everyone. I myself really enjoyed the walk with my two toddlers on their strollers.

lovely walk. idyllic walk through the gardens along the edge of the harbour, breathtaking views of the opera house and bridge, positive encouragement to use the grassed areas and lots of interesting art and sculptures to see. good views of visiting naval vessels too.
Nice view. Tho the botanic garden closes at 5PM and I didnt really get a chance to visit it, the walk from opera house to there is nice, not much people and can offer you some peaceful time.
A llitle bit worn out.. I was a little bit dissapointed when I came close to it. You can see it is 40 years old, but looks great from the water.

never get tired of doing this. This is just such a lovely walk, did it twice while in Sydney, its a great place to stop sit or lie on the grass and watch the people and the water. And then walk on to the Domain or Macquarie St or Hyde park
Garden of all seasons. Even if you don't like trees you will have to stop and admire this well plant garden for its location, its beautiful trees and well kept.

Fun Day Out. We caught the train to Circular Quay the walked to the Opera house. What a fantastic place to view the Harbour, people watch & marvel at the beautiful building. WE then followed the path to Botanic Gardens, such a beautiful haven in the middle of a busy city. Take the time to sit down & watch all the different people go by. Many come out to exercise at lunch time, great to watch& enjoy the sun. The Gardens are beautiful & peaceful. If possible go fora tour through Government House Open Fri-sun or check online http://www.hht.net.au/museums/government_house Well worth a look. You could spend a whole day just walking around the gardens if you like. We even had a lie down & a little nana nap in the sun. The perfect way to unwind

Wonderous views. A fantastic walk to soak up the Sydney views. Take a few timeouts along the walk to sit and admire the boats on the Harbour Take your shoes off and walk on the lush grass. Or be a child again and roll down the grassy hills. The kids will love being able to climb the old fig trees. Or take the motorized train as an easy option. But whatever your choice take a few hours to do or not to do. You will enjoy.

great morning walk. A wonderfully brisk walk was just an amazing way to start the day in the brilliant sunshine of a warm Sydney morning. The gardens are full of hidden treasures and the views are amazing.

Always a lovely walk.... We stay downtown when we visit Sydney and take our morning exercise by walking briskly for an hour around the Opera House and through the Gardens. We love it and always see so many beautiful birds. A wild rainbow lorikeet landed on my head and gave me start but I loved it.

A great start to our day in Sydney. We walked down through Hyde Park to the Botanical Gardens, then around the Opera House to the Ferry terminal. It took around 40 minutes. We were in attractive gardens all the way in the middle of a big city. A peaceful yet energising start to our one day in Sydney.

Lovely walk!. A beautiful walk between these two places, this path goes right along the shoreline. It offers beautiful views of the iconic things that make up Sydney--the water, the boats, the bridge, the opera house. It's lovely!
Definately a "must see" in Sydney!. A walk on Botanic Garden provides you one of the best views of Sydney icons: Opera House and Bridge.

Great Walk in a Beautiful Setting. We walked from the Hilton Sydney, to the Botanic Gardens, and then covered about every walkway there. Some areas were closed, but there was so much around us, that we did not miss it. We covered the entire property from every direction, and then came back to the Sydney Opera House for the afternoon tour. While not the famed "behind the scenes tour," with our guide, it was wonderful. It was too bad that our evenings were already filled, and that we could not attend any of the performances.

Lovely views and a pleasant stroll. You'll love the views but I'd recommend starting at the Botanic Garden end. I started at Finger wharf and walked all the way. Great people watching if you stop for a rest on a bench too.

Very enjoyable. Me personally I'm not a big fans of gardens (my OH is) but this was a very pleasant way to spend an afternoon after a morning in Sydney. We got a bit lost trying to find 2 of the cafes so ended up at what I think was a university music college cafe instead as we were quite hungryFree to get in which was a nice bonus too

Lovely walk. A really nice walk with fantastic views of sydney harbour. Many of the flowers in the gardens weren't in bloom as it was winter, but still worth the visit. Some of the walkway near the opera house is currently closed but you can still walk on the grass. Just watch out for the joggers...they're everywhere!

A gentle walk to absorb the city sites and sounds. A walk around the foreshore from the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens is a great way to stretch your legs and walk off a great lunch. If you want to take your shoes off and walk in the grass then you can do that too! On any day this walk gives one a different perspective of the busy city and harbour with all sorts of boats going by.

AN EARLY MORNING MUST. I walked from our hotel in The Rocks to the Botanic Gardens, via the Opera House, very early in the morning.... and it was an absolute pleasure. I took my camera and got some wonderful shots in the early morning sunrise. This is one of the best ways to see Sydneys' iconic Opera House and Harbour Bridge...

opera house to botanical gardens walk. this was our last day in Sydney and had a lovely walk. the gardens were ok but not the best we've ever been in and probably did expect a little more. we wouldn't do this again but still are glad we visited the gardens.

Relaxing and large. Don't miss going through the Botanic Gardens just because you don't like "gardens" or "parks" The location of this park is right next to the harbour and near the Opera House. It is so beautiful, large, well maintained and peaceful. It has a little cafe in the middle of the garden that have birds trying to take your food and just adding to the attractions. One of the highlights of my trip to Sydney and it was free!
Very pretty. Lovely part of Sydney considering we found the rest of it pretty average. Great view of the harbour bridge and the opera house although can't get over the number of joggers out!!!
Beautiful city walk. Walked through en route to Circular Quay, a highlight of our trip. The gardens are beautiful, well tended and clean, clean, clean. Would love to explore more.
Great relaxing walk. What a great walk..so much to look at and make sure you take your camera. Great view of the bridge and the opera house.
Picnic Perfect!. This is a must do, it's just beautiful and a great way to spend an afternoon, followed with a picnic. We will definitely be going back to explore more.
Botanic Gardens. Great way to spend a couple of hours wandering through the gardens and great views of the Opera House.

A walk on the green side. The walk from Circular Quay to the Opera House is best extended by continuing along the harbour & through the Botanic Gardens to Lady MacQuaries Chair. This short walk affords changing water scenes with many yachts & ferries plying the waterway as well as the greenery and calming effect of the gardens. Well worth the extra hour or two.

Sunny day in winter. I took the walk just after landing in Sydney.
The walk is beautiful right next to the water. Great viewes of the Opera house and the bridge.
I took the walk around lunch time and was swamped with joggers. I envy these people jogging route!

A Must Do Easy Walk!. Starting at the Opera House and walking East through the Botanic Gardens and around to Mrs Macquaries Chair is a truly majestic and easy walk. Its a great place for picnics if you are on a budget and perfect for a run if you are looking for exercise & of course the best views of Sydney, Opera House and The Bridge if you are a photographer!Lots of locals living in the East use it as their walk home so it is busy in peak hour but quiet for the rest of the day. If you want to venture further you can really explore the gardens which have some stunning local varieties. At the end of the walk, there is the Andrew Boy Charlton Swimming Pool which is on the edge of the harbour so a gorgeous place to relax if it is hot.

sydney opera house. opera house has breathtaking views of the harbour several restaurants close buy and a easy walk from ferry and the rocks most restaurants are with great views and are reasonably priced

Great views. A very easy walk which gives amazing views of the Harbour Bridge, Opera House and city skyline. You can also wander through the Botanical Gardens which provide excellent area to sit and relax and take in the spectacular views

Sydney at its best. On a sunny winter day, there is nothing better than grabbing a picnic blanket, a pair of sunnies, a good book and heading down to the Botanical Gardens just around from the Opera House and over looking Sydney Harbour. During the working week at lunchtime you will see hundreds of Sydney-siders taking a break from the office, jogging, walking, or just lying in the sun. This walk is beautiful and well worth a visit - it will help you appreciate the true beauty of Sydney Harbour.

Gardens in the City. It is a lovely park right in the middle of the city and once there, you are not aware of city life going on. You can walk around the gardens or jog around the outer edge, all with the harbour on view.

OPERA HOUSE ONE OF THE WONDERS OF THE WORLD. Interesting architecture designed by Johan Utzon a danish man, great views to the harbour and a stimulating walk in the botanical gardens to vies flora a nd fauna
Lovely walk beautiful gardens. Beautiful half day stroll around the waterfront and through the gardens. Well worth it. Easily accessible from the CBD and Opera House
botanical garden. vow, one can view different flora and fauna of well maintained garden.on the right side is the sea view. rare species of plants are to be seen

Great stroll with overseas visitors. A ferry to Circular Quay, a walk round to the Opera House then a stroll around Farm Cove to Mrs Macquarie's chair is a delightful way to show off the city.If you have time, walk up through the Botanic Gardens to the NSW Art Gallery. Entry to the Gallery is free and worth it.

An Australian Icon. Being a Sydney sider I am very proud of our Opera House. It is truly spectacular with its architectural magnificence. There are many different types of shows you can go to see it is just not all opera but for the opera lover is it wonderful but expensive. The interior is not spectacular like the Paris Opera House but its position on the harbour is. There are many restaurants and cafes where the food and coffee are excellent and on a Saturday night and some Sundays there is live music. The walk from the ferry quay or from the city itself is an easy walk. There are plaques in the footpath to tell you a little bit about the history of Sydney. On the opposite side of the bay there is also the overseas terminal and the park next to this is 'First Fleet Park' which is an area commemorating the landing of our First Fleet settlers in 1788. Here also is Cadman's Cottage one of the few original buildings. The walk to the Botanical Gardens is again very easy and the gardens are beautiful. Within the gardens there is a rock chair where Mrs Macquarie sat and contemplating here time here in Sydney in from 1810 to 1823. Her husband was Governor during these years.

my favorite walk. The location is handy where you are easily walk from Circular Quay to Opera House. Walk along the Botanic garden. Plants and trees are well organised around. I used to hear that this place is good at night time where a couple can drive in with lights off and park there. Very romantic. You will be find hundreds of bats hanging on the tree in DAY TIME. Amazing, isn't it?~~wao...I thought bats only stay in dark areas but it's not totally true.

Simply stunning. I walked from the Sydney museum through the Royal Botanical Garden and continued on right to the Opera House. Not only was this an enjoyable and tranquil walk, but the garden is amazing with so much variety of plant life. One will definitely enjoy themselves.

Pleasant walk. Just a wonderful walk to do with family, wedding party or your children. Toddlers may not enjoy but older children better suited. The walk provides foreshore, city and beautiful garden views to relax your day with the opportunity to end up in the magnificent Hyde Park to complete a great walking experience. Plenty of rest stops available to either just rest or take in the beauty of the surrounds.VReally Worth it!

Wow for the View. The walk is a must, this has got to be the most beautiful of leisurely walks to get the best vantage points of the Sydney Harbour, as well as the beautiful gardens/park that is free to the public. If you walk a round loop it would take approx an hour, but worth every minute of the hour. On your walk could also include going to the National Art Galley, Government House and or see a concert/play at the Opera House, or even stop for a lovely picnic lunch and make it a day trip. No need to do a guided tour, take it all in your own stride. The walk is easy, and can be done by anyone of any age including with children strollers and wheelchairs.

A different aspect of Sydney. The Opera House is a amazing building, you can stroll around the whole place. I you have a chance go and see a theatre production. In the front of the Opera House, is the Opera Bar, sit back enjoy a drink or meal to view our beautiful harbour. Free music entertainment on Sundays

spring is the best time to walk this. Spring is the best time to walk along this path way. You get to see the harbour from an differant veiw, you see the opera house and the on the the gardens where there are all differant kinds of flower and trees

Spectacular iconic walk. A visit to Sydney would simply be incomplete without this marvellous walk. Catch bus or ferry to Circular Quay and start walking towards opera house, through Botanical gardens and keep walking towards Art Gallery stopping at a cafe on the foreshore, about 300meters short of the Gallery. Of course gallery not to be missed, then walk through city, past St Mary's cathedral, towards QVB building and back to Circular Quay, with lots to see along the way.

Wonderful way to spend a few hours.. A great way to see Sydney and also soak up some history. A marvellous way to while away the day. Take in the glorious gardens, Mrs Macquarie's Chair, The Opera House Vista. Walk right through into the city.

Beautiful View. Don't miss the opportunity to enjoy harbour view, Harbour Bridge and Sydney Opera in your left, and various plant in your right. We came here in winter, but the sun was bright, we didn't feel too cold. After walked around, we stopped at Mrs. Macquaire's chair.We spent almost 2 hours to walk around, sat down at the garden chair waiting sunset time. Really worth a visit, we took many picture of plants and beautiful sunset with iconic background.

Watch out for speeding joggers!. This is one of the most iconic walks you will ever do. With the Sydney Opera House, the Sydney Harbour Bridge, Sydney Harbour and the Sydney City skyline ever present, its hard to know where to focus throughout the length of this walk. Be sure to do the entire foreshore, around to Mrs. Macquarie's chair, before going back to visit the Royal Botanic Gardens - and yes, while you are rubber necking the iconic sights the walk offers, keep an ear cocked for speeding joggers. They will, of course, generally avoid you but increasingly they have iPods attached to their ears!

Scenic and relaxing. Despite the building work around the Opera House, this was a really nice relaxing walk. You get an iconic view of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge from Lady Macquarie's Chair in the Botanical Gardens so that's a must.
Stunning views. Wow. What can I say. Look back and see the opera house and bridge. Great photo opportunities, a path will guide you but beware its quite popular so expect some pedestrian traffic

Botanic gardens. Beautiful peaceful walking the gardens are extensive, if you start your walk at Circular Quay, past the opera house and through the gardens , then a trip through Parliament house gives a real insight into history
What a marvel the Sydney Opera House is. Make sure you take the tour of the Opera House. It is very fantastic, one of the highlights of our entire trip.

even in winter worth a stroll. though undoubtedly more impressive in the spring and summer, still worth a stroll along the greenery and water, plus terrific views of the harbor, opera house, and bridge.

Iconic structure and lovely gardens. Beautiful walk around the Botanic Gardens - could have easily lost myself there for the afternoon watching the world go by - little bit of tranquillity within a very busy city.

Wonderful. Great walk through the Botanic Gardens with harbour views. Walked to Mrs Macquarie's chair (having just read a book about the Macquaries this brought history to life). Really interesting plants and trees - and no "keep off the grass" signs. It was a hot afternoon so we caught the little train back. Really worth a visit.
Great place to run / walk. Beautiful botanical gardens combined with scenic harbor views. You can almost forget you're there to exercise!
The historic gardens are beautiful. The historic gardens are beautiful with an ocean walk giving the best view of the Opera House and the Bridge.
Magnifique. Spectacular for walking or exercising any time of day. Numerous vantage points for great shots of bridge and opera house at sunset.
Inside tour. Do take a tour inside the opera house to know its history in making & also feel the majestic space thats within.

One of the best short walks in the world. Love this beautifula nd iconic part of Sydney.It starts with the worlds most recognisable building, a work of art that is spectacular in real life and moves through to exquisite nature in particular the wide lawns, ancient trees and lovely ponds with birdlife. All the while hugging the gorgeous Sydney harbour and watching the boats and ferries glide by.Go all the way through the gardens to Lady Macquaries chair, take a picnic or stop by at the Botanical Gardens cafe.
Picturesque and free!. This is one of the nicest things to do in Sydney. You get a view of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge in 1 go.

Nice and Relaxing walk. This is a lovely walk to do away from the City and the traffic. Take a stroll from The Opera House through The Batanic Gardens, have lunch at the nice Cafe or get something from the take away cafe, there is plenty of space for everyone to relax and enjoy the gardens and theView of the Harbour.I feel we are so lucky to live in Sydney as there is always something to do in and around the City. Regards, Marion.

Great Sydney walk. great sydney walk if you have 1-3 hours for a leisure walk in a beautiful and intresting enviprmrnt. Dont hesitate to sit and have coffee in one of the great coffee place on the way

WOW - its even better in person. I have seen postcards of The Opera House. Now I have ferried past it, walked around it and inside it. It is amazing. It is so big, well laid out. Heaps of helpful staff, and food places to eat. If you visit Sydney you should visit the Sydney Opera House
She's a tired old lady. The construction around it was a nuisance. Architecture was definitely great piece of art but looks aged.

Walk into a respite from the city. We loved getting away from the traffic and crowds and wandering the many paths of this well thought out park on the water. We spent hours exploring there and learned much Australian history in the meantime. A must do.
Great short walk. Perhaps one of the best short walks in the world , Great to do before breakfast, Great phot opportunities from Mrs Macquaries chair

picuresque walk. The walk way is very scenic with the sydney bridge,opera house and the harbour view. There was a lovely refreshing breeze in April and so many tourists enjoying themselves. The Botanic gardens are not seen until you come to the opera house but this is also beautifuly maintained and very clean.The view improves further once you are in the Gardens and I would say its a lovely relaxing walk in the evenings around sundown.

Lovely. We walked from Central Perk Backpacker on George street to the Botanic garden and back it was about a 2 hour stroll stopping for photos. The walk its self was lovely good views of Opera house and bridge. Plenty to see in the Gardens and there is also a small cafe. I would recommend this if your in Sydney.

Loved it!. Beautiful walk to stroll or jog! If you have little time in Sydney, I would recommend that you start your day in the Royal Gardens and walk your way to the Opera House, take the Opera house tour, maybe try to get cheap tickets for that nights performance (at times they offer discounts just to fill the hall) and end your day at the rocks at one of the very old bars/rest.

very good place to have a meal and a drink. it is a good place to have a drink and food, the best moment is from 5:00 pm to midnight,the people get out of the office and stop there for a drink or dinner,on the way to the opera, there are good restaurants with the best view of sydney.

Walk and a Scoot. Took our five year old along with her scooter - the place was crowded with tourist - but walking further and into the gardens - it was very nice. Very nice change away from the hot and humid asian climate.

Fave must do in Sydney!. I never get tired of the views here- always gorgeous and so many places to stop off and take it all in. A lovely place to run and get some exercise, though the scenery is a bit distracting and you'll find yourself stopping off for photo ops along the way.

LOVED IT!!!. I really enjoyed walking through the magical botanical gardens! They are not open all the time, so check the times before you go. The views of the harbor are magical, and I stopped many times to take pictures. It's also a great place for a picnic, jog, or just to sit and relax. Simply stunning!
Very gentle, but great views of harbour. This was a really nice walk, not too much in the way of botanicals, but excellent views of Sydney and the Harbour.
great walk. Weloved the wal from the Botanic gardens near our hotel to the opera House.Safe pleasant walk with options for stop and have coffee in this beautiful city
interesting. just lovely views and very inviting. The opera house is dated but still somehow manages to impress you.

Best view of Sydney. Though I've been to Sydney many times, I walked from the Opera House to Woolloomooloo for the first time last weekend. The weather was perfect, which certainly helped make the walk so enjoyable. But the view of the Bridge and Opera House from Mrs Macquaries Chair, which was at the halfway mark, was a real highlight. It wasn't a difficult walk, and could certainly be undertaken by someone with a pram, young children or older people. My only regret was that we did the walk a bit too early in the day, as we didn't feel like eating one of the famous pies at 'Harry's', despite the fact that they looked amazing. My only advice is make sure you have a plan once you reach Woolloomooloo, as we were at a bit of a loss as to what we should do after we arrived.
A great welcome to Sydney. This is a lovely walk - you can wander and explore the gardens and make it as short or as long as you like. Great photo opportunities.

Nice ramble but can be crowded. If you visit the Opera House to tick this essential must-see item off your Sydney list, it would seem a pity not to go just a little further and take the chance to walk on to the Botanic Gardens and follow the path around Sydney Cove to Mrs. Macquiarie's seat or deep into the Botanic Gardens themselves. Either option is a pleasing way to spend an hour or so and to gain a different view of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge.

A good nice peaceful walk. In this winter season, we thought it could be tough with small kids. but the experience was excellent. Take time and walk slowly - enjoy the scenic walk. To see around the garden, maybe "tractor train - Choo Choo Express" is a good idea. Make sure you have enough cash with you as this service donot take any card.

Very pleasantly scenic. I loved this walk. Most Sydney spiders seem to run it so beware of being mown down! The Fleet Steps is the site not only of greeting visiting Dignatories but also for health fitness fanatics to pound up and down under the watchful eye of their coaches!

On the flat. The walk is on the flat right around the coastline with great views and much to see and learn.there is a land train if you want to go up into the Gardens and you feel completely safe with many thousands of like people also walking, running, and jogging.

Beautiful Views and Gardens. What a wonderful peaceful walk, where you can take in the Views of the bridge and harbour. Look at all the Beautiful gardens and surrounds. Would recommend to anyone visiting Sydney.
Peaceful and a total breeze. The views are stunning and this is a lovely gentle stroll which serves as an excellent way to get in a good look at a great part of Sydney. Everyone should do this walk!!

Peaceful walk with really nice views. Definitely take this walk, its such a nice way to relax after being in the bustle of Sydney all day. It's a popular place for joggers and just for people to hang out. Really good views of the harbour and Opera house
Nice and easy. OK, so buy a ticket to tour the Opea House; buy a performance at the Oprea House.Talk an easy walk to the gardens: even in the "winter," the views are great!

A slice of heaven in Sydney.. Sunset walk time is delightful as you head west towards the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Gorgeous sandstone walls fringe the main path around the waterfront. Sydney's best views.

Worth the walk. We took a walking trip along the main throughfare from the Darling at the star and up to the gardens and along to the Opera House where we stopped and had lunch at a café along the Quay. This was an excellent activity and we enjoyed all that Sydney had to offer. One great stop along the way was Parliament House which was really worth the visit as it is full of amazing art work. Highly recommended to take a long walk in Sydney.

A walkers delight. Situated in the heart of the City, the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens Walk entices you with its calm, tranquil qualities that will have you leaving the frantic nature of the City behind. Beautiful views of the Harbour Bridge, a spectacular arrangement of flora and fauna and a must do walk for any traveller to Sydney
a great walk. It's about a 20 minute walk to the Botanic gardens and art museum. A great walk to stretch and get yourself mobile after a long flight.

Iconic views of Sydney. This walk gives you iconic pictures you see in the travel books. The Opera House, Bridge and harbor are all at your fingertips. If it's a nice afternoon and you like to walk, it's beautiful.

Stunning views of harbour. The Opera house to Botanical gardens walk is in the middle of major attractions in Sydney and great way to relax after a busy week. It has some great views of the Opera house and Harbour bridge. I like the view of Harbour bridge from Mrs Macquarie chair point is spectacular. If you want to take some family pics to remember your trip to Syndey this is the best place.

Simply Refreshing. Take a break form the busy city life, and into the serenity of the peaceful pace of the Botanic Gardens Walk. Enjoy the gentle breeze form the sea and the people slow jogging along~

lovely walk great views. this is a great walk - loved the please walk on the grass sign! - the views are stunning the gardens well worth a visit and remember to look up as there are loads of fruit bats in the trees! A lovely not to be missed walk.

Gorgeous views of Sydney Harbour from the serene gardens. Having chosen to get married in the Botanic Gardens, they're a favourite part of Sydney... an oasis of peace and calm that's a short walk from the Central Business District. :)

A Nice Self-Guided Walking Tour. Very pretty walk from the Opera House through the Botanical Gardens. Many displays and interpretive signs but not a lot of staff if you had questions. There are many pathways but an absence of signs giving you directions so take a map (usually free at your hotel. It took me over an hour but I stopped frequently along the way to look at the monuments and displays.
Gorgeous. The contrast between the stunning architecture of Sydney and the beauty of the trees and plants in the Botanical Gardens is amazing! Everywhere people are jogging and exercizing!
Underrated Gem. Excellent place to watch the world go by... Highly underarated in the shadow of the Opera House & Harbour... One of the best garden I've visited... Spectacular bay views...
The Opera House. Highly recommend seeing the Opera House as well as the Botanic Gardens. Take lots of pictures. You can get some GREAT shots from the Gardens.

The iconic Syndey Opera House and scenic Botanic Garden walk. The Sydney Opera House is quite an attraction up close, with wonderful and vast tiling over the roof and the overall structure resembling that of the sails on ships and boats. The Opera House lower walk-way is wonderfully patterned with a mirage of captured photo images of (people around the world) with smiling faces.The Botanic Gardens is such a wonderful place to bring the family and friends for a great day out. The train ride and history review by the guides is a wonderful and comfortable way to get around the gardens and learn about its history, if you're not the outdoorsy type. But if you are, take the walk around the Gardens and take in the calm and beautiful view and/or pitch a picnic near the ocean side and watch the ferries tugging along towards Manly and parts of Sydney's north.

True city lifestyle. It's pleasant to take the footpath in the park from the Gardens to the Opera House, admiring the city skyline view on one side, as well as having the sense that you are truly enveloped in the local city life, along with the dog walkers, rollerbladers and picnic-makers.

Beautiful!. Walking outside the Opera House and looking to the photgraphs was nice and I spend all day walking inmthe Botanic Gardens and looking at the flowers, trees, butterflies, etc. It is a beautiful place in a great location. The shop is really well stocked and offers a variety of nice products as well as high quality souvenirs.
Pleasant walk. Great when the sun is shining, and some amazing trees en route, which must be several hundred years old. Worth a stroll.

Stuning. How can this not be one of the nicest things to do in Sydney. I grew up in Sydney and regularly make this journey and am never disappointed. Stop for a drink, and watch the world and lovely harbour float on by. Make you take a camera!
Iconic. If its your first time in Sydney it is something you have to do. The Opera House is a must and the gardens are beautiful. It's a great walk that pretty much anyone can do.

Love this walk!. Lovely park area with parakeets and cockatoos, gorgeous views over the harbour and a pleasant way to walk back to the city or your hotel from the harbour. Safe and full of interesting plants and flowering trees etc.

This is a must - absolutely beautiful. If you are in Sydney and do not do this you are crazy. Walk around the front far enough and you get to the Woolloomooloo Wharf area with restaurants and bars. Plan the walk and then some down time for a brilliant Sydney day

Classic harbour views. Bring your camera and you'll get some great shots of the Harbour and its landmarks. If you continue on towards the Harbour Bridge you'll get to the Ferry wharves of Circular Quay. Hop on the Manly ferry for a cheap trip across the harbour to the beach and get more spectacular views!

Wonderful Garden. We not only walked the Garden but we also took the little train tour throughout the Garden for $5.Not too long but very informative. Also a bit hop on /hop off so you can stroll the different ares. Loved the Palm Grove, Wollemi Pine ,wishing tree and herb garden as well as the walk along the harbor to the chair.

I just love the Opera House. To have the sight on the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge from the Botanic Garden Walks is just overwhelming - the best you can have in Sydney. Arriving with the plane I saw the Opera House from above and immediately fell in love with it. I came back 3 times and I hope there will be many returns to this beloved place . Forget New York - I love Sydney !

A To Do Must. Wonderful place to be walking in makes you feel alive so much to see and enjoy. They say that opera House is on a par to Sydney Harbour Bridge as one of Sydney's Icon I would also add The Botanic Garden is an equal.

Outstanding. I took this walk as part of my day tour of Sydney. I was highly impressed with the views, the walk itself and the connection that was provided to the Sydney Harbour, the Opera House, The Rocks, and many other places and attractions. The weather was perfect for the walk and it was incredibly relaxing considering the hectic week that had preceded. This would be a great walk with family and I would highly encourage taking the time while you are in the area.

picturesque walk. Just a short stroll through the gates into the gardens, lots of shady trees & seats to watch the passing parade, also watch one of the many wedding that are celebrated in the gardens, feel like a bit more, strole around to Mrs Macquaries chair
Always somewhere quiet to relax. It's amazing that you can always find a peaceful place even when town is crowded. Shop worth a visit
Opera House. Very architectural yet simple . Nice view from the top overseeing the bridge Flight of steps up to the opera house was kind of long.

Does it get any better than this?. We walked from our hotel near Hyde Park, thru the botanical gardens, down to Mrs Macquaries Chair and back around to the Opera house on a sublimely beautiful June day. What an excellent way to get an overall picture of this waterfront city! A must do when in Sydney.

Best!. We booked the Opera House guided tour. I read reviews on Tripadvisor before booking it. There were mixed responses. But after touring it, I must recommened it to the visitors to do guided tour; and not just look at Opera House from outside. It is best from inside also. The auditoriums are large, spacious and worth looking. After visiting Opera House, we visited Royal Botanic Garden which is nearby. It is most relaxing walk. Greenary, Sydney skyline, Opera House and Harbour Bridge are seen very photogenic from this garden. We spend whole evening at Opera House and Royal Botanic Garden. Must visit.

Perfect morning walk after back scenes opera house tour. This is a beautiful walk along the water anytime. I did it after taking the behind the scenes tour of The Opera House. Love morning walks and the day was gorgeous. The Botanical Gardens are stunning in their own right and a perfect place to picnic or sit and read a book. Do not miss the harbor view from Mrs MacQuaries Chair. If you have the time continue on to Wooloomooloo. Then get your grand kids to spell it when you get home!

Away from the bustle of the city. Taking a walk around the back of the opera house towards the botanical gardens gives you a different appreciation of Sydney. On our second visit to Sydney we walked to the gardens twice to escape the busy, noisy city centre. We took a takeout and lunched on one of the benches looking out to the harbour view. Lots of joggers about at lunchtime so be careful not to get run down! Just step away onto the grass and find your spot under one of the many amazing trees. Loved this walk and believe its a must do on every trip to Sydney.
Nice picturesque walk. defiantly a must do for a nice day in Sydney beautiful scenery and nice walk around the gardens take your time and enjoy the views

Everything you dreamed it would be. Our first view of the Opera House from across the harbor took our breath away. It's truly more magnificent than expected. Wear comfortable shoes, or a least something you can walk well in because you will be putting on the miles. Take your time a stroll in and around the Opera House, we passed on the tour preferring to talk with locals about the venue. The stroll to the Botanical Gardens also is worth the trip. Have your camera ready for some awesome views.
An unbeatable walk!. What more can you say about this place. Just a great place. We have never got fed up of the changing views when you walk around.
Beautiful icon of Sydney. You must not miss this place in a visit to Sydney nice view of the Bay take some time to walk through the gardens

harbourside views are spectacular. One of my personal favourites is walking around the foreshore from the Rocks to Wooloomooloo via the botanical gardens and Mrs Macquaries Chair. On a sunny balmy day it doesn't get much better. Try to fit this in if I'm visiting Sydney to visit the daughters.

A park along the seaside. This is an unbeatable walk, which is why there are lots of people doing it on the weekend. Always lot to watch and enjoy. Great to get into a park so close to the cbd. Early in the morning there are plenty of walkers doing the circuit. Watch that the gates close at dusk which is early at this time of the year. It is quite a long way to walk around the park.
Lovely views. Lovely gardens to walk around either on your own, with your family or as a couple. Really beautiful vuews of the opera house and the harbour bridge.

Wonderful stroll. The views are incredible, especially if you strike a beautiful blue sunny day.
The only downfall was having to dodge the many joggers who frequent this walk. I have nothing against the joggers just would like them to remember people can walk here too.
Great place!. Impossible to miss the beauty of Opera house and botanic gardens ... great for a stroll with your partner enjoying its enchanting beauty
Nice walk on a sunny day. It's a nice way to discover all the angles of the opera house and the beautiful Botanic garden as well.

Lovely easy walk. Since we were booked in the Grand Quay we walked around the
area every evening. It was lovely easy walk.

You have to do this.... From my first travel here in 1990's, this has always been one of my most memorable walks anywhere in the world! The water front walk...and adjacent botanical garden is really wonderful....an easy stroll...if you take it all the way to Sister Mary's Point...you get spectacular views of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House.
Magic walk along the harbour. My wife and I love the peaceful and beautiful ambiance. We often come here for picnics and to have a relaxing time. There
The besy of Sydney. This is iconic and the most picturesque part of Sydney and it's harbour, this is a must for any visitor to Sydney. well worth it!!

wonderful photo opportunities. I spent ages on this walk - my first day after a long flight. Having left the UK on a snowy morning it was fantastic to be out in the sun! I stopped everywhere to take photos and couldn't believe the views of the opera house in front of the bridge. The whole area is beautifully kept. I couldn't get into see Government House as there was a reception on but did walk round the grounds. If you know about plants you would probably appreciate these more than I did but I did get great pleasure out of the ambience.

An Iconic Walk (or Run). Whenever I'm in Sydney, I always visit here. Though I tend to be running rather than walking, it's just such a fantastic place to be - during the day or the evening - that I couldn't imagine a visit to Sydney without a run around the Opera House, the Domain and the Botanic Gardens.
Don't Miss It!. Beautiful walk along the harbor from the Opera House to Botanic Gardens or vice versa. Don't forget your camera!

Great walk on a sunny day. Enjoyed walking through the botanic gardens and towards Mrs Macquarie chair, was particularly interesting when you get down to the waterfront and if you happen to be there during lunch time, you will see hundreds of city workers jogging, working out and playing sports in the nearby parks.The views are amazing over the city, the harbour and the bridge.great walk and highly recommended.

Fantastic walk. We started walking from the city to Opera House and through the gardens, including to historic lookouts. We veered off to the water front to look at yachts and turned back at Kings Cross. The gardens are beautiful with so much to see including plants and wildlife. It is a worthwhile place to visit.We had meant to go back but ran out of time.
Do it !. Worked really well for me starting from Kings X and walking down to Opera House & Harbour through the Gardens. You can take the metro back from Ferry terminal

Lovely walk. This is a stunning walk at any time of day but beautiful at sunset too. I had my wedding reception at the Opera House and our photos done in the Botanic Gardens (many years ago) so this walk is special to me.

wonderful walk. We walked from kings cross down to the harbour through the park and on to the opera house it is stunning you really get a feel for the place see the different rock formations and see lots of different wildlife .
Classic Sydney. amazing view of the harbour, a true sydney experience. You cannot visit Sydney without doing this walk. it's peaceful and the nature along the harbour is stunning.
Awesome experience.. No matter what time of the day you are around the Opera House it is an amazing experience. Walk around the Opera house and the botanical garden is so peaceful and so relaxing.

A walk in the Park. The walk from the Sydney Opera House through the Botanical Gardens and onwards to Mrs Macquarie's Chair and Wolloomooloo Bay is one of the classis Sydney walks on a sunny day. The Botanical Gardens sits on Farm Cove which was landing place for the First Fleet into Sydney Town. The name Farm Cove was given because it was the location of the farms needed to grow food for the new settlers from England circa 1778. The gardens are beautiful and the walk around the cove to Mrs Macquarie's chair is memorable. On the eastern side of the walk you will see a brass plaque on the walkway. The plaque denotes the location where Queen Elizabeth II first set foot on Australian soil. Take a picnic lunch for beautiful day around one of the most significant historical areas of Sydney along with one of the most beautiful harbours in the world.
Beautiful. It was just beautiful and the morning breeze was just breathtaking. Had lots of photos taken and make a wonderful memories.
Fabulous. Fabulous. Botanical gardens are great. Lovely cafe where they do great meals or restaurant above but we didn't use that. Beautiful flowers etc and well kept gardens.

Very pleasant, despite the construction work. When we were there in April 2013, there was some reconstruction in progress necessitating a climb over a temporary bridge. However, wait until you have cleared the scaffolding and the view of the Opera House from the Botanic Gardens is excellent. The Gardens themselves are also fine and a pleasant place to sit a while away a few minutes.
So relaxing. It is just a great walk, with water views. Biggest problem is so many people on the path, runners walkers, strollers.....But worth the effort.

Great place to relax and have a nice walk. This is a great place to pack some food and take the family for a walk. It is particularly nice over the weekend so there is no need to rush.
On a cool sunny day, its particularly nice and the gardens of course are worth diversions into them.
Must take this walk. all kinds of cockatoo's all over. they have moved the fruit bats, flying squirrels out finally as they were killing several of the trees you will see on youe

Wild Cockatoos. Part of our Explorer bus trip brought us to walk around the opera house and then over to the Botanical Gardens. We didn't have much time, but what we did see was very pretty. I personally like the birds and to see cockatoos free was a treat.

Day in Sydney. It's an easy stroll from Circular Quay to Opera House, round to Mrs. Macquarie's chair, then up to the Art Gallery by way of the Botanical Gardens. Lots of benches to sit and read, suggest you have water and snacks before you set out.
A bit of culture. We love just getting out there and doing the simple things, like going for a walk past the opera house. Such a fantastic day and if you are in the area i highly recommend it.

Beautiful. Sydney Opera House is not white!! I was blown away, I thought it was white..sails off white and building is brown..sails are made from over 1 million Ikea tiles..still stunning architecture!

A heavenly stroll or run. Nothing to dislike... a path that follows the waterfront, watching ferries, sailboats, the opera house, gorgeous terraced homes across the water, and to the left, a lovely garden landscape with native and other flora
Difinitly will return to it again. Nothing render you relaxation other than walk by the sea from one side and a nice botanic garden from the other side. This walk strongly recommended.
stunning. If you have the energy this is a great stroll , impressive to view the sydney opera house up close , magnificent views , the botanic gardens sensational ,
A must to see. On a sunning day in Sydney, the early morning walk from the opera house around the gardens is refreshing and beautiful to enjoy the start of the day. Easy walking.
Nice walk. Not a massive trek or anything but a nice walk around the pretty gardens then past the opera house to the harbor. Great walk to do when you first arrive in the city.
Loved it!. ´We encourage you to walk barefoot and to hug trees´ that was on sign in the park! Its lovely very beautiful and if you end in the harbour the views on the opera house are really amazing!

Walk from the iconic Opera House to a quiet haven in the City. Once you have enjoyed the delights of the Opera House, you should also take the short stroll around the water's edge into the magnificent Botanic Gardens of Sydney. As well as being a beautiful place to visit and stroll through, it presents as a quiet haven next to (almost within) the noise and chaos of the City right next door. The large lawn areas are great for kids and picnics.

Two of the planet's most recognisable views. We did this walk as the conclusion of a fascinating (and exhausting) day walking around this part of Sydney. After the bridge and the Rocks we made our way back to Circular Quay and walked along the promenade alongside the Opera House. Having looked across at the Opera House from Sydney Harbour Bridge we then enjoyed the view of the bridge from the Opera House - quite fantastic. A leisurely stroll brings you around the building giving you some close-up views of the structure. On the other side there are nice panoramas across the harbour and round into the inlet forming the boundary of the Botanical Gardens. We just walked through the gardens but it was obvious that you could spend quite a long time there as evidenced by the many people who had obviously spent most of their day there. Our stamina was beginning to run down by then but it was still an enjoyable and interesting stroll through these beautifully maintained gardens.
Marvel.... Architecture Marvel, Sydney trip would be incomplete if you do not be there... Excellent location surrounded by Water and the beautiful Botanical garden

Lovely walk in the park. This is a great walk in the park, so close to central city. Great views of the Sydney Harbour. We went to Carmen the opera on the waterfront at the Fleet steps and it was amazing. Well worth a look at.

It goes so fast. Sydney has it famous Opera house, but just next to this is Our Botanical gardens, free to enter, lots of places to get food, some very expensive, and some very cheap, lawns to stretch out on, a safe place for children to run and play, a great way to get to the Art gallery of NSW or the State Library.The garden walk from the Opera house to the Gallery takes about 15 min, or all day depending on your pace, love this place.

Superb. A brilliant way to take in the city Skyline with the Habour Bridge and the Opera House is to walk around to Mrs Macarthur's point. Not only a lovely walk around the edge of the Botanical Gardens but truely great photo opportunities once you get there.

Fantastic walk. The Botanic Gardens are breathtaking, wild parrots,and other birds, beautiful flowers, trees, and plants opening out to stunning views of the opera house. You could quite easily spend a couple of days walking through the gardens.

Beautiful way to take in hobour views and walk off lunch!. Plent of places to rest. Beautiful gardens to view. Especially if youa re walking with your wife of 25 years. Got married and had receiption n the Opera House and pictures were taken at Mrs Maquaries Chair. Just glad we got drive 25 years ago. Don't try and rush it.

Great to Wander. It's relaxing and it's free. Your can stroll or mooch, it's a really pleasant place to walk, there are plenty of great views and you know exactly where you are. Usually lots of people enjoying the place, especially at weekends.

Nice garden. The botanical garden is huge, very well looking after, many birds, and flowers, and fantastic trees. Every thing is so green. It is peaceful only the birds make the background noise. It is great to listen

Another great walk. This is another great walk, not much for the opera but for the botanic garden itself. Recommended.
If you want to make it a bit longer include the circular Quay area and the rocks.
Opera house and park. The opera house is awesome and the park is beautiful....great spot for lots of great photos...the walkway around the park is along the water and makes for a relaxing time..
Great unwinder. What could be better after a very long flight than to relax and have a good walk in the sunshine - the gardens are beautiful and all the views along the walkway.Not to be missed.

Great casual pace amble in fantastic gardens. Views are brilliant (sunny day on our stroll,) beautiful gardens and great history. A nice place to walk or just chill out on one of the many grassed areas.

Nice views. A nice paved pathway goes through the Botanic Gardens and connects to the Opera House, then we continued south through The Domain (a large green space) and down into Hyde Park to see the ANZAC memorial.

Fabulous Walk!. We had the perfect weather to enjoy this walk around the waterfront to Mrs Macquires Chair and through the Botanic Gardens. The gardens were well planned out and we took many photos along the way. A real asset to Sydney!

Lovely. The opera house is great to look at from different angles. The botanical gardens is a wonderful people watching spot. Grab an ice cream and wander around the harbour. Lovely sunday afternoon stroll.

Must tour, beware lots of steps/walking. Comfy shoes.. Every seat is a good seat. You can eat lunch and drink wine outside and they remind you when the show is about to start.
We saw Pirates movie with 50 pc orchestra. Wonderful!

Must do. A lovely walk along the Harbour, no visit to Sydney is complete without it! Some beautiful views of the Harbour, Opera House and Botanical Gardens all there for you. Many people out and about, especially at lunch hour.
The walk to do. We really enjoyed this walk which allowed to have different nice views of the Opera. The atmosphere is quiet when walking along this part of the coast.

One of the Most beautiful Walks. so many sights along the way to take in, and take photos of!
plenty of places to sit and relax, or picnic.
an unforgettable walk and well worth it

One of the most beautiful walks in the World. Sydney Harbor is a world renown sight by itself but when combined with its Opera House and Botanic Gardens then it becomes an unforgettable experience. It is hard to explain in words. One must see it to understand it.

Lovely walk and picnic spot. This is a lovely walk (although we did it as part of a bicycle tour with Bonza bikes). You can extend it by going up to the old Governors House which houses a sydney history museum.
Lovely Walk. This is a lovely little walk you must take in when visiting Sydney. I bring all my out of town friends here for a stroll. Great photo opportunities too.

Such a pretty walk. This walk has so much to offer. Views of the Opera House the Harbour Bridge, the harbour itself, the Botinical Gardens and the city skyline. What more could you ask for? How lucky you are in Sydney to have this beautiful place to enjoy.
Free pleasure. There is not a nicer place to relax in Sydney. The view of the harbour is ever changing as are the gardens. All this and the Opera House too!

One of my favorite places in Sydney. Can't say enough about the lovely, lovely Botanic Gardens and awesome Opera House...walking along and savoring the many varieties of plant life and trees...how beautiful is it to have this refuge right there in Sydney?
Lovely. On a nice day. A $10 train will take you around the park. Get lost in a book - or visit the succulent park. Or the rare plants enclosure. The fern room. Lovely day.

Some of the best gardens in the world - and admission is free. The pristine Royal Botanical Gardens are generally unknown to overseas tourists before they arrive, but most will discover the gardens thru their quest to see the adjacent Sydney Opera House. Free admission and lots of shade on a hot day.Supposedly a specimen of every plant species in the world is here. Don't miss the herb garden and the cactus garden, which are hidden away. Many city office workers come here lunch. It's a favourite place of the whole city. Search for Lady Macquarie's chair - it's on the eastern edge of the Gardens at the point underneath the cul de sac (near the Conservatory of Music) where the tourist buses stop to take pictures. Lady Macquarie's Point was where Lady Elizabeth Macquarie, the wife of Governor Lachlan Macquarie, would sit and watch boats coming into the harbor, and the sweeping views. The historic "chair" was carved out of a rock ledge for her, no doubt by convict labor. People liked Governor Macquarie much better than Governor Bligh - yes the same Captain Bligh from Mutiny on the Bounty. After Bligh was unceremoniously booted off his ship by a crew sick of his extreme and heavy-handed ways, he eventually made it back to England where he was appointed an early Governor of the State of New South Wales. What the hell were they thinking? Previously, Bligh had caused trouble on the discovery ship of Captain James Cook (the Endeavor, I believe) who charted the east coast of Australia and the west coast of North America. The book entitled: The Return of Lono: A Novel of Captain Cook's Last Voyage (by O.A. Bushnell) is an excellent account of Cook's last visit to Hawaii where he was clubbed to death in the surf at Kona over a stolen rowboat. The novel is a weaving of fact and fiction. Yes, sports fans, the roots from England and the beginnings of modern Australia and the United States all fits together. My apologies to the natives who were there first, but you know what I mean.I remember back in my high school days a friend and I once snuck into the Gardens at night after closing. Though Australia is still an innocent country in many ways, removed from a lot of the world's troubles, I probably wouldn't recommend such a nocturnal adventure nowadays. The kids of today are missing out on so much fun and innocent mischief due to the security concerns of recent times, even though many of them think they know it all. Remember the time when you could walk up to the gate at the airport to see off your friends boarding their plane?

Best views and photo ops of the Harbour. I agree with the reviews before me. You must stroll through the Royal Botanic Gardens to Mrs Macquarie's Chair. Bring your camera and some friends and take awesome photos of the Opera House, harbour and bridge. You cannot come to Sydney and miss this.
An awesome walk...... Sydney Opera House is breath taking; a walk through the Botanic Gardens is sheer joy! Hats of to Sydney's town planners and city officials.Pradeep Thatai
Best view of the opera house and bridge together. I'd do this walk in reverse and start by walking through the botanic gardens to MacQuarie point. Best view of opera house and the bridge.

A beautiful walk where nature and city kiss each other. This is for a leisurely afternoon and you will never regret you chose to do it. As you walk away from the Opera House you can see the walk in the form of an arc reaching out to the lovely Royal Botanical Garden. There are tall trees and so no dearth of shade and the cool breeze which comes from the harbour will keep you fresh and rejuvenated. The view of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House from this place is simply breath taking. This is easily the best walk in Sydney!

Iconic Opera House. Opera House is as always magnificent. Each time I see her I love her the same. With time there is more croud around. The food selection and eating places are better and better. Just to sit and have lunch or breakfast is just a great feel. Will go and see her again in October.
Lush and green. Lovely gardens and spectacular trees. Just a few minutes walk from the Opera House and Harbour. The views across all the harbour are just great.
A must, if you have more than 24 hours. Just do it. Gorgeous walk. Take bus #333 from Circular Quay to Bondi. Bronte Beach is much quieter than Bondi and only about 20 minutes away.

One of the best sites in Sydney. Everyone thinks of the Opera House as soon you mention Sydney - so, it's a MUST...myself? I'd never heard of the Botanical Gardens & am SO glad to have discovered them! My Daughter loved pretending to be the 'Princess' at the Government Building & having somewhere low-key to just lolly-gag throughout the day was wonderful!
a great walk. a very pleasant walk in the sunshine with great photo ops of the opera house and sydney harbour bridge.

Simply Beautiful. You will love it. Magnificent location. Sydney Harbour to me would be one of the best in the world, beautiful on the eye, opera house is domineering and beautifully contrasts with Harbour bridge had clean with lovely weather. Must see on visit to Sydney. Gardens are fantastic.

I love this place so nice and peaceful, good for a nap. Walk through the botanic gardens with my husband via Mrs Macquaries Chair. A very nice easy walk through the gardens and along the harbour. I must do if you want unwind and take it easy for the day.
Royal Botanical Gardens. Lovely and peaceful. The rose garden was not in full bloom however those that were in bloom were very pretty.
The operahouse is amazing. We did a 1 1/2 hour tour and booked for the same evening a concert with a big discount on the tickets.

Gorgeous... well worth the time!. I walked from Darling Harbor along the water's edge to the Opera House and all the way along the botanical gardens. Really amazing and soul fulfilling. If you are a wanderer at all, take the time to enjoy the beauty of this gem nestled like a secret amongst tall buildings and the landmark waterfront.

The Opera House is lovely.... Easy enough flat walk. While the gardens are great, I wouldn't invest too much time in them if you're on a time-budget. There are botanicals everywhere, and it seems that every one that I've visited claims to be the biggest, best or most exotic. They're lovely, exotic, spacious and interesting- just not as interesting as going out and having fun, or doing something a bit different.

Not to be missed. The Opera House continues to be one of the world's best known and stunning buildings. The gardens, that sit by its side, not so well known, but none the less well worth walking in to soak up the wonderful views and relax.

Pleasant walk. Opera house to botanical gardens is a scenic walk either you take stairs on to the highway or walk along water front to corner of the road besides indian restaurant on to highway and cross it and enter gardens with vast greenery.

Lovely gardens in the CBD. If you have made it as far as the Opera House, even if you are not a nature lover, you must walk back through the gardens.Some great photo opportunities of the opera house from a distance, plus views across the harbour.It's great to look at the beautiful gardens, then glance up and realise with the skyscrapers you are in the middle of a big city. Easy to forget once you enter the tranquility of the gardens.You can use them as a cut through on your way back to the CBD or set aside some time to enjoy the place, find the cafe and read your book for an hour on one of the plentiful benches around the place.For those interested, there are free guided tours of the botanical gardens with lots of history and knowledgeable tour guides.Enjoy
Best view of the bridge and opera house. The historic gardens are beautiful with an ocean walk giving the best view of the Opera House and the Bridge.

Opera... View. Yes well if you travel to Sydney, what else than a visit to the opera bar? Great view but be prepared to pay for it. Food was good to. Nothing difficult to decipher. Very busy and hard to get a table on a good weather weekend. I give it a 'very good' for the location.

It is a great walk. This walk is special because you can look back to the Harbour Bridge and have the Opera House in front - great photos. It is also a lovely walk between teh harbour and the gardens and not a bad way to get between Circular Quay and the Domain and Art Gallery on a nice day.

Just Do It ! Really enjoyable.. This is such a special walk. If you have limited time in Sydney this really deserves a place on your "To do" list. There were young people, older folk, people in wheel chairs so it is achieveable for most to go at least some way along the walk. It is a 'breath of fresh air' in the middle of busy Sydney. You can stop and buy a take away coffee and sit and watch the action in the harbour. It really is a lovely way to spend some time on a nice day. Highly recommended.

Gardens are Beautiful. We walked in the Botanical Gardens in the early morning (8:00 AM) and it was just beautiful. I did not realize how beautiful these gardens are. A great place for travelers to work out those travel kinks.

Unique and Unequalled. This walk is one that still takes my breath away - the fact that you are walking right up against the harbour contained by a seawall but remaining in a stunning garden is fabulous. At any time you can wander off the walk to sample the delights of the Botanic Gardens - the lungs of the CBD - to all the way around to Mrs Macquarie's Chair and finishing around the Boy Charlton Pool. This walk beats anything I have seen overseas - I love it and Sydney too.

Stroll around the harbour. Great cafes near the Opera House then a short stroll to the Botanic Gardens. We also took the tourist train around the gardens for a hop on hop off trip. Magic photo opportunities with the Harbour Bridge and Opera House.

The best way to see the harbour. This is a great walk. You get the best view of the harbour from the Botanic Gardens, and the Gardens themselves are just beautiful - especially the herb garden. The Botanic Gardens has lots of fantastic spots for a picnic on a sunny day. I also like the Botanic Gardens shop for quirky, botanical-themed, gifts. The Gardens have been a wonderful lunch hour escape from work for years - I love it. It's one of my favourite places in Sydney.

Enjoy!. This is not a long walk but you can lengthen it by spending more time in the Botanic Gardens and continuing on to the Andrew (Boy) Charlton Pool (great place for breakfast or lunch) and then on to Wooloomooroo

Do tour the inside of the Opera House. The norwegian architect is so very evident in the inside structure of the Opera House. So much concrete & teak. Luckily, we were able to go inside all 3 stages and were amazed how beautiful & artistically designed they were. We stayed in Potts Point, so walked through the Botonical Gardens several times and were able to tour the Governor's house. It reminded us of many of the "lesser" Great Homes of England...very liveable and the immediate gardens of the home were stunning.

Quiet serene and full of amazing birds. Beautiful grass and large trees. Roaming the lawns are large Sulfur Crested Cockatoos and huge fruit bats live in the trees above. There is even a train that you can hop on for a ride around the gardens (there's a small fee).

A gentle promenade. The walk from the opera house to the botanic gardens is easy and flat as long as you avoid the jiggers, skaters and bikers. The attractions are at either end, though as there is little to see on the walk itself.
Great views. This walk is easy, free, very pleasant and has great views of Sydney. I did it early morning and next time in Sydney I'll do it late afternoon.

just do it. we originally though another boring garden, but its so big and pretty and you can get some great sights of the city. It was also nice to have a bit of quiet with the city views but away from the hustle and bustle!

Beautiful spot. Something free in Sydney....do this walk in the afternoon but be aware the gates close at 6.30pm, take your camera, amazing trees and flowers, the birds are awesome...Rosellas, Cockatoo's and even bats. Watch the sun set behind the city skyline and opera house, harbour bridge from the point by mrs Mcquaries chair...brilliant

A must if are going that far. The only way to go inside is by a guided tour or attending a program. The price is right, but make sure you can walk up stairs and all around, it would not be for everyone. It was closed on Good Friday and open on Easter Saturday.

The Opera House, Harbour and Botanic Gardens. For the traveller with limited time, this would probably be the best walk in Sydney. You get to see three of Sydney's best attractions in one very enjoyable walk.
No water. Great scenic walk but make sure you have water with you.no where tobuywater till you get to the Opera House.Wonderful view of the Harbour bride.

Beautiful!. The first place in the world that I saw with a sign saying "please, walk on the grass!". And even with this request, they have a very beautiful and well cared grass. Big, beautiful, and you walk with view to the Opera House, to the Bridge and to Sydney Tower.

Another must do !!. Started this walk as a bit of a look see when on the steps of the opera house as they are building the new access road to the opera house and have constructed a set of steps as a walk over to the entrance of the gardens.Once inside we kept strolling and taking it all in, seems a very popular place to jog through by workers on their lunch break and some playing musical instruments in quiet spots among the trees or a nap in the shade or eat some lunch on a bench under a magnolia tree in flower like we did.The plants and trees are mostly labled as to their species and where they originated which is great as it builds ones knowledge. Any way we kept on walking and came accross a cafe which had a number of shaded tables outside so couldn't resist having a coffee with the Ibis birds waiting for tit bits. So a lovely afternoon spent among the plants trees and birds in a magnificent location overlooking the Opera House and Harbour and came away with loads of pictures.ps if you've got kids there is a smashing train ride they can take which takes the path along the edgeof the harbour!!

A nice walk. A good walk with interesting views over the harbour and nice gardens. A great selection of native and exotic plants and trees. The moreton bay figs at the opera house end of the gardens are amazing!

Cooling shade!. Great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of city life with wide range of flora and fauna and lots of seating and shady places if you need to get out of the sun. There is a cafe in the gardens serving basic food at a reasonable price and toilets adjoining.

Stunning view and relaxing afternoon. Fresh air, blue sky, beautiful view, quiet, nice to walk around and chit chat with friends. There is also a bar below Opera House, it's packed with local, business men and travellers. Good to take photos at sunset. Lovely!

Stunning from start to finish. The must see opera house is a triumph, whether you like it's form or not and the backlit toilet roll holders and funky sinks are a memory that will stick for a long time. From there, it is a leisurely flat stroll to the botanic gardens, with several routes to choose from, including a bayside walk as well as a path through a Japanese zen garden. A cool drink in the shady seats of the cafe is a good place to end up.
Such a Pleasant Walk. Not only do you get great photo ops of the Opera House, but this walk is a joy - just the place to sooth frazzled nerves!

Recommended. The Opera House is really interesting to look around and there are some great views of the harbour and bridge there as well as a nice outdoor bar. The botanical gardens are beautiful and definitely worth a visit!

Moonset or Sunrise. We are blessed living just down the road from these great icons!Most mornings we get up early enough to catch either the moon disappearing behind a cruise ship at CQ (this is a MUST SEE in late March early April) or see the sun rising at the end of the harbour.Even though the Opera House fore court has been in building mode for a while, there is nothing more impressive then to see the big cruise ships coming into the harbour between 530-6am during the cruising season.As they turn around right in front of the Opera House and back into the CQ mooring, it is like free open air theatre. We are always surprised why we are the only ones there to see it......Very much worth the early morning rise during the cruising season!The walk back through the Botanic gardens at that time is not possible because the gardens do not open until 7am however the walk through the Domain or past the Cathedral and water gardens above the Cook & Phillip pool are also worth while.As I said, we are blessed living at Coppertop Cottage and being able to do this every morning. We try and encourage our guests to come with us in the morning on a nice day (YES, it is an early rise.........

Best views of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. It's free; an easy walk from Circular Quay; nice views all around; best views of the two main iconic attractions at the end - what's not to like ? In addition there's Government House. You've got to do this when you're in Sydney.

A great place for a early morning jog. It's an easy, flat walk along the water between the Opera house and the botanical gardens.
