Peaceful, except at lunchtime. A lovely view, easy walk, lovely plants but the closer to lunch we got the more joggers were about. Go early and relax.

Beautiful. A lovely walk for all ages & not to hard - the only draw back is the gates don't open to walk all the way along the waterfront in the week until 7am, not good for all those early morning walkers or runners
Relaxing. Nothing bad to say, best do it on a sunny day and take a picnic and enjoy yourself. Very easy walk with plenty of stops on the way.
Worth a walk. We did the recommended walk (in the maps at the entrances) and then stopped for lunch down in Circular Quay. Just lovely.
Good for morning jog. Nice weather in October and went all the way up to Mrs. Macquarie's Chair (stone bench). Sydney Opera house and bridge lok awesome from the chair..

This is required. If you end up in Sydney, there's no reason not to do this. It should be a requirement. We enjoyed our walk from the four seasons through circular quay down to the opera house and into the botanic gardens. What a marvel! Sydney keeps its areas so clean. We were marveled at the giant trees and flowers everywhere.

Great gardens. A spectacular spot with views to the harbour, shady areas to sit and relax and amazing plants.
There are also cafes and a restaurant.

Beautiful walk!. My husband and I had limited time in Sydney! We LOVED this walk! It's free, beautiful, and let's you experience the absolute best of Sydney! It's as relaxing or as fitness intense as you want it to be. We saw people laying in the grass and people out for an afternoon jog! This will not disappoint and is worth a visit in Sydney whether your trip is short or long!

Escape the concrete jungle. A great park to get away from the hustle and bustle of Sydney city.
Nice wide tracks. Fantastic views. Find the shade of a tree overlooking the always active harbour and sit back and relax.

Average. nothing special. This was a very vanilla walk. If you live in a country with excellent gardens, then this really isn't going to wow you.
Here are some better gardens: SG Botanic Gardens, Hyde Park, Central Park
A nice easy walk. Starting at the Opera House, this is an easy walk on sealed paths through the gardens with lovely views of the harbour.

Take a leisurely walk. We often walk through Botanic Gardens from Woolloomooloo to the Opera House and then into the city and always enjoy it. A leisurely walk gives you magnificent vistas over the Bay, takes you through the ultra-relaxing Botanic Gardens and lands you on the steps of the Opera House before you even know you're there. Take your time - about an hour of gentle meandering - and unwind before your next adventure...

Gorgeous. This is a beautiful walk and lets you take in the beauty of Sydney Harbour, Kirribilli House, the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. As a child I used to love going to the Botanic Gardens, they were always something special and after these many years they still are. Government House and the Conservatorium of Music are places of historical interest.
Lovely retreat in the centre of Sydney. Excellent to get away from it all. Pleasant walk whilst watching the Opera House and the Sydney skyline.
Best exercise while on holliday. Workers run here during there lunch and its no secret why, this walk will blow any harbour walk in the world away
Stunning views. Stunning views. Great photo opportunities. And it's also where a lot of Aerobics Oz Style is filmed.
walk of life. just beside @ idyllic view. perfect for familes ., with all the tourist around. beautifully maintained

Where we got married. It's a great walk past the Opera House (so many close up views of the different angles of the building), through the Botanic Gardens to the point at the end, overlooking the Harbour. The views here are terrific. Back in 2005 I got married here under the old Fig Tree. That was a fabulous day and the wedding photos included the Opera House and Harbour Bridge in the background. Memorable.The Gardens themselves are ideal to wander around the plants and trees or just sit and relax on the grass with a picnic. So quiet and peaceful. The city seems so far away. Just chill and enjoy.Everytime we visit Sydney from UK, we do this walk.

Relaxing place, gorgeous view. The area is just so beautiful with colourful flowers and birds. I would have most certainly plopped down on the grass if it weren't for the many flies in the area that we just rushed over back to the Opera House. That said, the scenery is gorgeous, just cover your nose and mouth if those flies get near!

I go almost every day....... I go almost every day to walk there...
Its in the city! You can breath good air, see the bridge and relax over the grass!

Scenic. So many different paths to take and beautiful gardens to see. With the water always in sight it makes the walk breathtaking. In the gardens you can sit under a tree or wander round the shop and cafe. There are toilets. The gardens are very well kept and there is a train (for a fee) that will show you around the gardens with a guide if the walk is too much.

Great Walk in Downtown Sydney. It's easy to forget you are in the heart of a major city when touring the Botanic Gardens. Starting from the Opera House, walk the paths that criss-cross the Gardens to see a great variety of native Australian and other tropical vegetation. Best of all, it's entirely free!!

On a glorious early spring day.... On a glorious early spring day we lunched in the park and walked around the pathways. Great food at Botanic Garden/Art Gallery restaurant. Hard to believe you are in the middle of Sydney. Well cared for lawns and paths, you can see the OperaHouse and bridge as well as downtown form a whole different perspective. Would also be a glorious picnic spot.
Walked Botanical Gardens on a sunny day. Heaven...beautiful views and a fabulous way to spend a few hours looking at the flora and fauna....fun sea and boats
Just beautiful. Just like a lot of other places in Australia, this is simply beautiful. Perfect place to bring a picnic and just relax after walking around for a bit.

wonderful. Sydney is a big city, and we have an amazing place like the Botanic Gardens right in the middle. The walk from the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens is very special. Great views, it is an easy walk and the gardens are simply beautiful
Free guided tour. free guided tour around sydney. 2 different company. 2 different route. 2 different tour guide. tips depends on u.
This where I got Married. Hated the bats. Loved the views. If you can do the prom in the park at dusk.Start at the Rose garden and walk down

Hyde Park, Art Gallery, Botanical Gardens then Sydney Opera House Walk. We did this walk in reverse and thoroughly enjoyed being outside in the sun with great views - I would definitely recommend walking towards the Opera House (not starting there). We started walking north through Hyde Park and visited the Anzac War Memorial and after walking around the gaudy Archibald Fountain we crossed over the road to the Art Gallery Rd and visited the Art Gallery of NSW. Then we followed the road to Mrs Macquaries Rd and we walked around counter clockwise (went down to the outer path nearest the water for most of it but headed up to see "the chair" and also a great lookout back to the Opera House). Then we walked back to the Botanical Gardens. These were generally lovely park areas surrounding a middle garden. We stopped for lunch here at the cafe. After walking around the park areas and realising that the Palace Gardens were a general area (not specifically a garden) we headed back to the waterfront and continued west towards the Opera House so that we had great views as we approached. After climbing the many stairs at the Opera House and looking around we finished off our walk with a chilled (alcoholic) beverage at the Opera House Cafe. Avoid the lunchtime period if possible otherwise beware the joggers.

Botanic gardens more of a park. Did we miss it? No exotic plantings except the exceptionally neat and extensive lawns. It's a pleasant stroll from the Opera House into town but, actually, there aren't many trees, very few flower plantings, and no conservatory. If you're looking for -- or would enjoy discovering -- exotic plants, this is not the place to find them.
touristy but must do!. Its a good way to see the opera house from a different angle and take in some sun. Great views and a good walk.

An enjoyable stroll. This is a very pleasant walk with some gentle inclines. Following the harbour wall around from the Opera house and entering the gardens the views are beautiful. Lots of greenery and interesting trees and plants surrounding you which is very relaxing. There are some sculptures and a lake which is very peaceful to sit by. The birds in the gardens are interesting and vocal.
Must See Sydney Sightseeing. Amazing vistas, beautiful gardens. A perfect introduction to Sydney. Walk from Circular Quai to the NSW Art Gallery!

One of life's great experiences. It's cheap (because it's free), it affords spectacular Harbour views, it's on level ground throughout, and it ends up at THE Australian icons - the Opera House with the Sydney Harbour Bridge providing an unforgettably photogenic background.
The Opera House and Botanic Garden. This shouldn't be missed. There it is , the iconic Sidney Opera House, right next to the Royal Botanic Garden. Planning couldn't have been better.
A nice walk on a nice day.. Its a really a peaceful & pleasant walk on a nice Sydney day. You could take a picnic lunch with you - just dont go there after dark.

Interesting and well kept gardens. The space and cleanliness is lovely in the middle of such a big city. There could be more signage to the tea house. It's quite hard to find if you don't know it's there.
Amazing. Just amazing to look at. Walk around and take in the view, have a drink and soak up the sight. It is a must to see.

Lovely walk, pity the tropical house was closed, without warning though. If you want to enjoy beautiful views, a lovely park location and escape the hoards of tourists at the Opera House and circular quay, then take stroll through the botanical gardens, it's such an oasis in the middle of the city. Take your sun block, the shady areas are fairly limited, and the breeze off the bay can be deceptive, we saw lots of people frying today!!

magic. magic walk and Opera house and the Harbour bridge are world wonders! Went to see Aida at the Opera and cast, costumes where fantastic! Botanical gardens with the views..on a sunny day, are superb!
Lovely Gardens. The Botanic Gardens had a wonderful selection of plants and there were some wonderful birds there as well. Our grand-daughter enjoyed the train ride round the gardens.
Fabulous gardens, great views!. Wide open spaces, ambling walks, plenty of places to sit and watch the world go by. Absolutely stunning and a nice (free) way to pass the time.

Easy view. Just take a few mins for me to come here, just walk alone, feeling lonely but this place was really nice, huge range of flowers, i could get easily amazing view to Opera House and horizon. Couples come here is prefer!!!

A beautiful park with spectacular views of the opera house and harbour bridge in the distance!. The gardens offered my favorite view and vantage point of the harbour and offered vistas that let you get beautiful flowers, the opera house, and the bridge in one frame for the perfect photograph!
Really nice. Loved this walk. Great views and wildlife. I would recommend this to anyone who wants to just go for a stroll, run etc..

Spectacular views. We did the walk around the Botanic Gardens right down to the waters edge and through to the Opera House. A must for those who love to stroll through beautifully manicured gardens. The walk is not difficult and on a sunny day the views are glorious. The Opera House is an amazing site to behold sitting on the waters edge, walking around the back of the Opera House I notice the offices and workers with what must be the best office views in Australia, so lucky. View of Sydney Harbour Bridge from the back of the Opera House is uninterruped and makes for some excellent photo shots. A lovely way to spend a day!!

Probably one of the most beautiful places I've seen. Every day, on the way to the Opera House, we would walk through the magnificient Botanical Gardens. The manicured lawns, the variety of flora and fauna, the coast line, and most importantly, the respect with which the Sydneysiders treat this treasure are certainly something to cherish. How lucky the Sydneysiders are to have a place like this.

Batty. When I was 15, this was one of my ambitions. Walk in the Botanical Gardens, Sydney, from the Opera House. It is a very nice walk and there was a large colony of fruit bats to observce. Lots of birds and not too many people. The trees are mostly marked to show what they are. Several places to eat and drink.

A Good Stroll. I would recommend starting at one of the main gates in the Botanic Gardens and finishing at the Opera House. That way you can view the water and the Opera House as you draw closer and you can finish with a coffee or beer at one of the cafes in front of the Opera House.

Walk with the runners!. A great opportunity to photograph the city from the vantage point of the botanic gardens. Its a lovely setting. Also good for pictures of the Opera House in front of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. The gardens are also fascinating with good signs and planting features. The path is full of runners, so you have to make way for them and take care. A stunning location for a nice afternoon walk (or run!)

One of those "pinch me is this real?" moments. The Opera House is well....the Opera House. I'm an American visiting Sydney for the first time and just love this city! The Gardens are gorgeous and a great place to take lots of photos! Aside from the renovations going on to the Opera House, the views are gorgeous!

Pleasant passing of time. If you have nothing to do then this walk is for you. The walk is flat terrain apart from the exit paths in some areas. There are always new plantings and the Harbour is a never ending parade of motor vessels and sailing ships.
Nice walk. The Opera house we find a little outdated from the outside, can have some proper cleaning and maintenance. The gardens are very nice and relaxing to walk through.

Construction at the Opera House at this time. Just take a walk around the Opera House at the front and see the Harbour and the Harbour bridge on a sunny day. Walk through and around the Botanical Gardens which is always fabulous. The steps of the Opera House have a huge reno project going on at present but you can still pass through there. Check out the succulent gardens/desert vegetation too at the Gardens. The Fern/Palm cage is also worth a visit and if you want souvenirs see the little shop. Dining upstairs at the cafe across from the souvenir shop is good. Nice to sit outside at the downstairs cafe but there are annoying birds around on the tables etc.

Nice walk. I personally enjoy more flowers, the Botanical gardens here seem to have more trees. The park is beautiful and so are the birds. If you have extra time for a stroll it is nice but would not recommend going out of your way.

Nice Way to Unwind after a Busy Day in Sydney. This walk was the perfect way to end a great day in Sydney..and the Botanic Gardens is the best place to get great pictures of the Opera House and Bridge together
Best view in Sydney. Don't miss this one, walk from the opera house around the harbour front to the botanic gardens. Loads of things to watch on the harbour, its a flat easy walk.

heatwave in Spring. A neat way to spend early evening- what a way to enjoy the beautiful Sydney Harbour. Watching the boats skim from Manly to Circular Quay. It is such a beautiful, building and am always amazed atthe design when you actually see it.

An easy stroll. If you don't want a long walk but just a relaxed stroll then this is the walk for you, beauty all around, flat and well paved for walking and also for wheelchairs, it is a lovely spot.

Fantastic. What a building....Fantastic. A visit to Sydney should allways include a tour to the Opera house. We went there by Fery and that by it self is fantastic with the views of the Opera hous over the Harbour

Colourful and rejuvenating. Leisurely walk, not too many people so you could walk at your own pace and enjoy water views and plants and the trees with the autumn changing of colours. Scenery over the Harbour and Sydney skyline also fabulous. The Gardens are very well kept...loved the rose gardens. You do not feel like you are in a busy city. Use public transport to get to Circular Quay as parking is often difficult

beautiful. the first time i walked through loved every second. i stayed all day then went for a swim in the pool on the edge. i have never got board of it and now love it more than ever...... a month ago i moved so close that i get to walk through every day on my way to work. soooo lucky
Well Worth It. This walk from the opera house to the botanic gardens or the other way is so well worth it. Take in the historic views of sydney harbour. A must do

One of many such walks. This is the first part of a much longer walk to South Head or Clovelly - forks at Rushcutters Bay. It's very good. There are also many other walks the maps for which wan be accessed by Googling Sydney Coastal Walks

Beautiful and relaxing. We had great spring weather and thoroughly enjoyed walking through the gardens around to Mrs Macquareis chair and back again the the Opera House. The Botanic Gardens are superb. Dont rush! Enjoy.
Sydney Opera House. The perfect location for a wonderful evening watching Madam Butterfly. The leading lady was Japanese as was the Conductor.
Picture perfect Sydney delivers on this peaceful walk. well worth the effort from the Opera House to Mrs Macquarie's chair - a lovely view of the harbour and city.

Sydney Highlights.. If you have 10 hours in Sydney, spend it on a visit to the Opera House and the Botanical Gardens. If you have several days, start off in the same manner. If you have usfficient funds, enjoy a concert or some other event at the Opera House. Chances are you will find it a memorable event.

Royal Botanic Gardens a Lovely Stroll. We walked through the gardens to see Mrs. Macquarie's chair. We were impressed at the variety of plants, and how well kept the area was. On a sunny day, this is a fun spot...great photo opps!

Beautiful.... There was some construction going on during the time we were visiting, but they have made a pedestrian bridge leading straight from the Opera House into the Queen Elizabeth/Opera House gates.

Wander to your heart's content. Beautiful wide walks wondering all over the park. Take any path and enjoy the plants, animals, and sculptures. This is how we found Opera being staged on a floating stage with the bridge as a backdrop. Wander around you cannot fail to find something interesting to you.
Spend time. Good in the beggining of the day and stay untl late. Good walk and amazing view. Organize yourself to see the opera concerts
A welcome break from the city. A wonderful relaxing walk away from the busy city which can take you across to Woolloomooloo for a quiet drink.

Oasis in the middle of the City. the walk from Opera House to Botanic Gardens is easy and well worth the effort. The weather was great and there's a pretty view everywhere you look. Get energized by enjoying nature --- and it's smack dab in the middle of business/financial district --- every city should have this oasis!

A must do. We have walked along from the Opera House through the wonderful Botanic Gardens many times but never tire of the magnificent scenery. It is great for tourists and locals alike - you will always see something different on each walk and the backdrop of Sydney Harbour is amazing

Nothing Better Than This On A Spring Morning. We walked from the place we stayed in Potts Point. Along the way we passed through the magnificent Victoria Stree, Woolloomooloo Bay, Botanica Gardens and finally the Opera House which is near to Circular Quay where we took the ferry to Taronga Zoo.
We took our time and truly enjoyed the walk on a fine spring morning.
Outstanding!. What a place to walk and relax. Herb gardens, spring flowers, majestic trees and the Harbour in the background...magic!
Wonderful. so beautiful place to take a walk and take the whole city in. Wonderful gardens and great resturants along the walk that you can stop and have a bite to eat and take the city in.

Serenity beauty and the big Sydney sites on a calm natural walk on harbour. To be so close to the centre of a huge metropolis like Sydney and yet have such peace and tranquility. It's a lovely walk through mainly manicured gardens with sweeping trails as well as hidden gem trails that wind amongst the undergrowth in the Botanic Gardens. Stunning views of the harbour, you can almost imagine what it was like here before European settlement (Although you need to imagine the bush as well, many of these plants are exotics to suit Anglo tastes)

A pleasant easy and scenic walk. This is a very easy flat walk that takes you from the Opera House into the Bottanical Gardens and extends along the waters edge along the Harbour with magnificent views of the Harbour Bridge. The Bottanical gardens are magnificent and very well maintained and include landmarks like Mrs Macquaries Chair another great vantage point for viewing the harbour and NSW Government House. Places of interest on the ege of the gardens are The Art Gallery, The Mitchell Library and The Domain. There is also an Olympic sized public swimming pool near the Art Gallery. The gardens cover a lot of land so it is best to look at a map and plan a route to take in all that is of interest to you.
Stunning gardens with a beautiful view.. Beautiful gardens with a stunning paved walk around the waterfront. We did the walk on a very hot day and wished we had worn sunscreen and a hat.

Beautiful views. Wonderful views all along the walk from the Opera House to Mrs Macquarie 's chair. It was an easy walk with level pathways well maintained. The Botanic Gardens had many well positioned seats to take advantage of views and rest a while. Seval toilets along the way would ensure no-one was in distress. The only disappointment was that Government House Was not open for public viewing inside that day due to functions, however I was still able to enjoy a stroll around the well maintained flower beds and lawns.
Superb walk, beautifully scenic view of gardens and harbour. The whole walk is beautiful and stunningly planted. Well worth a visit and take time to enjoy and absorb

A Spectacular Short Walk in Sydney. One of the best walks (strolls really) in Sydney. Start at the Art Galler of NSW and walk down through the Botanic Gardens to the harbour, around to the Opera House, around Circular Quay to The Rocks and the Museum of Contemporary Art, then take a train from Circular Quay Station to Museum Station, stroll through Hyde Park and you're back where you started. Brilliant. See my Youtube video called Sydney - Jewel of the Pacific - it will show you this route. AW (Tony) Scott

Peaceful exploration at no cost. This walk was a highlight of my time in Sydney. First off its free, and that is a good thing! There are so many cool plants to look at. The best time I would say to go is in the morning, check out the Opera House and then maybe hop on a ferry to Manly beach!There are a lot of people running/jogging on the path along the water so you have to pay attention, but this view is great. You can even bring a snack and sit on a bench, just take some time and enjoy the view

Lovely Walk. Touring through the Opera House and Botanic Walk is lovely! The area seems always full of tourists and locals out for fitness routines. There are nice cafes- although the ones right on the water are more expensive. A good alternative is the cafe inside the gardens. There are two- the upper one is more costly than the one underneath. The gardens themselves are well done with lovely walkways, good variety of plants from around the world.

You couldn't be anywhere else. This is one of the best harbour walks. You couldn't be anywhere else. Start at the Opera house with it's location and view of the Harbour and bridge. This is where the first fleet and later vessels moored at now Circular Quay. The first cove as you walk is Farm Cove and where the first farm of the colony was. The rise of the Botannic Gardens on your right and magical Sydney Harbour at the left. Keep walking and you come to Mrs Macquaries Chair . Convict built by her Governor husband. If you keep going you come to restaurants in the park and just beyond is The Art gallery. To the Chair is about 15 min and to the Gallery maybe a further 15 min on. Terrific on a sunny day.

The Botanic Gardens are amazing!. We have visited gardens all over the world and these in Sydney are at or near the top of the list. There are huge specimens of unusual trees such as various Ficus and an African Olive tree. We also visited at the end of winter when many trees and plants were flowering. The walks through the Gardens with views of Sydney Harbour just make it an unforgettable experience.
Stunning. One of the worlds most gorgeous gardens - relax and enjoy the stunning scenery and gardens lapping at the edge of Sydney Harbour. Take a sumptuous picnic, a chilled wine and friends

A great Way To Earn Your Lunch!. Wear comfortable shoes, take it easy and try to avoid the legion of perspiring runners pounding the pavement at lunchtime, and this walk is really enjoyable, scenic and relaxing.

Great views and gardens to relax and unwind.. the gardens were great then the walk down to the sea was so relaxing and pleasant we did this on the sunday and so the families were out in force and made it a nice place to visit

a dream. the opeara house is an absolute must when you visit Sydney.We had a guided walk with a little very funny guy who showed us all around, explained everything with a lot of funny experiences he had had in all thoses years he is working there.

End of the day stroll back to Darling Harbour. We had completed our circuit of the Opera House and decided to walk back to our hotel, the Ibis Darling Harbour, via the Botanic Gardens. Loved the Gymea lilies and bush gardens. Good views across parts of the Sydney Harbour.

One of the top 3 walks in Sydney. A beautiful walk from the Opera House along the waters edge through to Mrs Macquarie's Chair and on to Wooloomooloo (just keep the water on your left all the time). To return, look for the pedestrian bridge back towards the 'giant matchsticks' sculpture and the Art Gallery Of NSW which is worth a quick or slow look...it's free.Alternatively, from Wooloomooloo, after stopping at Harry's Cafe De Wheels, walk up to the boho area of Potts Point and get a train back from Kings Cross.

Peaceful and Clean. The walk from the Opera House through the Gardens was well maintained, well lit, and a nice spot for a romantic and scenic stroll. There is some construction near the Opera House, but it is covered by a facade wall which reduces the impact.
Brisk Mornings made enjoyable. The stroll from the Opera House and through the Botanic Gardens was lovely early in the morning. You are never alone with the myriad of early morning joggers

Nice cooling walk, great views. We walked from the opera house to the botanic gardens, to Mrs Macquarie's point and exited via the art gallery.The walk is nice and pleasant, plenty of trees and flowers for you to admire as well. Theres also many benches for you to rest.As we walked during the late afternoon (4-5pm), some camera pictures were spoilt by the uneven reflection of the sun. So avoid this time if you are there for photo-taking.

A comfortable walk.. The walk was interesting although the gardens were a little colourless for my liking. The gardens are well maintained in most parts although there was areas that looked neglected. Maybe after winter things are a little jaded.

Beautiful peaceful escape from the CBD. Take the walk along the harbour foreshore from Circular Quay, around the Opera House and into the Botanic Gardens. View Old Government House, Lady Macquaries Chair and the countless garden beds, sculptures and places to sit down and relax and enjoy the harbour views.

a must!. if you cant walk far then there are trains which travel frequently between the 2. an excellent way to have a proper look around and take many photos. the botanic gardens were beautiful, peaceful and relaxing. take a book/lunch/ipod with you and you could be there all day just looking at the views.it wont take longer than 10 minutes to get between both. there are cafes and restaurants and toilets avalaible and everything is very clearly sign posted.

No better place to enjoy the views. Spectacular views, beautiful gardens, perfect place for a walk or picnic. Did I say how spectacular the views are of Dydney Harbour? A must for anyone visiting Sydney.

Nice walk. Some work being carried out at the moment so walking up the stairs gets off putting but its a beautiful place. The gardens are a great place to chill out & picnic or just read a book in the sun.
a Must-see. This promenade offers great views of the botanical garden and the Sydney opera house. A tourist must walk it all the way to Mrs. Maquarie's chair.

Beauty and the bay. The Sydney Opera House is a must see for many Sydney tourists. You can grab a great meal (Bennalong Restaurant) or just wonder around looking at the people and the view. Don't forget to walk into the Botanic Gardens, the restaurant is great and having a look at the labels under the trees and shrubs is very informative. Again the view is superb. You can even sit on the grass with a sandwich or a whole picnic. A great way to enjoy Sydney's harbour.

Beautiful. One of the nicest walks you do anywhere in the world. Find the Spring garden and enjoy the blossoms, tulips and primulas, then walk around to the Quay via the harbour front to the Opera House.
Scenic and beautiful. A scenic and beautiful walk and truly among the cleanest major cities I have ever visited anywhere in the world.

Beautiful way to start the day.. This area is beautiful. The gates are open quite early and the walk around the waterfront is very peaceful. Nice to see some flying foxes living in the heart of Sydney.
opera house walk to botanic gardins. beautiful scenary, very pleasant and relaxing, captures essence of city, mix of tourists and locals walking together

What a great walking path. I could walk this every day. At approximately 4pm (depending on season) the Rainbow Lorikeets come to certain trees to collect berries. What a stunning display of colors. Give about 2-3 hours for a leisurely stroll with plenty of stops.

opera house - construction work. botanic gardens and domain great.
current construction and bypass access on parts of the opera house steps and front area.
Beautiful!. Just beautiful. A must do if in Sydney, plus its free!! Nice place to get a bunch of pictures if you are a photo aficionado as me.

Iconic Sydney Walk - a must. A truely iconic walk, taking in the very best of Sydney. The Opera House gets more impressive as you get closer - amazing just how big it is. The views are stunning, Harbour Bridge, ferries, Garden Island and the North Shore - then around to the gardens, which are immaculate.

wildlife. lovely park with lots wildlife ..follows the water around to the opera house ..nice flat walk..opera house leads onto many cafe and restaurants on the harbour ..great view and photos of harbour bridge

Great photo opportunities. The Opera House is iconic and great for photos as it is close to the harbour bridge. It only took us a couple of minutes to walk to the Botanic Gardens. They are huge and as we were going to be walking round the harbour afterwards we decided to take the little train which costs $10. It stops in 4 places so you can get on and off when you want. The Herb Garden was very pretty and there are some wonderful sculptures around as well as all the flowers and trees. The train driver gives a commentary and points out plants and trees of interest and gave us a lot of historical information. We finished the ride with enough energy to take the ferry from Circular Quay and walk round Darling Harbour

Sydney at it's best. One of the top must do's whilst in Sydney is to take the walk from the Opera House with its stunning curvatures and backdrop to the Botanic gardens with their unique Australian plants and trees, and tranquil setting. If you are lucky, you will encounter the odd exhibition, or demonstration of Australian and Pacific culture such as song and dance demonstrations with their stunning costumes and the like. This walk along the harbour or through the pathways winding into fantastic vistas provides memories for all. A highly recommended option.

Beautiful. Proud to be an Australian! What a fantastic icon. The Opera house and harbour is simply magical. The Botanic Gardens are lovely and peaceful. I loved the way the harbour bridge just randomly appears and disappears while walking through the grounds and you turn different corners. Nothing at all to dislike.
An icon. A must-see when in Sydney - take a stroll around the outside and enjoy the views of the harbour and the Bridge. The inside is also beautiful.

Do it in reverse.. I would recommend walking through the gardens towards the Opera House. This allows you to enjoy the gardens and then have the crowning glory of reaching Sydney Harbour. There are some great pictures to be had of the Opera House as you make your way around the water's edge toward the Harbour.

Just a nice relaxing stroll. I'm sure this would be a spectacular walk when spring has completely sprung and the construction equipment is gone. Right now, it's just a nice place to walk outside of the city hustle and bustle.
How fun to see what I only saw pictures of. A wedding party was getting pictures made with the bride dressed beautifully. The groom looked so happy, too. Fantastic!

Oasis of calm in the centre of Sydney. We like to enter the botanic gardens at Bent and Macquarie street and zig zag down the gardens towards the harbour. The herb garden is worth a look and depending on season will have different smells to offer. If you like prickles the cactus garden is worth a look as are the water features and statues. The fruit bats are far fewer these days and visitors can still get a thrill and occasionally a shock to see these furry creatures hanging around in the day before taking flight at dusk.When you reach the water turn left and follow the path along to the Opera House for views missing from most post cards and along to Circular Key, the Museum of Art and the rocks for great pubs and eating.

Nice walk!. Waling around the opera house is beautiful. Nice clean restrooms on the lower level of the harbor walk beside the Opera House. Could have spent all day wandering the Royal Botanic Gardens.

well known view. A walk to the most known gardens in Sydney is a real pleasuer. we Walked through the gardens saw lot of great trees. if you are looking for highlights of Sydney, there you'll find it.

Beautiful way to appreciate the harbour and gardens at once. A very easy stroll from the Opera House to Botanic Gardens - perfect on a sunny Sydney day. The water shimmers, and if it becomes too hot on the walkway, plenty of shade around the Botanic Gardens.
Walks. The walk along the foreshore is a must for everyone to enjoy, there is plenty to see and take interest in. I recommend this walk for persons of all ages.

Lovely view from the Opera House. The Opera House is a very beautiful piece of art standing by the sea. We loved to walk around it but didn't have the time to go to the Biotanic Garden. It would be better if the Opera House can light up a bit more at night time as it was not very outstanding when we were cruising towards the harbour
Great walk. Walked from Hyde Park to the Opera House via the Gardens. Visited the Governers residence along the way. It was a lovely relaxing walk.
Great Walk. A walk in the most famous and awesome gardens in Sydney, we covered the gardens walking and saw many great trees and Cactus plants. Some of the best views in Sydney.

Delightful. An easy walk from the icon that is the Opera House to the jewel of the harbour - the gardens. How lucky are we to have these gardens! Even when raining they are lovely. What out for the joggers on weekday lunchtimes though.
Free and first class. So nice to be able to enjoy that magnificant location completely free of charge. Reasonably flat in most locations and views to die for.

Breathtaking view. Living in Sydney for several years, taking regular walks in the botanical garden while enjoying the scenery of the ocean and garden was one of my favorite pass times. Great place to go for a walk/run or simply lie on the grass and read a book. A great location for a unique pass time!
Had to see it again. I never grow tired of seeing the Opera House. Views of the Harbour Bridge are fantastic. The Botanic Gardens Walk is a nice area for runners.
Very nice area. A must see, the Opera House is iconic and the grounds around there are beautiful with the water in the background. Many picture opportunities.
An English park in the sub-tropics. Huge ficus trees, a great situation, sacred ibises and cockatoos, and brightly coloured lorikeets all over. Splendid.
Wonderful Gardens. The views from the Botanic Gardens Walk are wonderful. A great place to take a break from work and enjoy some greenery.

Easy walk with gorgeous views.. This is a fairly easy walk - not hilly, and has gorgeous views of the Opera house and Sydney Harbour bridge. We did this walk full circle from our hotel and included a trip across the bridge. If you do the bridge you must be able to do several flights of stairs to get up to bridge level

Simply Beautiful. We found ourselves inadvertently walking through the Botanic Gardens after visiting the Art Gallery of NSW just south in The Domain. The gardens are beautiful, expansive and impeccably maintained. I was impressed by the Fernery as well the Palm Dome and loved seeing the massive bats tangle from the trees. We walked along Farm Cove, which offers an amazing panoramic vista the Opera House, Harbour Bridge and skyline. While there (April/May 2012) some construction was taking place on the Opera House steps and nearby structures, but it was not intrusive and in no way dampened the experience and impact of such a famous landmark. Educational, inexpensive and entertaining!

History in every step you take.. A comfortable, easy walk to enjoy the famous Sydney landmarks of Circular Quay, The Opera House and harbour foreshores on land that was the site of the first farm of the first settlement of Australia in 1788. The Gardens are carefully kept and botany well labelled and are a perfect picnic venue in the heart of Sydney.

A "Must-Do" in Syndey. This walk is great with all the views: Opera House, harbour, botanic gardens, the bridge. It's beautiful, not too crowded (at least in August), and very peaceful. I recommend walking all the way around to the marina at Woolloomooloo, and rewarding yourself with a meat pie from Harry's Cafe de Wheels.

Go to the cafe. The walk in the sunshine from the opera house to the botanic garden was very enjoyable! You can also take the tourist train. There is a very nice cafe in the garden. We saw a lot of birds and number of interesting trees. It was a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Gorgeous and well maintained. Great way to spend an an hour or two exploring all the unique vegetation, birds, and animals. Keep an eye out for the beautiful parrots nesting in the trees.

BEAUTIFUL SCENERY. I love doing this walk since it gives beautiful scenery to a persons eye. It is a spectacular walk. You don't feel like your exercising since you are distracted by the beautiful, fresh outlook. It is beautiful to do on a sunset or sunrise or even on a beautiful day.
Both a Must See. Stunning Building - must be on every one's list of must see places - while walking in the gardens visit the governors house gardens too
Nice on the outside. The opera house is an impressive building from the outside but i found it a concrete monster on the inside.

World class architecture- Sydney Opera House. Definitely must go for all fancy architecture & construction details lovers. Comfortable pedestrian walk along harbour & way to Opera House. Friendly & professional guide tour. Have a more understanding to the building history of the heritage building & star architect through the guide tour. Nice cafe bar & relaxing restaurant is must go also.

Photo opportunity for you buffs.... Would recommend to take a taxi into Mrs. Macquarie Chair area (in the Botanical Gardens) and walk along the bay to the Sydney Opera House. Great photo shots of the Opera House and the Bridge together!

Worth setting aside an afternoon. This is something which costs nothing and you will see a lot!Firstly the great views from the Opera House then you can choose a number of routes through the Botanic Gardens where you'll encounter the largest trees and many interesting examples of vegetation. Some of the fig trees are enormous. This walk is close if you're staying in the hotels on the quay or in northern Macquarie Street - the Intercontinental, Sir Stamford or Quay Grand. It is right on your doorstep.
Relaxing exercise. Beautiful park like gardens, rare specimens (if you're into that), gorgeous views of the harbour that sneak up and surprise you... What more could you ask for!
The most beautiful walk in Sydney. the views are superb every step of the way. Everybody loves it from serious joggers to families with kids on tricycles. take your camera.
A must do!!. I've been to Sydney many many times and can't believe I haven't done this lovely relaxing walk before. Fantastic!!

You Have to See this Amazing Icon!. The Opera House is world famous. You can just go there and walk around it yourself or take a tour of the Opera House or perhaps dress up for the evening and go for a dinner and show. The Gardens are a lovely place for a walk, run or picnic as they are right on the Harbour.
Beautiful walk through the gardens.. Just beautiful plants, the lay out of the gardens, the pathways, the statues, it was peaceful and lovely to walk through.
Amazing. This part of the city is spectacular. The opera house and botanic gardens are my favorite places in Sydney.

Beautiful walk. on a sunny but cool day in Sydney, this was a great finish to breakfast. Actually walked the oposite direction from Woolloomooloo to the Opera House via the Botanical Gardens. Lots of work done in the gardens in recent years make this an extraordinary space in the middle of a busy city and harbour.

My favorite walking place in sydney. Great combination of a beautiful and serene water-front with lovely greenery in the botanical park. Park closes by 530 pm in the evening - so, you need to get there early.

Just gorgeous!. Short walk between Opera House and the Botanic Gardens, which you will absolutely love! Both nestled in Sydney Harbor near the water taxi/ferr bay and along the bus route, you can find lots of great restaurants to enjoy; wonderful little shops. And when you enter the Gardens, you may be tempted to climb the nearest Jackson Fig, but refrain from doing so. Although ifd you do slip up, the grounds-people are very nice about it.

add this to the to do list. What a beautiful / amazing walk.The gardens are stunning, you need to stop and look up as you walk as the skyline is glorious. Walked back through here at dusk and saw all the bats flying which was even better

Great romantic walk. Nothing beats this scenic and leisurely stroll by the sea. I would recommend that you start from Circular Quay, heading towards the Sydney Opera House, where you can spend an hour or so touring it. Just five minutes' walk along the shore, you will reach the Royal Botanic Gardens, a lush and vast park where they invite you to walk on the grass. It is filled with many species of plants and herbs. Stop by the central lake where you can see birdlife as well as eels swimming along. Better yet, bring some food and wine and have a picnic. A lovely way to spend a spring morning

Amazing design.. Thre's nothing I can think of that I did not like. I liked almost everything, the view across to the Sydney habour bridge and the other side of the city. Fantastic view, good bars and kitchen.

Relaxing.. I visit Sydney on a regular bases. I make a point to walk through the Botanic Garden. In the winter time in Australia there is always
intresting flowers to look at.

Beautiful. we did this on our first day by accident! we went to the botanic gardens and then there is was the opera house!! very exciting to see the opera house from all different agles and distances and then to eventually see it up close! :)

One of the nicest city walks ever!. Every direction you look there is the immense beauty of city. There is space, amazing architecture, native trees, children, runners, water and just keep walking through the botanical garden another highlight of my Sydney city trip.

Absolutely beautiful. There is a postcard view in every direction during this walk. It isn't a difficult walk, doesn't take too long, and will provide you with limitless pictures to take home and show off. It's also a great place to jog / power walk / picnic / etc.

Breathtaking. The bird life, the breathtaking water landscape views, the gardens themselves. The only disappointment is the fact that the Botanic Gardens ran the Flying Fox Bats out of the Gardens. I always look forward to seeing them and this year's visit proved very disappointing.

Must do!. Great location....great views....beautiful and well done!
Also a lap pool on the right side with some sexy swim studs!
The bats in the Botanical gardens are a must do!

WOW. I have been around the world a bit... seen some parks, and i just can't stop comparing this park to any other I have seen.It is amazing... Recommendation, go to the chinese market, buy all sorts of interesting food and drinks (the cold tea with the round thingies inside is yummy) don't take to much... just for the walk.you can walk down to the park. Walk around...take your time... close to the river, more in the garden.When i was there there were so many parrots of all sorts and birds.Crumble up some bread you got from the market and see how they all come to you... at one point i had more that 4 Kakatoo on me sitting... and birds all over.Take your time to just relax. If it's summer time see how all the ausies sunbath on the grass :)
The gardens are beautiful. You can easily stroll the gardens. They are beautiful, grand, serene and a wonderful respite if you want to get away from the hubbub of the city. Do not miss!
Great walk for photos. Great wee walk for taking some nice pictures of the Harbour bridge and Opera house. Beautiful surroundings and easy for anyone (mobile impaired) to do.
Nice walk. We did this on the way back to our hotel, and were not dissappointed. Beautiful gardens and a great way to walk around the city without all the cars!

Needed More Time!. Could have spent a whole day in the Botanic Gardens alone, we only walked through them to get to the Opera House. Will know for next time to allow at least half a day or more to check it out more thoroughly.

Sydney photo opportunity. Sydney has some great views and the harbour provides a large percentage of them. This pathway takes in some great scenery, with amazing Sydney icons and the CBD skyline real highlights. The gardens along the way are stunning too.  For me, the real highlight of this pathway is the sunset. From here you can watch the sky come alight behind the CBD skyline, the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. An excellent vantage point for photographs. Expect to see wedding parties taking photos on the pathway in the afternoon.  An excellent part of Sydney and highly recommended.

a treat to one's eyes. If you want to get in shape and also want to relax your eyes, take this walk everyday as my hubby and I did. You will see the park full of joggers and tourists. The gardens are gorgeous and mesmerizing,

This place was good. Opera house is really nice to see. The structure is really amazing. Botanical Garden is a very nice place rst. You can go ith your family and freinds and enjoy having a lunch or snacks in the grass bed. As we did you can take some cards and play cards. The place was very ell maintained and nice.
Easy access and great views. Take the ferry or train to Circular Quay and wander across. Very Sydney thing to do and you get million dollar views for free.

Casual walk before a concert at the Opera House.. The walk through the botanic gardens before our 2:00 concert was an excellent prelude to an afternoon of Wagner. There are lots of wonderful specimens and displays including the tropical garden, rose gardens and native plants.
Stunning. A beautiful Garden to walk through and an easy relaxing walk from Circular Quay. Walk in the garden or walk along the harbours edge
A must!. A cool place to go in the heart of the city! Beautiful trees and flowers. Look for the bats at the top of the trees... They sleep most of the day!

Always beautiful and interesting. I've lived in Sydney since 2003 and used to live near the Domain, so I used to jog between the Opera House and the gardens. Its a lovely lovely walk, with many interesting people to watch, and absolutely amazing views. Sydney can be annoying for many reasons, but this walk and those views make it all worthwhile.
wow. This is a great place to spend time! I really loved the bats that hang from the trees near the cafe. The views of the harbour and bridge are amazing and it's a great place to have a picnic.
Beautiful walk. Big garden with beatiful trees. Nice by sunny days! Take a map and go visiting the government house (free)
Lovely walk to Mrs McQuaries Chair. Lovely views and pretty gardens. The path from the opera house and along the front is easy to find and you can loop into the city centre from there.
Beautiful walk. Nice easy walk around the best harbour in the world. We walked right to the end and came back for a nice lunch at Circular Quay

Rellly nice wlk, very nice gardnes. If you like urban green lungs, this is the place.
Very big and diversified park with lots of nice places to sit and relax.
Look for the friendly Kakadoos (white parrot with yellow "spike" head feathers)

Great Walk. If you enjoy walking, then you should try this.
It's a beautiful walk where you can take it at your leisure, enjoy the sights as you go and stop and take some great pictures.
Definitely would do it again.
Beauty in the middle of the city. The walk from the Opera House to the Botanical Gardens is gorgeous, it is so quiet and tranquil - amazing to think you are in the middle of the city

Nice walk during the cooler months. The botanic park is worth visiting any time but in summer the walk can be a bit hard to manage. The pleasant walk from the Opera House to the Botanic Garden also goes near the NSW Art Gallery. There are lots of nooks and crannies in the Botanic garden for some seclusion and contemplation.
beautiful. very peaceful nice walk great picture spots...everywhere..when sun is going down the opera house and bridge are gorgeous

Love the gardens. I work near the gardens and so try and go there as much as I can in good weather. There are so many different areas to run, have a picnic, relax, take awesome photography etc etc. One of the things I like doing include walking round the cove until you get a great view back on the city, the harbour and the opera house.There are very cool forest type spots higher up in the gardens which are great on a really hot Summer day as they keep quite cool. There is also good access to many parts of the city via the garden gates on the city side as well as Woolloomooloo on the opposite side.If you are looking to do some exercise then head down on a week day lunch as there are hundreds of people training which can provide some extra motivation if you don't mind sharing a path.

A quite refrain from teh surrounding city. One can loose oneself in the Gardens. A great place for a run or a stroll. Lots of birds that have become very used to humans and you can get rather close to many of them. The plants are wonderfully maintained and a wide variety.
Nice spot for photos. The structure of the Opera House. The garden is good for a stroll or jogging, very nice views as well.

Lovely break from the city. Provides a great escape from the city, however expect to be mowed over by pretentious yuppies kitted in the latest fitness fashions by Stella for Adidas SS12/13 with polarized Prada aviators, they're bronzed by the cream of a tub, with their iphone glued to their arm by the mix of sweat and cream, and transfered to a parallel universe by the beats coming from headphones seemingly wired into their brain.Don't forget to bring a bottle of water!

Scenic, but not Remarkable. Like most tourists, I had to see the iconic Sydney Opera House. The building is impressive. Due to a performance, I was unable to see inside. Taking pictures out front is difficult. You can not capture the beauty of the building up close. The best shot is on the ferry. I believe it is the one to Manly. Take the ferry and you will get a fantastic background shot.The Opera House/Botanic Garden walk is lovely. For a leisurely day exploring central Sydney, the walk is perfect. However, I visited Australia with a taste for adventure. If you are short on time, skip this walk and head to the mountains or outback for abseiling, four wheel driving and other adventures. The gardens are lovely, but not necessarily unique. There are countless scenic walks in Sydney. This is not the best.
A visit to Sydney isn't complete without this. You can't visit Sydney without viewing the Opera House. The Gardens are beautiful as well. Worth the time to visit.

Stunning view of Sydney Harbour and Botanic Garden. This one absolutely a must do stuff in Sydney. You will discover a lot of beautiful flowers and plants in the Botanic Garden and see a great view of Sydney Harbour and the Opera House. If you plan to visit Sydney, I can recommend you to do this walk. I can also recommend you to see the sunset from the Botanic Garden, so amazing.
Nice building and wonderful garden. Take your time to visit the Opera House, looking at the panorama and visit the garden. Relax yourself and do not forget your camera.

Breathtaking. Just go, see for yourself how beautiful it is. The Opera House is unbelievable. I couldn't believe how big the arched windows were and the wonderful view from them over the harbour. I attended a Ballet there and loved it. The surrounding area was beautiful and you can hop on a little open train that goes round the Botanical Gardens which stops in different places in the gardens, which enable you to have a good look round.

Take the time for a walk.... Definitely take the time to take the walk from the Opera House to the Botanic Gardens - and then into the Gardens. Good photo opportunities, and the Gardens themselves are just so pleasant and peaceful. A very nice setting in the city.
Beautiful walk on a sunny day. If its a nice day ,a must do on your day in Sydney.Very peaceful,normally not too many people ,ticks all the boxes when with a partner or family

Actually you should do this other way round!. Start your walk opposite the State Library's Mitchell Wing and walk following signs for opera house, basically downhill and towards harbour. If you get it right opera house will come at you through the trees or else...to your left along pathway on harbourrs edge. Either way just another of Sydney's magic moments!
great walk in a great garden. The botanic garden walks give you lots of different views to the bay and the opera house. The garden is very nice, clean and informative on local plants and trees.
very impressive. The famous opera house has a good strolling path for walking around the outside and the botanical gardens next door are also very scenic and interesting - all free!

Great for early morning Cardio. 6am cardio session? This is the place to be - no traffic lights to hold you up, plenty of stairs to run up and down. Note though that the gardens arent accessible until 7am. Even if youre not into exercise the walk is beautiful, peaceful and there are plenty of places to sit your bum down if you want a rest. In the middle of the gardens near the kiosk and toilets is where the fruit bats gather to sleep - this is amazing!!!! Look up and you will see hundreds of them.
A great way to see these icons of Sydney. On a clear day... you can enjoy this walk even more. We've walked it in the rain too and it's still lovely.

Great Picture Opportunities. The garden is beautiful, but the images of the Opera House with the Bridge in the background while looking over the harbour are amazing. Getting to Macquarie's Chair provides a great relaxation spot while watching the sun set over the bridge.
opera house and botanic gardens walk. Brilliant beautiful park, beware joggers, they are legion and may bump into you

Work in progress!. There was a lot of construction work going on here today with a digger having excavated a hole about 2 meters deep but it was all fenced off so don't know what they were mining for?

Very nice, serene walk. We walked from Hyde Park to the Botanic Gardens, going as far as Mrs MacQuarie's Chair before turning around and walking towards the Opera House. Everyone visiting Sydney should do this walk. It is peaceful, serene, and lovely.
Easy stroll. Beautiful views and grounds. Easy access from Opera House and a lovely place for a rest of the grass.

Lovely view of the harbourside. If you're going down to the opera house during the day, you must walk over to the Botanic Gardens! The Gardens are simply beautiful and there's amazing views from any point of the Gardens. With many places to rest,read a book,people watch, or sight see, the Botanic Gardens walk is totally worth the extra time!
Beautiful. view after amazing view unfolds...take a picnic for mrs macquaries chair

Great. Fantastic tour of the Opera House and also got to see the Sydney philharmonic orchestra playing one evening...a special experience. The botanic gardens are a great attraction and had a fantastic backdrop of the city skyline, harbour bridge and the opera house (great for photos).

Beautiful. The Opera house is in a great location with spectacular views all around it. Lots of places to take pictures and can sit on the steps and enjoy the view of the Opera House. The Botanic Gardens are beautiful, very relaxing and the Cafe makes amazing chicken schnitzel. Will visit both again :)

What a beautiful walk. Wonderful botanical garden that takes you past Government House and to the Opera House.
On a clear day, take a rug and picnic and sit under the large trees and enjoy the scenery

A Glorious walk. Take your time and wander around the oaths and then off into the botanical gardens, it's all free and affords visitors some of the most delightful views of Sydney Harbour and across the Opera House to the Harbour Bridge.

A Beautiful Building. Its just breathtaking and have a walk around it as you find little shops selling all different trinkets, and watching artists paint the house, we got a beautiful hand drawing that we both watched being drawn for 5 Dollers, and inside th sound is truly amazing
Relaxing. Relaxing walk and perfect for watching a beautiful sunset behind Opera House and Harbour Bridge.

Great Walk. The stunning Opera House is a precurser to a leisurely walk the the gardens. Numerous species of plants and trails leading off through rain forest like conditions...even including the bats.
Peace and Quiet. Beautiful place to stoll in the well maintained gardens don't forget to visit the eels in the pond. Beautiful place to get close to the Harbour Wall.

Definitely check out the Botanic Gardens. We spent nearly a whole day here strolling among the fascinating plants and listening to the many strange Australian birds. A kookaburra flew right up to us near the Government House. The views of the harbor and the city were amazing.

Well worth the journey. Love the layout, Warm, sheltered area wth lots of great places to sit and vantage points to view the harbour. Walking from the Art Gallery to Opera House was an easy stroll and enjoyable people watching experience

Lovely walk in the centre of Sydney. A beautiful walk in which you get to see the iconic Sydney Opera House, some great views across the harbour, and then get to explore the fantastic botanical gardens - and all in the centre of Sydney! A very peaceful walk with lots to see, well worth doing if you have a bit of time to spare. One of the best parts is once you are done you are still so close to the city centre if you want to go shopping, or to buses/ferries if you want to spend the rest of the day elsewhere.
Great Walk on a sunny day!. Really Great Walk and lots to see, soak up the atmosphere of this area of Sydney!
Beautiful gardens. grab the train, is great little ride around the gardens, you get to see all the park in 25 minutes, and you can hop on and hop off

one of the best jogs on planet earth!. this whole area is a beautiful place to jog, walk or stroll with your lover! incredible views of the opera house, harbour bridge, bay, downtown, you make it! this is where the photographers come to due the wedding and money shots....

Opera House and Botanic Gardens Walk. Very pleasant and easy walk along the foreshores of Sydney Harbour with great views and atmosphere. Depending on how much of the Gardens you wish to walk, the walk could take from 1.5 hours to 3 hours and possibly longer if you include the walk to Mrs Macquarie's Chair (highly recommended due to the views).

Beautiful walk but lots of construction happening. We often walk from the Rocks area through Circular Quay around the foreshore of the Opera House to the Botanical Gardens and did so this week. Just be aware that you can't walk up the front steps of the Opera House at the moment as there is a lot of construction going on and they are waterproofing the steps. You can still get through, just not so pretty at the moment. We also often do the reverse walk, parking near the Art Gallery and walking through the gardens to the Opera House. The Gardens are so big that you can always find a new path and discover a new little garden area to explore.
A great walk.. This is a very easy walk with stunning views of the harbour. Just be aware that many office workers run this route at lunchtime and can get rather annoyed if you gettin their way!
World class views. Sydney has more natural beauty than just about any place on earth, and this walk is one of the best in town.

opera house steps under renovation. Most of the steps are out of bounds as the waterproof membrane underneath is being replaced; the sign 'to the gardens' has the arrow pointing the wrong way ...go right, not left.The gardens are looking particularly lush, not surprising as they have had a lot of rain lately. I particularly enjoyed the path up to Government House, and took a tour (weekends, by ticket from the gatehouse).

Great structure to visit along with a beautiful garden to walk.. The Opera House was spetacular/ impressive. Would be a beautiful place to attend an opera or consert. Botanic Gardennext door was beautiful and very relaxing to walk.
Amazing. This structure never ceases to amazes me. Really worth checking out up close.

On a sunny day in June. Not far from the City centre geographically but a world away in that the peacefulness of the Botanic Gardens walk was an absolute joy..The gardens looked even better than last year, the sun shone and It was lovely to walk round to the Opera house, watching the Ferries bobbing alsssson toward Circular Quay or over to Manly.The Coffee shop was a bonus,,,great coffee
Well worth the Visit!. I love this part of Sydney. The smells from the botanical gardens, the architecture of the Opera house and surrounding buildings and the wonderful cafes and restaurants nearby.
great views. even in winter the gardens are lovely and you will be rewarded with fantastic views of the Opera House, Harbour and Harbour Bridge.Botanic restaurant is also very good
a great walk. One of the beautiful walks in the world. Not to be missed.
A lovely place for a stroll. We liked walking through the park & the children loved running along & climbing the trees. We had a great view of the Opera House as we approached.

The most lovely walk in the city. I have done this walk quite a number of times and one of my friends had her wedding pictures done here. You cannot get a better view in Sydney around the harbour in an relaxing environment. Have a picnic, take some pictures. Soak up the city in the quiet and better yet don't pay a cent. No tourist should miss this. From a displaced Sydneysider tourist.
A great way to stretch your legs.. The palm garden was stunning. It was like a prehistoric jungle. We also enjoyed the bamboo grove; the creaking of the giant bamboo was amazing and eerie.

What a Way to See the Best of Sydney.. Seeing the famous Sydney Opera House up close is an amazing sight. Along with this, watching the ferries come and go across the Harbour, getting a great view of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and then walking around to the prettiest, best located Royal Botanic Gardens in the world must be the highlight of a visit to Sydney. You can sit at one of the many cafes beside the Opera House to take in the atmosphere, or you can wander around to the Botanic Gardens to have lunch and a walk amongst a huge variety of plants, all set beside the beautiful harbour. Sydney is probably the most beautiful modern city in the world, as this experience will prove.
I night to remember. wonderful experience excellent service and food. The opera House day or night at its best.
Harbourside Stroll. A combination of outstanding harbour views and a quality botanical garden experience
Best views. What a great way to experience Sydney Harbour and the Botanical Gardens. Lush grounds, vibrant people, quiet & peaceful way to spend a day with no stress

The tour of the Opera House is time well spent. We took the early tour of the Opera House and it was not crowded at all. The guide clearly enjoyed his job and shared lots of information about the Opera House in an entertaining way. It only takes an hour but is time well spent. Make sure to use a coupon. They are available online and in guidebooks.
Magical. One of Sydney's prettiest most tranquil spots, I love it.
Wonderful Walk. One of the most beautiful walks, especially early in the morning when only the runners are about. Very peaceful and great views of the Opera House.
Fabulous Walk. Sydney is one fabulous city walk and I really enjoyed all aspects of this starting in the Botanic Gardens and finishing at the Opera House.

Great Building. Great history and story all in our life time, well worth doing the tour to find out the history and see the entire building, the guide was very good and the ear phones made listening to the guide very easy. A great asset to Sydney along with the Botanic gardens and the Govern Generals Home.
beautiful. walk all the way around the opera house and simply carry on to the gardens which offer lovely views of the bridge etc as well as all the plants , the gardens offer ,
Very nice. This is a lovely walk round from the Opera House to the botanical gardens.Great views from the other side of the harbour and best of all its free.
What's not to love?. Read the title! (the Gardens have a living Wollemi Pine--dinosaur food).

Expectations fullfilled. If in Sydney you should not only consider walking around the famous Opera House but I suggest to take time to explore the amazing Royal Botanical Gardens. Numerous paved and unpaved paths lead to hidden places and all is very carefully maintained. The gardens are also a great escape to detach yourself from the suffocating tourist blob that just sticks mainly to the Opera House. The best experience of the Opera House is of course if you actually go and enjoy one of the plays. Best bucks for your money! Avoid all other costly tourist traps.
Beautiful Gardens Stunning Voices. Walking in the Winter Sunshine watching the Joggers dash byListening to (Bethlehem) Tauronga (Youth) Choir sing NZ Anthem in the House pure magic
Relaxing. A nice spot to see lots of different plants though shame about the bats.

Take the stroll. Grab a picnic lunch in the city before taking the stroll from the Quay around to Mrs. Macquaries Chair. Cop a squat there - you will not be disappointed by the view you have, as you eat. This is a peaceful and breathtaking walk. Then walk off lunch through to and explore the rest of the gardens.
Peaceful oasis. Escape the hustle and bustle of the city , plus great views looking back towards the opera house , bridge and the city skyline
Nice to see it for real. This is really what Sydney is so popular for. Its great to see this for real.
lovely walk. take a good pair of shoes this is a lovely walk and the gardens are beautiful, we got chatting to some of the other walkers and it was great fun to learn more about the exotic plants.

Away from touristy areas, Sydney is another big city. The walk from the Opera House to the Botanical gardens is quaint at first, then gets a bit crazy as you have to look for traffic opposite what you are used to - and it is the CBD (central business district) with the hospital very close.
Great location for running. Loved this area for a walk or jog through the gardens. A great place for a single traveller.
Beautiful scenery.... The Gardens are HUGE! There is a whole day's worth of grounds to explore.

Excellent View of Opera House and Bridge. A must-do in Sydney. we walked from st. mary's cathedral all the way through the botanic gardens and to Mrs Macquarie's Chair. The view there is fantastic. The walk from that point to the opera house was also enjoyable. A must if you want excellent shots of the opera house and sydney bridge!

A Stroll Along the Harbour and Through the Gardens. We stayed in Manly, a town about 40 minutes away from downtown Sydney by boat. After coming into the harbour by ferry, we followed the Writers Walk, a 50 person bronze plaque trail along the harbourfront, including plaques for Robert Louis Stevenson and Jack London, took pictures of the iconic Sydney Opera House, and then entered into the Royal Botanic Gardens, an amazing park stretching out along the water. The Botanic Gardens, established in 1816 and home to over 17,000 plant species, has, for us, really fascinating flora and fauna; almost every creature and plant we saw was one we don’t have at home in Canada. Funny Ibis birds with long curved beaks, noisy mynah birds (cheeky beggars), red-beaked ducks with tiny babies (it was Spring there when we visited), and other interesting varieties of birds captured our attention, as did the trees full of Flying Foxes, an indigenous variety of large fruit bat. These creatures have colonised several trees in the park, from which the wardens are trying to remove them, with little luck, as far as I can tell. The Mynah birds have incredibly sentient faces. There are a couple of venues for art exhibitions in the Gardens and we were lucky enough to be able to check out the Artisans in the Garden art exhibition at the Lions Gate Pavilion in the Gardens, an interesting show of sculpture, pottery, jewellery, and ceramic art in a garden setting. We then wandered through the fern pavilion, in which beautiful varieties of tree fern were displayed – these are really amazing – and the Palace Gardens, whose sculpture reminded me very much of the Boboli Gardens in Florence. This walk is highly recommended. See more info and lots of pictures here: http://lmaclean.ca/2011/10/a-ferryboat-ride-and-a-stroll-through-the-gardens-sydney/

Worth coming from the USA for!. Was looking forward to seeing the Sydney opera house on our recent trip to Australia and it did not disappoint. Loved walking around these beautiful gardens too. Just lovely
walking in the sunshine. A great little retreat from the City , very relaxing setting.
Spectacular views. Relaxing, Free and enjoyable. Great picture oportunities. We walked to Mrs. MacQuaries chair then back through the park. The bats were interesting and something different.

One of the best runs in Australia. Every time I visit Sydney I try to take my early morning run around the opera house, across to Mrs Macquaries chair and back to the city. In the first light of the day, this is one of the best ways to see this part of the city, clean, fresh and almost empty. If you do the run/walk anti-clockwise (looking at a map with the harbour in the top), and time it right, you get the first direct rays of sun on both the bridge and then the Opera House.Even if you are not a runner - get up early and see one of the most beautiful vistas in the world
Great walk. Good exercise, nice views and very peaceful in the middle of the city

A must do area of Sydney. get up early - grab a take-away coffee and get out for a walk. head down through the middle of Hyde Park, then through the Domain and you'll end up at the Opera House with the sun glistening on the harbour. How cant love Sydney

Wonderful views. This is a fantastic walk, close to the central city and Circular Quay area. Views of the Opera House, Harbour Bridge and harbour in general are excellent. Botantic Gardens are beautiful, great for all ages to explore. Recommend walking to Mrs Macquarie's Chair, which is on the first point heading away from the Opera House. The best views on the walk are available from this vantage.
Many photo Options. Walked from Botanic Gardens (Mrs. Macquaries Chair) to the Opera House (= vice versa). Ideal for taking pictures of the Opera House, Harbour Bridge and Harbour

Lovely Way to Spend a Gorgeous Winter Sunday in Sydnry.. Beautiful day, I walked from the Four Seasons, at the SW corner of Circular Quay, to the Opera House, and back south to enter the Botanical Garden close to the Circular Memory sculpture garden. Toured the grounds of Government House, and then went down to the water. Walked around to MacQuarie Point and Mrs. MacQuarie's Chair. I loved every minute. Something like NY Central Park on a beautiful October Sunday, by the water.

Dress for the Occasion. Took an evening performance here. Disappointed that we were the couple to dress for the occasion! Very laid back approach but perhaps thats because we are british and that how we do it in London. The bar was good with very prompt service. All in all we enjoyed the whole evening.
Loved it!. I have done this walk several times in the past 5 years and I am still not tired of it. The walk is beautiful and very therapeutic.
Short walk but must be done while in Sydney. Love it in the summer. Just grab an ice cream, a hat, a sunscreen and enjoy the views.

Iconic Stroll in Sydney. As a child I was taken to the Botanical Gardens to meet with other young families. Now I really enjoy meeting friends at the Quay and walking to the Opera House, through the Gardens and up to Martin Place for the train trip home.
Nice place to take a walk!. This place is nice to take a walk and take pictures!

City escape. Escape the hustle and bustle of the city and take a stroll through the wonderful gardens to the Opera House. It really is a great avenue to approach this iconic building. The gardens are beatuful and the views of the water are always so calming. You can also easily walk to Mrs Macquarie's Point, with it's convict carved sandstone chair, and enjoy all thats on offer there.
Relax and enjoy. . Walk up from the harbor and enjoy the botanical garden and visit Government House.

Beautiful!. This walk really is spectacular! Its free, easy and surrounded by wonderful scenery- really just a great way to spend a couple of hours in Sydney city.Once you're done with the walk (and depending on which way you've done it), a trip to either the Opera Bar or the Art Gallery really is a great way to top off you're day! Or a short walk around to The Rocks to get your evening started!

Relaxing and beautiful walk. I used to stay in Sydney for 4 years. Whenever I was stress or boring, I would take a train/bus to circular quay and walk from opera house to the botanic gardens. I really enjoyed the walk. The harbour view was fantastic. Although it might be a little bit too long for some people, you will appreciate the great view along the way and very excited to reach Mrs. Macquarie point, where you can discover the best spot to take a photo with the opera house and harbour bridge. Sometimes, I had the walks with my friends. We love to stop a while, sit on the grass, eat some snacks and chit chat while enjoying the great view, it's so relaxing. If I had a chance to go back to Sydney again, I will definitely take this walk again.
Delightful walk. This is a great walk, summe or winter. Great views of the harbour gardens and opera house, and all free!

May 2012. My husband and I found this walk by accident. We walked around the Sydney Opera House (taking pictures of the front) and saw the pathway. I told him we'd probably get really good pictures of us, with the Sydney Opera House and Bridge from the path, and I was absolutely correct. We didn't even know we were entering the Botanic Gardens (ok, we are one of those couples who travels and does some research, but we like to find out most things once we get there so we didn't even know about this walkway) and it was a nice surprise to see such nice, landscaped areas to walk while we enjoyed the Sydney Harbour views.Once we reached the end of the pathway (which is outside the Botanic Garden's property), we realized we had reached a point where lots of tourist groups bring their guests because there were at least 100 people posing for pics with the Sydney Opera House and Bridge behind them, but honestly, I thought we took better pictures along the walkway. While we were there, at least five buses came and dropped off visitors, so we didn't stay long.Oh! Another neat sight along the way is a sandstone wall with steps carved into them that you can take pictures in. Very unique.Suggestion: Once you reach the end of the walkway; go back! We tried to walk towards what we assumed would be the road and public transportation and we walked for an hour before we came into "civilization". Yes it was all paved, but there wasn't much to see. In hindsight, we would have just walked back along the path towards the Sydney Opera House and Harbour because it was just as far as we walked trying to find a bus.Bring water. There isn't any place to buy anything along the walk. There are bathrooms along the way (although they aren't right on the path; you'll have to do some walking) and it is quite a distance, so wear comfortable shoes and clothing.

My Favorite walk in the City Of Sydney. I love other walks but nothing beats walking from my Home in Darlinghurst to Lady MacQuarires Chair thru the Boyanical Gardens to the Opera house and Quay I LOVE it Beautiful invigorating in Winter Health plus.
Beautiful view. Downhill or flat from top of gardens to the opera house. Prepare for beautiful gardens and views
